Night Dragon.name: Acquire and/or use 3rd party infrastructure services
Night Dragon.description: [Night Dragon](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0014) used servers in China, the U.S., and the Netherlands in an attempt to hide their operations.

Night Dragon.name: Acquire and/or use 3rd party software services
Night Dragon.description: [Night Dragon](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0014) used third party hosting services in the U.S. in an attempt to hide their operations.

Night Dragon.name: Remote access tool development
Night Dragon.description: [Night Dragon](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0014) used privately developed and customized remote access tools.

Night Dragon.name: Credential Dumping
Night Dragon.description: [Night Dragon](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0014) has dumped account hashes with [Carbanak](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0008) and cracked them with Cain & Abel.

Night Dragon.name: Exploit Public-Facing Application
Night Dragon.description: [Night Dragon](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0014) has performed SQL injection attacks of extranet web servers to gain access.

Night Dragon.name: Disabling Security Tools
Night Dragon.description: [Night Dragon](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0014) has disabled anti-virus and anti-spyware tools in some instances on the victim’s machines. The actors have also disabled proxy settings to allow direct communication from victims to the Internet.[

Night Dragon.name: Spearphishing Link
Night Dragon.description: [Night Dragon](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0014) sent spearphishing emails containing links to compromised websites where malware was downloaded.

Night Dragon.name: Valid Accounts
Night Dragon.description: [Night Dragon](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0014) has used compromised VPN accounts to gain access to victim systems.

Night Dragon.name: Commonly Used Port
Night Dragon.description: [Night Dragon](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0014) has used ports 25 and 80 for C2 communications.

Night Dragon.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Night Dragon.description: A [Night Dragon](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0014) DLL included an XOR-encoded section.

Night Dragon.name: Pass the Hash
Night Dragon.description: [Night Dragon](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0014) used pass-the-hash tools to gain usernames and passwords.

Night Dragon.name: Remote Access Tools
Night Dragon.description: [Night Dragon](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0014) has used several remote administration tools as persistent infiltration channels.

Night Dragon.name: User Execution
Night Dragon.description: [Night Dragon](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0014) enticed users to click on links in spearphishing emails to download malware.

Night Dragon.name: External Remote Services
Night Dragon.description: [Night Dragon](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0014) has used compromised VPN accounts to gain access to victim systems.

Night Dragon.name: Software Packing
Night Dragon.description: [Night Dragon](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0014) is known to use software packing in its tools.

Night Dragon.name: Data Staged
Night Dragon.description: [Night Dragon](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0014) has copied files to company web servers and subsequently downloaded them.

APT1.name: Domain registration hijacking
APT1.description: [APT1](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0006) hijacked FQDNs associated with legitimate websites hosted by hop points. Mandiant considers them to be “hijacked” since they were originally registered for a legitimate reason but are used by APT1 for malicious purposes.

APT1.name: Obtain/re-use payloads
APT1.description: [APT1](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0006) used publicly available privilege escalation tools.

APT1.name: Compromise 3rd party infrastructure to support delivery
APT1.description: [APT1](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0006) comrpomised a vast set of 3rd party victim hop points as part of their network infrastructure.

APT1.name: Compromise 3rd party infrastructure to support delivery
APT1.description: [APT1](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0006) hijacked FQDNs associated with legitimate websites hosted by hop points. Mandiant considers them to be “hijacked” since they were originally registered for a legitimate reason but were used by APT1 for malicious purposes.

APT1.name: Acquire and/or use 3rd party software services
APT1.description: [APT1](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0006) used third party email services in the registration of whois records.

APT1.name: Dynamic DNS
APT1.description: [APT1](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0006) used dynamic DNS to register hundreds of FQDNs.

APT1.name: Credential Dumping
APT1.description: [APT1](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0006) has been known to use credential dumping.

APT1.name: Command-Line Interface
APT1.description: [APT1](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0006) has used the Windows command shell to execute commands.

APT1.name: Remote Desktop Protocol
APT1.description: The [APT1](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0006) group is known to have used RDP during operations.

APT1.name: Data from Local System
APT1.description: [APT1](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0006) has collected files from a local victim.

APT1.name: Data Compressed
APT1.description: [APT1](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0006) has used RAR to compress files before moving them outside of the victim network.

APT1.name: Scripting
APT1.description: [APT1](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0006) has used batch scripting to automate execution of commands.

APT1.name: Process Discovery
APT1.description: [APT1](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0006) gathered a list of running processes on the system using tasklist /v.

APT1.name: Email Collection
APT1.description: [APT1](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0006) uses two utilities, GETMAIL and MAPIGET, to steal email. GETMAIL extracts emails from archived Outlook .pst files, and MAPIGET steals email still on Exchange servers that has not yet been archived.

APT1.name: Masquerading
APT1.description: The file name AcroRD32.exe, a legitimate process name for Adobe's Acrobat Reader, was used by [APT1](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0006) as a name for malware.

APT1.name: System Network Connections Discovery
APT1.description: [APT1](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0006) used the net use command to get a listing on network connections.

APT1.name: Account Discovery
APT1.description: [APT1](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0006) used the commands net localgroup,net user, and net group to find accounts on the system.

APT1.name: Automated Collection
APT1.description: [APT1](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0006) used a batch script to perform a series of discovery techniques and saves it to a text file.

APT1.name: Pass the Hash
APT1.description: The [APT1](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0006) group is known to have used pass the hash.

APT1.name: Network Share Discovery
APT1.description: [APT1](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0006) listed connected network shares.

APT1.name: System Service Discovery
APT1.description: [APT1](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0006) used the commands net start and tasklist to get a listing of the services on the system.

APT1.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
APT1.description: [APT1](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0006) used the ipconfig /all command to gather network configuration information.

APT16.name: Compromise 3rd party infrastructure to support delivery
APT16.description: [APT16](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0023) has compromised otherwise legitimate sites as staging servers for second-stage payloads.

APT16.name: Identify business relationships
APT16.description: [APT16](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0023) spearphished journalists, apparently targeting those interested in contact information for DPP members or politicians.

Cleaver.name: Obfuscation or cryptography
Cleaver.description: [Cleaver](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0003) has used zhCat to encrypt traffic or use inline obfuscation to make detection more difficult. zhCat makes message traffic look benign.

Cleaver.name: Develop social network persona digital footprint
Cleaver.description: [Cleaver](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0003) fake personas included profile photos, details, and network connections.

Cleaver.name: Create custom payloads
Cleaver.description: [Cleaver](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0003) has created customized tools and payloads for functions including ARP poisoning, encryption, credential dumping, ASP.NET shells, web backdoors, process enumeration, WMI querying, HTTP and SMB communications, network interface sniffing, and keystroke logging.

Cleaver.name: Credential Dumping
Cleaver.description: [Cleaver](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0003) has been known to dump credentials.

APT17.name: Develop social network persona digital footprint
APT17.description: [APT17](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0025) created biographical sections on TechNet profile pages to appear more legitimate.

APT17.name: Build social network persona
APT17.description: [APT17](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0025) posted in forum threads and created profile pages in Microsoft TechNet.

APT17.name: Obfuscate infrastructure
APT17.description: [APT17](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0025) obfuscated infrastructure using a multi-layered malware beaconing approach.

APT28.name: Obtain/re-use payloads
APT28.description: [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) reused the SOURFACE downloader as the payload of a lure document.

APT28.name: Buy domain name
APT28.description: [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) registered domains imitating NATO and OSCE security websites and Caucasus information resources.

APT28.name: Data Obfuscation
APT28.description: [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) added "junk data" to each encoded string, preventing trivial decoding without knowledge of the junk removal algorithm. Each implant was given a "junk length" value when created, tracked by the controller software to allow seamless communication but prevent analysis of the command protocol on the wire.

APT28.name: Replication Through Removable Media
APT28.description: [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) uses a tool to infect connected USB devices and transmit itself to air-gapped computers when the infected USB device is inserted.

APT28.name: Email Collection
APT28.description: [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) has collected emails from victim Microsoft Exchange servers.

APT28.name: Remote File Copy
APT28.description: [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) has downloaded additional files, including by using a first-stage downloader to contact the C2 server to obtain the second-stage implant.

APT28.name: Dynamic Data Exchange
APT28.description: [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) has delivered [JHUHUGIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0044) and [Koadic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0250) by executing PowerShell commands through DDE in Word documents.

APT28.name: Hidden Files and Directories
APT28.description: [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) has saved files with hidden file attributes.

APT28.name: Timestomp
APT28.description: [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) has performed timestomping on victim files.

APT28.name: Spearphishing Link
APT28.description: [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) sent spearphishing emails which used a URL-shortener service to masquerade as a legitimate service and to redirect targets to credential harvesting sites.

APT28.name: Peripheral Device Discovery
APT28.description: [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) uses a module to receive a notification every time a USB mass storage device is inserted into a victim.

APT28.name: Screen Capture
APT28.description: [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) has used tools to take screenshots from victims.

APT28.name: File and Directory Discovery
APT28.description: [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) has used [Forfiles](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0193) to locate PDF, Excel, and Word documents during. The group also searched a compromised DCCC computer for specific terms.

APT28.name: Indicator Removal on Host
APT28.description: [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) has cleared event logs, including by using the commands wevtutil cl System and wevtutil cl Security.

APT28.name: User Execution
APT28.description: [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) attempted to get users to click on Microsoft Office attachments containing malicious macro scripts.

APT28.name: Component Object Model Hijacking
APT28.description: [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) has used COM hijacking for persistence by replacing the legitimate MMDeviceEnumerator object with a payload.

APT28.name: Spearphishing Attachment
APT28.description: [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) sent spearphishing emails containing malicious Microsoft Office attachments.

APT28.name: Data from Information Repositories
APT28.description: [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) has collected information from Microsoft SharePoint services within target networks.

APT28.name: Logon Scripts
APT28.description: An [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) loader Trojan adds the Registry key HKCU\Environment\UserInitMprLogonScript to establish persistence.

APT28.name: Command-Line Interface
APT28.description: [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) uses cmd.exe to execute commands and custom backdoors.

description.name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel

APT28.name: Network Sniffing
APT28.description: [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) deployed the open source tool Responder to conduct NetBIOS Name Service poisoning, which captured usernames and hashed passwords that allowed access to legitimate credentials.

APT28.name: Bootkit
APT28.description: [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) has deployed a bootkit along with [Downdelph](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0134) to ensure its persistence on the victim. The bootkit shares code with some variants of [BlackEnergy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0089).

APT28.name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
APT28.description: [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) has exploited CVE-2014-4076, CVE-2015-2387, CVE-2015-1701, CVE-2017-0263 to escalate privileges.

APT28.name: Exploitation for Defense Evasion
APT28.description: [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) has used CVE-2015-4902 to bypass security features.

APT28.name: Automated Collection
APT28.description: [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) used a publicly available tool to gather and compress multiple documents on the DCCC and DNC networks.

APT28.name: Access Token Manipulation
APT28.description: [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) has used CVE-2015-1701 to access the SYSTEM token and copy it into the current process as part of privilege escalation.

APT28.name: Data from Removable Media
APT28.description: An [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) backdoor may collect the entire contents of an inserted USB device.

APT28.name: Data Staged
APT28.description: [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) has stored captured credential information in a file named pi.log.

APT28.name: Pass the Hash
APT28.description: [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) has used pass the hash for lateral movement.

APT28.name: Valid Accounts
APT28.description: [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) has used legitimate credentials to maintain access to a victim network and exfiltrate data. The group also used credentials stolen through a spearphishing email to login to the DCCC network.

APT28.name: Trusted Relationship
APT28.description: Once [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) gained access to the DCCC network, the group then proceeded to use that access to compromise the DNC network.

APT28.name: Rundll32
APT28.description: [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) executed [CHOPSTICK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0023) by using rundll32 commands such as rundll32.exe “C:\Windows\twain_64.dll”. [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) also executed a .dll for a first stage dropper using rundll32.exe. An [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) loader Trojan saved a batch script that uses rundll32 to execute a DLL payload.

APT28.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
APT28.description: [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) used SMTP as a communication channel in various implants, initially using self-registered Google Mail accounts and later compromised email servers of its victims. Later implants such as [CHOPSTICK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0023) use a blend of HTTP and other legitimate channels, depending on module configuration.

APT28.name: PowerShell
APT28.description: [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) downloads and executes PowerShell scripts.

APT28.name: Communication Through Removable Media
APT28.description: [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) uses a tool that captures information from air-gapped computers via an infected USB and transfers it to network-connected computer when the USB is inserted.

APT28.name: Data from Local System
APT28.description: [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) has retrieved internal documents from machines inside victim environments, including by using [Forfiles](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0193) to stage documents before.

APT28.name: Credential Dumping
APT28.description: [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) regularly deploys both publicly available and custom password retrieval tools on victims.

APT28.name: File Deletion
APT28.description: [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) has intentionally deleted computer files to cover their tracks, including with use of the program CCleaner.

description.name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel

APT28.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
APT28.description: [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) encrypted a .dll payload using RTL and a custom encryption algorithm. [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) has also obfuscated payloads with base64, XOR, and RC4.

APT28.name: Rootkit
APT28.description: [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) has used a UEFI (Unified Extensible Firmware Interface) rootkit known as [LoJax](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0397).

APT28.name: Data Compressed
APT28.description: [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) used a publicly available tool to gather and compress multiple documents on the DCCC and DNC networks.

APT28.name: Scripting
APT28.description: An [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) loader Trojan uses a batch script to run its payload. The group has also used macros to execute payloads.

APT28.name: Connection Proxy
APT28.description: [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) used other victims as proxies to relay command traffic, for instance using a compromised Georgian military email server as a hop point to NATO victims. The group has also used a tool that acts as a proxy to allow C2 even if the victim is behind a router. [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) has also used a machine to relay and obscure communications between [CHOPSTICK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0023) and their server.

description.name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel

APT28.name: Process Discovery
APT28.description: An [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) loader Trojan will enumerate the victim's processes searching for explorer.exe if its current process does not have necessary permissions.

APT28.name: Exploitation of Remote Services
APT28.description: [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) exploited a Windows SMB Remote Code Execution Vulnerability to conduct lateral movement.

APT28.name: Input Capture
APT28.description: [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) has used tools to perform keylogging.

APT28.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
APT28.description: An [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) macro uses the command certutil -decode to decode contents of a .txt file storing the base64 encoded payload.

APT28.name: Exploitation for Client Execution
APT28.description: [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) has exploited Microsoft Office vulnerability CVE-2017-0262 for execution.

APT28.name: Office Application Startup
APT28.description: [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) has used the Office Test persistence mechanism within Microsoft Office by adding the Registry key HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Office test\Special\Perf to execute code.

APT28.name: Template Injection
APT28.description: [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) used weaponized Microsoft Word documents abusing the remote template function to retrieve a malicious macro.

APT28.name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
APT28.description: [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) installed a Delphi backdoor that used a custom algorithm for C2 communications.

TEMP.Veles.name: Acquire and/or use 3rd party infrastructure services
TEMP.Veles.description: [TEMP.Veles](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0088) has used Virtual Private Server (VPS) infrastructure.

TEMP.Veles.name: Masquerading
TEMP.Veles.description: [TEMP.Veles](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0088) has performed a variety of methods to look like valid users, including renaming files and mimicking legitimate administrator activities.

TEMP.Veles.name: Credential Dumping
TEMP.Veles.description: [TEMP.Veles](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0088) has used [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002) and a custom tool, SecHack, to harvest credentials.

TEMP.Veles.name: Image File Execution Options Injection
TEMP.Veles.description: [TEMP.Veles](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0088) has modified and added entries within HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Image File Execution Options to maintain persistence.

TEMP.Veles.name: Scheduled Task
TEMP.Veles.description: [TEMP.Veles](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0088) has used scheduled task XML triggers.

TEMP.Veles.name: Timestomp
TEMP.Veles.description: [TEMP.Veles](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0088) used timestomping to modify the $STANDARD_INFORMATION attribute on tools.

TEMP.Veles.name: File Deletion
TEMP.Veles.description: [TEMP.Veles](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0088) routinely deleted tools, logs, and other files after they were finished with them.

TEMP.Veles.name: Data Staged
TEMP.Veles.description: [TEMP.Veles](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0088) has created staging folders in directories that were infrequently used by legitimate users or processes.

TEMP.Veles.name: Remote Services
TEMP.Veles.description: [TEMP.Veles](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0088) has relied on encrypted SSH-based tunnels to transfer tools and for remote command/program execution.

TEMP.Veles.name: External Remote Services
TEMP.Veles.description: [TEMP.Veles](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0088) has used a VPN to persist in the victim environment.

TEMP.Veles.name: Web Shell
TEMP.Veles.description: [TEMP.Veles](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0088) has planted webshells on Outlook Exchange servers.

TEMP.Veles.name: Uncommonly Used Port
TEMP.Veles.description: [TEMP.Veles](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0088) has used ports 4444, 8531, and 50501 for C2.

TEMP.Veles.name: PowerShell
TEMP.Veles.description: [TEMP.Veles](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0088) has used a publicly-available PowerShell-based tool, WMImplant. The group has also used PowerShell to perform [Timestomp](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1099)ing.

TEMP.Veles.name: Indicator Removal from Tools
TEMP.Veles.description: [TEMP.Veles](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0088) has modified files based on the open-source project cryptcat in an apparent attempt to decrease AV detection rates.

APT3.name: Data Staged
APT3.description: [APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) has been known to stage files for exfiltration in a single location.

APT3.name: Account Discovery
APT3.description: [APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) has used a tool that can obtain info about local and global group users, power users, and administrators.

APT3.name: Input Capture
APT3.description: [APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) has used a keylogging tool that records keystrokes in encrypted files.

APT3.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
APT3.description: A keylogging tool used by [APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) gathers network information from the victim, including the MAC address, IP address, WINS, DHCP server, and gateway.

APT3.name: Accessibility Features
APT3.description: [APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) replaces the Sticky Keys binary C:\Windows\System32\sethc.exe for persistence.

APT3.name: Remote Desktop Protocol
APT3.description: [APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) enables the Remote Desktop Protocol for persistence.

APT3.name: Data from Local System
APT3.description: [APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) will identify Microsoft Office documents on the victim's computer.

APT3.name: Redundant Access
APT3.description: [APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) has been known to use multiple backdoors per campaign.

APT3.name: Scheduled Task
APT3.description: An [APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) downloader creates persistence by creating the following scheduled task: schtasks /create /tn "mysc" /tr C:\Users\Public\test.exe /sc ONLOGON /ru "System".

APT3.name: Graphical User Interface
APT3.description: [APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) has interacted with compromised systems to browse and copy files through its graphical user interface in [Remote Desktop Protocol](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1076) sessions.

APT3.name: File and Directory Discovery
APT3.description: [APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) has a tool that looks for files and directories on the local file system.

APT3.name: Remote File Copy
APT3.description: [APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) has a tool that can copy files to remote machines.

APT3.name: Connection Proxy
APT3.description: An [APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) downloader establishes SOCKS5 connections for its initial C2.

APT3.name: Remote System Discovery
APT3.description: [APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) has a tool that can detect the existence of remote systems.

APT3.name: Uncommonly Used Port
APT3.description: An [APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) downloader establishes SOCKS5 connections to two separate IP addresses over TCP port 1913 and TCP port 81.

APT3.name: Command-Line Interface
APT3.description: An [APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) downloader uses the Windows command "cmd.exe" /C whoami. The group also uses a tool to execute commands on remote computers.

APT3.name: Valid Accounts
APT3.description: [APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) leverages valid accounts after gaining credentials for use within the victim domain.

APT3.name: Scripting
APT3.description: [APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) has used PowerShell on victim systems to download and run payloads after exploitation.

APT3.name: Permission Groups Discovery
APT3.description: [APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) has a tool that can enumerate the permissions associated with Windows groups.

APT3.name: Process Discovery
APT3.description: [APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) has a tool that can list out currently running processes.

APT3.name: Credential Dumping
APT3.description: [APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) has used a tool to dump credentials by injecting itself into lsass.exe and triggering with the argument "dig." The group has also used a tools to dump passwords from browsers.

APT3.name: PowerShell
APT3.description: [APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) has used PowerShell on victim systems to download and run payloads after exploitation.

APT3.name: New Service
APT3.description: [APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) has a tool that creates a new service for persistence.

APT3.name: Multi-Stage Channels
APT3.description: An [APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) downloader first establishes a SOCKS5 connection to 192.157.198[.]103 using TCP port 1913; once the server response is verified, it then requests a connection to 192.184.60[.]229 on TCP port 81.

APT3.name: System Network Connections Discovery
APT3.description: [APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) has a tool that can enumerate current network connections.

APT3.name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
APT3.description: [APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) has a tool that exfiltrates data over the C2 channel.

APT3.name: Rundll32
APT3.description: [APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) has a tool that can run DLLs.

APT3.name: Software Packing
APT3.description: [APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) has been known to pack their tools.

APT3.name: Standard Non-Application Layer Protocol
APT3.description: An [APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) downloader establishes SOCKS5 connections for its initial C2.

APT3.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
APT3.description: [APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) obfuscates files or information to help evade defensive measures.

APT3.name: System Owner/User Discovery
APT3.description: An [APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) downloader uses the Windows command "cmd.exe" /C whoami to verify that it is running with the elevated privileges of “System.”

APT3.name: Create Account
APT3.description: [APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) has been known to create or enable accounts, such as support_388945a0.

APT3.name: Data Compressed
APT3.description: [APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) has used tools to compress data before exfilling it.

APT3.name: Indicator Removal from Tools
APT3.description: [APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) has been known to remove indicators of compromise from tools.

APT3.name: Commonly Used Port
APT3.description: [APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) uses commonly used ports (like HTTPS/443) for command and control.

APT3.name: System Information Discovery
APT3.description: [APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) has a tool that can obtain information about the local system.

APT3.name: Account Manipulation
APT3.description: [APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) has been known to add created accounts to local admin groups to maintain elevated access.

APT3.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
APT3.description: [APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) places scripts in the startup folder for persistence.

APT3.name: Windows Admin Shares
APT3.description: [APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) will copy files over to Windows Admin Shares (like ADMIN$) as part of lateral movement.

APT3.name: DLL Side-Loading
APT3.description: [APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) has been known to side load DLLs with a valid version of Chrome with one of their tools.

APT3.name: Brute Force
APT3.description: [APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) has been known to brute force password hashes to be able to leverage plain text credentials.

APT3.name: File Deletion
APT3.description: [APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) has a tool that can delete files.

APT3.name: Credentials in Files
APT3.description: [APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) has a tool that can locate credentials in files on the file system such as those from Firefox or Chrome.

APT37.name: Exploitation for Client Execution
APT37.description: [APT37](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0067) has used Flash Player (CVE-2016-4117, CVE-2018-4878) and Word (CVE-2017-0199) exploits for execution.

APT37.name: Process Discovery
APT37.description: [APT37](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0067)'s Freenki malware lists running processes using the Microsoft Windows API.

description.name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel

APT37.name: Data from Local System
APT37.description: [APT37](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0067) has collected data from victims' local systems.

APT37.name: User Execution
APT37.description: [APT37](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0067) has sent spearphishing attachments attempting to get a user to open them.

APT37.name: Command-Line Interface
APT37.description: [APT37](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0067) has used the command-line interface.

APT37.name: Credential Dumping
APT37.description: [APT37](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0067) has used a credential stealer known as ZUMKONG that can harvest usernames and passwords stored in browsers.

APT37.name: System Information Discovery
APT37.description: [APT37](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0067) collects the computer name, the BIOS model, and execution path.

APT37.name: System Owner/User Discovery
APT37.description: [APT37](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0067) identifies the victim username.

APT37.name: Remote File Copy
APT37.description: [APT37](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0067) has downloaded second stage malware from compromised websites.

APT37.name: Audio Capture
APT37.description: [APT37](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0067) has used an audio capturing utility known as SOUNDWAVE that captures microphone input.

APT37.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
APT37.description: [APT37](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0067)'s has added persistence via the Registry key HKCU\Software\Microsoft\CurrentVersion\Run\.

APT37.name: Execution through API
APT37.description: [APT37](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0067) leverages the Windows API calls: VirtualAlloc(), WriteProcessMemory(), and CreateRemoteThread() for process injection.

APT37.name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
APT37.description: [APT37](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0067) credential stealer ZUMKONG emails credentials from the victim using HTTP POST requests.

APT37.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
APT37.description: [APT37](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0067) sends images to users that are embedded with shellcode. The group also obfuscates strings and payloads, including through the use of steganography.

APT37.name: Spearphishing Attachment
APT37.description: [APT37](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0067) delivers malware using spearphishing emails with malicious HWP attachments.

APT37.name: Process Injection
APT37.description: [APT37](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0067) injects its malware variant, [ROKRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0240), into the cmd.exe process.

APT37.name: Drive-by Compromise
APT37.description: [APT37](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0067) has used strategic web compromises, particularly of South Korean websites, to distribute malware. The group has also used torrent file-sharing sites to more indiscriminately disseminate malware to victims. As part of their compromises, the group has used a Javascript based profiler called RICECURRY to profile a victim's web browser and deliver malicious code accordingly.

APT37.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
APT37.description: [APT37](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0067) uses HTTPS to conceal C2 communications.

APT37.name: Disk Structure Wipe
APT37.description: [APT37](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0067) has access to destructive malware that is capable of overwriting a machine's Master Boot Record (MBR).

APT37.name: Web Service
APT37.description: [APT37](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0067) leverages social networking sites and cloud platforms (AOL, Twitter, Yandex, Mediafire, pCloud, Dropbox, and Box) for C2.

APT37.name: Commonly Used Port
APT37.description: [APT37](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0067) has used port 8080 for C2.

APT37.name: Scripting
APT37.description: [APT37](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0067) executes shellcode and a script to decode Base64 strings.

APT37.name: Code Signing
APT37.description: [APT37](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0067) has signed its malware with an invalid digital certificates listed as “Tencent Technology (Shenzhen) Company Limited.”

APT37.name: Dynamic Data Exchange
APT37.description: [APT37](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0067) has used Windows DDE for execution of commands and a malicious VBS.

APT37.name: Peripheral Device Discovery
APT37.description: [APT37](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0067) has a Bluetooth device harvester, which uses Windows Bluetooth APIs to find information on connected Bluetooth devices.

APT37.name: Bypass User Account Control
APT37.description: [APT37](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0067) has a function in the initial dropper to bypass Windows UAC in order to execute the next payload with higher privileges.

FIN7.name: Video Capture
FIN7.description: [FIN7](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0046) created a custom video recording capability that could be used to monitor operations in the victim's environment.

FIN7.name: Code Signing
FIN7.description: [FIN7](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0046) has signed [Carbanak](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0030) payloads with legally purchased code signing certificates. [FIN7](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0046) has also digitally signed their phishing documents, backdoors and other staging tools to bypass security controls.

FIN7.name: Masquerading
FIN7.description: [FIN7](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0046) has created a scheduled task named “AdobeFlashSync” to establish persistence.

FIN7.name: Shortcut Modification
FIN7.description: [FIN7](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0046) created several .LNK files on the victim's machine.

FIN7.name: Application Shimming
FIN7.description: [FIN7](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0046) has used application shim databases for persistence.

FIN7.name: User Execution
FIN7.description: [FIN7](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0046) lured victims to double-click on images in the attachments they sent which would then execute the hidden LNK file.

FIN7.name: PowerShell
FIN7.description: [FIN7](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0046) uses a PowerShell script to launch shellcode that retrieves an additional payload.

FIN7.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
FIN7.description: [FIN7](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0046) has performed C2 using DNS via A, OPT, and TXT records.

FIN7.name: Dynamic Data Exchange
FIN7.description: [FIN7](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0046) spear phishing campaigns have included malicious Word documents with DDE execution.

FIN7.name: Mshta
FIN7.description: [FIN7](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0046) has used mshta.exe to execute VBScript to execute malicious code on victim systems.

FIN7.name: Command-Line Interface
FIN7.description: [FIN7](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0046) used cmd.exe to launch commands on the victim’s machine.

FIN7.name: Web Service
FIN7.description: [FIN7](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0046) used legitimate services like Google Docs, Google Scripts, and Pastebin for C2.

FIN7.name: Spearphishing Attachment
FIN7.description: [FIN7](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0046) sent spearphishing emails with either malicious Microsoft Documents or RTF files attached.

FIN7.name: New Service
FIN7.description: [FIN7](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0046) created new Windows services and added them to the startup directories for persistence.

FIN7.name: Remote File Copy
FIN7.description: [FIN7](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0046) has downloaded additional malware to execute on the victim's machine, including by using a PowerShell script to launch shellcode that retrieves an additional payload.

FIN7.name: Commonly Used Port
FIN7.description: [FIN7](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0046) has used ports 53, 80, 443, and 8080 for C2.

FIN7.name: Scheduled Task
FIN7.description: [FIN7](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0046) malware has created scheduled tasks to establish persistence.

FIN7.name: Scripting
FIN7.description: [FIN7](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0046) used SQL, VBS and JavaScript scripts to help perform tasks on the victim's machine.

FIN7.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
FIN7.description: [FIN7](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0046) has used fragmented strings, environment variables, standard input (stdin), and native character-replacement functionalities to obfuscate commands.

FIN7.name: Screen Capture
FIN7.description: [FIN7](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0046) captured screenshots and desktop video recordings.

FIN7.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
FIN7.description: [FIN7](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0046) malware has created Registry Run and RunOnce keys to establish persistence, and has also added items to the Startup folder.

FIN7.name: Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion
FIN7.description: [FIN7](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0046) used images embedded into document lures that only activate the payload when a user double clicks to avoid sandboxes.

OilRig.name: Process Discovery
OilRig.description: [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) has run tasklist on a victim's machine.

OilRig.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
OilRig.description: A [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) macro has run a PowerShell command to decode file contents. [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) has also used [certutil](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0160) to decode base64-encoded files on victims.

OilRig.name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
OilRig.description: [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) has used custom DNS Tunneling protocols for C2.

OilRig.name: Automated Collection
OilRig.description: [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) has used automated collection.

OilRig.name: File Deletion
OilRig.description: [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) has deleted files associated with their payload after execution.

OilRig.name: Redundant Access
OilRig.description: [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) has used [RGDoor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0258) via Web shell to establish redundant access. The group has also used harvested credentials to gain access to Internet-accessible resources such as Outlook Web Access, which could be used for redundant access.

OilRig.name: Screen Capture
OilRig.description: [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) has a tool called CANDYKING to capture a screenshot of user's desktop.

OilRig.name: Remote Services
OilRig.description: [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) has used Putty to access compromised systems.

OilRig.name: Permission Groups Discovery
OilRig.description: [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) has used net group /domain, net localgroup administrators, net group “domain admins” /domain, and net group “Exchange Trusted Subsystem” /domain to find group permission settings on a victim.

OilRig.name: Network Service Scanning
OilRig.description: [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) has used the publicly available tool SoftPerfect Network Scanner as well as a custom tool called GOLDIRONY to conduct network scanning.

OilRig.name: Scripting
OilRig.description: [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) has used various types of scripting for execution, including .bat and .vbs scripts. The group has also used macros to deliver malware such as [QUADAGENT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0269) and [OopsIE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0264).

OilRig.name: External Remote Services
OilRig.description: [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) uses remote services such as VPN, Citrix, or OWA to persist in an environment.

OilRig.name: Remote Desktop Protocol
OilRig.description: [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) has used Remote Desktop Protocol for lateral movement. The group has also used tunneling tools to tunnel RDP into the environment.

OilRig.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
OilRig.description: [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) has used WMI for execution.

OilRig.name: Scheduled Task
OilRig.description: [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) has created scheduled tasks that run a VBScript to execute a payload on victim machines.

OilRig.name: System Network Connections Discovery
OilRig.description: [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) has used netstat -an on a victim to get a listing of network connections.

OilRig.name: System Service Discovery
OilRig.description: [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) has used sc query on a victim to gather information about services.

OilRig.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
OilRig.description: [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) has run ipconfig /all on a victim.

OilRig.name: Query Registry
OilRig.description: [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) has used reg query “HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Terminal Server Client\Default” on a victim to query the Registry.

OilRig.name: Input Capture
OilRig.description: [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) has used a keylogging tool called KEYPUNCH.

description.name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel

OilRig.name: Command-Line Interface
OilRig.description: [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) has used the command-line interface for execution.

OilRig.name: System Information Discovery
OilRig.description: [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) has run hostname and systeminfo on a victim.

OilRig.name: Account Discovery
OilRig.description: [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) has run net user, net user /domain, net group “domain admins” /domain, and net group “Exchange Trusted Subsystem” /domain to get account listings on a victim.

OilRig.name: Brute Force
OilRig.description: [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) has used brute force techniques to obtain credentials.

OilRig.name: Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol
OilRig.description: [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) has exfiltrated data over FTP separately from its primary C2 channel over DNS.

OilRig.name: Spearphishing Attachment
OilRig.description: [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) has sent spearphising emails with malicious attachments to potential victims using compromised and/or spoofed email accounts.

OilRig.name: User Execution
OilRig.description: [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) has delivered malicious links and macro-enabled documents that required targets to click the "enable content" button to execute the payload on the system.

OilRig.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
OilRig.description: [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) has encrypted and encoded data in its malware, including by using base64.

OilRig.name: PowerShell
OilRig.description: [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) has used PowerShell scripts for execution, including use of a macro to run a PowerShell command to decode file contents.

OilRig.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
OilRig.description: [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) has used HTTP and DNS for C2. The group has also used the Plink utility and other tools to create tunnels to C2 servers.

OilRig.name: Web Shell
OilRig.description: [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) has used Web shells, often to maintain access to a victim network.

OilRig.name: Indicator Removal from Tools
OilRig.description: [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) has tested malware samples to determine AV detection and subsequently modified the samples to ensure AV evasion.

OilRig.name: System Owner/User Discovery
OilRig.description: [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) has run whoami on a victim.

OilRig.name: Credential Dumping
OilRig.description: [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) has used credential dumping tools such as [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002) and [LaZagne](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0349) to steal credentials to accounts logged into the compromised system and to Outlook Web Access.

OilRig.name: Spearphishing Link
OilRig.description: [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) has sent spearphising emails with malicious links to potential victims.

OilRig.name: Fallback Channels
OilRig.description: [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) malware ISMAgent falls back to its DNS tunneling mechanism if it is unable to reach the C2 server over HTTP.

OilRig.name: Password Policy Discovery
OilRig.description: [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) has used net.exe in a script with net accounts /domain to find the password policy of a domain.

OilRig.name: Compiled HTML File
OilRig.description: [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) has used a CHM payload to load and execute another malicious file once delivered to a victim.

OilRig.name: Valid Accounts
OilRig.description: [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) has used compromised credentials to access other systems on a victim network.

OilRig.name: Remote File Copy
OilRig.description: [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) can download remote files onto victims.

OilRig.name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
OilRig.description: [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) used the Plink utility and other tools to create tunnels to C2 servers.

APT29.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
APT29.description: [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) added Registry Run keys to establish persistence.

APT29.name: Scripting
APT29.description: [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) has used encoded PowerShell scripts uploaded to [CozyCar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0046) installations to download and install [SeaDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0053), as well as to evade defenses.

APT29.name: Exploitation for Client Execution
APT29.description: [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) has used multiple software exploits for common client software, like Microsoft Word and Adobe Reader, to gain code execution as part of.

APT29.name: Accessibility Features
APT29.description: [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) used sticky-keys to obtain unauthenticated, privileged console access.

APT29.name: Bypass User Account Control
APT29.description: [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) has bypassed UAC.

APT29.name: PowerShell
APT29.description: [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) has used encoded PowerShell scripts uploaded to [CozyCar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0046) installations to download and install [SeaDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0053). [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) also used PowerShell scripts to evade defenses.

APT29.name: User Execution
APT29.description: [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) has used various forms of spearphishing attempting to get a user to open links or attachments, including, but not limited to, malicious Microsoft Word documents, .pdf, and .lnk files.

APT29.name: Windows Management Instrumentation Event Subscription
APT29.description: [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) has used WMI event filters to establish persistence.

APT29.name: Software Packing
APT29.description: [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) used UPX to pack files.

APT29.name: Multi-hop Proxy
APT29.description: A backdoor used by [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) created a Tor hidden service to forward traffic from the Tor client to local ports 3389 (RDP), 139 (Netbios), and 445 (SMB) enabling full remote access from outside the network.

APT29.name: Spearphishing Attachment
APT29.description: [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) has used spearphishing emails with an attachment to deliver files with exploits to initial victims.

APT29.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
APT29.description: [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) used WMI to steal credentials and execute backdoors at a future time.

APT29.name: Pass the Ticket
APT29.description: [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) used Kerberos ticket attacks for lateral movement.

APT29.name: Domain Fronting
APT29.description: [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) has used the meek domain fronting plugin for Tor to hide the destination of C2 traffic.

APT29.name: File Deletion
APT29.description: [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) used [SDelete](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0195) to remove artifacts from victims.

APT29.name: Standard Non-Application Layer Protocol
APT29.description: [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) uses TCP for C2 communications.

APT29.name: Spearphishing Link
APT29.description: [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) has used spearphishing with a link to trick victims into clicking on a link to a zip file containing malicious files.

APT29.name: Rundll32
APT29.description: [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) has used rundll32.exe for execution.

APT29.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
APT29.description: [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) uses PowerShell to use Base64 for obfuscation.

APT29.name: Scheduled Task
APT29.description: [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) used named and hijacked scheduled tasks to establish persistence.

APT29.name: Commonly Used Port
APT29.description: [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) has used Port Number 443 for C2.

APT29.name: Shortcut Modification
APT29.description: [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) drops a Windows shortcut file for execution.

APT29.name: Indicator Removal on Host
APT29.description: [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) used [SDelete](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0195) to remove artifacts from victims.

menuPass.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
menuPass.description: [menuPass](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0045) uses a modified version of pentesting script wmiexec.vbs, which logs into a remote machine using WMI.

menuPass.name: Credential Dumping
menuPass.description: [menuPass](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0045) has used a modified version of pentesting tools wmiexec.vbs and secretsdump.py to dump credentials.

menuPass.name: Valid Accounts
menuPass.description: [menuPass](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0045) has used valid accounts shared between Managed Service Providers and clients to move between the two environments.

menuPass.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
menuPass.description: [menuPass](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0045) has used several tools to scan for open NetBIOS nameservers and enumerate NetBIOS sessions.

menuPass.name: Data from Network Shared Drive
menuPass.description: [menuPass](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0045) has collected data from remote systems by mounting network shares with net use and using Robocopy to transfer data.

menuPass.name: Account Discovery
menuPass.description: [menuPass](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0045) has used the Microsoft administration tool csvde.exe to export Active Directory data.

menuPass.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
menuPass.description: [menuPass](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0045) has encoded strings in its malware with base64 as well as with a simple, single-byte XOR obfuscation using key 0x40.

menuPass.name: Scripting
menuPass.description: [menuPass](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0045) has used malicious macros embedded inside Office documents to execute files.

menuPass.name: System Network Connections Discovery
menuPass.description: [menuPass](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0045) has used net use to conduct connectivity checks to machines.

menuPass.name: User Execution
menuPass.description: [menuPass](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0045) has attempted to get victims to open malicious files such as Windows Shortcuts (.lnk) and/or Microsoft Office documents, sent via email as part of spearphishing campaigns.

menuPass.name: Connection Proxy
menuPass.description: [menuPass](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0045) has used a global service provider's IP as a proxy for C2 traffic from a victim.

menuPass.name: Scheduled Task
menuPass.description: [menuPass](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0045) has used a script (atexec.py) to execute a command on a target machine via Task Scheduler.

menuPass.name: Trusted Relationship
menuPass.description: [menuPass](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0045) has used legitimate access granted to Managed Service Providers in order to access victims of interest.

menuPass.name: Command-Line Interface
menuPass.description: [menuPass](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0045) executes commands using a command-line interface and reverse shell. The group has used a modified version of pentesting script wmiexec.vbs to execute commands.

menuPass.name: DLL Search Order Hijacking
menuPass.description: [menuPass](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0045) has used DLL search order hijacking.

menuPass.name: Process Hollowing
menuPass.description: [menuPass](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0045) has used process hollowing in iexplore.exe to load the [RedLeaves](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0153) implant.

menuPass.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
menuPass.description: [menuPass](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0045) has used [certutil](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0160) in a macro to decode base64-encoded content contained in a dropper document attached to an email. The group has also used certutil -decode to decode files on the victim’s machine when dropping [UPPERCUT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0275).

menuPass.name: Spearphishing Attachment
menuPass.description: [menuPass](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0045) has sent malicious Office documents via email as part of spearphishing campaigns as well as executables disguised as documents.

menuPass.name: Data Staged
menuPass.description: [menuPass](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0045) stages data prior to exfiltration in multi-part archives, often saved in the Recycle Bin.

menuPass.name: Remote Desktop Protocol
menuPass.description: [menuPass](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0045) has used RDP connections to move across the victim network.

menuPass.name: DLL Side-Loading
menuPass.description: [menuPass](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0045) has used DLL side-loading to launch versions of Mimikatz and PwDump6 as well as [UPPERCUT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0275).

menuPass.name: Remote System Discovery
menuPass.description: [menuPass](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0045) uses scripts to enumerate IP ranges on the victim network. [menuPass](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0045) has also issued the command net view /domain to a [PlugX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0013) implant to gather information about remote systems on the network.

menuPass.name: File Deletion
menuPass.description: A [menuPass](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0045) macro deletes files after it has decoded and decompressed them.

menuPass.name: Remote File Copy
menuPass.description: [menuPass](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0045) has installed updates and new malware on victims.

menuPass.name: Remote Services
menuPass.description: [menuPass](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0045) has used Putty Secure Copy Client (PSCP) to transfer data.

menuPass.name: PowerShell
menuPass.description: [menuPass](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0045) uses [PowerSploit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0194) to inject shellcode into PowerShell.

menuPass.name: Data Compressed
menuPass.description: [menuPass](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0045) has compressed files before exfiltration using TAR and RAR.

menuPass.name: Network Service Scanning
menuPass.description: [menuPass](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0045) has used tcping.exe, similar to [Ping](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0097), to probe port status on systems of interest.

menuPass.name: Masquerading
menuPass.description: [menuPass](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0045) has been seen changing malicious files to appear legitimate. They have also renamed [certutil](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0160) and move it to a different location on system to avoid detection based on use of the tool.

menuPass.name: Data Encrypted
menuPass.description: [menuPass](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0045) has encrypted files and information before exfiltration.

menuPass.name: Data from Local System
menuPass.description: [menuPass](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0045) has collected various files from the compromised computers.

menuPass.name: Input Capture
menuPass.description: [menuPass](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0045) has used key loggers to steal usernames and passwords.

Ke3chang.name: Data from Local System
Ke3chang.description: [Ke3chang](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0004) gathered information and files from local directories for exfiltration.

Ke3chang.name: System Service Discovery
Ke3chang.description: [Ke3chang](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0004) performs service discovery using net start commands.

Ke3chang.name: Data Encrypted
Ke3chang.description: [Ke3chang](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0004) is known to use RAR with passwords to encrypt data prior to exfiltration.

Ke3chang.name: System Information Discovery
Ke3chang.description: [Ke3chang](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0004) performs operating system information discovery using systeminfo.

Ke3chang.name: Permission Groups Discovery
Ke3chang.description: [Ke3chang](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0004) performs discovery of permission groups net group /domain.

Ke3chang.name: Account Discovery
Ke3chang.description: [Ke3chang](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0004) performs account discovery using commands such as net localgroup administrators and net group "REDACTED" /domain on specific permissions groups.

Ke3chang.name: Email Collection
Ke3chang.description: [Ke3chang](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0004) used a .NET tool to dump data from Microsoft Exchange mailboxes.

Ke3chang.name: Remote System Discovery
Ke3chang.description: [Ke3chang](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0004) has used network scanning and enumeration tools, including [Ping](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0097).

Ke3chang.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Ke3chang.description: [Ke3chang](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0004) performs local network configuration discovery using ipconfig.

Ke3chang.name: Credential Dumping
Ke3chang.description: [Ke3chang](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0004) has dumped credentials, including by using [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002).

Ke3chang.name: Command-Line Interface
Ke3chang.description: Malware used by [Ke3chang](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0004) can run commands on the command-line interface.

Ke3chang.name: Pass the Ticket
Ke3chang.description: [Ke3chang](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0004) has used [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002) to generate Kerberos golden tickets.

Ke3chang.name: Windows Admin Shares
Ke3chang.description: [Ke3chang](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0004) actors have been known to copy files to the network shares of other computers to move laterally.

Ke3chang.name: File and Directory Discovery
Ke3chang.description: [Ke3chang](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0004) uses command-line interaction to search files and directories.

Ke3chang.name: New Service
Ke3chang.description: [Ke3chang](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0004) backdoor RoyalDNS established persistence through adding a service called Nwsapagent.

Ke3chang.name: External Remote Services
Ke3chang.description: [Ke3chang](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0004) regained access after eviction via the corporate VPN solution with a stolen VPN certificate, which they had extracted from a compromised host.

Ke3chang.name: Data from Information Repositories
Ke3chang.description: [Ke3chang](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0004) used a SharePoint enumeration and data dumping tool known as spwebmember.

Ke3chang.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Ke3chang.description: Several [Ke3chang](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0004) backdoors achieved persistence by adding a Run key.

Ke3chang.name: Process Discovery
Ke3chang.description: [Ke3chang](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0004) performs process discovery using tasklist commands.

Ke3chang.name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
Ke3chang.description: [Ke3chang](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0004) transferred compressed and encrypted RAR files containing exfiltration through the established backdoor command and control channel during operations.

Ke3chang.name: System Network Connections Discovery
Ke3chang.description: [Ke3chang](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0004) performs local network connection discovery using netstat.

Ke3chang.name: Scripting
Ke3chang.description: [Ke3chang](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0004) has used batch scripts in its malware to install persistence mechanisms.

Ke3chang.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Ke3chang.description: [Ke3chang](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0004) malware RoyalCli and BS2005 have communicated over HTTP with the C2 server through Internet Explorer (IE) by using the COM interface IWebBrowser2. Additionally, [Ke3chang](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0004) malware RoyalDNS has used DNS for C2.

Ke3chang.name: Input Capture
Ke3chang.description: [Ke3chang](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0004) has used keyloggers.

Ke3chang.name: Data Compressed
Ke3chang.description: The [Ke3chang](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0004) group has been known to compress data before exfiltration.

Ke3chang.name: Service Execution
Ke3chang.description: [Ke3chang](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0004) has used a tool known as RemoteExec (similar to [PsExec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0029)) to remotely execute batch scripts and binaries.

Ke3chang.name: Masquerading
Ke3chang.description: [Ke3chang](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0004) has used the right-to-left override character in spearphishing attachment names to trick targets into executing .scr and .exe files.

Patchwork.name: File and Directory Discovery
Patchwork.description: A [Patchwork](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0040) payload has searched all fixed drives on the victim for files matching a specified list of extensions.

Patchwork.name: System Information Discovery
Patchwork.description: [Patchwork](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0040) collected the victim computer name, OS version, and architecture type and sent the information to its C2 server. [Patchwork](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0040) also enumerated all available drives on the victim's machine.

Patchwork.name: Process Hollowing
Patchwork.description: A [Patchwork](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0040) payload uses process hollowing to hide the UAC bypass vulnerability exploitation inside svchost.exe.

Patchwork.name: Dynamic Data Exchange
Patchwork.description: [Patchwork](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0040) leveraged the DDE protocol to deliver their malware.

Patchwork.name: Data Encrypted
Patchwork.description: [Patchwork](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0040) encrypted the collected files' path with AES and then encoded them with base64.

Patchwork.name: Remote File Copy
Patchwork.description: [Patchwork](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0040) payloads download additional files from the C2 server.

Patchwork.name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Patchwork.description: [Patchwork](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0040) uses malicious documents to deliver remote execution exploits as part of. The group has previously exploited CVE-2017-8570, CVE-2012-1856, CVE-2014-4114, CVE-2017-0199, and CVE-2015-1641.

Patchwork.name: File Deletion
Patchwork.description: [Patchwork](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0040) removed certain files and replaced them so they could not be retrieved.

Patchwork.name: Security Software Discovery
Patchwork.description: [Patchwork](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0040) scanned the “Program Files” directories for a directory with the string “Total Security” (the installation path of the “360 Total Security” antivirus tool).

Patchwork.name: Credential Dumping
Patchwork.description: [Patchwork](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0040) dumped the login data database from \AppData\Local\Google\Chrome\User Data\Default\Login Data.

Patchwork.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Patchwork.description: [Patchwork](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0040) has obfuscated a script with Crypto Obfuscator.

Patchwork.name: Scheduled Task
Patchwork.description: A [Patchwork](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0040) file stealer can run a TaskScheduler DLL to add persistence.

Patchwork.name: DLL Side-Loading
Patchwork.description: A [Patchwork](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0040) .dll that contains [BADNEWS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0128) is loaded and executed using DLL side-loading.

Patchwork.name: Automated Collection
Patchwork.description: [Patchwork](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0040) developed a file stealer to search C:\ and collect files with certain extensions. [Patchwork](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0040) also executed a script to enumerate all drives, store them as a list, and upload generated files to the C2 server.

Patchwork.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Patchwork.description: [Patchwork](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0040) has added the path of its second-stage malware to the startup folder to achieve persistence. One of its file stealers has also persisted by adding a Registry Run key.

Patchwork.name: Binary Padding
Patchwork.description: [Patchwork](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0040) apparently altered [NDiskMonitor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0272) samples by adding four bytes of random letters in a likely attempt to change the file hashes.

Patchwork.name: Drive-by Compromise
Patchwork.description: [Patchwork](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0040) has used watering holes to deliver files with exploits to initial victims.

Patchwork.name: Bypass User Account Control
Patchwork.description: [Patchwork](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0040) bypassed User Access Control (UAC).

Patchwork.name: PowerShell
Patchwork.description: [Patchwork](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0040) used [PowerSploit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0194) to download payloads, run a reverse shell, and execute malware on the victim's machine.

Patchwork.name: Indicator Removal from Tools
Patchwork.description: [Patchwork](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0040) apparently altered [NDiskMonitor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0272) samples by adding four bytes of random letters in a likely attempt to change the file hashes.

Patchwork.name: Software Packing
Patchwork.description: A [Patchwork](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0040) payload was packed with UPX.

Patchwork.name: Spearphishing Attachment
Patchwork.description: [Patchwork](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0040) has used spearphishing with an attachment to deliver files with exploits to initial victims.

Patchwork.name: Data Staged
Patchwork.description: [Patchwork](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0040) copied all targeted files to a directory called index that was eventually uploaded to the C&C server.

Patchwork.name: System Owner/User Discovery
Patchwork.description: [Patchwork](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0040) collected the victim username and whether it was running as admin, then sent the information to its C2 server.

Patchwork.name: User Execution
Patchwork.description: [Patchwork](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0040) embedded a malicious macro in a Word document and lured the victim to click on an icon to execute the malware.

Patchwork.name: Data Encoding
Patchwork.description: [Patchwork](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0040) used Base64 to encode C2 traffic.

Patchwork.name: Spearphishing Link
Patchwork.description: [Patchwork](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0040) has used spearphishing with links to deliver files with exploits to initial victims. The group has used embedded image tags (known as web bugs) with unique, per-recipient tracking links in their emails for the purpose of identifying which recipients opened messages.

Patchwork.name: Modify Registry
Patchwork.description: A [Patchwork](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0040) payload deletes Resiliency Registry keys created by Microsoft Office applications in an apparent effort to trick users into thinking there were no issues during application runs.

Patchwork.name: Masquerading
Patchwork.description: [Patchwork](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0040) installed its payload in the startup programs folder as "Baidu Software Update." The group also adds its second stage payload to the startup programs as “Net Monitor."

Patchwork.name: Data from Local System
Patchwork.description: [Patchwork](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0040) collected and exfiltrated files from the infected system.

Patchwork.name: Scripting
Patchwork.description: [Patchwork](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0040) used Visual Basic Scripts (VBS), JavaScript code, batch files, and .SCT files on victim machines.

Patchwork.name: Remote Desktop Protocol
Patchwork.description: [Patchwork](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0040) attempted to use RDP to move laterally.

Patchwork.name: Web Service
Patchwork.description: [Patchwork](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0040) hides base64-encoded and encrypted C2 server locations in comments on legitimate websites.

Patchwork.name: Command-Line Interface
Patchwork.description: [Patchwork](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0040) ran a reverse shell with Meterpreter.

Gorgon Group.name: Spearphishing Attachment
Gorgon Group.description: [Gorgon Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0078) sent emails to victims with malicious Microsoft Office documents attached.

Gorgon Group.name: Disabling Security Tools
Gorgon Group.description: [Gorgon Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0078) malware can attempt to disable security features in Microsoft Office and Windows Defender using the taskkill command.

Gorgon Group.name: Process Injection
Gorgon Group.description: [Gorgon Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0078) malware can download a remote access tool, [ShiftyBug](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0294), and inject into another process.

Gorgon Group.name: Shortcut Modification
Gorgon Group.description: [Gorgon Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0078) malware can create a .lnk file and add a Registry Run key to establish persistence.

Gorgon Group.name: Command-Line Interface
Gorgon Group.description: [Gorgon Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0078) malware can use cmd.exe to download and execute payloads and to execute commands on the system.

Gorgon Group.name: Execution through API
Gorgon Group.description: [Gorgon Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0078) malware can leverage the Windows API call, CreateProcessA(), for execution.

Gorgon Group.name: Remote File Copy
Gorgon Group.description: [Gorgon Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0078) malware can download additional files from C2 servers.

Gorgon Group.name: Uncommonly Used Port
Gorgon Group.description: [Gorgon Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0078) has used a variant of [ShiftyBug](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0294) that communicates with its C2 server over port 6666.

Gorgon Group.name: User Execution
Gorgon Group.description: [Gorgon Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0078) attempted to get users to launch malicious Microsoft Office attachments delivered via spearphishing emails.

Gorgon Group.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Gorgon Group.description: [Gorgon Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0078) malware can decode contents from a payload that was Base64 encoded and write the contents to a file.

Gorgon Group.name: Process Hollowing
Gorgon Group.description: [Gorgon Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0078) malware can use process hollowing to inject one of its trojans into another process.

Gorgon Group.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Gorgon Group.description: [Gorgon Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0078) malware can create a .lnk file and add a Registry Run key to establish persistence.

Gorgon Group.name: PowerShell
Gorgon Group.description: [Gorgon Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0078) malware can use PowerShell commands to download and execute a payload and open a decoy document on the victim’s machine.

Gorgon Group.name: Modify Registry
Gorgon Group.description: [Gorgon Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0078) malware can deactivate security mechanisms in Microsoft Office by editing several keys and values under HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Office\.

Gorgon Group.name: Scripting
Gorgon Group.description: [Gorgon Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0078) has used macros in [Spearphishing Attachment](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1193)s as well as executed VBScripts on victim machines.

Dragonfly 2.0.name: Masquerading
Dragonfly 2.0.description: [Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) created accounts disguised as legitimate backup and service accounts as well as an email administration account.

Dragonfly 2.0.name: Permission Groups Discovery
Dragonfly 2.0.description: [Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) used batch scripts to enumerate administrators in the environment.

Dragonfly 2.0.name: User Execution
Dragonfly 2.0.description: [Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) has used various forms of spearphishing in attempts to get users to open links or attachments.

Dragonfly 2.0.name: Command-Line Interface
Dragonfly 2.0.description: [Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) used command line for execution.

Dragonfly 2.0.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Dragonfly 2.0.description: [Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) used SMB for C2.

Dragonfly 2.0.name: Create Account
Dragonfly 2.0.description: [Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) created accounts on victims, including administrator accounts, some of which appeared to be tailored to each individual staging target.

Dragonfly 2.0.name: Disabling Security Tools
Dragonfly 2.0.description: [Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) has disabled host-based firewalls. The group has also globally opened port 3389.

Dragonfly 2.0.name: Modify Registry
Dragonfly 2.0.description: [Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) modified the Registry to perform multiple techniques through the use of [Reg](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0075).

Dragonfly 2.0.name: Template Injection
Dragonfly 2.0.description: [Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) has injected SMB URLs into malicious Word spearphishing attachments to initiate [Forced Authentication](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1187).

Dragonfly 2.0.name: Email Collection
Dragonfly 2.0.description: [Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) accessed email accounts using Outlook Web Access.

Dragonfly 2.0.name: Drive-by Compromise
Dragonfly 2.0.description: [Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) compromised legitimate organizations' websites to create watering holes to compromise victims.

Dragonfly 2.0.name: Credential Dumping
