Dragonfly 2.0.description: [Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) dropped and executed SecretsDump and CrackMapExec, tools that can dump password hashes.

Dragonfly 2.0.name: Remote System Discovery
Dragonfly 2.0.description: [Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) likely obtained a list of hosts in the victim environment.

Dragonfly 2.0.name: Indicator Removal on Host
Dragonfly 2.0.description: [Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) cleared Windows event logs and other logs produced by tools they used, including system, security, terminal services, remote services, and audit logs. The actors also deleted specific Registry keys.

Dragonfly 2.0.name: Scheduled Task
Dragonfly 2.0.description: [Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) used scheduled tasks to automatically log out of created accounts every 8 hours as well as to execute malicious files.

Dragonfly 2.0.name: File and Directory Discovery
Dragonfly 2.0.description: [Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) used a batch script to gather folder and file names from victim hosts.

Dragonfly 2.0.name: Network Share Discovery
Dragonfly 2.0.description: [Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) identified and browsed file servers in the victim network, sometimes , viewing files pertaining to ICS or Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA) systems.

Dragonfly 2.0.name: Valid Accounts
Dragonfly 2.0.description: [Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) compromised user credentials and used valid accounts for operations.

Dragonfly 2.0.name: Data from Local System
Dragonfly 2.0.description: [Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) collected data from local victim systems.

Dragonfly 2.0.name: Query Registry
Dragonfly 2.0.description: [Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) queried the Registry to identify victim information.

Dragonfly 2.0.name: Forced Authentication
Dragonfly 2.0.description: [Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) has gathered hashed user credentials over SMB using spearphishing attachments with external resource links and by modifying .LNK file icon resources to collect credentials from virtualized systems.

Dragonfly 2.0.name: Scripting
Dragonfly 2.0.description: [Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) used various types of scripting to perform operations, including Python and batch scripts. The group was observed installing Python 2.7 on a victim.

Dragonfly 2.0.name: Screen Capture
Dragonfly 2.0.description: [Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) has performed screen captures of victims, including by using a tool, scr.exe (which matched the hash of ScreenUtil).

Dragonfly 2.0.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Dragonfly 2.0.description: [Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) used batch scripts to enumerate network information, including information about trusts, zones, and the domain.

Dragonfly 2.0.name: File Deletion
Dragonfly 2.0.description: [Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) deleted many of its files used during operations as part of cleanup, including removing applications and deleting screenshots.

Dragonfly 2.0.name: Remote File Copy
Dragonfly 2.0.description: [Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) copied and installed tools for operations once in the victim environment.

Dragonfly 2.0.name: Shortcut Modification
Dragonfly 2.0.description: [Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) manipulated .lnk files to gather user credentials in conjunction with [Forced Authentication](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1187).

Dragonfly 2.0.name: Web Shell
Dragonfly 2.0.description: [Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) commonly created Web shells on victims' publicly accessible email and web servers, which they used to maintain access to a victim network and download additional malicious files.

Dragonfly 2.0.name: Spearphishing Attachment
Dragonfly 2.0.description: [Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) used spearphishing with Microsoft Office attachments to target victims.

Dragonfly 2.0.name: Brute Force
Dragonfly 2.0.description: [Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) dropped and executed tools used for password cracking, including Hydra.

Dragonfly 2.0.name: Spearphishing Link
Dragonfly 2.0.description: [Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) used spearphishing with PDF attachments containing malicious links that redirected to credential harvesting websites.

Dragonfly 2.0.name: External Remote Services
Dragonfly 2.0.description: [Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) used VPNs and Outlook Web Access (OWA) to maintain access to victim networks.

Dragonfly 2.0.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Dragonfly 2.0.description: [Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) added the registry value ntdll to the Registry Run key to establish persistence.

Dragonfly 2.0.name: Remote Desktop Protocol
Dragonfly 2.0.description: [Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) moved laterally via RDP.

Dragonfly 2.0.name: PowerShell
Dragonfly 2.0.description: [Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) used PowerShell scripts for execution.

Dragonfly 2.0.name: System Owner/User Discovery
Dragonfly 2.0.description: [Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) used the command query user on victim hosts.

Dragonfly 2.0.name: Data Staged
Dragonfly 2.0.description: [Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) created a directory named "out" in the user's %AppData% folder and copied files to it.

Dragonfly 2.0.name: Account Manipulation
Dragonfly 2.0.description: [Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) added newly created accounts to the administrators group to maintain elevated access.

Dragonfly 2.0.name: Commonly Used Port
Dragonfly 2.0.description: [Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) used SMB over ports 445 or 139 for C2. The group also established encrypted connections over port 443.

Dragonfly 2.0.name: Account Discovery
Dragonfly 2.0.description: [Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) used batch scripts to enumerate users in the victim environment.

Dragonfly 2.0.name: Data Compressed
Dragonfly 2.0.description: [Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) compressed data into .zip files prior to exfiltrating it.

BRONZE BUTLER.name: Data Compressed
BRONZE BUTLER.description: [BRONZE BUTLER](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0060) has compressed data into password-protected RAR archives prior to exfiltration.

BRONZE BUTLER.name: User Execution
BRONZE BUTLER.description: [BRONZE BUTLER](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0060) has attempted to get users to launch malicious Microsoft Word attachments delivered via spearphishing emails.

BRONZE BUTLER.name: Bypass User Account Control
BRONZE BUTLER.description: [BRONZE BUTLER](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0060) malware xxmm contains a UAC bypass tool for privilege escalation.

BRONZE BUTLER.name: Scheduled Task
BRONZE BUTLER.description: [BRONZE BUTLER](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0060) has used [at](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0110) and [schtasks](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0111) to register a scheduled task to execute malware during lateral movement.

BRONZE BUTLER.name: Masquerading
BRONZE BUTLER.description: [BRONZE BUTLER](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0060) has given malware the same name as an existing file on the file share server to cause users to unwittingly launch and install the malware on additional systems.

BRONZE BUTLER.name: Web Service
BRONZE BUTLER.description: [BRONZE BUTLER](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0060)'s MSGET downloader uses a dead drop resolver to access malicious payloads.

BRONZE BUTLER.name: File and Directory Discovery
BRONZE BUTLER.description: [BRONZE BUTLER](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0060) has collected a list of files from the victim and uploaded it to its C2 server, and then created a new list of specific files to steal.

BRONZE BUTLER.name: Screen Capture
BRONZE BUTLER.description: [BRONZE BUTLER](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0060) has used a tool to capture screenshots.

BRONZE BUTLER.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
BRONZE BUTLER.description: [BRONZE BUTLER](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0060) malware has used HTTP for C2.

BRONZE BUTLER.name: Drive-by Compromise
BRONZE BUTLER.description: [BRONZE BUTLER](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0060) compromised three Japanese websites using a Flash exploit to perform watering hole attacks.

BRONZE BUTLER.name: Credential Dumping
BRONZE BUTLER.description: [BRONZE BUTLER](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0060) has used various tools to perform credential dumping.

BRONZE BUTLER.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
BRONZE BUTLER.description: [BRONZE BUTLER](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0060) downloads encoded payloads and decodes them on the victim.

BRONZE BUTLER.name: Account Discovery
BRONZE BUTLER.description: [BRONZE BUTLER](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0060) has used net user /domain to identify account information.

BRONZE BUTLER.name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
BRONZE BUTLER.description: [BRONZE BUTLER](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0060) has used RC4 encryption (for Datper malware) and AES (for xxmm malware) to obfuscate HTTP traffic.

BRONZE BUTLER.name: File Deletion
BRONZE BUTLER.description: The [BRONZE BUTLER](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0060) uploader or malware the uploader uses command to delete the RAR archives after they have been exfiltrated.

BRONZE BUTLER.name: Remote System Discovery
BRONZE BUTLER.description: [BRONZE BUTLER](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0060) typically use ping and [Net](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0039) to enumerate systems.

BRONZE BUTLER.name: Data from Local System
BRONZE BUTLER.description: [BRONZE BUTLER](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0060) has exfiltrated files stolen from local systems.

BRONZE BUTLER.name: System Time Discovery
BRONZE BUTLER.description: [BRONZE BUTLER](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0060) has used net time to check the local time on a target system.

BRONZE BUTLER.name: Scripting
BRONZE BUTLER.description: [BRONZE BUTLER](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0060) has used VBS, VBE, and batch scripts for execution.

BRONZE BUTLER.name: Exploitation for Client Execution
BRONZE BUTLER.description: [BRONZE BUTLER](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0060) has exploited Microsoft Word vulnerability CVE-2014-4114 for execution.

BRONZE BUTLER.name: Remote File Copy
BRONZE BUTLER.description: [BRONZE BUTLER](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0060) has used various tools to download files, including DGet (a similar tool to wget).

BRONZE BUTLER.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
BRONZE BUTLER.description: [BRONZE BUTLER](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0060) has used a batch script that adds a Registry Run key to establish malware persistence.

BRONZE BUTLER.name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
BRONZE BUTLER.description: [BRONZE BUTLER](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0060) has used a tool called RarStar that encodes data with a custom XOR algorithm when posting it to a C2 server.

BRONZE BUTLER.name: Data Encrypted
BRONZE BUTLER.description: [BRONZE BUTLER](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0060) has compressed and encrypted data into password-protected RAR archives prior to exfiltration.

BRONZE BUTLER.name: Binary Padding
BRONZE BUTLER.description: [BRONZE BUTLER](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0060) downloader code has included "0" characters at the end of the file to inflate the file size in a likely attempt to evade anti-virus detection.

BRONZE BUTLER.name: Pass the Ticket
BRONZE BUTLER.description: [BRONZE BUTLER](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0060) has created forged Kerberos Ticket Granting Ticket (TGT) and Ticket Granting Service (TGS) tickets to maintain administrative access.

BRONZE BUTLER.name: Spearphishing Attachment
BRONZE BUTLER.description: [BRONZE BUTLER](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0060) used spearphishing emails with malicious Microsoft Word attachments to infect victims.

BRONZE BUTLER.name: Data Encoding
BRONZE BUTLER.description: Several [BRONZE BUTLER](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0060) tools encode data with base64 when posting it to a C2 server.

BRONZE BUTLER.name: Data from Network Shared Drive
BRONZE BUTLER.description: [BRONZE BUTLER](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0060) has exfiltrated files stolen from file shares.

BRONZE BUTLER.name: PowerShell
BRONZE BUTLER.description: [BRONZE BUTLER](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0060) has used PowerShell for execution.

BRONZE BUTLER.name: Command-Line Interface
BRONZE BUTLER.description: [BRONZE BUTLER](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0060) uses the command-line interface.

APT19.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
APT19.description: [APT19](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0073) used an HTTP malware variant and a Port 22 malware variant to collect the MAC address and IP address from the victim’s machine.

APT19.name: User Execution
APT19.description: [APT19](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0073) attempted to get users to launch malicious attachments delivered via spearphishing emails.

APT19.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
APT19.description: [APT19](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0073) used HTTP for C2 communications. [APT19](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0073) also used an HTTP malware variant to communicate over HTTP for C2.

APT19.name: Data Encoding
APT19.description: An [APT19](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0073) HTTP malware variant used Base64 to encode communications to the C2 server.

APT19.name: Regsvr32
APT19.description: [APT19](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0073) used Regsvr32 to bypass application whitelisting techniques.

APT19.name: Scripting
APT19.description: [APT19](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0073) downloaded and launched code within a SCT file.

APT19.name: System Information Discovery
APT19.description: [APT19](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0073) collected system architecture information. [APT19](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0073) used an HTTP malware variant and a Port 22 malware variant to gather the hostname and CPU information from the victim’s machine.

APT19.name: Rundll32
APT19.description: [APT19](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0073) configured its payload to inject into the rundll32.exe.

APT19.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
APT19.description: An [APT19](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0073) HTTP malware variant establishes persistence by setting the Registry key HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\Windows Debug Tools-%LOCALAPPDATA%\.

APT19.name: System Owner/User Discovery
APT19.description: [APT19](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0073) used an HTTP malware variant and a Port 22 malware variant to collect the victim’s username.

APT19.name: DLL Side-Loading
APT19.description: [APT19](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0073) launched an HTTP malware variant and a Port 22 malware variant using a legitimate executable that loaded the malicious DLL.

APT19.name: Modify Registry
APT19.description: [APT19](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0073) uses a Port 22 malware variant to modify several Registry keys.

APT19.name: PowerShell
APT19.description: [APT19](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0073) used PowerShell commands to execute payloads.

APT19.name: Drive-by Compromise
APT19.description: [APT19](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0073) performed a watering hole attack on forbes.com in 2014 to compromise targets.

APT19.name: Spearphishing Attachment
APT19.description: [APT19](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0073) sent spearphishing emails with malicious attachments in RTF and XLSM formats to deliver initial exploits.

APT19.name: Modify Existing Service
APT19.description: An [APT19](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0073) Port 22 malware variant registers itself as a service.

APT19.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
APT19.description: An [APT19](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0073) HTTP malware variant decrypts strings using single-byte XOR keys.

APT19.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
APT19.description: [APT19](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0073) used Base64 to obfuscate commands and the payload.

description.name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel

Lazarus Group.name: Access Token Manipulation
Lazarus Group.description: [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) keylogger KiloAlfa obtains user tokens from interactive sessions to execute itself with API call CreateProcessAsUserA under that user's context.

description.name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel

Lazarus Group.name: Account Manipulation
Lazarus Group.description: [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) malware WhiskeyDelta-Two contains a function that attempts to rename the administrator’s account.

Lazarus Group.name: Drive-by Compromise
Lazarus Group.description: [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) delivered [RATANKBA](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0241) to victims via a compromised legitimate website.

Lazarus Group.name: Hidden Files and Directories
Lazarus Group.description: A [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) VBA Macro sets its file attributes to System and Hidden.

Lazarus Group.name: Process Injection
Lazarus Group.description: A [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) malware sample performs reflective DLL injection.

Lazarus Group.name: Compiled HTML File
Lazarus Group.description: [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) has used CHM files to move concealed payloads as part of.

Lazarus Group.name: Scripting
Lazarus Group.description: A Destover-like variant used by [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) uses a batch file mechanism to delete its binaries from the system.

Lazarus Group.name: Bootkit
Lazarus Group.description: [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) malware WhiskeyAlfa-Three modifies sector 0 of the Master Boot Record (MBR) to ensure that the malware will persist even if a victim machine shuts down.

Lazarus Group.name: Remote Desktop Protocol
Lazarus Group.description: [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) malware SierraCharlie uses RDP for propagation.

Lazarus Group.name: File Deletion
Lazarus Group.description: [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) malware deletes files in various ways, including "suicide scripts" to delete malware binaries from the victim. [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) also uses secure file deletion to delete files from the victim.

Lazarus Group.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Lazarus Group.description: [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) malware attempts to maintain persistence by saving itself in the Start menu folder or by adding a Registry Run key.

Lazarus Group.name: Spearphishing Attachment
Lazarus Group.description: [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) has targeted victims with spearphishing emails containing malicious Microsoft Word documents.

Lazarus Group.name: Data Staged
Lazarus Group.description: [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) malware IndiaIndia saves information gathered about the victim to a file that is saved in the %TEMP% directory, then compressed, encrypted, and uploaded to a C2 server.

Lazarus Group.name: Data Encoding
Lazarus Group.description: A [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) malware sample encodes data with base64.

Lazarus Group.name: Input Capture
Lazarus Group.description: [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) malware KiloAlfa contains keylogging functionality.

Lazarus Group.name: Commonly Used Port
Lazarus Group.description: Some [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) malware uses a list of ordered port numbers to choose a port for C2 traffic, which includes commonly used ports such as 443, 53, 80, 25, and 8080.

Lazarus Group.name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
Lazarus Group.description: [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) malware IndiaIndia saves information gathered about the victim to a file that is uploaded to one of its 10 C2 servers. Another [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) malware sample also performs exfiltration over the C2 channel.

Lazarus Group.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Lazarus Group.description: [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) malware uses multiple types of encryption and encoding in its malware files, including AES, Caracachs, RC4, basic XOR with constant 0xA7, and other techniques.

Lazarus Group.name: File and Directory Discovery
Lazarus Group.description: Several [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) malware samples use a common function to identify target files by their extension. [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) malware families can also enumerate files and directories, including a Destover-like variant that lists files and gathers information for all drives.

Lazarus Group.name: System Owner/User Discovery
Lazarus Group.description: Various [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) malware enumerates logged-on users.

Lazarus Group.name: Disabling Security Tools
Lazarus Group.description: Various [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) malware modifies the Windows firewall to allow incoming connections or disable it entirely using [netsh](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0108). [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) malware TangoDelta attempts to terminate various processes associated with McAfee. Additionally, [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) malware SHARPKNOT disables the Microsoft Windows System Event Notification and Alerter services.

Lazarus Group.name: Timestomp
Lazarus Group.description: Several [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) malware families use timestomping, including modifying the last write timestamp of a specified Registry key to a random date, as well as copying the timestamp for legitimate .exe files (such as calc.exe or mspaint.exe) to its dropped files.

Lazarus Group.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Lazarus Group.description: A [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) malware sample conducts C2 over HTTP.

Lazarus Group.name: System Time Discovery
Lazarus Group.description: A Destover-like implant used by [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) can obtain the current system time and send it to the C2 server.

Lazarus Group.name: Data from Local System
Lazarus Group.description: [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) malware IndiaIndia saves information gathered about the victim to a file that is uploaded to one of its 10 C2 servers. [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) malware RomeoDelta copies specified directories from the victim's machine, then archives and encrypts the directories before uploading to its C2 server.

Lazarus Group.name: Shortcut Modification
Lazarus Group.description: A [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) malware sample adds persistence on the system by creating a shortcut in the user’s Startup folder.

Lazarus Group.name: Application Window Discovery
Lazarus Group.description: [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) malware IndiaIndia obtains and sends to its C2 server the title of the window for each running process. The KilaAlfa keylogger also reports the title of the window in the foreground.

Lazarus Group.name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
Lazarus Group.description: Several [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) malware families encrypt C2 traffic using custom code that uses XOR with an ADD operation and XOR with a SUB operation. Another [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) malware sample XORs C2 traffic. [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) malware also uses a unique form of communication encryption known as FakeTLS that mimics TLS but uses a different encryption method, evading SSL man-in-the-middle decryption attacks.

Lazarus Group.name: Credential Dumping
Lazarus Group.description: [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) leveraged [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002) to extract Windows Credentials of currently logged-in users and steals passwords stored in browsers.

Lazarus Group.name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Lazarus Group.description: [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) has exploited Adobe Flash vulnerability CVE-2018-4878 for execution.

Lazarus Group.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Lazarus Group.description: [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) malware IndiaIndia obtains and sends to its C2 server information about the first network interface card’s configuration, including IP address, gateways, subnet mask, DHCP information, and whether WINS is available.

description.name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel

Lazarus Group.name: New Service
Lazarus Group.description: Several [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) malware families install themselves as new services on victims.

Lazarus Group.name: Query Registry
Lazarus Group.description: [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) malware IndiaIndia checks Registry keys within HKCU and HKLM to determine if certain applications are present, including SecureCRT, Terminal Services, RealVNC, TightVNC, UltraVNC, Radmin, mRemote, TeamViewer, FileZilla, pcAnyware, and Remote Desktop. Another [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) malware sample checks for the presence of the following Registry key:HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Bitcoin\Bitcoin-Qt.

Lazarus Group.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
Lazarus Group.description: [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) malware SierraAlfa uses the Windows Management Instrumentation Command-line application wmic to start itself on a target system during lateral movement.

Lazarus Group.name: Process Discovery
Lazarus Group.description: Several [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) malware families gather a list of running processes on a victim system and send it to their C2 server. A Destover-like variant used by [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) also gathers process times.

Lazarus Group.name: Remote File Copy
Lazarus Group.description: Several [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) malware families are capable of downloading and executing binaries from its C2 server.

Lazarus Group.name: Data Encrypted
Lazarus Group.description: [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) malware IndiaIndia saves information gathered about the victim to a file that is compressed with Zlib, encrypted, and uploaded to a C2 server. [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) malware RomeoDelta archives specified directories in .zip format, encrypts the .zip file, and uploads it to its C2 server. A [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) malware sample encrypts data using a simple byte based XOR operation prior to exfiltration.

Lazarus Group.name: Connection Proxy
Lazarus Group.description: [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) uses multiple proxies to obfuscate network traffic from victims.

Lazarus Group.name: Windows Admin Shares
Lazarus Group.description: [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) malware SierraAlfa accesses the ADMIN$ share via SMB to conduct lateral movement.

Lazarus Group.name: Fallback Channels
Lazarus Group.description: [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) malware SierraAlfa sends data to one of the hard-coded C2 servers chosen at random, and if the transmission fails, chooses a new C2 server to attempt the transmission again.

Lazarus Group.name: Brute Force
Lazarus Group.description: [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) malware attempts to connect to Windows shares for lateral movement by using a generated list of usernames, which center around permutations of the username Administrator, and weak passwords.

Lazarus Group.name: User Execution
Lazarus Group.description: [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) has attempted to get users to launch a malicious Microsoft Word attachment delivered via a spearphishing email.

Lazarus Group.name: Uncommonly Used Port
Lazarus Group.description: Some [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) malware uses a list of ordered port numbers to choose a port for C2 traffic, which includes uncommonly used ports such as 995, 1816, 465, 1521, 3306, and many others.

Lazarus Group.name: Multiband Communication
Lazarus Group.description: Some [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) malware uses multiple channels for C2, such as RomeoWhiskey-Two, which consists of a RAT channel that parses data in datagram form and a Proxy channel that forms virtual point-to-point sessions.

Lazarus Group.name: Data Compressed
Lazarus Group.description: [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) malware IndiaIndia saves information gathered about the victim to a file that is compressed with Zlib, encrypted, and uploaded to a C2 server. [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) malware RomeoDelta archives specified directories in .zip format, encrypts the .zip file, and uploads it to its C2 server.

Lazarus Group.name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Lazarus Group.description: [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) malware uses Caracachs encryption to encrypt C2 payloads.

Lazarus Group.name: System Information Discovery
Lazarus Group.description: Several [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) malware families collect information on the type and version of the victim OS, as well as the victim computer name and CPU information. A Destover-like variant used by [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) also collects disk space information and sends it to its C2 server.

Lazarus Group.name: Command-Line Interface
Lazarus Group.description: [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) malware uses cmd.exe to execute commands on victims.

Lazarus Group.name: Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol
Lazarus Group.description: [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) malware SierraBravo-Two generates an email message via SMTP containing information about newly infected victims.

Lazarus Group.name: Service Stop
Lazarus Group.description: [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) has stopped the MSExchangeIS service to render Exchange contents inaccessible to users.

Lazarus Group.name: Disk Structure Wipe
Lazarus Group.description: [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) malware SHARPKNOT overwrites and deletes the Master Boot Record (MBR) on the victim's machine and has possessed MBR wiper malware since at least 2009.

Lazarus Group.name: Disk Content Wipe
Lazarus Group.description: [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) has used malware like WhiskeyAlfa to overwrite the first 64MB of every drive with a mix of static and random buffers. A similar process is then used to wipe content in logical drives and, finally, attempt to wipe every byte of every sector on every drive. WhiskeyBravo can be used to overwrite the first 4.9MB of physical drives. WhiskeyDelta can overwrite the first 132MB or 1.5MB of each drive with random data from heap memory.

Lazarus Group.name: Data Destruction
Lazarus Group.description: [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) has used a custom secure delete function to overwrite file contents with data from heap memory.

Lazarus Group.name: Resource Hijacking
Lazarus Group.description: [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) has subset groups like Bluenoroff who have used cryptocurrency mining software on victim machines.

description.name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel

APT33.name: Spearphishing Link
APT33.description: [APT33](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0064) has sent spearphishing emails containing links to .hta files.

APT33.name: User Execution
APT33.description: [APT33](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0064) has lured users to click links to malicious HTML applications delivered via spearphishing emails.

APT33.name: Valid Accounts
APT33.description: [APT33](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0064) has used valid accounts for initial access and privilege escalation.

description.name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel

APT33.name: Exploitation for Client Execution
APT33.description: [APT33](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0064) has attempted to exploit a known vulnerability in WinRAR (CVE-2018-20250).

APT33.name: Network Sniffing
APT33.description: [APT33](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0064) has used SniffPass to collect credentials by sniffing network traffic.

APT33.name: Credential Dumping
APT33.description: [APT33](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0064) has used a variety of publicly available tools like [LaZagne](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0349), [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002), Gpppassword, SniffPass, and ProcDump to dump credentials.

APT33.name: Data Compressed
APT33.description: [APT33](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0064) has used WinRAR to compress data prior to exfil.

APT33.name: Remote File Copy
APT33.description: [APT33](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0064) has downloaded additional files and programs from its C2 server.

APT33.name: PowerShell
APT33.description: [APT33](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0064) has utilized PowerShell to download files from the C2 server and run various scripts.

APT33.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
APT33.description: [APT33](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0064) has deployed a tool known as DarkComet to the Startup folder of a victim.

APT33.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
APT33.description: [APT33](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0064) has used HTTP for command and control.

APT33.name: Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol
APT33.description: [APT33](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0064) has used FTP to exfiltrate files (separately from the C2 channel).

APT33.name: Uncommonly Used Port
APT33.description: [APT33](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0064) has used ports 808 and 880 for command and control.

APT33.name: Scheduled Task
APT33.description: [APT33](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0064) has created a scheduled task to execute a .vbe file multiple times a day.

APT33.name: Data Encoding
APT33.description: [APT33](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0064) has used base64 to encode command and control traffic.

APT33.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
APT33.description: [APT33](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0064) has used base64 to encode payloads.

APT33.name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
APT33.description: [APT33](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0064) has used AES for encryption of command and control traffic.

APT33.name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
APT33.description: [APT33](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0064) has used a publicly available exploit for CVE-2017-0213 to escalate privileges on a local system.

APT33.name: Commonly Used Port
APT33.description: [APT33](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0064) has used port 443 for command and control.

APT33.name: Brute Force
APT33.description: [APT33](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0064) has used password spraying to gain access to target systems.

APT33.name: Execution Guardrails
APT33.description: [APT33](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0064) has used kill dates in their malware to guardrail execution.

Leviathan.name: Command-Line Interface
Leviathan.description: [Leviathan](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0065) uses a backdoor known as BADFLICK that is is capable of generating a reverse shell.

Leviathan.name: BITS Jobs
Leviathan.description: [Leviathan](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0065) has used bitsadmin.exe to download additional tools.

Leviathan.name: Regsvr32
Leviathan.description: [Leviathan](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0065) has used regsvr32 for execution.

Leviathan.name: Scripting
Leviathan.description: [Leviathan](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0065) has used multiple types of scripting for execution, including JavaScript, JavaScript Scriptlets in XML, and VBScript.

Leviathan.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Leviathan.description: [Leviathan](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0065) has used a DLL known as SeDll to decrypt and execute other JavaScript backdoors.

Leviathan.name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Leviathan.description: [Leviathan](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0065) has exploited multiple Microsoft Office and .NET vulnerabilities for execution, including CVE-2017-0199, CVE-2017-8759, and CVE-2017-11882.

Leviathan.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Leviathan.description: [Leviathan](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0065) has obfuscated code using base64 and gzip compression.

Leviathan.name: Data Staged
Leviathan.description: [Leviathan](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0065) has used C:\Windows\Debug and C:\Perflogs as staging directories.

Leviathan.name: PowerShell
Leviathan.description: [Leviathan](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0065) has used PowerShell for execution.

Leviathan.name: Valid Accounts
Leviathan.description: [Leviathan](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0065) has used valid, compromised email accounts for defense evasion, including to send malicious emails to other victim organizations.

Leviathan.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Leviathan.description: [Leviathan](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0065) has used JavaScript to create a shortcut file in the Startup folder that points to its main backdoor.

Leviathan.name: Remote File Copy
Leviathan.description: [Leviathan](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0065) has downloaded additional scripts and files from adversary-controlled servers. [Leviathan](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0065) has also used an uploader known as LUNCHMONEY that can exfiltrate files to Dropbox.

Leviathan.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
Leviathan.description: [Leviathan](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0065) has used WMI for execution.

Leviathan.name: Shortcut Modification
Leviathan.description: [Leviathan](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0065) has used JavaScript to create a shortcut file in the Startup folder that points to its main backdoor.

Leviathan.name: Web Service
Leviathan.description: [Leviathan](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0065) has received C2 instructions from user profiles created on legitimate websites such as Github and TechNet.

Leviathan.name: Windows Management Instrumentation Event Subscription
Leviathan.description: [Leviathan](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0065) has used WMI for persistence.

Leviathan.name: Spearphishing Attachment
Leviathan.description: [Leviathan](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0065) has sent spearphishing emails with malicious attachments, including .rtf, .doc, and .xls files.

Leviathan.name: Spearphishing Link
Leviathan.description: [Leviathan](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0065) has sent spearphishing emails with links, often using a fraudulent lookalike domain and stolen branding.

Leviathan.name: Binary Padding
Leviathan.description: [Leviathan](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0065) has inserted garbage characters into code, presumably to avoid anti-virus detection.

Leviathan.name: User Execution
Leviathan.description: [Leviathan](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0065) has sent spearphishing emails links and attachments attempting to get a user to click.

Leviathan.name: Code Signing
Leviathan.description: [Leviathan](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0065) has used stolen code signing certificates to sign malware.

Leviathan.name: Remote Services
Leviathan.description: [Leviathan](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0065) used ssh for internal reconnaissance.

Leviathan.name: Credential Dumping
Leviathan.description: [Leviathan](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0065) has used publicly available tools to dump password hashes.

Leviathan.name: Remote Desktop Protocol
Leviathan.description: [Leviathan](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0065) has targeted RDP credentials and used it to move through the victim environment.

Leviathan.name: Web Shell
Leviathan.description: [Leviathan](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0065) relies on web shells for an initial foothold as well as persistence into the victim's systems.

Cobalt Group.name: Remote Desktop Protocol
Cobalt Group.description: [Cobalt Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0080) has used Remote Desktop Protocol to conduct lateral movement.

Cobalt Group.name: CMSTP
Cobalt Group.description: [Cobalt Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0080) has used the command cmstp.exe /s /ns C:\Users\ADMINI~W\AppData\Local\Temp\XKNqbpzl.txt to bypass AppLocker and launch a malicious script.

Cobalt Group.name: Redundant Access
Cobalt Group.description: [Cobalt Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0080) has used TeamViewer to preserve remote access in case control using the Cobalt Strike module was lost.

Cobalt Group.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Cobalt Group.description: [Cobalt Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0080) has used HTTPS and DNS tunneling for C2. The group has also used the Plink utility to create SSH tunnels.

Cobalt Group.name: Scheduled Task
Cobalt Group.description: [Cobalt Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0080) has created Windows tasks to establish persistence.

Cobalt Group.name: User Execution
Cobalt Group.description: [Cobalt Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0080) has sent emails containing malicious attachments or links that require users to execute a file or macro to infect the victim machine.

Cobalt Group.name: Spearphishing Link
Cobalt Group.description: [Cobalt Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0080) has sent emails with URLs pointing to malicious documents.

Cobalt Group.name: Network Service Scanning
Cobalt Group.description: [Cobalt Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0080) leveraged an open-source tool called SoftPerfect Network Scanner to perform network scanning.

Cobalt Group.name: New Service
Cobalt Group.description: [Cobalt Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0080) has created new services to establish persistence.

Cobalt Group.name: Remote File Copy
Cobalt Group.description: [Cobalt Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0080) has used public sites such as github.com and sendspace.com to upload files and then download them to victim computers. The group's JavaScript backdoor is also capable of downloading files.

Cobalt Group.name: Bypass User Account Control
Cobalt Group.description: [Cobalt Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0080) has bypassed UAC.

Cobalt Group.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Cobalt Group.description: [Cobalt Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0080) obfuscated several scriptlets and code used on the victim’s machine, including through use of XOR and RC4.

Cobalt Group.name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
Cobalt Group.description: [Cobalt Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0080) has used exploits to increase their levels of rights and privileges.

Cobalt Group.name: Spearphishing Attachment
Cobalt Group.description: [Cobalt Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0080) has sent spearphishing emails with various attachment types to corporate and personal email accounts of victim organizations. Attachment types have included .rtf, .doc, .xls, archives containing LNK files, and password protected archives containing .exe and .scr executables.

Cobalt Group.name: Process Injection
Cobalt Group.description: [Cobalt Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0080) has injected code into trusted processes.

Cobalt Group.name: Regsvr32
Cobalt Group.description: [Cobalt Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0080) has used regsvr32.exe to execute scripts.

Cobalt Group.name: File Deletion
Cobalt Group.description: [Cobalt Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0080) deleted the DLL dropper from the victim’s machine to cover their tracks.

Cobalt Group.name: Dynamic Data Exchange
Cobalt Group.description: [Cobalt Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0080) has sent malicious Word OLE compound documents to victims.

Cobalt Group.name: Remote Access Tools
Cobalt Group.description: [Cobalt Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0080) used the Ammyy Admin tool as well as TeamViewer for remote access.

Cobalt Group.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Cobalt Group.description: [Cobalt Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0080) has used Registry Run keys for persistence. The group has also set a Startup path to launch the PowerShell shell command and download Cobalt Strike.

Cobalt Group.name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Cobalt Group.description: [Cobalt Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0080) had exploited multiple vulnerabilities for execution, including Microsoft’s Equation Editor (CVE-2017-11882), an Internet Explorer vulnerability (CVE-2018-8174), CVE-2017-8570, CVE-2017-0199, and CVE-2017-8759.

Cobalt Group.name: Logon Scripts
Cobalt Group.description: [Cobalt Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0080) has added persistence by registering the file name for the next stage malware under UserInitMprLogonScript.

Cobalt Group.name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Cobalt Group.description: [Cobalt Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0080) has used the Plink utility to create SSH tunnels.

Cobalt Group.name: Security Software Discovery
Cobalt Group.description: [Cobalt Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0080) used a JavaScript backdoor that is capable of collecting a list of the security solutions installed on the victim's machine.

Cobalt Group.name: Scripting
Cobalt Group.description: [Cobalt Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0080) has sent Word OLE compound documents with malicious obfuscated VBA macros that will run upon user execution and executed JavaScript scriptlets on the victim's machine. The group has also used an exploit toolkit known as Threadkit that launches .bat files.

Cobalt Group.name: XSL Script Processing
Cobalt Group.description: [Cobalt Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0080) used msxsl.exe to bypass AppLocker and to invoke Jscript code from an XSL file.

Cobalt Group.name: PowerShell
Cobalt Group.description: [Cobalt Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0080) has used powershell.exe to download and execute scripts.

Cobalt Group.name: Command-Line Interface
Cobalt Group.description: [Cobalt Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0080) has used a JavaScript backdoor that is capable of launching cmd.exe to execute shell commands.

Cobalt Group.name: Signed Binary Proxy Execution
Cobalt Group.description: [Cobalt Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0080) has used odbcconf to proxy the execution of malicious DLL files.

PittyTiger.name: Valid Accounts
PittyTiger.description: [PittyTiger](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0011) attempts to obtain legitimate credentials during operations.

Stealth Falcon.name: Data from Local System
Stealth Falcon.description: [Stealth Falcon](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0038) malware gathers data from the local victim system.

Stealth Falcon.name: Scripting
Stealth Falcon.description: [Stealth Falcon](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0038) malware uses PowerShell and WMI to script data collection and command execution on the victim.

Stealth Falcon.name: System Owner/User Discovery
Stealth Falcon.description: [Stealth Falcon](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0038) malware gathers the registered user and primary owner name via WMI.

Stealth Falcon.name: System Information Discovery
Stealth Falcon.description: [Stealth Falcon](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0038) malware gathers system information via WMI, including the system directory, build number, serial number, version, manufacturer, model, and total physical memory.

Stealth Falcon.name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
Stealth Falcon.description: After data is collected by [Stealth Falcon](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0038) malware, it is exfiltrated over the existing C2 channel.

Stealth Falcon.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Stealth Falcon.description: [Stealth Falcon](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0038) malware communicates with its C2 server via HTTPS.

Stealth Falcon.name: Credential Dumping
Stealth Falcon.description: [Stealth Falcon](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0038) malware gathers passwords from multiple sources, including Windows Credential Vault, Internet Explorer, Firefox, Chrome, and Outlook.

Stealth Falcon.name: PowerShell
Stealth Falcon.description: [Stealth Falcon](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0038) malware uses PowerShell commands to perform various functions, including gathering system information via WMI and executing commands from its C2 server.

Stealth Falcon.name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Stealth Falcon.description: [Stealth Falcon](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0038) malware encrypts C2 traffic using RC4 with a hard-coded key.

Stealth Falcon.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
Stealth Falcon.description: [Stealth Falcon](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0038) malware gathers system information via Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI).

Stealth Falcon.name: Scheduled Task
Stealth Falcon.description: [Stealth Falcon](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0038) malware creates a scheduled task entitled “IE Web Cache” to execute a malicious file hourly.

Stealth Falcon.name: Process Discovery
Stealth Falcon.description: [Stealth Falcon](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0038) malware gathers a list of running processes.

Stealth Falcon.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Stealth Falcon.description: [Stealth Falcon](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0038) malware gathers the Address Resolution Protocol (ARP) table from the victim.

Stealth Falcon.name: Query Registry
Stealth Falcon.description: [Stealth Falcon](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0038) malware attempts to determine the installed version of .NET by querying the Registry.

FIN8.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
FIN8.description: [FIN8](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0061) has used environment variables and standard input (stdin) to obfuscate command-line arguments. [FIN8](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0061) also obfuscates malicious macros delivered as payloads.

FIN8.name: Spearphishing Attachment
FIN8.description: [FIN8](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0061) has distributed targeted emails containing Word documents with embedded malicious macros.

FIN8.name: Commonly Used Port
FIN8.description: [FIN8](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0061) has tunneled RDP backdoors over port 443.

FIN8.name: Valid Accounts
FIN8.description: [FIN8](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0061) has utilized [Valid Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1078) during and.

FIN8.name: Data Compressed
FIN8.description: [FIN8](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0061) has used RAR to compress collected data before.

FIN8.name: Remote File Copy
FIN8.description: [FIN8](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0061) has used remote code execution to download subsequent payloads.

FIN8.name: User Execution
FIN8.description: [FIN8](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0061) has leveraged both Spearphishing Link and Spearphishing Attachment attempting to gain User Execution.

FIN8.name: Scripting
FIN8.description: [FIN8](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0061) has used a Batch file to automate frequently executed post compromise cleanup activities.

FIN8.name: Remote Desktop Protocol
FIN8.description: [FIN8](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0061) has used RDP for.

FIN8.name: Command-Line Interface
FIN8.description: [FIN8](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0061) executes commands remotely via cmd.exe.

FIN8.name: File Deletion
FIN8.description: [FIN8](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0061) has deleted tmp and prefetch files during post compromise cleanup activities.

FIN8.name: Indicator Removal on Host
FIN8.description: [FIN8](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0061) has cleared logs during post compromise cleanup activities.

FIN8.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
FIN8.description: [FIN8](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0061)'s malicious spearphishing payloads use WMI to launch malware and spawn cmd.exe execution. [FIN8](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0061) has also used WMIC during and post compromise cleanup activities.

FIN8.name: Credential Dumping
FIN8.description: [FIN8](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0061) harvests credentials using Invoke-Mimikatz or Windows Credentials Editor (WCE).

FIN8.name: Remote System Discovery
FIN8.description: [FIN8](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0061) uses [dsquery](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0105) and other Active Directory utilities to enumerate hosts.

FIN8.name: Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol
FIN8.description: [FIN8](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0061) has used FTP to exfiltrate collected data.

FIN8.name: Scheduled Task
FIN8.description: [FIN8](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0061) has used scheduled tasks to maintain RDP backdoors.

FIN8.name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
FIN8.description: [FIN8](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0061) has used the Plink utility to tunnel RDP back to C2 infrastructure.

FIN8.name: Windows Admin Shares
FIN8.description: [FIN8](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0061) has attempted to map to C$ on enumerated hosts to test the scope of their current credentials/context.

FIN8.name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
FIN8.description: [FIN8](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0061) has exploited the CVE-2016-0167 local vulnerability.

FIN8.name: PowerShell
FIN8.description: [FIN8](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0061)'s malicious spearphishing payloads are executed as [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1086). [FIN8](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0061) has also used [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1086) during and.

FIN8.name: Data Staged
FIN8.description: [FIN8](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0061) aggregates staged data from a network into a single location.

FIN8.name: Security Software Discovery
FIN8.description: [FIN8](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0061) has used Registry keys to detect and avoid executing in potential sandboxes.

FIN8.name: Modify Registry
FIN8.description: [FIN8](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0061) has deleted Registry keys during post compromise cleanup activities.

FIN8.name: Spearphishing Link
FIN8.description: [FIN8](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0061) has distributed targeted emails containing links to malicious documents with embedded macros.

description.name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel

Deep Panda.name: Regsvr32
Deep Panda.description: [Deep Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0009) has used regsvr32.exe to execute a server variant of [Derusbi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0021) in victim networks.

Deep Panda.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
Deep Panda.description: The [Deep Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0009) group is known to utilize WMI for lateral movement.

Deep Panda.name: Indicator Removal from Tools
Deep Panda.description: [Deep Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0009) has updated and modified its malware, resulting in different hash values that evade detection.

Deep Panda.name: Windows Admin Shares
Deep Panda.description: [Deep Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0009) uses net.exe to connect to network shares using net use commands with compromised credentials.

Deep Panda.name: Remote System Discovery
Deep Panda.description: [Deep Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0009) has used ping to identify other machines of interest.

Deep Panda.name: Scripting
Deep Panda.description: [Deep Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0009) has used PowerShell scripts to download and execute programs in memory, without writing to disk.

Deep Panda.name: Process Discovery
Deep Panda.description: [Deep Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0009) uses the Microsoft [Tasklist](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0057) utility to list processes running on systems.

Deep Panda.name: Accessibility Features
Deep Panda.description: [Deep Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0009) has used the sticky-keys technique to bypass the RDP login screen on remote systems during intrusions.

Deep Panda.name: PowerShell
Deep Panda.description: [Deep Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0009) has used PowerShell scripts to download and execute programs in memory, without writing to disk.

Deep Panda.name: Web Shell
Deep Panda.description: [Deep Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0009) uses Web shells on publicly accessible Web servers to access victim networks.

Poseidon Group.name: System Network Connections Discovery
Poseidon Group.description: [Poseidon Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0033) obtains and saves information about victim network interfaces and addresses.

Poseidon Group.name: Masquerading
Poseidon Group.description: [Poseidon Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0033) tools attempt to spoof anti-virus processes as a means of self-defense.

Poseidon Group.name: PowerShell
Poseidon Group.description: The [Poseidon Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0033)'s Information Gathering Tool (IGT) includes PowerShell components.

Poseidon Group.name: System Service Discovery
Poseidon Group.description: After compromising a victim, [Poseidon Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0033) discovers all running services.

Poseidon Group.name: Process Discovery
Poseidon Group.description: After compromising a victim, [Poseidon Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0033) lists all running processes.

Poseidon Group.name: Credential Dumping
Poseidon Group.description: [Poseidon Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0033) conducts credential dumping on victims, with a focus on obtaining credentials belonging to domain and database servers.

Poseidon Group.name: Account Discovery
Poseidon Group.description: [Poseidon Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0033) searches for administrator accounts on both the local victim machine and the network.

Honeybee.name: Bypass User Account Control
Honeybee.description: [Honeybee](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0072) uses a combination of NTWDBLIB.dll and cliconfg.exe to bypass UAC protections using DLL hijacking.

Honeybee.name: AppCert DLLs
Honeybee.description: [Honeybee](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0072)'s service-based DLL implant can execute a downloaded file with parameters specified using CreateProcessAsUser.

Honeybee.name: File Deletion
Honeybee.description: [Honeybee](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0072) removes batch files to reduce fingerprint on the system as well as deletes the CAB file that gets encoded upon infection.

Honeybee.name: Data Compressed
Honeybee.description: [Honeybee](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0072) adds collected files to a temp.zip file saved in the %temp% folder, then base64 encodes it and uploads it to control server.

Honeybee.name: Process Discovery
Honeybee.description: [Honeybee](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0072) gathers a list of processes using the tasklist command and then is sent back to the control server.

Honeybee.name: System Information Discovery
Honeybee.description: [Honeybee](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0072) gathers computer name and information using the systeminfo command.

Honeybee.name: Modify Existing Service
Honeybee.description: [Honeybee](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0072) has batch files that modify the system service COMSysApp to load a malicious DLL.

Honeybee.name: Data Staged
Honeybee.description: [Honeybee](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0072) adds collected files to a temp.zip file saved in the %temp% folder, then base64 encodes it and uploads it to control server.

Honeybee.name: File and Directory Discovery
Honeybee.description: [Honeybee](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0072)'s service-based DLL implant traverses the FTP server’s directories looking for files with keyword matches for computer names or certain keywords.

Honeybee.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Honeybee.description: [Honeybee](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0072) drops a Word file containing a Base64-encoded file in it that is read, decoded, and dropped to the disk by the macro.

Honeybee.name: Data Encrypted
Honeybee.description: [Honeybee](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0072) adds collected files to a temp.zip file saved in the %temp% folder, then base64 encodes it and uploads it to control server.

Honeybee.name: Scripting
Honeybee.description: [Honeybee](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0072) embeds a Visual Basic script within a malicious Word document as part of initial access; the script is executed when the Word document is opened. The actors also used batch scripting.

Honeybee.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Honeybee.description: [Honeybee](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0072) drops files with base64-encoded data.

Honeybee.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Honeybee.description: [Honeybee](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0072) uses a batch file that configures the ComSysApp service to autostart in order to establish persistence.

Honeybee.name: Modify Registry
Honeybee.description: [Honeybee](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0072) uses a batch file that modifies Registry keys to launch a DLL into the svchost.exe process.

Honeybee.name: Process Injection
Honeybee.description: [Honeybee](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0072) uses a batch file to load a DLL into the svchost.exe process.

Honeybee.name: Data from Local System
Honeybee.description: [Honeybee](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0072) collects data from the local victim system.

Honeybee.name: Code Signing
Honeybee.description: [Honeybee](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0072) uses a dropper called MaoCheng that harvests a stolen digital signature from Adobe Systems.

Honeybee.name: Service Execution
Honeybee.description: [Honeybee](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0072) launches a DLL file that gets executed as a service using svchost.exe

Honeybee.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Honeybee.description: [Honeybee](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0072) uses FTP for command and control.

Honeybee.name: Automated Exfiltration
Honeybee.description: [Honeybee](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0072) performs data exfiltration is accomplished through the following command-line command: from (- --).txt.

Honeybee.name: Command-Line Interface
Honeybee.description: Several commands are supported by the [Honeybee](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0072)'s implant via the command-line interface and there’s also a utility to execute any custom command on an infected endpoint.

Elderwood.name: Software Packing
Elderwood.description: [Elderwood](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0066) has packed malware payloads before delivery to victims.

Elderwood.name: Supply Chain Compromise
Elderwood.description: [Elderwood](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0066) has targeted manufacturers in the supply chain for the defense industry.

Elderwood.name: Drive-by Compromise
Elderwood.description: [Elderwood](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0066) has delivered zero-day exploits and malware to victims by injecting malicious code into specific public Web pages visited by targets within a particular sector.

Elderwood.name: Spearphishing Link
Elderwood.description: [Elderwood](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0066) has delivered zero-day exploits and malware to victims via targeted emails containing a link to malicious content hosted on an uncommon Web server.

Elderwood.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Elderwood.description: [Elderwood](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0066) has encrypted documents and malicious executables.

Elderwood.name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Elderwood.description: [Elderwood](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0066) has used exploitation of endpoint software, including Microsoft Internet Explorer Adobe Flash vulnerabilities, to gain execution. They have also used zero-day exploits.

Elderwood.name: Spearphishing Attachment
Elderwood.description: [Elderwood](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0066) has delivered zero-day exploits and malware to victims via targeted emails containing malicious attachments.

Elderwood.name: User Execution
Elderwood.description: [Elderwood](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0066) has leveraged multiple types of spearphishing in order to attempt to get a user to open links and attachments.

Elderwood.name: Remote File Copy
Elderwood.description: The Ritsol backdoor trojan used by [Elderwood](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0066) can download files onto a compromised host from a remote location.

CopyKittens.name: Rundll32
CopyKittens.description: [CopyKittens](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0052) uses rundll32 to load various tools on victims, including a lateral movement tool named Vminst, Cobalt Strike, and shellcode.

CopyKittens.name: Data Compressed
CopyKittens.description: [CopyKittens](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0052) uses ZPP, a .NET console program, to compress files with ZIP.

CopyKittens.name: Data Encrypted
CopyKittens.description: [CopyKittens](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0052) encrypts data with a substitute cipher prior to exfiltration.

CopyKittens.name: Code Signing
CopyKittens.description: [CopyKittens](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0052) digitally signed an executable with a stolen certificate from legitimate company AI Squared.

description.name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel

APT18.name: External Remote Services
APT18.description: [APT18](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0026) actors leverage legitimate credentials to log into external remote services.

APT18.name: File and Directory Discovery
APT18.description: [APT18](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0026) can list files information for specific directories.

APT18.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
APT18.description: [APT18](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0026) uses HTTP and DNS for C2 communications.

APT18.name: Valid Accounts
APT18.description: [APT18](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0026) actors leverage legitimate credentials to log into external remote services.

APT18.name: Remote File Copy
APT18.description: [APT18](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0026) can upload a file to the victim’s machine.

APT18.name: Command-Line Interface
APT18.description: [APT18](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0026) uses cmd.exe to execute commands on the victim’s machine.

APT18.name: Scheduled Task
APT18.description: [APT18](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0026) actors used the native [at](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0110) Windows task scheduler tool to use scheduled tasks for execution on a victim network.

APT18.name: File Deletion
APT18.description: [APT18](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0026) actors deleted tools and batch files from victim systems.

APT18.name: System Information Discovery
APT18.description: [APT18](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0026) can collect system information from the victim’s machine.

description.name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel

Scarlet Mimic.name: Masquerading
Scarlet Mimic.description: [Scarlet Mimic](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0029) has used the left-to-right override character in self-extracting RAR archive spearphishing attachment file names.

APT32.name: Application Deployment Software
APT32.description: [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) compromised McAfee ePO to move laterally by distributing malware as a software deployment task.

APT32.name: Regsvr32
APT32.description: [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) created a [Scheduled Task](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1053) that used regsvr32.exe to execute a COM scriptlet that dynamically downloaded a backdoor and injected it into memory. The group has also used regsvr32 to run their backdoor.

APT32.name: System Owner/User Discovery
APT32.description: [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) collected the victim's username and executed the whoami command on the victim's machine.

APT32.name: Web Shell
APT32.description: [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) has used Web shells to maintain access to victim websites.

APT32.name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
APT32.description: [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) has used CVE-2016-7255 to escalate privileges.

APT32.name: PowerShell
APT32.description: [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) has used PowerShell-based tools, PowerShell one-liners, and shellcode loaders for execution.

APT32.name: Pass the Hash
APT32.description: [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) has used pass the hash for lateral movement.

APT32.name: Account Discovery
APT32.description: [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) enumerated administrative users and DC servers using the commands net localgroup administrators and net group "Domain Controllers" /domain.

APT32.name: Modify Existing Service
APT32.description: [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) modified Windows Services to ensure PowerShell scripts were loaded on the system.

APT32.name: NTFS File Attributes
APT32.description: [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) used NTFS alternate data stream to hide their payloads.

APT32.name: Remote System Discovery
APT32.description: [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) used the net view command to show all shares available, including the administrative shares such as C$ and ADMIN$. [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) also used the ping command.

APT32.name: Timestomp
APT32.description: [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) has used scheduled task raw XML with a backdated timestamp of June 2, 2016. The group has also set the creation time of the files dropped by the second stage of the exploit to match the creation time of kernel32.dll. Additionally, [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) has used a random value to modify the timestamp of the file storing the clientID.

APT32.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
APT32.description: [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) uses the Invoke-Obfuscation framework to obfuscate their PowerShell and also performs other code obfuscation. [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) has also encoded payloads using Base64 and a framework called "Dont-Kill-My-Cat (DKMC). [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) also encrypts the library used for network exfiltration with AES-256 in CBC mode in their macOS backdoor.

APT32.name: Indicator Removal on Host
APT32.description: [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) has cleared select event log entries.

APT32.name: Binary Padding
APT32.description: [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) includes garbage code to mislead anti-malware software and researchers.

APT32.name: Remote File Copy
APT32.description: [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) has added JavaScript to victim websites to download additional frameworks that profile and compromise website visitors.

APT32.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
APT32.description: [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) has used JavaScript that communicates over HTTP or HTTPS to attacker controlled domains to download additional frameworks. The group has also used email for C2 via an Office macro. The group's backdoor can also exfiltrate data by encoding it in the subdomain field of DNS packets.

APT32.name: Spearphishing Link
APT32.description: [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) has sent spearphishing emails containing malicious links.

APT32.name: System Network Connections Discovery
APT32.description: [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) used the netstat -anpo tcp command to display TCP connections on the victim's machine.

APT32.name: New Service
APT32.description: [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) creates a Windows service to establish persistence.

APT32.name: Scheduled Task
APT32.description: [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) has used scheduled tasks to persist on victim systems.

APT32.name: Drive-by Compromise
APT32.description: [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) has infected victims by tricking them into visiting compromised watering hole websites.

APT32.name: Commonly Used Port
APT32.description: [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) has used port 80 for C2 communications.

APT32.name: System Information Discovery
APT32.description: [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) has collected the OS version and computer name from victims. One of the group's backdoors can also query the Windows Registry to gather system information, and another macOS backdoor performs a fingerprint of the machine on its first connection to the C&C server.

APT32.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
APT32.description: [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) used WMI to deploy their tools on remote machines and to gather information about the Outlook process.

APT32.name: Credential Dumping
APT32.description: [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) used Mimikatz, GetPassword_x64, and  customized versions of Windows Credential Dumper, HookChangePassword, and Outlook Credential Dumper to harvest credentials.

APT32.name: Office Application Startup
APT32.description: [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) installed a backdoor macro in Microsoft Outlook for persistence.

APT32.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
APT32.description: [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) used the ipconfig /all command to gather the IP address from the system.

APT32.name: Spearphishing Attachment
APT32.description: [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) has sent spearphishing emails with a malicious executable disguised as a document or spreadsheet.

APT32.name: Signed Script Proxy Execution
APT32.description: [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) has used PubPrn.vbs within execution scripts to execute malware, possibly bypassing defenses.

APT32.name: User Execution
APT32.description: [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) has attempted to lure users to execute a malicious dropper delivered via a spearphishing attachment.

APT32.name: Valid Accounts
APT32.description: [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) has used legitimate local admin account credentials.

APT32.name: Masquerading
APT32.description: [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) has used hidden or non-printing characters to help masquerade file names on a system, such as appending a Unicode no-break space character to a legitimate service name. They have also used by moving and renaming pubprn.vbs to a .txt file to avoid detection. Additionally, the group has renamed a NetCat binary to kb-10233.exe to masquerade as a Windows update.

APT32.name: Scripting
APT32.description: [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) has used macros, PowerShell scripts, COM scriptlets, and VBS scripts.

APT32.name: Mshta
APT32.description: [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) has used mshta.exe for code execution.

APT32.name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
APT32.description: [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) uses [Cobalt Strike](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0154)'s malleable C2 functionality to blend in with network traffic. The group's backdoor can also exfiltrate data by encoding it in the subdomain field of DNS packets. Additionally, one of the group's macOS backdoors implements a specific format for the C2 packet involving random values.

APT32.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
APT32.description: [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) established persistence using Registry Run keys, both to execute PowerShell and VBS scripts as well as to execute their backdoor directly.

APT32.name: Pass the Ticket
APT32.description: [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) successfully gained remote access by using pass the ticket.

APT32.name: Network Service Scanning
APT32.description: [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) performed network scanning on the network to search for open ports, services, OS finger-printing, and other vulnerabilities.

APT32.name: Windows Admin Shares
APT32.description: [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) used [Net](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0039) to use Windows' hidden network shares to copy their tools to remote machines for execution.

APT32.name: DLL Side-Loading
APT32.description: [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) ran legitimately-signed executables from Symantec and McAfee which load a malicious DLL. The group also side-loads its backdoor by dropping a library and a legitimate, signed executable (AcroTranscoder).

APT32.name: Uncommonly Used Port
APT32.description: [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) backdoor can use HTTP over an uncommon TCP port (e.g 14146) which is specified in the backdoor configuration.

APT32.name: Exploitation for Client Execution
APT32.description: [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) has used RTF document that includes an exploit to execute malicious code. (CVE-2017-11882)

APT32.name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
APT32.description: [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050)'s backdoor has exfiltrated data using the already opened channel with its C&C server.

APT32.name: Data Encrypted
APT32.description: [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) backdoors have encrypted data before exfiltration, including by using RC4 encryption.

APT32.name: File and Directory Discovery
APT32.description: [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050)'s backdoor possesses the capability to list files and directories on a machine.

APT32.name: Query Registry
APT32.description: [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050)'s backdoor can query the Windows Registry to gather system information.

APT32.name: Data Compressed
APT32.description: [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050)'s backdoor has used LZMA compression before exfiltration.

APT32.name: Modify Registry
APT32.description: [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050)'s backdoor has modified the Windows Registry to store the backdoor's configuration.

APT32.name: Service Execution
APT32.description: [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050)'s backdoor has used Windows services as a way to execute its malicious payload.

APT32.name: Hidden Files and Directories
APT32.description: [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050)'s macOS backdoor hides the clientID file via a chflags function.

APT32.name: File Deletion
APT32.description: [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050)'s macOS backdoor can receive a “delete” command.

APT32.name: File Permissions Modification
