APT32.description: [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050)'s macOS backdoor changes the permission of the file it wants to execute to 755.

APT32.name: Software Packing
APT32.description: [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) uses UPX to pack their macOS backdoor.

APT32.name: Command-Line Interface
APT32.description: [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) has used cmd.exe for execution.

Orangeworm.name: Windows Admin Shares
Orangeworm.description: [Orangeworm](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0071) has copied its backdoor across open network shares, including ADMIN$, C$WINDOWS, D$WINDOWS, and E$WINDOWS.

Threat Group-3390.name: Remote System Discovery
Threat Group-3390.description: [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) has used the net view command.

Threat Group-3390.name: Account Discovery
Threat Group-3390.description: [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) has used net user to conduct internal discovery of systems.

Threat Group-3390.name: Remote File Copy
Threat Group-3390.description: After re-establishing access to a victim network, [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) actors download tools including [gsecdump](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0008) and WCE that are staged temporarily on websites that were previously compromised but never used.

Threat Group-3390.name: Data Encrypted
Threat Group-3390.description: [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) has used RAR to compress, encrypt, and password-protect files prior to exfiltration.

Threat Group-3390.name: Redundant Access
Threat Group-3390.description: [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) has deployed backup web shells and obtained OWA account credentials during intrusions that it subsequently used to attempt to regain access when evicted from a victim network.

Threat Group-3390.name: DLL Search Order Hijacking
Threat Group-3390.description: [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) has performed DLL search order hijacking to execute their payload.

Threat Group-3390.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Threat Group-3390.description: [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) malware has used HTTP for C2.

Threat Group-3390.name: PowerShell
Threat Group-3390.description: [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) has used PowerShell for execution.

Threat Group-3390.name: DLL Side-Loading
Threat Group-3390.description: [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) has used DLL side-loading, including by using legitimate Kaspersky antivirus variants in which the DLL acts as a stub loader that loads and executes the shell code.

Threat Group-3390.name: Process Injection
Threat Group-3390.description: A [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) tool can spawn svchost.exe and inject the payload into that process.

Threat Group-3390.name: System Network Connections Discovery
Threat Group-3390.description: [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) has used net use to conduct internal discovery of systems. The group has also used quser.exe to identify existing RDP sessions on a victim.

Threat Group-3390.name: External Remote Services
Threat Group-3390.description: [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) actors look for and use VPN profiles during an operation to access the network using external VPN services.

Threat Group-3390.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Threat Group-3390.description: A [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) tool can encrypt payloads using XOR. [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) malware is also obfuscated using Metasploit’s shikata_ga_nai encoder as well as compressed with LZNT1 compression.

Threat Group-3390.name: Bypass User Account Control
Threat Group-3390.description: A [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) tool can use a public UAC bypass method to elevate privileges.

Threat Group-3390.name: Windows Remote Management
Threat Group-3390.description: [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) has used WinRM to enable remote execution.

Threat Group-3390.name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
Threat Group-3390.description: [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) has used CVE-2014-6324 to escalate privileges.

Threat Group-3390.name: Data Transfer Size Limits
Threat Group-3390.description: [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) actors have split RAR files for exfiltration into parts.

Threat Group-3390.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
Threat Group-3390.description: A [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) tool can use WMI to execute a binary.

Threat Group-3390.name: Data Compressed
Threat Group-3390.description: [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) has used RAR to compress, encrypt, and password-protect files prior to exfiltration.

Threat Group-3390.name: File Deletion
Threat Group-3390.description: [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) has deleted existing logs and exfiltrated file archives from a victim.

Threat Group-3390.name: Credential Dumping
Threat Group-3390.description: [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) actors have used [gsecdump](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0008) and a modified version of [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002) called Wrapikatz to dump credentials. They have also dumped credentials from domain controllers.

Threat Group-3390.name: Network Share Connection Removal
Threat Group-3390.description: [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) has detached network shares after exfiltrating files, likely to evade detection.

Threat Group-3390.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Threat Group-3390.description: [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) actors use nbtscan to discover vulnerable systems.

Threat Group-3390.name: Commonly Used Port
Threat Group-3390.description: C2 traffic for most [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) tools occurs over Port Numbers 53, 80, and 443.

Threat Group-3390.name: Command-Line Interface
Threat Group-3390.description: [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) has used command-line interfaces for execution.

Threat Group-3390.name: Modify Registry
Threat Group-3390.description: A [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) tool can create a new Registry key under HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Classes\.

Threat Group-3390.name: Drive-by Compromise
Threat Group-3390.description: [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) has extensively used strategic web compromises to target victims.

Threat Group-3390.name: Valid Accounts
Threat Group-3390.description: [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) actors obtain legitimate credentials using a variety of methods and use them to further lateral movement on victim networks.

Threat Group-3390.name: Data from Local System
Threat Group-3390.description: [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) ran a command to compile an archive of file types of interest from the victim user's directories.

Threat Group-3390.name: Data Staged
Threat Group-3390.description: [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) has staged encrypted archives for exfiltration on Internet-facing servers that had previously been compromised with [China Chopper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0020).

Threat Group-3390.name: Input Capture
Threat Group-3390.description: [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) actors installed a credential logger on Microsoft Exchange servers. [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) also leveraged the reconnaissance framework, ScanBox, to capture keystrokes.

Threat Group-3390.name: Automated Collection
Threat Group-3390.description: [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) ran a command to compile an archive of file types of interest from the victim user's directories.

Threat Group-3390.name: Disabling Security Tools
Threat Group-3390.description: [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) has used appcmd.exe to disable logging on a victim server.

Threat Group-3390.name: Scheduled Task
Threat Group-3390.description: [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) actors use [at](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0110) to schedule tasks to run self-extracting RAR archives, which install [HTTPBrowser](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0070) or [PlugX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0013) on other victims on a network.

Threat Group-3390.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Threat Group-3390.description: A [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) tool can add the binary’s path to the Registry key Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run to add persistence.

Threat Group-3390.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Threat Group-3390.description: During execution, [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) malware deobfuscates and decompresses code that was encoded with Metasploit’s shikata_ga_nai encoder as well as compressed with LZNT1 compression.

Threat Group-3390.name: Query Registry
Threat Group-3390.description: A [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) tool can read and decrypt stored Registry values.

Threat Group-3390.name: New Service
Threat Group-3390.description: A [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) tool can create a new service, naming it after the config information, to gain persistence.

Threat Group-3390.name: Network Service Scanning
Threat Group-3390.description: [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) actors use the Hunter tool to conduct network service discovery for vulnerable systems.

Threat Group-3390.name: Web Shell
Threat Group-3390.description: [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) has used a variety of Web shells.

Threat Group-3390.name: Exploitation of Remote Services
Threat Group-3390.description: [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) has exploited MS17-101 to move laterally to other systems on the network.

Threat Group-3390.name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Threat Group-3390.description: [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) has exploited the Microsoft SharePoint vulnerability CVE-2019-0604.

FIN5.name: Redundant Access
FIN5.description: [FIN5](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0053) maintains access to victim environments by using [Valid Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1078) to access [External Remote Services](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1133) as well as establishing a backup RDP tunnel by using [FLIPSIDE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0173).

FIN5.name: File Deletion
FIN5.description: [FIN5](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0053) uses [SDelete](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0195) to clean up the environment and attempt to prevent detection.

FIN5.name: Remote System Discovery
FIN5.description: [FIN5](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0053) has used the open source tool Essential NetTools to map the network and build a list of targets.

FIN5.name: Indicator Removal on Host
FIN5.description: [FIN5](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0053) has cleared event logs from victims.

FIN5.name: Valid Accounts
FIN5.description: [FIN5](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0053) has used legitimate VPN, RDP, Citrix, or VNC credentials to maintain access to a victim environment.

FIN5.name: Credential Dumping
FIN5.description: [FIN5](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0053) has dumped credentials from victims. Specifically, the group has used the tool GET5 Penetrator to look for remote login and hard-coded credentials.

FIN5.name: Data Staged
FIN5.description: [FIN5](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0053) scripts save memory dump data into a specific directory on hosts in the victim environment.

FIN5.name: Scripting
FIN5.description: [FIN5](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0053) scans processes on all victim systems in the environment and uses automated scripts to pull back the results.

FIN5.name: External Remote Services
FIN5.description: [FIN5](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0053) has used legitimate VPN, Citrix, or VNC credentials to maintain access to a victim environment.

FIN5.name: Automated Collection
FIN5.description: [FIN5](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0053) scans processes on all victim systems in the environment and uses automated scripts to pull back the results.

Magic Hound.name: Commonly Used Port
Magic Hound.description: [Magic Hound](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0059) malware has communicated with C2 servers over port 6667 (for IRC) and port 8080.

Magic Hound.name: File and Directory Discovery
Magic Hound.description: [Magic Hound](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0059) malware can list a victim's logical drives and the type, as well the total/free space of the fixed devices. Other malware can list a directory's contents.

Magic Hound.name: Remote File Copy
Magic Hound.description: [Magic Hound](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0059) has downloaded additional code and files from servers onto victims.

Magic Hound.name: Scripting
Magic Hound.description: [Magic Hound](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0059) malware has used .vbs scripts for execution.

Magic Hound.name: Email Collection
Magic Hound.description: [Magic Hound](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0059) has collected .PST archives.

Magic Hound.name: Command-Line Interface
Magic Hound.description: [Magic Hound](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0059) has used the command-line interface.

Magic Hound.name: System Owner/User Discovery
Magic Hound.description: [Magic Hound](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0059) malware has obtained the victim username and sent it to the C2 server.

Magic Hound.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Magic Hound.description: [Magic Hound](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0059) malware gathers the victim's local IP address, MAC address, and external IP address.

Magic Hound.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Magic Hound.description: [Magic Hound](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0059) malware has used base64-encoded commands and files, and has also encrypted embedded strings with AES.

Magic Hound.name: Spearphishing Attachment
Magic Hound.description: [Magic Hound](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0059) sent malicious attachments to victims over email, including an Excel spreadsheet containing macros to download Pupy.

Magic Hound.name: System Information Discovery
Magic Hound.description: [Magic Hound](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0059) malware has used a PowerShell command to check the victim system architecture to determine if it is an x64 machine. Other malware has obtained the OS version, UUID, and computer/host name to send to the C2 server.

Magic Hound.name: Uncommonly Used Port
Magic Hound.description: [Magic Hound](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0059) malware has communicated with its C2 server over ports 4443 and 3543.

Magic Hound.name: Data Compressed
Magic Hound.description: [Magic Hound](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0059) has used RAR to stage and compress local folders.

Magic Hound.name: Spearphishing via Service
Magic Hound.description: [Magic Hound](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0059) used various social media channels to spearphish victims.

Magic Hound.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Magic Hound.description: [Magic Hound](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0059) malware has used Registry Run keys to establish persistence.

Magic Hound.name: PowerShell
Magic Hound.description: [Magic Hound](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0059) has used PowerShell for execution and privilege escalation.

Magic Hound.name: File Deletion
Magic Hound.description: [Magic Hound](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0059) has deleted and overwrote files to cover tracks.

Magic Hound.name: User Execution
Magic Hound.description: [Magic Hound](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0059) has attempted to get users to execute malware via social media and spearphishing emails.

description.name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel

Magic Hound.name: Process Discovery
Magic Hound.description: [Magic Hound](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0059) malware can list running processes.

Magic Hound.name: Spearphishing Link
Magic Hound.description: [Magic Hound](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0059) sent shortened URL links over email to victims. The URLs linked to Word documents with malicious macros that execute PowerShells scripts to download Pupy.

Magic Hound.name: Web Service
Magic Hound.description: [Magic Hound](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0059) malware can use a SOAP Web service to communicate with its C2 server.

Magic Hound.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Magic Hound.description: [Magic Hound](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0059) malware has used HTTP and IRC for C2.

Magic Hound.name: Input Capture
Magic Hound.description: [Magic Hound](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0059) malware is capable of keylogging.

Magic Hound.name: Credential Dumping
Magic Hound.description: [Magic Hound](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0059) stole domain credentials from Microsoft Active Directory Domain Controller and leveraged [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002).

Magic Hound.name: Screen Capture
Magic Hound.description: [Magic Hound](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0059) malware can take a screenshot and upload the file to its C2 server.

DarkHydrus.name: Forced Authentication
DarkHydrus.description: [DarkHydrus](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0079) used [Template Injection](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1221) to launch an authentication window for users to enter their credentials.

DarkHydrus.name: Spearphishing Attachment
DarkHydrus.description: [DarkHydrus](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0079) has sent spearphishing emails with password-protected RAR archives containing malicious Excel Web Query files (.iqy). The group has also sent spearphishing emails that contained malicious Microsoft Office documents that use the “attachedTemplate” technique to load a template from a remote server.

DarkHydrus.name: Template Injection
DarkHydrus.description: [DarkHydrus](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0079) used an open-source tool, Phishery, to inject malicious remote template URLs into Microsoft Word documents and then sent them to victims to enable [Forced Authentication](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1187).

DarkHydrus.name: User Execution
DarkHydrus.description: [DarkHydrus](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0079) has sent malware that required users to hit the enable button in Microsoft Excel to allow an .iqy file to be downloaded.

DarkHydrus.name: PowerShell
DarkHydrus.description: [DarkHydrus](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0079) leveraged PowerShell to download and execute additional scripts for execution.

Dark Caracal.name: Scripting
Dark Caracal.description: [Dark Caracal](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0070) has used macros in Word documents that would download a second stage if executed.

Dark Caracal.name: User Execution
Dark Caracal.description: [Dark Caracal](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0070) makes their malware look like Flash Player, Office, or PDF documents in order to entice a user to click on it.

Dark Caracal.name: Spearphishing via Service
Dark Caracal.description: [Dark Caracal](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0070) spearphished victims via Facebook and Whatsapp.

Dark Caracal.name: Data from Local System
Dark Caracal.description: [Dark Caracal](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0070) collected complete contents of the 'Pictures' folder from compromised Windows systems.

Dark Caracal.name: File and Directory Discovery
Dark Caracal.description: [Dark Caracal](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0070) collected file listings of all default Windows directories.

Dark Caracal.name: Drive-by Compromise
Dark Caracal.description: [Dark Caracal](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0070) leveraged a watering hole to serve up malicious code.

Dark Caracal.name: Compiled HTML File
Dark Caracal.description: [Dark Caracal](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0070) leveraged a compiled HTML file that contained a command to download and run an executable.

Dark Caracal.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Dark Caracal.description: [Dark Caracal](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0070)'s version of [Bandook](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0234) adds a registry key to HKEY_USERS\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run for persistence.

Dark Caracal.name: Screen Capture
Dark Caracal.description: [Dark Caracal](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0070) took screen shots using their Windows malware.

Dark Caracal.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Dark Caracal.description: [Dark Caracal](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0070)'s version of [Bandook](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0234) communicates with their server over a TCP port using HTTP payloads Base64 encoded and suffixed with the string “&&&”.

Dark Caracal.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Dark Caracal.description: [Dark Caracal](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0070) has obfuscated strings in [Bandook](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0234) by base64 encoding, and then encrypting them.

MuddyWater.name: Masquerading
MuddyWater.description: [MuddyWater](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0069) has used filenames and Registry key names associated with Windows Defender. The group has also stored obfuscated JavaScript code in an image file named temp.jpg.

MuddyWater.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
MuddyWater.description: [MuddyWater](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0069) has added Registry Run key KCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\SystemTextEncoding to establish persistence.

MuddyWater.name: Spearphishing Attachment
MuddyWater.description: [MuddyWater](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0069) has compromised third parties and used compromised accounts to send spearphishing emails with targeted attachments to recipients.

MuddyWater.name: Scripting
MuddyWater.description: [MuddyWater](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0069) has used VBScript and JavaScript files to execute its [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) payload. [MuddyWater](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0069) has also used Microsoft scriptlets, macros, and PowerShell scripts.[

MuddyWater.name: Credential Dumping
MuddyWater.description: [MuddyWater](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0069) has performed credential dumping with [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002), [LaZagne](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0349), and other tools, including by dumping passwords saved in victim web browsers and email.

MuddyWater.name: System Owner/User Discovery
MuddyWater.description: [MuddyWater](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0069) has used malware that can collect the victim’s username.

MuddyWater.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
MuddyWater.description: [MuddyWater](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0069) has used malware that leveraged WMI for execution and querying host information.

MuddyWater.name: Screen Capture
MuddyWater.description: [MuddyWater](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0069) has used malware that can capture screenshots of the victim’s machine.

MuddyWater.name: Bypass User Account Control
MuddyWater.description: [MuddyWater](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0069) uses various techniques to bypass UAC.

MuddyWater.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
MuddyWater.description: [MuddyWater](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0069) decoded base64-encoded PowerShell commands using a VBS file.

MuddyWater.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
MuddyWater.description: [MuddyWater](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0069) has used Daniel Bohannon’s Invoke-Obfuscation framework. The group has also used other obfuscation methods, including Base64 obfuscation of VBScripts and PowerShell commands.

MuddyWater.name: Rundll32
MuddyWater.description: [MuddyWater](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0069) has used malware that leveraged rundll32.exe in a Registry Run key to execute a .dll.

MuddyWater.name: CMSTP
MuddyWater.description: [MuddyWater](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0069) has used CMSTP.exe and a malicious INF to execute its [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) payload.

MuddyWater.name: User Execution
MuddyWater.description: [MuddyWater](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0069) has attempted to get users to enable macros and launch malicious Microsoft Word documents delivered via spearphishing emails.

MuddyWater.name: Dynamic Data Exchange
MuddyWater.description: [MuddyWater](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0069) has used malware that can execute PowerShell scripts via DDE.

MuddyWater.name: Security Software Discovery
MuddyWater.description: [MuddyWater](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0069) has used malware to check running processes against a hard-coded list of security tools often used by malware researchers.

MuddyWater.name: Command-Line Interface
MuddyWater.description: [MuddyWater](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0069) has used a custom tool for creating reverse shells.

MuddyWater.name: Remote File Copy
MuddyWater.description: [MuddyWater](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0069) has used malware that can upload additional files to the victim’s machine.

MuddyWater.name: Connection Proxy
MuddyWater.description: [MuddyWater](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0069) has controlled [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) from behind a proxy network to obfuscate the C2 location.

MuddyWater.name: Process Discovery
MuddyWater.description: [MuddyWater](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0069) has used malware to obtain a list of running processes on the system.

MuddyWater.name: Data Compressed
MuddyWater.description: [MuddyWater](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0069) has used the native Windows cabinet creation tool, makecab.exe, likely to compress stolen data to be uploaded.

MuddyWater.name: Credentials in Files
MuddyWater.description: [MuddyWater](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0069) has run a tool that steals passwords saved in victim email.

MuddyWater.name: Distributed Component Object Model
MuddyWater.description: [MuddyWater](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0069) has used malware that has the capability to execute malware via COM and Outlook.

MuddyWater.name: Mshta
MuddyWater.description: [MuddyWater](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0069) has used mshta.exe to execute its [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) payload and to pass a PowerShell one-liner for execution.

MuddyWater.name: System Information Discovery
MuddyWater.description: [MuddyWater](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0069) has used malware that can collect the victim’s OS version and machine name.

MuddyWater.name: PowerShell
MuddyWater.description: [MuddyWater](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0069) has used PowerShell for execution.

MuddyWater.name: File and Directory Discovery
MuddyWater.description: [MuddyWater](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0069) has used malware that checked if the ProgramData folder had folders or files with the keywords "Kasper," "Panda," or "ESET."

MuddyWater.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
MuddyWater.description: [MuddyWater](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0069) has used malware to collect the victim’s IP address and domain name.

MuddyWater.name: Compile After Delivery
MuddyWater.description: [MuddyWater](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0069) has used the .NET csc.exe tool to compile executables from downloaded C# code.

MuddyWater.name: Multi-Stage Channels
MuddyWater.description: [MuddyWater](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0069) has used one C2 to obtain enumeration scripts and monitor web logs, but a different C2 to send data back.

GCMAN.name: Remote Services
GCMAN.description: [GCMAN](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0036) uses Putty and VNC for lateral movement.

APT12.name: User Execution
APT12.description: [APT12](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0005) has attempted to get victims to open malicious Microsoft Word and PDF attachment sent via spearphishing.

APT12.name: Exploitation for Client Execution
APT12.description: [APT12](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0005) has exploited multiple vulnerabilities for execution, including Microsoft Office vulnerabilities (CVE-2009-3129, CVE-2012-0158) and vulnerabilities in Adobe Reader and Flash (CVE-2009-4324, CVE-2009-0927, CVE-2011-0609, CVE-2011-0611).

APT12.name: Spearphishing Attachment
APT12.description: [APT12](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0005) has sent emails with malicious Microsoft Office documents and PDFs attached.

APT12.name: Web Service
APT12.description: [APT12](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0005) has used blogs and WordPress for C2 infrastructure.

Darkhotel.name: Replication Through Removable Media
Darkhotel.description: [Darkhotel](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0012)'s selective infector modifies executables stored on removable media as a method of spreading across computers.

Darkhotel.name: Code Signing
Darkhotel.description: [Darkhotel](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0012) has used code-signing certificates on its malware that are either forged due to weak keys or stolen. [Darkhotel](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0012) has also stolen certificates and signed backdoors and downloaders with them.

Darkhotel.name: Taint Shared Content
Darkhotel.description: [Darkhotel](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0012) used a virus that propagates by infecting executables stored on shared drives.

Darkhotel.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Darkhotel.description: [Darkhotel](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0012) has collected the IP address and network adapter information from the victim’s machine.

Darkhotel.name: User Execution
Darkhotel.description: [Darkhotel](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0012) sent spearphishing emails with malicious attachments that required users to click on an image in the document to drop the malware to disk.

Darkhotel.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Darkhotel.description: [Darkhotel](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0012) has obfuscated code used in an operation using RC4 and other methods.

Darkhotel.name: Drive-by Compromise
Darkhotel.description: [Darkhotel](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0012) used embedded iframes on hotel login portals to redirect selected victims to download malware.

Darkhotel.name: Scripting
Darkhotel.description: [Darkhotel](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0012) has dropped an mspaint.lnk shortcut to disk which launches a shell script that downloads and executes a file.

Darkhotel.name: Process Discovery
Darkhotel.description: [Darkhotel](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0012) has searched for anti-malware strings and anti-virus processes running on the system.

Darkhotel.name: Spearphishing Attachment
Darkhotel.description: [Darkhotel](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0012) has sent spearphishing emails with malicious RAR attachments.

Darkhotel.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Darkhotel.description: [Darkhotel](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0012) has decrypted strings and imports using RC4 during execution.

Darkhotel.name: Security Software Discovery
Darkhotel.description: [Darkhotel](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0012) has searched for anti-malware strings and anti-virus processes running on the system.

Darkhotel.name: System Information Discovery
Darkhotel.description: [Darkhotel](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0012) has collected the hostname, OS version, service pack version, and the processor architecture from the victim’s machine.

Darkhotel.name: Shortcut Modification
Darkhotel.description: [Darkhotel](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0012) has dropped an mspaint.lnk shortcut to disk which launches a shell script that downloads and executes a file.

Darkhotel.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Darkhotel.description: [Darkhotel](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0012) has been known to establish persistence by adding programs to the Run Registry key.

Axiom.name: Data Obfuscation
Axiom.description: The [Axiom](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0001) group has used other forms of obfuscation, include commingling legitimate traffic with communications traffic so that network streams appear legitimate. Some malware that has been used by [Axiom](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0001) also uses steganography to hide communication in PNG image files.

Axiom.name: Credential Dumping
Axiom.description: [Axiom](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0001) has been known to dump credentials.

Axiom.name: Exploit Public-Facing Application
Axiom.description: [Axiom](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0001) has been observed using SQL injection to gain access to systems.

Axiom.name: Accessibility Features
Axiom.description: [Axiom](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0001) actors have been known to use the Sticky Keys replacement within RDP sessions to obtain persistence.

Axiom.name: Remote Desktop Protocol
Axiom.description: The [Axiom](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0001) group is known to have used RDP during operations.

RTM.name: Web Service
RTM.description: [RTM](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0048) has used an RSS feed on Livejournal to update a list of encrypted C2 server names.

FIN6.name: Account Discovery
FIN6.description: [FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037) has used Metasploit’s [PsExec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0029) NTDSGRAB module to obtain a copy of the victim's Active Directory database.

FIN6.name: Remote System Discovery
FIN6.description: [FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037) used publicly available tools (including Microsoft's built-in SQL querying tool, osql.exe) to map the internal network and conduct reconnaissance against Active Directory, Structured Query Language (SQL) servers, and NetBIOS.

FIN6.name: Scheduled Task
FIN6.description: [FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037) has used scheduled tasks to establish persistence for various malware it uses, including downloaders known as HARDTACK and SHIPBREAD and PoS malware known as TRINITY.

FIN6.name: Data Encrypted
FIN6.description: TRINITY malware used by [FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037) encodes data gathered from the victim with a simple substitution cipher and single-byte XOR using the 0xAA key.

FIN6.name: Remote Desktop Protocol
FIN6.description: [FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037) used RDP to move laterally in victim networks.

FIN6.name: Automated Collection
FIN6.description: [FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037) has used a script to iterate through a list of compromised PoS systems, copy data to a log file, and remove the original data files.

FIN6.name: Data Compressed
FIN6.description: Following data collection, [FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037) has compressed log files into a ZIP archive prior to staging and exfiltration.

FIN6.name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
FIN6.description: [FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037) has used tools to exploit Windows vulnerabilities in order to escalate privileges. The tools targeted CVE-2013-3660, CVE-2011-2005, and CVE-2010-4398, all of which could allow local users to access kernel-level privileges.

FIN6.name: PowerShell
FIN6.description: [FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037) has used a Metasploit PowerShell module to download and execute shellcode and to set up a local listener.

FIN6.name: Network Service Scanning
FIN6.description: [FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037) used publicly available tools (including Microsoft's built-in SQL querying tool, osql.exe) to map the internal network and conduct reconnaissance against Active Directory, Structured Query Language (SQL) servers, and NetBIOS.

FIN6.name: Scripting
FIN6.description: [FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037) has used a Metasploit PowerShell module to download and execute shellcode and to set up a local listener. [FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037) has also used scripting to iterate through a list of compromised PoS systems, copy data to a log file, and remove the original data files.

FIN6.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
FIN6.description: [FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037) has used Registry Run keys to establish persistence for its downloader tools known as HARDTACK and SHIPBREAD.

FIN6.name: Data Staged
FIN6.description: TRINITY malware used by [FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037) identifies payment card track data on the victim and then copies it to a local file in a subdirectory of C:\Windows\. Once the malware collects the data, [FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037) actors compressed data and moved it to another staging system before exfiltration.

FIN6.name: Valid Accounts
FIN6.description: To move laterally on a victim network, [FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037) has used credentials stolen from various systems on which it gathered usernames and password hashes.

FIN6.name: Credential Dumping
FIN6.description: [FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037) has used [Windows Credential Editor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0005) for credential dumping, as well as Metasploit’s [PsExec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0029) NTDSGRAB module to obtain a copy of the victim's Active Directory database.

FIN6.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
FIN6.description: [FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037) used the Plink command-line utility to create SSH tunnels to C2 servers.

FIN6.name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
FIN6.description: [FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037) used the Plink command-line utility to create SSH tunnels to C2 servers.

FIN6.name: Masquerading
FIN6.description: [FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037) has renamed the "psexec" service name to "mstdc" to masquerade as a legitimate Windows executable.

FIN6.name: Web Service
FIN6.description: [FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037) has used Pastebin to host content for the operation.

FIN6.name: Permission Groups Discovery
FIN6.description: [FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037) has used tools like Adfind to query users, groups, organizational units, and trusts.

FIN6.name: Service Execution
FIN6.description: [FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037) has created Windows services to execute encoded PowerShell commands.

Carbanak.name: Masquerading
Carbanak.description: [Carbanak](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0008) malware names itself "svchost.exe," which is the name of the Windows shared service host program.

Carbanak.name: Valid Accounts
Carbanak.description: [Carbanak](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0008) actors used legitimate credentials of banking employees to perform operations that sent them millions of dollars.

Carbanak.name: New Service
Carbanak.description: [Carbanak](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0008) malware installs itself as a service to provide persistence and SYSTEM privileges.

Carbanak.name: Web Service
Carbanak.description: [Carbanak](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0008) has used a VBScript named "ggldr" that uses Google Apps Script, Sheets, and Forms services for C2.

Carbanak.name: Rundll32
Carbanak.description: [Carbanak](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0008) installs VNC server software that executes through rundll32.

Carbanak.name: Disabling Security Tools
Carbanak.description: [Carbanak](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0008) may use [netsh](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0108) to add local firewall rule exceptions.

Carbanak.name: Remote Access Tools
Carbanak.description: [Carbanak](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0008) used legitimate programs such as AmmyAdmin and Team Viewer for remote interactive C2 to target systems.

Group5.name: Uncommonly Used Port
Group5.description: [Group5](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0043) C2 servers communicated with malware over TCP 8081, 8282, and 8083.

Group5.name: File Deletion
Group5.description: Malware used by [Group5](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0043) is capable of remotely deleting files from victims.

Group5.name: Screen Capture
Group5.description: Malware used by [Group5](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0043) is capable of watching the victim's screen.

Group5.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Group5.description: [Group5](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0043) disguised its malicious binaries with several layers of obfuscation, including encrypting the files.

Group5.name: Input Capture
Group5.description: Malware used by [Group5](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0043) is capable of capturing keystrokes.

Group5.name: Software Packing
Group5.description: [Group5](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0043) packed an executable by base64 encoding the PE file and breaking it up into numerous lines.

Rancor.name: Spearphishing Attachment
Rancor.description: [Rancor](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0075) has attached a malicious document to an email to gain initial access.

Rancor.name: Scheduled Task
Rancor.description: [Rancor](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0075) launched a scheduled task to gain persistence using the schtasks /create /sc command.

Rancor.name: Remote File Copy
Rancor.description: [Rancor](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0075) has downloaded additional malware, including by using [certutil](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0160).

Rancor.name: Command-Line Interface
Rancor.description: [Rancor](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0075) has used cmd.exe to execute commmands.

Rancor.name: Scripting
Rancor.description: [Rancor](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0075) has used shell and VBS scripts as well as embedded macros for execution.

Rancor.name: User Execution
Rancor.description: [Rancor](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0075) attempted to get users to click on an embedded macro within a Microsoft Office Excel document to launch their malware.

Rancor.name: Signed Binary Proxy Execution
Rancor.description: [Rancor](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0075) has used msiexec to download and execute malicious installer files over HTTP.

Dust Storm.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Dust Storm.description: [Dust Storm](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0031) has encoded payloads with a single-byte XOR, both skipping the key itself and zeroing in an attempt to avoid exposing the key.

Dust Storm.name: Data from Local System
Dust Storm.description: [Dust Storm](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0031) has used Android backdoors capable of exfiltrating specific files directly from the infected devices.

Dust Storm.name: File and Directory Discovery
Dust Storm.description: [Dust Storm](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0031) has used Android backdoors capable of enumerating specific files on the infected devices.

BlackOasis.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
BlackOasis.description: [BlackOasis](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0063)'s first stage shellcode contains a NOP sled with alternative instructions that was likely designed to bypass antivirus tools.

Molerats.name: Credential Dumping
Molerats.description: [Molerats](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0021) used the public tool BrowserPasswordDump10 to dump passwords saved in browsers on victims.

Molerats.name: Process Discovery
Molerats.description: [Molerats](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0021) actors obtained a list of active processes on the victim and sent them to C2 servers.

Molerats.name: Code Signing
Molerats.description: [Molerats](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0021) has used forged Microsoft code-signing certificates on malware.

Gamaredon Group.name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
Gamaredon Group.description: A [Gamaredon Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0047) file stealer transfers collected files to a hardcoded C2 server.

Gamaredon Group.name: System Information Discovery
Gamaredon Group.description: A [Gamaredon Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0047) file stealer can gather the victim's computer name and drive serial numbers to send to a C2 server.

Gamaredon Group.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Gamaredon Group.description: A [Gamaredon Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0047) file stealer can communicate over HTTP for C2.

Gamaredon Group.name: Peripheral Device Discovery
Gamaredon Group.description: [Gamaredon Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0047) tools contained an application to check performance of USB flash drives.

Gamaredon Group.name: Remote File Copy
Gamaredon Group.description: Tools used by [Gamaredon Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0047) are capable of downloading and executing additional payloads.

Gamaredon Group.name: System Owner/User Discovery
Gamaredon Group.description: A [Gamaredon Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0047) file stealer can gather the victim's username to send to a C2 server.

Gamaredon Group.name: Data from Removable Media
Gamaredon Group.description: A [Gamaredon Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0047) file stealer has the capability to steal data from newly connected logical volumes on a system, including USB drives.

Gamaredon Group.name: Scripting
Gamaredon Group.description: [Gamaredon Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0047) has used various batch scripts to establish C2, download additional files, and conduct other functions.

description.name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel

Turla.name: Brute Force
Turla.description: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) may attempt to connect to systems within a victim's network using net use commands and a predefined list or collection of passwords.

Turla.name: Spearphishing Link
Turla.description: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) attempted to trick targets into clicking on a link featuring a seemingly legitimate domain from Adobe.com to download their malware and gain initial access.

Turla.name: Query Registry
Turla.description: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) surveys a system upon check-in to discover information in the Windows Registry with the reg query command. [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has also retrieved PowerShell payloads hidden in Registry keys as well as checking keys associated with null session named pipes .

Turla.name: PowerShell
Turla.description: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has used PowerShell to execute commands/scripts, in some cases via a custom executable or code from [Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363)'s PSInject. [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has also used PowerShell scripts to load and execute malware in memory.

Turla.name: System Service Discovery
Turla.description: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) surveys a system upon check-in to discover running services and associated processes using the tasklist /svc command.

Turla.name: File and Directory Discovery
Turla.description: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) surveys a system upon check-in to discover files in specific locations on the hard disk %TEMP% directory, the current user's desktop, and in the Program Files directory. [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) RPC backdoors have also searched for files matching the lPH*.dll pattern.

Turla.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Turla.description: A [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) Javascript backdoor added a local_update_check value under the Registry key HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run to establish persistence. Additionally, a [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) custom executable containing Metasploit shellcode is saved to the Startup folder to gain persistence.

Turla.name: Web Service
Turla.description: A [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) JavaScript backdoor has used Google Apps Script as its C2 server.

Turla.name: Process Injection
Turla.description: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has used Metasploit to perform reflective DLL injection in order to escalate privileges. [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has also used [PowerSploit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0194)'s Invoke-ReflectivePEInjection.ps1 to reflectively load a PowerShell payload into a random process on the victim system.

Turla.name: User Execution
Turla.description: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has used spearphishing via a link to get users to download and run their malware.

Turla.name: Remote File Copy
Turla.description: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has used shellcode to download Meterpreter after compromising a victim. [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) RPC backdoors can also download files onto victim machines.

Turla.name: Remote System Discovery
Turla.description: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) surveys a system upon check-in to discover remote systems on a local network using the net view and net view /DOMAIN commands.

Turla.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Turla.description: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) surveys a system upon check-in to discover network configuration details using the arp -a, nbtstat -n, nbtscan, and net config commands. [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) RPC backdoors have also retrieved registered RPC interface information from process memory.

Turla.name: System Information Discovery
Turla.description: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) surveys a system upon check-in to discover operating system configuration details using the systeminfo and set commands.

Turla.name: Winlogon Helper DLL
Turla.description: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) established persistence by adding a Shell value under the Registry key HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion]Winlogon.

Turla.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Turla.description: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has used HTTP and HTTPS for C2 communications.

Turla.name: Indicator Removal from Tools
Turla.description: Based on comparison of [Gazer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0168) versions, [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) made an effort to obfuscate strings in the malware that could be used as IoCs, including the mutex name and named pipe.

Turla.name: Process Discovery
Turla.description: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) surveys a system upon check-in to discover running processes using the tasklist /v command. [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) RPC backdoors have also enumerated processes associated with specific open ports or named pipes.

Turla.name: System Network Connections Discovery
Turla.description: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) surveys a system upon check-in to discover active local network connections using the netstat -an, net use, net file, and net session commands. [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) RPC backdoors have also enumerated the IPv4 TCP connection table via the GetTcpTable2 API call.

Turla.name: Spearphishing Attachment
Turla.description: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has used spearphishing emails to deliver [BrainTest](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0293) as a malicious attachment.

Turla.name: Windows Admin Shares
Turla.description: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) used net use commands to connect to lateral systems within a network.

Turla.name: System Time Discovery
Turla.description: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) surveys a system upon check-in to discover the system time by using the net time command.

description.name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel

Turla.name: Modify Registry
Turla.description: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has used the Registry to store encrypted payloads.

Turla.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Turla.description: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has used encryption (including salted 3DES via [PowerSploit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0194)'s Out-EncryptedScript.ps1), random variable names, and base64 encoding to obfuscate PowerShell commands and payloads.

Turla.name: Windows Management Instrumentation Event Subscription
Turla.description: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has used WMI event filters and consumers to establish persistence.

Turla.name: Execution through API
Turla.description: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) and its RPC backdoors have used APIs calls for various tasks related to subverting AMSI and accessing then executing commands through RPC and/or named pipes.

Turla.name: Disabling Security Tools
Turla.description: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has used a AMSI bypass, which patches the in-memory amsi.dll, in PowerShell scripts to bypass Windows antimalware products.

Turla.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Turla.description: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has used a custom decryption routine, which pulls key and salt values from other artifacts such as a WMI filter or [PowerShell Profile](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1504), to decode encrypted PowerShell payloads.

Turla.name: Connection Proxy
Turla.description: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) RPC backdoors have included local UPnP RPC proxies.

Turla.name: Data from Removable Media
Turla.description: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) RPC backdoors can collect files from USB thumb drives.

Turla.name: Access Token Manipulation
Turla.description: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) RPC backdoors can impersonate or steal process tokens before executing commands.

Turla.name: Data from Local System
Turla.description: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) RPC backdoors can upload files from victim machines.

Turla.name: Command-Line Interface
Turla.description: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) RPC backdoors have used cmd.exe to execute commands.

description.name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel

Turla.name: Credentials in Files
Turla.description: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has gathered credentials from the Windows Credential Manager tool.

Turla.name: Scripting
Turla.description: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has used PowerShell and VBS scripts throughout its operations.

Turla.name: Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol
Turla.description: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has used WebDAV to upload stolen USB files to a cloud drive.

Turla.name: Data Encrypted
Turla.description: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has encrypted files stolen from connected USB drives into a RAR file before exfiltration.

admin@338.name: Account Discovery
admin@338.description: [admin@338](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0018) actors used the following commands following exploitation of a machine with [LOWBALL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0042) malware to enumerate user accounts: net user >> %temp%\download net user /domain >> %temp%\download

admin@338.name: Permission Groups Discovery
admin@338.description: [admin@338](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0018) actors used the following command following exploitation of a machine with [LOWBALL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0042) malware to list local groups: net localgroup administrator >> %temp%\download

admin@338.name: Command-Line Interface
admin@338.description: Following exploitation with [LOWBALL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0042) malware, [admin@338](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0018) actors created a file containing a list of commands to be executed on the compromised computer.

admin@338.name: System Information Discovery
admin@338.description: [admin@338](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0018) actors used the following commands after exploiting a machine with [LOWBALL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0042) malware to obtain information about the OS: ver >> %temp%\download systeminfo >> %temp%\download

admin@338.name: Masquerading
admin@338.description: [admin@338](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0018) actors used the following command to rename one of their tools to a benign file name: ren "%temp%\upload" audiodg.exe

admin@338.name: File and Directory Discovery
admin@338.description: [admin@338](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0018) actors used the following commands after exploiting a machine with [LOWBALL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0042) malware to obtain information about files and directories: dir c:\ >> %temp%\download dir "c:\Documents and Settings" >> %temp%\download dir "c:\Program Files\" >> %temp%\download dir d:\ >> %temp%\download

admin@338.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
admin@338.description: [admin@338](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0018) actors used the following command after exploiting a machine with [LOWBALL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0042) malware to acquire information about local networks: ipconfig /all >> %temp%\download

admin@338.name: System Network Connections Discovery
admin@338.description: [admin@338](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0018) actors used the following command following exploitation of a machine with [LOWBALL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0042) malware to display network connections: netstat -ano >> %temp%\download

admin@338.name: System Service Discovery
admin@338.description: [admin@338](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0018) actors used the following command following exploitation of a machine with [LOWBALL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0042) malware to obtain information about services: net start >> %temp%\download

Leafminer.name: Network Service Scanning
Leafminer.description: [Leafminer](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0077) scanned network services to search for vulnerabilities in the victim system.

Leafminer.name: Brute Force
Leafminer.description: [Leafminer](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0077) used a tool called BruteForcer to perform a brute force attack.

Leafminer.name: Credential Dumping
Leafminer.description: [Leafminer](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0077) used several tools for retrieving login and password information.

Leafminer.name: Create Account
Leafminer.description: [Leafminer](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0077) used a tool called Imecab to set up a persistent remote access account on the victim machine.

Leafminer.name: File and Directory Discovery
Leafminer.description: [Leafminer](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0077) used a tool called MailSniper to search for files on the desktop and another utility called Sobolsoft to extract attachments from EML files.

Leafminer.name: Drive-by Compromise
Leafminer.description: [Leafminer](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0077) has infected victims using watering holes.

Leafminer.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Leafminer.description: [Leafminer](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0077) obfuscated scripts that were used on victim machines.

Leafminer.name: Redundant Access
Leafminer.description: [Leafminer](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0077) used a tool called Imecab to set up a persistent remote access account on the victim machine.

Leafminer.name: Email Collection
Leafminer.description: [Leafminer](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0077) used a tool called MailSniper to search through the Exchange server mailboxes for keywords.

Leafminer.name: Remote System Discovery
Leafminer.description: [Leafminer](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0077) used Microsoft’s Sysinternals tools to gather detailed information about remote systems.

PLATINUM.name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
PLATINUM.description: [PLATINUM](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0068) has leveraged a zero-day vulnerability to escalate privileges.

PLATINUM.name: Standard Non-Application Layer Protocol
PLATINUM.description: [PLATINUM](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0068) has used the Intel® Active Management Technology (AMT) Serial-over-LAN (SOL) channel for command and control.

PLATINUM.name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
PLATINUM.description: [PLATINUM](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0068) has used the Intel® Active Management Technology (AMT) Serial-over-LAN (SOL) channel for command and control.

PLATINUM.name: Credential Dumping
PLATINUM.description: [PLATINUM](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0068) has used keyloggers that are also capable of dumping credentials.

PLATINUM.name: Remote File Copy
PLATINUM.description: [PLATINUM](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0068) has transferred files using the Intel® Active Management Technology (AMT) Serial-over-LAN (SOL) channel.

PLATINUM.name: Process Injection
PLATINUM.description: [PLATINUM](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0068) has used various methods of process injection including hot patching.

PLATINUM.name: Drive-by Compromise
PLATINUM.description: [PLATINUM](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0068) has sometimes used drive-by attacks against vulnerable browser plugins.

PLATINUM.name: Spearphishing Attachment
PLATINUM.description: [PLATINUM](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0068) has sent spearphishing emails with attachments to victims as its primary initial access vector.

PLATINUM.name: User Execution
PLATINUM.description: [PLATINUM](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0068) has attempted to get users to open malicious files by sending spearphishing emails with attachments to victims.

PLATINUM.name: Hooking
PLATINUM.description: [PLATINUM](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0068) is capable of using Windows hook interfaces for information gathering such as credential access.

PLATINUM.name: Masquerading
PLATINUM.description: [PLATINUM](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0068) has renamed rar.exe to avoid detection.

TA459.name: Spearphishing Attachment
TA459.description: [TA459](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0062) has targeted victims using spearphishing emails with malicious Microsoft Word attachments.

TA459.name: Exploitation for Client Execution
TA459.description: [TA459](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0062) has exploited Microsoft Word vulnerability CVE-2017-0199 for execution.

TA459.name: User Execution
TA459.description: [TA459](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0062) has attempted to get victims to open malicious Microsoft Word attachment sent via spearphishing.

TA459.name: PowerShell
TA459.description: [TA459](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0062) has used PowerShell for execution of a payload.

Suckfly.name: Network Service Scanning
Suckfly.description: [Suckfly](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0039) the victim's internal network for hosts with ports 8080, 5900, and 40 open.

Suckfly.name: Valid Accounts
Suckfly.description: [Suckfly](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0039) used legitimate account credentials that they dumped to navigate the internal victim network as though they were the legitimate account owner.

Suckfly.name: Command-Line Interface
Suckfly.description: Several tools used by [Suckfly](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0039) have been command-line driven.

Suckfly.name: Credential Dumping
Suckfly.description: [Suckfly](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0039) used a signed credential-dumping tool to obtain victim account credentials.

Suckfly.name: Code Signing
Suckfly.description: [Suckfly](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0039) has used stolen certificates to sign its malware.

Sowbug.name: File and Directory Discovery
Sowbug.description: [Sowbug](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0054) identified and extracted all Word documents on a server by using a command containing * .doc and *.docx. The actors also searched for documents based on a specific date range and attempted to identify all installed software on a victim.

Sowbug.name: Data Compressed
Sowbug.description: [Sowbug](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0054) extracted documents and bundled them into a RAR archive.

Sowbug.name: Network Share Discovery
Sowbug.description: [Sowbug](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0054) listed remote shared drives that were accessible from a victim.

Sowbug.name: Command-Line Interface
Sowbug.description: [Sowbug](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0054) has used command line during its intrusions.

Sowbug.name: Data from Network Shared Drive
Sowbug.description: [Sowbug](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0054) extracted Word documents from a file server on a victim network.

Sowbug.name: System Information Discovery
Sowbug.description: [Sowbug](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0054) obtained OS version and hardware configuration from a victim.

Sowbug.name: Masquerading
Sowbug.description: [Sowbug](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0054) named its tools to masquerade as Windows or Adobe Reader software, such as by using the file name adobecms.exe and the directory CSIDL_APPDATA\microsoft\security.

Thrip.name: Remote Access Tools
Thrip.description: [Thrip](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0076) used a cloud-based remote access software called LogMeIn for their attacks.

Thrip.name: PowerShell
Thrip.description: [Thrip](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0076) leveraged PowerShell to run commands to download payloads, traverse the compromised networks, and carry out reconnaissance.

Thrip.name: Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol
Thrip.description: [Thrip](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0076) has used WinSCP to exfiltrate data from a targeted organization over FTP.

Winnti Group.name: Rootkit
Winnti Group.description: [Winnti Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0044) used a rootkit to modify typical server functionality.

Winnti Group.name: Code Signing
Winnti Group.description: [Winnti Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0044) used stolen certificates to sign its malware.

Winnti Group.name: Process Discovery
Winnti Group.description: [Winnti Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0044) looked for a specific process running on infected servers.

FIN10.name: PowerShell
FIN10.description: [FIN10](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0051) uses PowerShell for execution as well as PowerShell Empire to establish persistence.

FIN10.name: Scripting
FIN10.description: [FIN10](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0051) has executed malicious .bat files containing PowerShell commands.

FIN10.name: File Deletion
FIN10.description: [FIN10](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0051) has used batch scripts and scheduled tasks to delete critical system files.

FIN10.name: System Owner/User Discovery
FIN10.description: [FIN10](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0051) has used Meterpreter to enumerate users on remote systems.

FIN10.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
FIN10.description: [FIN10](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0051) has established persistence by using the Registry option in PowerShell Empire to add a Run key.

FIN10.name: Scheduled Task
FIN10.description: [FIN10](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0051) has established persistence by using S4U tasks as well as the Scheduled Task option in PowerShell Empire.

FIN10.name: Valid Accounts
FIN10.description: [FIN10](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0051) has used stolen credentials to connect remotely to victim networks using VPNs protected with only a single factor. The group has also moved laterally using the Local Administrator account.

FIN10.name: Remote Desktop Protocol
FIN10.description: [FIN10](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0051) has used RDP to move laterally to systems in the victim environment.

FIN10.name: Remote File Copy
FIN10.description: [FIN10](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0051) has deployed Meterpreter stagers and SplinterRAT instances in the victim network after moving laterally.

description.name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel

Naikon.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Naikon.description: [Naikon](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0019) uses commands such as netsh interface show to discover network interface settings.

Naikon.name: Security Software Discovery
Naikon.description: [Naikon](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0019) uses commands such as netsh advfirewall firewall to discover local firewall settings.

Strider.name: Connection Proxy
Strider.description: [Strider](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0041) has used local servers with both local network and Internet access to act as internal proxy nodes to exfiltrate data from other parts of the network without direct Internet access.

Strider.name: Credential Dumping
Strider.description: [Strider](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0041) has registered its persistence module on domain controllers as a Windows LSA (Local System Authority) password filter to dump credentials any time a domain, local user, or administrator logs in or changes a password.

Tropic Trooper.name: Hidden Files and Directories
Tropic Trooper.description: [Tropic Trooper](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0081) has created a hidden directory under C:\ProgramData\Apple\Updates\.

Tropic Trooper.name: Commonly Used Port
Tropic Trooper.description: [Tropic Trooper](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0081) can use ports 443 and 53 for C2 communications via malware called TClient.

Tropic Trooper.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Tropic Trooper.description: [Tropic Trooper](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0081) used shellcode with an XOR algorithm to decrypt a payload.

Tropic Trooper.name: Process Injection
Tropic Trooper.description: [Tropic Trooper](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0081) has injected a DLL backdoor into a file dllhost.exe.

Tropic Trooper.name: Process Discovery
Tropic Trooper.description: [Tropic Trooper](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0081) enumerates the running processes on the system.

Tropic Trooper.name: Winlogon Helper DLL
Tropic Trooper.description: [Tropic Trooper](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0081) creates the Registry key HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon\Shell and sets the value to establish persistence.

Tropic Trooper.name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Tropic Trooper.description: [Tropic Trooper](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0081) has executed commands through Microsoft security vulnerabilities, including CVE-2017-11882, CVE-2018-0802, and CVE-2012-0158.

Tropic Trooper.name: Spearphishing Attachment
Tropic Trooper.description: [Tropic Trooper](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0081) sent spearphishing emails that contained malicious Microsoft Office attachments.

Tropic Trooper.name: Security Software Discovery
Tropic Trooper.description: [Tropic Trooper](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0081) searches for anti-virus software running on the system.

Tropic Trooper.name: BITS Jobs
Tropic Trooper.description: [Tropic Trooper](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0081) has leveraged the BITSadmin command-line tool to create a job and launch a malicious process.

Tropic Trooper.name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Tropic Trooper.description: [Tropic Trooper](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0081) uses SSL to connect to C2 servers.

Tropic Trooper.name: Template Injection
Tropic Trooper.description: [Tropic Trooper](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0081) delivered malicious documents with the XLSX extension, typically used by OpenXML documents, but the file itself was actually an OLE (XLS) document.

Tropic Trooper.name: DLL Side-Loading
Tropic Trooper.description: [Tropic Trooper](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0081) has been known to side-load DLLs using a valid version of Windows Address Book executable with one of their tools.

Tropic Trooper.name: Network Service Scanning
Tropic Trooper.description: [Tropic Trooper](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0081) used pr to scan for open ports on target systems.

Tropic Trooper.name: Network Share Discovery
Tropic Trooper.description: [Tropic Trooper](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0081) used netview to scan target systems for shared resources.

Tropic Trooper.name: System Information Discovery
Tropic Trooper.description: [Tropic Trooper](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0081) has detected a target system’s OS version.

Tropic Trooper.name: System Owner/User Discovery
Tropic Trooper.description: [Tropic Trooper](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0081) used letmein to scan for saved usernames on the target system.

Tropic Trooper.name: New Service
Tropic Trooper.description: [Tropic Trooper](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0081) installs a service pointing to a malicious DLL dropped to disk.

SilverTerrier.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
SilverTerrier.description: [SilverTerrier](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0083) uses SMTP, FTP, and HTTP for C2 communications.

FIN4.name: User Execution
FIN4.description: [FIN4](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0085) has lured victims to launch malicious attachments and click malicious links delivered via spearphishing emails (often sent from compromised accounts).

FIN4.name: Input Prompt
FIN4.description: [FIN4](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0085) has presented victims with spoofed Windows Authentication prompts to collect their credentials.

FIN4.name: Valid Accounts
FIN4.description: [FIN4](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0085) has used legitimate credentials to hijack email communications.

FIN4.name: Multi-hop Proxy
FIN4.description: [FIN4](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0085) has used Tor to log in to victims' email accounts.

FIN4.name: Email Collection
FIN4.description: [FIN4](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0085) has accessed and hijacked email communications using stolen credentials.

FIN4.name: Spearphishing Attachment
FIN4.description: [FIN4](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0085) has used spearphishing emails containing attachments (which are often stolen, legitimate documents sent from compromised accounts) with embedded malicious macros.

FIN4.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
FIN4.description: [FIN4](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0085) has used HTTP POST requests to transmit data.

FIN4.name: Spearphishing Link
FIN4.description: [FIN4](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0085) has used spearphishing emails (often sent from compromised accounts) containing malicious links.

FIN4.name: Input Capture
FIN4.description: [FIN4](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0085) has captured credentials via fake Outlook Web App (OWA) login pages and has also used a .NET based keylogger.

FIN4.name: Scripting
FIN4.description: [FIN4](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0085) has used VBA macros to display a dialog box and collect victim credentials.

FIN4.name: Stored Data Manipulation
FIN4.description: [FIN4](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0085) has created rules in victims' Microsoft Outlook accounts to automatically delete emails containing words such as “hacked," "phish," and “malware" in a likely attempt to prevent organizations from communicating about their activities.

APT38.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
APT38.description: [APT38](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0082) used a backdoor, QUICKRIDE, to communicate to the C2 server over HTTP and HTTPS.

APT38.name: Input Capture
APT38.description: [APT38](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0082) used a Trojan called KEYLIME to capture keystrokes from the victim’s machine.

APT38.name: Process Discovery
APT38.description: [APT38](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0082) leveraged Sysmon to understand the processes, services in the organization.

APT38.name: Modify Registry
APT38.description: [APT38](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0082) uses a tool called CLEANTOAD that has the capability to modify Registry keys.

APT38.name: Drive-by Compromise
APT38.description: [APT38](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0082) has conducted watering holes schemes to gain initial access to victims.

APT38.name: Clipboard Data
APT38.description: [APT38](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0082) used a Trojan called KEYLIME to collect data from the clipboard.

APT38.name: Software Packing
APT38.description: [APT38](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0082) has used several code packing methods such as Themida, Enigma, VMProtect, and Obsidium, to pack their implants.

APT38.name: Command-Line Interface
APT38.description: [APT38](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0082) has used a command-line tunneler, NACHOCHEESE, to give them shell access to a victim’s machine.

APT38.name: Remote File Copy
APT38.description: [APT38](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0082) used a backdoor, NESTEGG, that has the capability to download and upload files to and from a victim’s machine.

APT38.name: Port Monitors
APT38.description: [APT38](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0082) installed a port monitoring tool, MAPMAKER, to print the active TCP connections on the local system.

APT38.name: File Deletion
APT38.description: [APT38](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0082) has used a utility called CLOSESHAVE that can securely delete a file from the system.

APT38.name: Indicator Removal on Host
APT38.description: [APT38](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0082) clears Window Event logs and Sysmon logs from the system.

APT38.name: Runtime Data Manipulation
APT38.description: [APT38](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0082) has used DYEPACK.FOX to manipulate PDF data as it is accessed to remove traces of fraudulent SWIFT transactions from the data displayed to the end user.

APT38.name: Transmitted Data Manipulation
APT38.description: [APT38](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0082) has used DYEPACK to manipulate SWIFT messages en route to a printer.

APT38.name: Stored Data Manipulation
APT38.description: [APT38](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0082) has used DYEPACK to create, delete, and alter records in databases used for SWIFT transactions.

APT38.name: Disk Structure Wipe
APT38.description: [APT38](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0082) has used a custom MBR wiper named BOOTWRECK to render systems inoperable.

APT38.name: Data Encrypted for Impact
APT38.description: [APT38](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0082) has used Hermes ransomware to encrypt files with AES256.

APT38.name: Data Destruction
APT38.description: [APT38](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0082) has used a custom secure delete function to make deleted files unrecoverable.

Gallmaker.name: Spearphishing Attachment
Gallmaker.description: [Gallmaker](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0084) sent emails with malicious Microsoft Office documents attached.

Gallmaker.name: User Execution
Gallmaker.description: [Gallmaker](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0084) sent victims a lure document with a warning that asked victims to “enable content” for execution.

Gallmaker.name: Dynamic Data Exchange
Gallmaker.description: [Gallmaker](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0084) attempted to exploit Microsoft’s DDE protocol in order to gain access to victim machines and for execution.

Gallmaker.name: PowerShell
Gallmaker.description: [Gallmaker](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0084) used PowerShell to download additional payloads.

Gallmaker.name: Data Compressed
Gallmaker.description: [Gallmaker](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0084) has used WinZip, likely to archive data prior to exfiltration.

Putter Panda.name: Disabling Security Tools
Putter Panda.description: Malware used by [Putter Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0024) attempts to terminate processes corresponding to two components of Sophos Anti-Virus (SAVAdminService.exe and SavService.exe).

Putter Panda.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
