Putter Panda.description: A dropper used by [Putter Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0024) installs itself into the ASEP Registry key HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run with a value named McUpdate.

Putter Panda.name: Process Injection
Putter Panda.description: An executable dropped onto victims by [Putter Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0024) aims to inject the specified DLL into a process that would normally be accessing the network, including Outlook Express (msinm.exe), Outlook (outlook.exe), Internet Explorer (iexplore.exe), and Firefox (firefox.exe).

Putter Panda.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Putter Panda.description: Droppers used by [Putter Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0024) use RC4 or a 16-byte XOR key consisting of the bytes 0xA0 – 0xAF to obfuscate payloads.

Threat Group-1314.name: Command-Line Interface
Threat Group-1314.description: [Threat Group-1314](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0028) actors spawned shells on remote systems on a victim network to execute commands.

Threat Group-1314.name: Windows Admin Shares
Threat Group-1314.description: [Threat Group-1314](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0028) actors mapped network drives using net use.

Threat Group-1314.name: Valid Accounts
Threat Group-1314.description: [Threat Group-1314](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0028) actors used compromised credentials for the victim's endpoint management platform, Altiris, to move laterally.

Threat Group-1314.name: Third-party Software
Threat Group-1314.description: [Threat Group-1314](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0028) actors used a victim's endpoint management platform, Altiris, for lateral movement.

Equation.name: Component Firmware
Equation.description: [Equation](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0020) is known to have the capability to overwrite the firmware on hard drives from some manufacturers.

Equation.name: Execution Guardrails
Equation.description: [Equation](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0020) has been observed utilizing environmental keying in payload delivery.

Equation.name: Peripheral Device Discovery
Equation.description: [Equation](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0020) has used tools with the functionality to search for specific information about the attached hard drive that could be used to identify and overwrite the firmware.

Moafee.name: Binary Padding
Moafee.description: [Moafee](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0002) has been known to employ binary padding.

Taidoor.name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Taidoor.description: [Taidoor](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0015) uses RC4 to encrypt the message body of HTTP content.

Stolen Pencil.name: Network Sniffing
Stolen Pencil.description: [Stolen Pencil](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0086) has a tool to sniff the network for passwords.

Stolen Pencil.name: Valid Accounts
Stolen Pencil.description: [Stolen Pencil](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0086) has a tool to add a Windows admin account in order to allow them to ensure continued access via RDP.

Stolen Pencil.name: Input Capture
Stolen Pencil.description: [Stolen Pencil](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0086) has a tool to log keystrokes to %userprofile%\appdata\roaming\apach.{txt,log}.

Stolen Pencil.name: Remote Desktop Protocol
Stolen Pencil.description: [Stolen Pencil](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0086) utilized RDP for direct remote point-and-click access.

Stolen Pencil.name: Browser Extensions
Stolen Pencil.description: [Stolen Pencil](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0086) victims are prompted to install malicious Google Chrome extensions which gave the threat actor the ability to read data from any website accessed.

Stolen Pencil.name: Spearphishing Link
Stolen Pencil.description: [Stolen Pencil](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0086) sent spearphishing emails containing links to domains controlled by the threat actor.

Stolen Pencil.name: Credentials in Files
Stolen Pencil.description: [Stolen Pencil](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0086) has used tools that are capable of obtaining credentials from saved mail.

Stolen Pencil.name: Redundant Access
Stolen Pencil.description: [Stolen Pencil](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0086) has a tool to add a Windows admin account in order to allow them to ensure continued access via RDP.

APT39.name: Spearphishing Attachment
APT39.description: [APT39](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0087) leveraged spearphishing emails with malicious attachments to initially compromise victims.

APT39.name: Spearphishing Link
APT39.description: [APT39](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0087) leveraged spearphishing emails with malicious links to initially compromise victims.

APT39.name: Remote Desktop Protocol
APT39.description: [APT39](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0087) has been seen using RDP for lateral movement and persistence.

APT39.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
APT39.description: [APT39](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0087) has maintained persistence using the startup folder.

APT39.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
APT39.description: [APT39](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0087) has used nbtscan to discover vulnerable systems.

APT39.name: Data Compressed
APT39.description: [APT39](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0087) has used WinRAR and 7-Zip to compress an archive stolen data.

APT39.name: Connection Proxy
APT39.description: [APT39](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0087) used custom tools to create SOCK5 proxies between infected hosts.

APT39.name: Credential Dumping
APT39.description: [APT39](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0087) has used Mimikatz, Ncrack, Windows Credential Editor and ProcDump to dump credentials.

APT39.name: Scripting
APT39.description: [APT39](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0087) utilized custom scripts to perform internal reconnaissance.

APT39.name: Valid Accounts
APT39.description: [APT39](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0087) has used stolen credentials to compromise Outlook Web Access (OWA).

APT39.name: Network Service Scanning
APT39.description: [APT39](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0087) used a custom port scanner known as BLUETORCH

APT39.name: Remote Services
APT39.description: [APT39](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0087) used secure shell (SSH) to move laterally among their targets.

APT39.name: Web Shell
APT39.description: [APT39](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0087) has installed ANTAK and ASPXSPY web shells.

APT39.name: User Execution
APT39.description: [APT39](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0087) has sent spearphishing emails in an attempt to lure users to click on a malicious attachment or link.

APT39.name: Software Packing
APT39.description: [APT39](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0087) has repacked a modified version of [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002) to thwart anti-virus detection.

APT39.name: System Owner/User Discovery
APT39.description: [APT39](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0087) used [Remexi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0375) to collect usernames from the system.

description.name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel

The White Company.name: System Time Discovery
The White Company.description: [The White Company](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0089) has checked the current date on the victim system.

The White Company.name: Security Software Discovery
The White Company.description: [The White Company](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0089) has checked for specific antivirus products on the target’s computer, including Kaspersky, Quick Heal, AVG, BitDefender, Avira, Sophos, Avast!, and ESET.

The White Company.name: File Deletion
The White Company.description: [The White Company](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0089) has the ability to delete its malware entirely from the target system.

The White Company.name: Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion
The White Company.description: [The White Company](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0089) has performed anti-analysis checks to determine if its malware was in a debugging environment.

The White Company.name: Exploitation for Client Execution
The White Company.description: [The White Company](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0089) has taken advantage of a known vulnerability in Microsoft Word (CVE 2012-0158) to execute code.

The White Company.name: Software Packing
The White Company.description: [The White Company](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0089) has obfuscated their payloads through packing.

The White Company.name: User Execution
The White Company.description: [The White Company](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0089) has used phishing lure documents that trick users into opening them and infecting their computers.

The White Company.name: Spearphishing Attachment
The White Company.description: [The White Company](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0089) has sent phishing emails with malicious Microsoft Word attachments to victims.

WIRTE.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
WIRTE.description: [WIRTE](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0090) has used HTTP for network communication.

WIRTE.name: Scripting
WIRTE.description: [WIRTE](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0090) has used VBS and PowerShell scripts throughout its operation.

WIRTE.name: PowerShell
WIRTE.description: [WIRTE](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0090) has used PowerShell for script execution.

WIRTE.name: Remote File Copy
WIRTE.description: [WIRTE](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0090) has downloaded PowerShell code from the C2 server to be executed.

WIRTE.name: Regsvr32
WIRTE.description: [WIRTE](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0090) has used Regsvr32.exe to trigger the execution of a malicious script.

WIRTE.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
WIRTE.description: [WIRTE](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0090) has decoded a base64 encoded document which was embedded in a VBS script.

description.name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel

Silence.name: Video Capture
Silence.description: [Silence](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0091) has been observed making videos of victims to observe bank employees day to day activities.

Silence.name: File Deletion
Silence.description: [Silence](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0091) deleted scheduled task files after its execution.

Silence.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Silence.description: [Silence](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0091) has used environment variable string substitution for obfuscation.

Silence.name: Execution through API
Silence.description: [Silence](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0091) leverages the Windows API to perform a variety of tasks.

Silence.name: Compiled HTML File
Silence.description: [Silence](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0091) has weaponized CHM files in their phishing campaigns.

Silence.name: User Execution
Silence.description: [Silence](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0091) attempts to get users to launch malicious attachments delivered via spearphishing emails.

Silence.name: Command-Line Interface
Silence.description: [Silence](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0091) has used Windows command-line to run commands.

Silence.name: Service Execution
Silence.description: [Silence](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0091) has used Winexe to install a service on the remote system.

Silence.name: Scripting
Silence.description: [Silence](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0091) has used JS, VBS, and PowerShell scripts.

Silence.name: Scheduled Task
Silence.description: [Silence](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0091) has used scheduled tasks to stage its operation.

Silence.name: Spearphishing Attachment
Silence.description: [Silence](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0091) has sent emails with malicious DOCX, CHM and ZIP attachments.

TA505.name: Spearphishing Attachment
TA505.description: [TA505](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0092) has used spearphishing emails with malicious attachments to initially compromise victims.

TA505.name: Dynamic Data Exchange
TA505.description: [TA505](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0092) has leveraged malicious Word documents that abused DDE.

TA505.name: Spearphishing Link
TA505.description: [TA505](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0092) has sent spearphishing emails containing malicious links.

TA505.name: PowerShell
TA505.description: [TA505](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0092) has used PowerShell to download and execute malware and reconnaissance scripts.

TA505.name: Scripting
TA505.description: [TA505](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0092) has used PowerShell, VBS, and JavaScript for code execution.

TA505.name: Data Encrypted for Impact
TA505.description: [TA505](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0092) has used a wide variety of ransomware, such as Locky, Jaff, Bart, Philadelphia, and GlobeImposter, to encrypt victim files and demand a ransom payment.

TA505.name: Credentials in Files
TA505.description: [TA505](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0092) has used malware to gather credentials from FTP clients and Outlook.

TA505.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
TA505.description: [TA505](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0092) has password-protected malicious Word documents and used base64 encoded PowerShell commands.

TA505.name: User Execution
TA505.description: [TA505](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0092) has used lures to get users to click links in emails and attachments, enable content in malicious attachments, and execute malicious files contained in archives. For example, [TA505](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0092) makes their malware look like legitimate Microsoft Word documents, .pdf and/or .lnk files.

TA505.name: Signed Binary Proxy Execution
TA505.description: [TA505](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0092) has used msiexec to download and execute malicious Windows Installer files.

TA505.name: Rundll32
TA505.description: [TA505](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0092) has leveraged rundll32.exe to execute malicious DLLs.

TA505.name: Code Signing
TA505.description: [TA505](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0092) has signed payloads with code signing certificates from Thawte and Sectigo.

TA505.name: Remote File Copy
TA505.description: [TA505](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0092) has downloaded additional malware to execute on victim systems.

Soft Cell.name: Exploit Public-Facing Application
Soft Cell.description: [Soft Cell](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0093) exploited a publicly-facing server to gain access to the network.

Soft Cell.name: DLL Side-Loading
Soft Cell.description: [Soft Cell](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0093) used DLL side-loading to covertly load [PoisonIvy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0012) into memory on the victim machine.

Soft Cell.name: Valid Accounts
Soft Cell.description: [Soft Cell](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0093) leveraged valid accounts to maintain access to a victim network.

Soft Cell.name: Create Account
Soft Cell.description: [Soft Cell](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0093) created rogue, high-privileged domain user accounts to maintain access across waves of a compromise.

Soft Cell.name: Web Shell
Soft Cell.description: [Soft Cell](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0093) used Web shells to persist in victim environments and assist in execution and exfiltration.

Soft Cell.name: PowerShell
Soft Cell.description: [Soft Cell](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0093) used PowerShell for execution to assist in lateral movement as well as for dumping credentials stored on compromised machines.

Soft Cell.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
Soft Cell.description: [Soft Cell](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0093) used WMI for execution to assist in lateral movement as well as for installing tools across multiple assets.

Soft Cell.name: Command-Line Interface
Soft Cell.description: [Soft Cell](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0093) used the Windows command shell to execute commands.

Soft Cell.name: Credentials in Registry
Soft Cell.description: [Soft Cell](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0093) used reg commands to dump specific hives from the Windows Registry, such as the SAM hive, and obtain password hashes.

Soft Cell.name: Credential Dumping
Soft Cell.description: [Soft Cell](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0093) used a modified version of [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002) along with a PowerShell-based [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002) to dump credentials on the victim machines.

Soft Cell.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Soft Cell.description: [Soft Cell](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0093) used ipconfig /all to obtain information about the victim network configuration. The group also ran a modified version of nbtscan to identify available NetBIOS name servers.

Soft Cell.name: System Network Connections Discovery
Soft Cell.description: [Soft Cell](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0093) used netstat -oan to obtain information about the victim network connections.

Soft Cell.name: System Owner/User Discovery
Soft Cell.description: [Soft Cell](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0093) used whoami and query user to obtain information about the victim user.

Soft Cell.name: Remote File Copy
Soft Cell.description: [Soft Cell](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0093) dropped additional tools to victims during their operation, including portqry.exe, a renamed cmd.exe file, winrar, and [HTRAN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0040).

Soft Cell.name: Masquerading
Soft Cell.description: [Soft Cell](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0093) used a renamed cmd.exe file to evade detection.

Soft Cell.name: Scheduled Task
Soft Cell.description: [Soft Cell](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0093) established persistence for [PoisonIvy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0012) by created a scheduled task.

Soft Cell.name: Software Packing
Soft Cell.description: [Soft Cell](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0093) packed some payloads using different types of packers, both known and custom.

Soft Cell.name: Connection Proxy
Soft Cell.description: [Soft Cell](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0093) used a modified version of [HTRAN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0040) to redirect connections between networks.

Soft Cell.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Soft Cell.description: [Soft Cell](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0093) used a modified version of [HTRAN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0040) in which they obfuscated strings such as debug messages in an apparent attempt to evade detection.

Soft Cell.name: Data Staged
Soft Cell.description: [Soft Cell](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0093) compressed and staged files in multi-part archives in the Recycle Bin prior to exfiltration.

Soft Cell.name: Data Encrypted
Soft Cell.description: [Soft Cell](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0093) used winrar to compress and encrypt stolen data prior to exfiltration.

Soft Cell.name: Data Compressed
Soft Cell.description: [Soft Cell](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0093) used winrar to compress and encrypt stolen data prior to exfiltration.

Soft Cell.name: External Remote Services
Soft Cell.description: [Soft Cell](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0093) established VPN access into victim environments.

Soft Cell.name: Remote System Discovery
Soft Cell.description: [Soft Cell](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0093) used a modified version of nbtscan to identify available NetBIOS name servers over the network as well as ping to identify remote systems.

Soft Cell.name: Data from Local System
Soft Cell.description: [Soft Cell](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0093) collected data from the victim's local system, including password hashes from the SAM hive in the Registry.

Soft Cell.name: Pass the Hash
Soft Cell.description: [Soft Cell](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0093) used dumped hashes to authenticate to other machines via pass the hash.

Soft Cell.name: Indicator Removal from Tools
Soft Cell.description: [Soft Cell](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0093) ensured each payload had a unique hash, including by using different types of packers.

Soft Cell.name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
Soft Cell.description: [Soft Cell](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0093) used Web shells and [HTRAN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0040) for C2 as well as to exfiltrate data.

BADNEWS.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
BADNEWS.description: [BADNEWS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0128) establishes a backdoor over HTTP.

BADNEWS.name: DLL Side-Loading
BADNEWS.description: [BADNEWS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0128) typically loads its DLL file into a legitimate signed Java or VMware executable.

BADNEWS.name: Peripheral Device Discovery
BADNEWS.description: [BADNEWS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0128) checks for new hard drives on the victim, such as USB devices, by listening for the WM_DEVICECHANGE window message.

BADNEWS.name: Scheduled Task
BADNEWS.description: [BADNEWS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0128) creates a scheduled task to establish by executing a malicious payload every subsequent minute.

BADNEWS.name: Execution through API
BADNEWS.description: [BADNEWS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0128) has a command to download an .exe and execute it via CreateProcess API. It can also run with ShellExecute.

BADNEWS.name: Data from Network Shared Drive
BADNEWS.description: When it first starts, [BADNEWS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0128) crawls the victim's mapped drives and collects documents with the following extensions: .doc, .docx, .pdf, .ppt, .pptx, and .txt.

BADNEWS.name: Remote File Copy
BADNEWS.description: [BADNEWS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0128) is capable of downloading additional files through C2 channels, including a new version of itself.

BADNEWS.name: File and Directory Discovery
BADNEWS.description: [BADNEWS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0128) identifies files with certain extensions from USB devices, then copies them to a predefined directory.

BADNEWS.name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
BADNEWS.description: [BADNEWS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0128) encrypts C2 data with a ROR by 3 and an XOR by 0x23.

BADNEWS.name: Screen Capture
BADNEWS.description: [BADNEWS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0128) has a command to take a screenshot and send it to the C2 server.

BADNEWS.name: Data from Local System
BADNEWS.description: When it first starts, [BADNEWS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0128) crawls the victim's local drives and collects documents with the following extensions: .doc, .docx, .pdf, .ppt, .pptx, and .txt.

BADNEWS.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
BADNEWS.description: [BADNEWS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0128) installs a registry Run key to establish persistence.

BADNEWS.name: Input Capture
BADNEWS.description: When it first starts, [BADNEWS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0128) spawns a new thread to log keystrokes.

BADNEWS.name: Code Signing
BADNEWS.description: [BADNEWS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0128) is sometimes signed with an invalid Authenticode certificate in an apparent effort to make it look more legitimate.

BADNEWS.name: Data Staged
BADNEWS.description: [BADNEWS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0128) copies documents under 15MB found on the victim system to is the user's %temp%\SMB\ folder. It also copies files from USB devices to a predefined directory.

BADNEWS.name: Web Service
BADNEWS.description: [BADNEWS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0128) can use multiple C2 channels, including RSS feeds, Github, forums, and blogs. [BADNEWS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0128) also collects C2 information via a dead drop resolver.

BADNEWS.name: Data from Removable Media
BADNEWS.description:
[BADNEWS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0128) copies files with certain extensions from USB devices to
a predefined directory.

BADNEWS.name: Command-Line Interface
BADNEWS.description: [BADNEWS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0128) is capable of executing commands via cmd.exe.

BADNEWS.name: Automated Collection
BADNEWS.description:
[BADNEWS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0128) monitors USB devices and copies files with certain extensions to
a predefined directory.

BADNEWS.name: Data Encoding
BADNEWS.description: [BADNEWS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0128) encodes C2 traffic with base64.

BADNEWS.name: Process Hollowing
BADNEWS.description: [BADNEWS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0128) has a command to download an .exe and use process hollowing to inject it into a new process.

BADNEWS.name: Data Obfuscation
BADNEWS.description: After encrypting C2 data, [BADNEWS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0128) converts it into a hexadecimal representation and then encodes it into base64.

BADNEWS.name: Masquerading
BADNEWS.description: [BADNEWS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0128) attempts to hide its payloads using legitimate filenames.

Bankshot.name: Data from Local System
Bankshot.description: [Bankshot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0239) collects files from the local system.

Bankshot.name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Bankshot.description: [Bankshot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0239) leverages a known zero-day vulnerability in Adobe Flash to execute the implant into the victims’ machines.

Bankshot.name: Access Token Manipulation
Bankshot.description: [Bankshot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0239) grabs a user token using WTSQueryUserToken and then creates a process by impersonating a logged-on user.

Bankshot.name: Modify Existing Service
Bankshot.description: [Bankshot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0239) can terminate a specific process by its process id.

Bankshot.name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
Bankshot.description: [Bankshot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0239) exfiltrates data over its C2 channel.

Bankshot.name: Remote File Copy
Bankshot.description: [Bankshot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0239) uploads files and secondary payloads to the victim's machine.

Bankshot.name: Uncommonly Used Port
Bankshot.description: [Bankshot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0239) binds and listens on port 1058.

Bankshot.name: Timestomp
Bankshot.description: [Bankshot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0239) modifies the time of a file as specified by the control server.

Bankshot.name: Indicator Removal on Host
Bankshot.description: [Bankshot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0239) delets all artifacts associated with the malware from the infected machine.

Bankshot.name: Automated Collection
Bankshot.description: [Bankshot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0239) recursively generates a list of files within a directory and sends them back to the control server.

Bankshot.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Bankshot.description: [Bankshot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0239) decodes embedded XOR strings.

Bankshot.name: Execution through API
Bankshot.description: [Bankshot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0239) creates processes using the Windows API calls: CreateProcessA() and CreateProcessAsUserA().

Bankshot.name: Process Discovery
Bankshot.description: [Bankshot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0239) identifies processes and collects the process ids.

Bankshot.name: Command-Line Interface
Bankshot.description: [Bankshot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0239) uses the command-line interface to execute arbitrary commands.

Bankshot.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Bankshot.description: [Bankshot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0239) uses HTTP for command and control communication.

Bankshot.name: File and Directory Discovery
Bankshot.description: [Bankshot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0239) searches for files on the victim's machine.

Bankshot.name: Data Obfuscation
Bankshot.description: [Bankshot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0239) generates a false TLS handshake using a public certificate to disguise C2 network communications.

Bankshot.name: Account Discovery
Bankshot.description: [Bankshot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0239) gathers domain and account names/information through process monitoring.

Bankshot.name: File Deletion
Bankshot.description: [Bankshot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0239) marks files to be deleted upon the next system reboot and uninstalls and removes itself from the system.

Bankshot.name: System Information Discovery
Bankshot.description: [Bankshot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0239) gathers system information, network addresses, disk type, disk free space, and the operation system version.

Bankshot.name: Data Encoding
Bankshot.description: [Bankshot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0239) encodes commands from the control server using a range of characters and gzip.

Bankshot.name: Query Registry
Bankshot.description: [Bankshot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0239) searches for certain Registry keys to be configured before executing the payload.

Bankshot.name: Modify Registry
Bankshot.description: [Bankshot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0239) writes data into the Registry key HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Pniumj.

ADVSTORESHELL.name: Execution through API
ADVSTORESHELL.description: [ADVSTORESHELL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0045) is capable of starting a process using CreateProcess.

ADVSTORESHELL.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
ADVSTORESHELL.description: Most of the strings in [ADVSTORESHELL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0045) are encrypted with an XOR-based algorithm; some strings are also encrypted with 3DES and reversed. API function names are also reversed, presumably to avoid detection in memory.

ADVSTORESHELL.name: Input Capture
ADVSTORESHELL.description: [ADVSTORESHELL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0045) can perform keylogging.

ADVSTORESHELL.name: Peripheral Device Discovery
ADVSTORESHELL.description: [ADVSTORESHELL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0045) can list connected devices.

ADVSTORESHELL.name: File Deletion
ADVSTORESHELL.description: [ADVSTORESHELL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0045) can delete files and directories.

ADVSTORESHELL.name: Component Object Model Hijacking
ADVSTORESHELL.description: Some variants of [ADVSTORESHELL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0045) achieve persistence by registering the payload as a Shell Icon Overlay handler COM object.

ADVSTORESHELL.name: Command-Line Interface
ADVSTORESHELL.description: [ADVSTORESHELL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0045) can create a remote shell and run a given command.

ADVSTORESHELL.name: Modify Registry
ADVSTORESHELL.description: [ADVSTORESHELL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0045) is capable of setting and deleting Registry values.

ADVSTORESHELL.name: Scheduled Transfer
ADVSTORESHELL.description: [ADVSTORESHELL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0045) collects, compresses, encrypts, and exfiltrates data to the C2 server every 10 minutes.

ADVSTORESHELL.name: System Information Discovery
ADVSTORESHELL.description: [ADVSTORESHELL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0045) can run [Systeminfo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0096) to gather information about the victim.

ADVSTORESHELL.name: Query Registry
ADVSTORESHELL.description: [ADVSTORESHELL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0045) can enumerate registry keys.

ADVSTORESHELL.name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
ADVSTORESHELL.description: [ADVSTORESHELL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0045) exfiltrates data over the same channel used for C2.

ADVSTORESHELL.name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
ADVSTORESHELL.description: A variant of [ADVSTORESHELL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0045) encrypts some C2 with 3DES and RSA.

ADVSTORESHELL.name: Data Compressed
ADVSTORESHELL.description: [ADVSTORESHELL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0045) compresses output data generated by command execution with a custom implementation of the Lempel–Ziv–Welch (LZW) algorithm.

ADVSTORESHELL.name: Process Discovery
ADVSTORESHELL.description: [ADVSTORESHELL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0045) can list running processes.

ADVSTORESHELL.name: Data Staged
ADVSTORESHELL.description: [ADVSTORESHELL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0045) stores output from command execution in a .dat file in the %TEMP% directory.

ADVSTORESHELL.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
ADVSTORESHELL.description: [ADVSTORESHELL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0045) connects to port 80 of a C2 server using Wininet API.

ADVSTORESHELL.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
ADVSTORESHELL.description: [ADVSTORESHELL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0045) achieves persistence by adding itself to the HKCU\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run Registry key.

ADVSTORESHELL.name: Data Encrypted
ADVSTORESHELL.description: [ADVSTORESHELL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0045) encrypts with the 3DES algorithm and a hardcoded key prior to exfiltration.

ADVSTORESHELL.name: Data Encoding
ADVSTORESHELL.description: C2 traffic from [ADVSTORESHELL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0045) is encrypted, then encoded with Base64 encoding.

ADVSTORESHELL.name: File and Directory Discovery
ADVSTORESHELL.description: [ADVSTORESHELL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0045) can list files and directories.

ADVSTORESHELL.name: Commonly Used Port
ADVSTORESHELL.description: A variant of [ADVSTORESHELL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0045) attempts communication to the C2 server over HTTP on port 443.

ADVSTORESHELL.name: Rundll32
ADVSTORESHELL.description: [ADVSTORESHELL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0045) has used rundll32.exe in a Registry value to establish persistence.

Felismus.name: Remote File Copy
Felismus.description: [Felismus](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0171) can download files from remote servers.

Felismus.name: Masquerading
Felismus.description: [Felismus](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0171) has masqueraded as legitimate Adobe Content Management System files.

Felismus.name: Security Software Discovery
Felismus.description: [Felismus](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0171) checks for processes associated with anti-virus vendors.

Felismus.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Felismus.description: [Felismus](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0171) collects the victim LAN IP address and sends it to the C2 server.

Felismus.name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Felismus.description: Some [Felismus](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0171) samples use AES to encrypt C2 traffic.

Felismus.name: System Owner/User Discovery
Felismus.description: [Felismus](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0171) collects the current username and sends it to the C2 server.

Felismus.name: System Information Discovery
Felismus.description: [Felismus](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0171) collects the system information, including hostname and OS version, and sends it to the C2 server.

Felismus.name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
Felismus.description: Some [Felismus](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0171) samples use a custom encryption method for C2 traffic using AES, base64 encoding, and multiple keys.

Calisto.name: File Deletion
Calisto.description: [Calisto](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0274) has the capability to use rm -rf to remove folders and files from the victim's machine.

Calisto.name: Hidden Files and Directories
Calisto.description: [Calisto](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0274) uses a hidden directory named .calisto to store data from the victim’s machine before exfiltration.

Calisto.name: Account Manipulation
Calisto.description: [Calisto](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0274) adds permissions and remote logins to all users.

Calisto.name: Masquerading
Calisto.description: [Calisto](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0274)'s installation file is an unsigned DMG image under the guise of Intego’s security solution for mac.

Calisto.name: Keychain
Calisto.description: [Calisto](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0274) collects Keychain storage data and copies those passwords/tokens to a file.

Calisto.name: Data from Local System
Calisto.description: [Calisto](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0274) can collect data from user directories.

Calisto.name: Commonly Used Port
Calisto.description: [Calisto](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0274) attempted to contact the C2 server over TCP using port 80.

Calisto.name: Data Staged
Calisto.description: [Calisto](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0274) uses a hidden directory named .calisto to store data from the victim’s machine before exfiltration.

Calisto.name: Browser Bookmark Discovery
Calisto.description: [Calisto](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0274) collects information on bookmarks from Google Chrome.

Calisto.name: Data Compressed
Calisto.description: [Calisto](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0274) uses the zip -r command to compress the data collected on the local system.

Calisto.name: Launch Agent
Calisto.description: [Calisto](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0274) adds a .plist file to the /Library/LaunchAgents folder to maintain persistence.

Calisto.name: Remote File Copy
Calisto.description: [Calisto](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0274) has the capability to upload and download files to the victim's machine.

Calisto.name: Launchctl
Calisto.description: [Calisto](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0274) uses launchctl to enable screen sharing on the victim’s machine.

Calisto.name: Create Account
Calisto.description: [Calisto](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0274) has the capability to add its own account to the victim's machine.

Calisto.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Calisto.description: [Calisto](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0274) runs the ifconfig command to obtain the IP address from the victim’s machine.

Calisto.name: Input Prompt
Calisto.description: [Calisto](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0274) presents an input prompt asking for the user's login and password.

DDKONG.name: Rundll32
DDKONG.description: [DDKONG](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0255) uses Rundll32 to ensure only a single instance of itself is running at once.

DDKONG.name: File and Directory Discovery
DDKONG.description: [DDKONG](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0255) lists files on the victim’s machine.

DDKONG.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
DDKONG.description: [DDKONG](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0255) decodes an embedded configuration using XOR.

DDKONG.name: Remote File Copy
DDKONG.description: [DDKONG](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0255) downloads and uploads files on the victim’s machine.

HTTPBrowser.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
HTTPBrowser.description: [HTTPBrowser](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0070) has used HTTP, HTTPS, and DNS for command and control.

HTTPBrowser.name: Commonly Used Port
HTTPBrowser.description: One [HTTPBrowser](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0070) variant connected to its C2 server over port 8080.

HTTPBrowser.name: Masquerading
HTTPBrowser.description: [HTTPBrowser](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0070)'s installer contains a malicious file named navlu.dll to decrypt and run the RAT. navlu.dll is also the name of a legitimate Symantec DLL.

HTTPBrowser.name: Remote File Copy
HTTPBrowser.description: [HTTPBrowser](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0070) is capable of writing a file to the compromised system from the C2 server.

HTTPBrowser.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
HTTPBrowser.description: [HTTPBrowser](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0070)'s code may be obfuscated through structured exception handling and return-oriented programming.

HTTPBrowser.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
HTTPBrowser.description: [HTTPBrowser](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0070) has established persistence by setting the HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run key value for wdm to the path of the executable. It has also used the Registry entry HKEY_USERS\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run vpdn “%ALLUSERPROFILE%\%APPDATA%\vpdn\VPDN_LU.exe” to establish persistence.

HTTPBrowser.name: File and Directory Discovery
HTTPBrowser.description: [HTTPBrowser](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0070) is capable of listing files, folders, and drives on a victim.

HTTPBrowser.name: Command-Line Interface
HTTPBrowser.description: [HTTPBrowser](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0070) is capable of spawning a reverse shell on a victim.

HTTPBrowser.name: Input Capture
HTTPBrowser.description: [HTTPBrowser](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0070) is capable of capturing keystrokes on victims.

HTTPBrowser.name: File Deletion
HTTPBrowser.description: [HTTPBrowser](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0070) deletes its original installer file once installation is complete.

HTTPBrowser.name: DLL Search Order Hijacking
HTTPBrowser.description: [HTTPBrowser](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0070) abuses the Windows DLL load order by using a legitimate Symantec anti-virus binary, VPDN_LU.exe, to load a malicious DLL that mimics a legitimate Symantec DLL, navlu.dll.

DustySky.name: Fallback Channels
DustySky.description: [DustySky](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0062) has two hard-coded domains for C2 servers; if the first does not respond, it will try the second.

DustySky.name: Process Discovery
DustySky.description: [DustySky](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0062) collects information about running processes from victims.

DustySky.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
DustySky.description: The [DustySky](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0062) dropper uses a function to obfuscate the name of functions and other parts of the malware.

DustySky.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
DustySky.description: [DustySky](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0062) achieves persistence by creating a Registry entry in HKCU\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run.

DustySky.name: Remote File Copy
DustySky.description: [DustySky](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0062) searches for network drives and removable media and duplicates itself onto them.

DustySky.name: File and Directory Discovery
DustySky.description: [DustySky](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0062) scans the victim for files that contain certain keywords from a list that is obtained from the C2 as a text file. It also collects information about installed software.

DustySky.name: Security Software Discovery
DustySky.description: [DustySky](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0062) checks for the existence of anti-virus.

DustySky.name: System Information Discovery
DustySky.description: [DustySky](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0062) extracts basic information about the operating system.

DustySky.name: Replication Through Removable Media
DustySky.description: [DustySky](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0062) searches for removable media and duplicates itself onto it.

DustySky.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
DustySky.description: The [DustySky](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0062) dropper uses Windows Management Instrumentation to extract information about the operating system and whether an anti-virus is active.

DustySky.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
DustySky.description: [DustySky](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0062) has used both HTTP and HTTPS for C2.

Duqu.name: Access Token Manipulation
Duqu.description: [Duqu](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0038) examines running system processes for tokens that have specific system privileges. If it finds one, it will copy the token and store it for later use. Eventually it will start new processes with the stored token attached. It can also steal tokens to acquire administrative privileges.

Duqu.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Duqu.description: The reconnaissance modules used with [Duqu](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0038) can collect information on network configuration.

Duqu.name: Commonly Used Port
Duqu.description: [Duqu](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0038) uses a custom command and control protocol that communicates over commonly used ports, and is frequently encapsulated by application layer protocols.

Duqu.name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
Duqu.description: [Duqu](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0038) is capable of using its command and control protocol over port 443. However, Duqu is also capable of encapsulating its command protocol over standard application layer protocols. The Duqu command and control protocol implements many of the same features as TCP and is a reliable transport protocol.

Duqu.name: Application Window Discovery
Duqu.description: The discovery modules used with [Duqu](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0038) can collect information on open windows.

Duqu.name: Account Discovery
Duqu.description: The discovery modules used with [Duqu](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0038) can collect information on accounts and permissions.

Duqu.name: Data Compressed
Duqu.description: Modules can be pushed to and executed by [Duqu](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0038) that copy data to a staging area, compress it, and XOR encrypt it.

Duqu.name: Process Hollowing
Duqu.description: [Duqu](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0038) is capable of loading executable code via process hollowing.

Duqu.name: System Network Connections Discovery
Duqu.description: The discovery modules used with [Duqu](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0038) can collect information on network connections.

Duqu.name: New Service
Duqu.description: [Duqu](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0038) creates a new service that loads a malicious driver when the system starts. When Duqu is active, the operating system believes that the driver is legitimate, as it has been signed with a valid private key.

Duqu.name: Data Obfuscation
Duqu.description: When the [Duqu](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0038) command and control is operating over HTTP or HTTPS, Duqu uploads data to its controller by appending it to a blank JPG file.

Duqu.name: Input Capture
Duqu.description: [Duqu](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0038) can track key presses with a keylogger module.

Duqu.name: Windows Admin Shares
Duqu.description: Adversaries can instruct [Duqu](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0038) to spread laterally by copying itself to shares it has enumerated and for which it has obtained legitimate credentials (via keylogging or other means). The remote host is then infected by using the compromised credentials to schedule a task on remote machines that executes the malware.

Duqu.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Duqu.description: [Duqu](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0038) uses a custom command and control protocol that communicates over commonly used ports, and is frequently encapsulated by application layer protocols.

Duqu.name: Data Staged
Duqu.description: Modules can be pushed to and executed by [Duqu](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0038) that copy data to a staging area, compress it, and XOR encrypt it.

Duqu.name: Data Encrypted
Duqu.description: Modules can be pushed to and executed by [Duqu](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0038) that copy data to a staging area, compress it, and XOR encrypt it.

Duqu.name: Process Injection
Duqu.description: [Duqu](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0038) will inject itself into different processes to evade detection. The selection of the target process is influenced by the security software that is installed on the system (Duqu will inject into different processes depending on which security suite is installed on the infected host).

Duqu.name: Scheduled Task
Duqu.description: Adversaries can instruct [Duqu](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0038) to spread laterally by copying itself to shares it has enumerated and for which it has obtained legitimate credentials (via keylogging or other means). The remote host is then infected by using the compromised credentials to schedule a task on remote machines that executes the malware.

Duqu.name: Connection Proxy
Duqu.description: [Duqu](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0038) can be configured to have commands relayed over a peer-to-peer network of infected hosts if some of the hosts do not have Internet access.

Duqu.name: Process Discovery
Duqu.description: The discovery modules used with [Duqu](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0038) can collect information on process details.

Duqu.name: Valid Accounts
Duqu.description: Adversaries can instruct [Duqu](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0038) to spread laterally by copying itself to shares it has enumerated and for which it has obtained legitimate credentials (via keylogging or other means). The remote host is then infected by using the compromised credentials to schedule a task on remote machines that executes the malware.

Duqu.name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Duqu.description: The [Duqu](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0038) command and control protocol's data stream can be encrypted with AES-CBC.

Duqu.name: Signed Binary Proxy Execution
Duqu.description: [Duqu](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0038) has used msiexec to execute malicious Windows Installer packages. Additionally, a PROPERTY=VALUE pair containing a 56-bit encryption key has been used to decrypt the main payload from the installer packages.

BACKSPACE.name: Disabling Security Tools
BACKSPACE.description: The "ZR" variant of [BACKSPACE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0031) will check to see if known host-based firewalls are installed on the infected systems. [BACKSPACE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0031) will attempt to establish a C2 channel, then will examine open windows to identify a pop-up from the firewall software and will simulate a mouse-click to allow the connection to proceed.

BACKSPACE.name: Modify Registry
BACKSPACE.description: [BACKSPACE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0031) is capable of deleting Registry keys, sub-keys, and values on a victim system.

BACKSPACE.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
BACKSPACE.description: [BACKSPACE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0031) uses HTTP as a transport to communicate with its command server.

BACKSPACE.name: Command-Line Interface
BACKSPACE.description: Adversaries can direct [BACKSPACE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0031) to execute from the command-line on infected hosts, or have [BACKSPACE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0031) create a reverse shell.

BACKSPACE.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
BACKSPACE.description: [BACKSPACE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0031) achieves persistence by creating a shortcut to itself in the CSIDL_STARTUP directory.

BACKSPACE.name: System Information Discovery
BACKSPACE.description: During its initial execution, [BACKSPACE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0031) extracts operating system information from the infected host.

BACKSPACE.name: Connection Proxy
BACKSPACE.description: The "ZJ" variant of [BACKSPACE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0031) allows "ZJ link" infections with Internet access to relay traffic from "ZJ listen" to a command server.

BACKSPACE.name: Query Registry
BACKSPACE.description: [BACKSPACE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0031) is capable of enumerating and making modifications to an infected system's Registry.

BACKSPACE.name: Multi-Stage Channels
BACKSPACE.description: [BACKSPACE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0031) attempts to avoid detection by checking a first stage command and control server to determine if it should connect to the second stage server, which performs "louder" interactions with the malware.

BACKSPACE.name: Shortcut Modification
BACKSPACE.description: [BACKSPACE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0031) achieves persistence by creating a shortcut to itself in the CSIDL_STARTUP directory.

BACKSPACE.name: File and Directory Discovery
BACKSPACE.description: [BACKSPACE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0031) allows adversaries to search for files.

BACKSPACE.name: Data Obfuscation
BACKSPACE.description: Newer variants of [BACKSPACE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0031) will encode C2 communications with a custom system.

BACKSPACE.name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
BACKSPACE.description: Adversaries can direct [BACKSPACE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0031) to upload files to the C2 Server.

BACKSPACE.name: Process Discovery
BACKSPACE.description: [BACKSPACE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0031) may collect information about running processes.

Carbanak.name: File Deletion
Carbanak.description: [Carbanak](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0030) has a command to delete files.

Carbanak.name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
Carbanak.description: [Carbanak](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0030) uses XOR with random keys for its communications.

Carbanak.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Carbanak.description: The [Carbanak](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0030) malware communicates to its command server using HTTP with an encrypted payload.

Carbanak.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Carbanak.description: [Carbanak](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0030) encrypts strings to make analysis more difficult.

Carbanak.name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Carbanak.description: [Carbanak](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0030) encrypts the message body of HTTP traffic with RC2 (in CBC mode) and Base64 encoding.

Carbanak.name: Input Capture
Carbanak.description: [Carbanak](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0030) logs key strokes for configured processes and sends them back to the C2 server.

Carbanak.name: Process Discovery
Carbanak.description: [Carbanak](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0030) lists running processes.

Carbanak.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Carbanak.description: [Carbanak](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0030) stores a configuration files in the startup directory to automatically execute commands in order to persist across reboots.

Carbanak.name: Credential Dumping
Carbanak.description: [Carbanak](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0030) obtains Windows logon password details.

Carbanak.name: Email Collection
Carbanak.description: [Carbanak](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0030) searches recursively for Outlook personal storage tables (PST) files within user directories and sends them back to the C2 server.

Carbanak.name: Commonly Used Port
Carbanak.description: [Carbanak](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0030) uses Port Numbers 443 and 80 for the C2 server.

Carbanak.name: Remote Access Tools
Carbanak.description: [Carbanak](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0030) has a plugin for VNC and Ammyy Admin Tool.

Carbanak.name: Screen Capture
Carbanak.description: [Carbanak](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0030) performs desktop video recording and captures screenshots of the desktop and sends it to the C2 server.

Carbanak.name: Query Registry
Carbanak.description: [Carbanak](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0030) checks the Registry key HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Internet Settings for proxy configurations information.

Carbanak.name: Data Transfer Size Limits
Carbanak.description: [Carbanak](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0030) exfiltrates data in compressed chunks if a message is larger than 4096 bytes .

Carbanak.name: Process Injection
Carbanak.description: [Carbanak](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0030) downloads an executable and injects it directly into a new process.

Carbanak.name: Command-Line Interface
Carbanak.description: [Carbanak](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0030) has a command to create a reverse shell.

Carbanak.name: Remote Desktop Protocol
Carbanak.description: [Carbanak](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0030) enables concurrent Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP).

Carbanak.name: Create Account
Carbanak.description: [Carbanak](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0030) can create a Windows account.

Carbanak.name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
Carbanak.description: [Carbanak](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0030) uses a custom binary protocol for C2 communications.

GeminiDuke.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
GeminiDuke.description: [GeminiDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0049) collects information on network settings and Internet proxy settings from the victim.

GeminiDuke.name: Process Discovery
GeminiDuke.description: [GeminiDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0049) collects information on running processes and environment variables from the victim.

GeminiDuke.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
GeminiDuke.description: [GeminiDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0049) uses HTTP and HTTPS for command and control.

GeminiDuke.name: System Service Discovery
GeminiDuke.description: [GeminiDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0049) collects information on programs and services on the victim that are configured to automatically run at startup.

GeminiDuke.name: Account Discovery
GeminiDuke.description: [GeminiDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0049) collects information on local user accounts from the victim.

GeminiDuke.name: File and Directory Discovery
GeminiDuke.description: [GeminiDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0049) collects information from the victim, including installed drivers, programs previously executed by users, programs and services configured to automatically run at startup, files and folders present in any user's home folder, files and folders present in any user's My Documents, programs installed to the Program Files folder, and recently accessed files, folders, and programs.

DOGCALL.name: Screen Capture
DOGCALL.description: [DOGCALL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0213) is capable of capturing screenshots of the victim's machine.

DOGCALL.name: Remote File Copy
DOGCALL.description: [DOGCALL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0213) can download and execute additional payloads.

DOGCALL.name: Web Service
DOGCALL.description: [DOGCALL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0213) is capable of leveraging cloud storage APIs such as Cloud, Box, Dropbox, and Yandex for C2.

DOGCALL.name: Audio Capture
DOGCALL.description: [DOGCALL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0213) can capture microphone data from the victim's machine.

JPIN.name: System Information Discovery
JPIN.description: [JPIN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0201) can obtain system information such as OS version and disk space.

JPIN.name: Process Injection
JPIN.description: [JPIN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0201) can inject content into lsass.exe to load a module.

JPIN.name: Remote File Copy
JPIN.description: [JPIN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0201) can download files and upgrade itself.

JPIN.name: File and Directory Discovery
JPIN.description: [JPIN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0201) can enumerate drives and their types. It can also change file permissions using cacls.exe.

JPIN.name: Security Software Discovery
JPIN.description: [JPIN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0201) checks for the presence of certain security-related processes and deletes its installer/uninstaller component if it identifies any of them.

JPIN.name: Disabling Security Tools
JPIN.description: [JPIN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0201) lower disable security settings by changing Registry keys.

JPIN.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
JPIN.description: [JPIN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0201) can communicate over FTP and send email over SMTP.

JPIN.name: File Deletion
JPIN.description: [JPIN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0201)'s installer/uninstaller component deletes itself if it encounters a version of Windows earlier than Windows XP or identifies security-related processes running.

JPIN.name: File Permissions Modification
JPIN.description: [JPIN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0201) can use the command-line utility cacls.exe to change file permissions.

JPIN.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
JPIN.description: A [JPIN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0201) uses a encrypted and compressed payload that is disguised as a bitmap within the resource section of the installer.

JPIN.name: Command-Line Interface
JPIN.description: [JPIN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0201) can use the command-line utility cacls.exe to change file permissions.

JPIN.name: System Owner/User Discovery
JPIN.description: [JPIN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0201) can obtain the victim user name.

JPIN.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
JPIN.description: [JPIN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0201) can obtain network information, including DNS, IP, and proxies.

JPIN.name: Permission Groups Discovery
JPIN.description: [JPIN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0201) can obtain the victim user name.

JPIN.name: BITS Jobs
JPIN.description: A [JPIN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0201) variant downloads the backdoor payload via the BITS service.

Elise.name: Data Encoding
Elise.description: [Elise](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0081) exfiltrates data using cookie values that are Base64-encoded.

Elise.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Elise.description: If establishing persistence by installation as a new service fails, one variant of [Elise](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0081) establishes persistence for the created .exe file by setting the following Registry key: HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\svchost : %APPDATA%\Microsoft\Network\svchost.exe. Other variants have set the following Registry keys for persistence: HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\imejp : [self] and HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\IAStorD.

Elise.name: System Service Discovery
Elise.description: [Elise](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0081) executes net start after initial communication is made to the remote server.

Elise.name: Masquerading
Elise.description: If installing itself as a service fails, [Elise](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0081) instead writes itself as a file named svchost.exe saved in %APPDATA%\Microsoft\Network.

Elise.name: Data Staged
Elise.description: [Elise](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0081) creates a file in AppData\Local\Microsoft\Windows\Explorer and stores all harvested data in that file.

Elise.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Elise.description: [Elise](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0081) executes ipconfig /all after initial communication is made to the remote server.

Elise.name: System Information Discovery
Elise.description: [Elise](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0081) executes systeminfo after initial communication is made to the remote server.

Elise.name: Rundll32
Elise.description: After copying itself to a DLL file, a variant of [Elise](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0081) calls the DLL file using rundll32.exe.

Elise.name: Remote File Copy
Elise.description: [Elise](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0081) can download additional files from the C2 server for execution.

Elise.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Elise.description: [Elise](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0081) encrypts several of its files, including configuration files.

Elise.name: File and Directory Discovery
Elise.description: A variant of [Elise](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0081) executes dir C:\progra~1 when initially run.

Elise.name: Timestomp
Elise.description: [Elise](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0081) performs timestomping of a CAB file it creates.

Elise.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Elise.description: [Elise](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0081) communicates over HTTP or HTTPS for C2.

Elise.name: File Deletion
Elise.description: [Elise](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0081) is capable of launching a remote shell on the host to delete itself.

Elise.name: Account Discovery
Elise.description: [Elise](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0081) executes net user after initial communication is made to the remote server.

Bisonal.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Bisonal.description: [Bisonal](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0268) can execute ipconfig on the victim’s machine.

Bisonal.name: Rundll32
Bisonal.description: [Bisonal](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0268) uses rundll32.exe to execute as part of the Registry Run key it adds: HKEY_CURRENT_USER \Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\”vert” = “rundll32.exe c:\windows\temp\pvcu.dll , Qszdez”.

Bisonal.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Bisonal.description: [Bisonal](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0268) decodes strings in the malware using XOR and RC4.

Bisonal.name: File Deletion
Bisonal.description: [Bisonal](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0268) deletes its dropper and VBS scripts from the victim’s machine.

Bisonal.name: Scripting
Bisonal.description: [Bisonal](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0268)'s dropper creates VBS scripts on the victim’s machine.

Bisonal.name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
Bisonal.description: [Bisonal](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0268) variants reported on in 2014 and 2015 used a simple XOR cipher for C2.

Bisonal.name: Process Discovery
Bisonal.description: [Bisonal](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0268) can obtain a list of running processes on the victim’s machine.

Bisonal.name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Bisonal.description: Some [Bisonal](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0268) samples encrypt C2 communications with RC4.

Bisonal.name: Command-Line Interface
Bisonal.description: [Bisonal](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0268) can launch cmd.exe to execute commands on the system.

Bisonal.name: System Information Discovery
Bisonal.description: [Bisonal](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0268) has a command to gather system information from the victim’s machine.

Bisonal.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Bisonal.description: [Bisonal](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0268)'s DLL file and non-malicious decoy file are encrypted with RC4.

Bisonal.name: Remote File Copy
Bisonal.description: [Bisonal](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0268) has the capability to download files to execute on the victim’s machine.

Bisonal.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Bisonal.description: [Bisonal](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0268) adds itself to the Registry key HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\CurrentVersion\Run\ for persistence.

Dipsind.name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
Dipsind.description: A [Dipsind](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0200) variant uses a C2 mechanism similar to port knocking that allows attackers to connect to a victim without leaving the connection open for more than a few sectonds.

Dipsind.name: Winlogon Helper DLL
Dipsind.description: A [Dipsind](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0200) variant registers as a Winlogon Event Notify DLL to establish persistence.

Dipsind.name: Scheduled Transfer
Dipsind.description: [Dipsind](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0200) can be configured to only run during normal working hours, which would make its communications harder to distinguish from normal traffic.

Dipsind.name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Dipsind.description: [Dipsind](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0200) encrypts C2 data with AES256 in ECB mode.

Helminth.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Helminth.description: The [Helminth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0170) config file is encrypted with RC4.

Helminth.name: Code Signing
Helminth.description: [Helminth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0170) samples have been signed with legitimate, compromised code signing certificates owned by software company AI Squared.

Helminth.name: Process Discovery
Helminth.description: [Helminth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0170) has used [Tasklist](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0057) to get information on processes.

Helminth.name: Data Staged
Helminth.description: [Helminth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0170) creates folders to store output from batch scripts prior to sending the information to its C2 server.

Helminth.name: Permission Groups Discovery
Helminth.description: [Helminth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0170) has checked for the local admin group domain admin group and Exchange Trusted Subsystem groups using the commands net group Exchange Trusted Subsystem /domain and net group domain admins /domain.

Helminth.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Helminth.description: [Helminth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0170) establishes persistence by creating a shortcut in the Start Menu folder.

Helminth.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Helminth.description: [Helminth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0170) can use HTTP or DNS for C2.

Helminth.name: Shortcut Modification
Helminth.description: [Helminth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0170) establishes persistence by creating a shortcut.

Helminth.name: Clipboard Data
Helminth.description: The executable version of [Helminth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0170) has a module to log clipboard contents.

Helminth.name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Helminth.description: [Helminth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0170) encrypts data sent to its C2 server over HTTP with RC4.

Helminth.name: Scheduled Task
Helminth.description: [Helminth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0170) has used a scheduled task for persistence.

Helminth.name: Automated Collection
Helminth.description: A [Helminth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0170) VBScript receives a batch script to execute a set of commands in a command prompt.

Helminth.name: Input Capture
Helminth.description: The executable version of [Helminth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0170) has a module to log keystrokes.

Helminth.name: Data Transfer Size Limits
Helminth.description: [Helminth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0170) splits data into chunks up to 23 bytes and sends the data in DNS queries to its C2 server.

Helminth.name: Data Encoding
Helminth.description: For C2 over HTTP, [Helminth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0170) encodes data with base64 and sends it via the "Cookie" field of HTTP requests. For C2 over DNS, [Helminth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0170) converts ASCII characters into their hexadecimal values and sends the data in cleartext.

Helminth.name: PowerShell
Helminth.description: One version of [Helminth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0170) uses a PowerShell script.

Helminth.name: Scripting
Helminth.description: One version of [Helminth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0170) consists of VBScript and PowerShell scripts. The malware also uses batch scripting.

BADCALL.name: Connection Proxy
BADCALL.description: [BADCALL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0245) functions as a proxy server between the victim and C2 server.

BADCALL.name: Disabling Security Tools
BADCALL.description: [BADCALL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0245) disables the Windows firewall before binding to a port.

BADCALL.name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
BADCALL.description: [BADCALL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0245) encrypts C2 traffic using an XOR/ADD cipher and uses a FakeTLS method.

BADCALL.name: System Information Discovery
BADCALL.description: [BADCALL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0245) collects the computer name and host name on the compromised system.

CHOPSTICK.name: Fallback Channels
CHOPSTICK.description: [CHOPSTICK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0023) can switch to a new C2 channel if the current one is broken.

CHOPSTICK.name: Communication Through Removable Media
CHOPSTICK.description: Part of [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007)'s operation involved using [CHOPSTICK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0023) modules to copy itself to air-gapped machines, using files written to USB sticks to transfer data and command traffic.

CHOPSTICK.name: Replication Through Removable Media
CHOPSTICK.description: Part of [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007)'s operation involved using [CHOPSTICK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0023) modules to copy itself to air-gapped machines and using files written to USB sticks to transfer data and command traffic.

CHOPSTICK.name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
CHOPSTICK.description: [CHOPSTICK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0023) encrypts C2 communications with RC4 as well as TLS.

CHOPSTICK.name: File and Directory Discovery
CHOPSTICK.description: An older version of [CHOPSTICK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0023) has a module that monitors all mounted volumes for files with the extensions .doc, .docx, .pgp, .gpg, .m2f, or .m2o.

CHOPSTICK.name: Remote File Copy
CHOPSTICK.description: [CHOPSTICK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0023) is capable of performing remote file transmission.

CHOPSTICK.name: Connection Proxy
CHOPSTICK.description: [CHOPSTICK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0023) used a proxy server between victims and the C2 server.

CHOPSTICK.name: Command-Line Interface
CHOPSTICK.description: [CHOPSTICK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0023) is capable of performing remote command execution.

CHOPSTICK.name: Screen Capture
CHOPSTICK.description: [CHOPSTICK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0023) has the capability to capture screenshots.

CHOPSTICK.name: Query Registry
CHOPSTICK.description: [CHOPSTICK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0023) provides access to the Windows Registry, which can be used to gather information.

CHOPSTICK.name: Security Software Discovery
CHOPSTICK.description: [CHOPSTICK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0023) checks for antivirus and forensics software.

CHOPSTICK.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
CHOPSTICK.description: Various implementations of [CHOPSTICK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0023) communicate with C2 over HTTP, SMTP, and POP3.

CHOPSTICK.name: Modify Registry
CHOPSTICK.description: [CHOPSTICK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0023) may store RC4 encrypted configuration information in the Windows Registry.

CHOPSTICK.name: Domain Generation Algorithms
CHOPSTICK.description: [CHOPSTICK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0023) can use a DGA for [Fallback Channels](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1008), domains are generated by concatenating words from lists.

CozyCar.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
CozyCar.description: [CozyCar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0046)'s main method of communicating with its C2 servers is using HTTP or HTTPS.

CozyCar.name: Command-Line Interface
CozyCar.description: A module in [CozyCar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0046) allows arbitrary commands to be executed by invoking C:\Windows\System32\cmd.exe.

CozyCar.name: Web Service
CozyCar.description: [CozyCar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0046) uses Twitter as a backup C2 channel to Twitter accounts specified in its configuration file.

CozyCar.name: New Service
CozyCar.description: One persistence mechanism used by [CozyCar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0046) is to register itself as a Windows service.

CozyCar.name: Security Software Discovery
CozyCar.description: The main [CozyCar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0046) dropper checks whether the victim has an anti-virus product installed. If the installed product is on a predetermined list, the dropper will exit.

CozyCar.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
CozyCar.description:
One persistence mechanism used by [CozyCar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0046) is to set itself to be executed at system startup by adding a Registry value under one of the following Registry keys:
HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\
HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\
HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Policies\Explorer\Run
HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Policies\Explorer\Run

CozyCar.name: Masquerading
CozyCar.description: The [CozyCar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0046) dropper has masqueraded a copy of the infected system's rundll32.exe executable that was moved to the malware's install directory and renamed according to a predefined configuration file.

CozyCar.name: Scheduled Task
CozyCar.description: One persistence mechanism used by [CozyCar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0046) is to register itself as a scheduled task.

CozyCar.name: System Information Discovery
CozyCar.description: A system info module in [CozyCar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0046) gathers information on the victim host’s configuration.

CozyCar.name: Credential Dumping
CozyCar.description: Password stealer and NTLM stealer modules in [CozyCar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0046) harvest stored credentials from the victim, including credentials used as part of Windows NTLM user authentication. [CozyCar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0046) has also executed [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002) for further victim penetration.

CozyCar.name: Rundll32
CozyCar.description: The [CozyCar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0046) dropper copies the system file rundll32.exe to the install location for the malware, then uses the copy of rundll32.exe to load and execute the main [CozyCar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0046) component.

CozyCar.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
CozyCar.description: The payload of [CozyCar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0046) is encrypted with simple XOR with a rotating key. The [CozyCar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0046) configuration file has been encrypted with RC4 keys.

CozyCar.name: Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion
CozyCar.description: Some versions of [CozyCar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0046) will check to ensure it is not being executed inside a virtual machine or a known malware analysis sandbox environment. If it detects that it is, it will exit.

BBSRAT.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
BBSRAT.description: [BBSRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0127) uses GET and POST requests over HTTP or HTTPS for command and control to obtain commands and send ZLIB compressed data back to the C2 server.

BBSRAT.name: File and Directory Discovery
BBSRAT.description: [BBSRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0127) can list file and directory information.

BBSRAT.name: DLL Side-Loading
BBSRAT.description: DLL side-loading has been used to execute [BBSRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0127) through a legitimate Citrix executable, ssonsvr.exe. The Citrix executable was dropped along with [BBSRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0127) by the dropper.

BBSRAT.name: Process Hollowing
BBSRAT.description: [BBSRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0127) has been seen loaded into msiexec.exe through process hollowing to hide its execution.

BBSRAT.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
BBSRAT.description: [BBSRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0127) has been loaded through DLL side-loading of a legitimate Citrix executable that is set to persist through the Registry Run key location HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\ssonsvr.exe.

BBSRAT.name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
BBSRAT.description: [BBSRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0127) uses a custom encryption algorithm on data sent back to the C2 server over HTTP.

BBSRAT.name: Commonly Used Port
BBSRAT.description: [BBSRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0127) uses HTTP TCP port 80 and HTTPS TCP port 443 for communications.

BBSRAT.name: Component Object Model Hijacking
BBSRAT.description: [BBSRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0127) has been seen persisting via COM hijacking through replacement of the COM object for MruPidlList {42aedc87-2188-41fd-b9a3-0c966feabec1} or Microsoft WBEM New Event Subsystem {F3130CDB-AA52-4C3A-AB32-85FFC23AF9C1} depending on the system's CPU architecture.

BBSRAT.name: Service Execution
