BBSRAT.description: [BBSRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0127) can start, stop, or delete services.

BBSRAT.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
BBSRAT.description: [BBSRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0127) uses [Expand](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0361) to decompress a CAB file into executable content.

BBSRAT.name: Data Compressed
BBSRAT.description: [BBSRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0127) can compress data with ZLIB prior to sending it back to the C2 server.

BlackEnergy.name: Process Injection
BlackEnergy.description: [BlackEnergy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0089) injects its DLL component into svchost.exe.

BlackEnergy.name: Screen Capture
BlackEnergy.description: [BlackEnergy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0089) is capable of taking screenshots.

BlackEnergy.name: New Service
BlackEnergy.description: One variant of [BlackEnergy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0089) creates a new service using either a hard-coded or randomly generated name.

BlackEnergy.name: Peripheral Device Discovery
BlackEnergy.description: [BlackEnergy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0089) can gather very specific information about attached USB devices, to include device instance ID and drive geometry.

BlackEnergy.name: Data Destruction
BlackEnergy.description: [BlackEnergy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0089) 2 contains a "Destroy" plug-in that destroys data stored on victim hard drives by overwriting file contents.

BlackEnergy.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
BlackEnergy.description: The [BlackEnergy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0089) 3 variant drops its main DLL component and then creates a .lnk shortcut to that file in the startup folder.

BlackEnergy.name: Windows Admin Shares
BlackEnergy.description: [BlackEnergy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0089) has run a plug-in on a victim to spread through the local network by using [PsExec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0029) and accessing admin shares.

BlackEnergy.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
BlackEnergy.description: A [BlackEnergy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0089) 2 plug-in uses WMI to gather victim host details.

BlackEnergy.name: System Information Discovery
BlackEnergy.description: [BlackEnergy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0089) has used [Systeminfo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0096) to gather the OS version, as well as information on the system configuration, BIOS, the motherboard, and the processor.

BlackEnergy.name: Fallback Channels
BlackEnergy.description: [BlackEnergy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0089) has the capability to communicate over a backup channel via plus.google.com.

BlackEnergy.name: Process Discovery
BlackEnergy.description: [BlackEnergy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0089) has gathered a process list by using [Tasklist](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0057).exe.

BlackEnergy.name: Bypass User Account Control
BlackEnergy.description: [BlackEnergy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0089) attempts to bypass default User Access Control (UAC) settings by exploiting a backward-compatibility setting found in Windows 7 and later.

BlackEnergy.name: Shortcut Modification
BlackEnergy.description: The [BlackEnergy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0089) 3 variant drops its main DLL component and then creates a .lnk shortcut to that file in the startup folder.

BlackEnergy.name: Network Service Scanning
BlackEnergy.description: [BlackEnergy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0089) has conducted port scans on a host.

BlackEnergy.name: Indicator Removal on Host
BlackEnergy.description: The [BlackEnergy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0089) component KillDisk is capable of deleting Windows Event Logs.

BlackEnergy.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
BlackEnergy.description: [BlackEnergy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0089) communicates with its C2 server over HTTP.

BlackEnergy.name: File System Permissions Weakness
BlackEnergy.description: One variant of [BlackEnergy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0089) locates existing driver services that have been disabled and drops its driver component into one of those service's paths, replacing the legitimate executable. The malware then sets the hijacked service to start automatically to establish persistence.

BlackEnergy.name: Credentials in Files
BlackEnergy.description: [BlackEnergy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0089) has used a plug-in to gather credentials stored in files on the host by various software programs, including The Bat! email client, Outlook, and Windows Credential Store.

BlackEnergy.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
BlackEnergy.description: [BlackEnergy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0089) has gathered information about network IP configurations using [ipconfig](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0100).exe and about routing tables using [route](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0103).exe.

BlackEnergy.name: File and Directory Discovery
BlackEnergy.description: [BlackEnergy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0089) gathers a list of installed apps from the uninstall program Registry. It also gathers registered mail, browser, and instant messaging clients from the Registry. [BlackEnergy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0089) has searched for given file types.

BlackEnergy.name: System Network Connections Discovery
BlackEnergy.description: [BlackEnergy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0089) has gathered information about local network connections using [netstat](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0104).

BlackEnergy.name: Input Capture
BlackEnergy.description: [BlackEnergy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0089) has run a keylogger plug-in on a victim.

ChChes.name: Disabling Security Tools
ChChes.description: [ChChes](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0144) can alter the victim's proxy configuration.

ChChes.name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
ChChes.description: [ChChes](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0144) can encrypt C2 data with a custom technique using MD5, base64-encoding, and RC4.

ChChes.name: Remote File Copy
ChChes.description: [ChChes](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0144) is capable of downloading files, including additional modules.

ChChes.name: Masquerading
ChChes.description: [ChChes](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0144) copies itself to an .exe file with a filename that is likely intended to imitate Norton Antivirus but has several letters reversed (e.g. notron.exe).

ChChes.name: Code Signing
ChChes.description: [ChChes](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0144) samples were digitally signed with a certificate originally used by Hacking Team that was later leaked and subsequently revoked.

ChChes.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
ChChes.description: [ChChes](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0144) communicates to its C2 server over HTTP and embeds data within the Cookie HTTP header.

ChChes.name: System Information Discovery
ChChes.description: [ChChes](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0144) collects the victim hostname, window resolution, and Microsoft Windows version.

ChChes.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
ChChes.description: [ChChes](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0144) establishes persistence by adding a Registry Run key.

ChChes.name: Process Discovery
ChChes.description: [ChChes](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0144) collects its process identifier (PID) on the victim.

ChChes.name: Credential Dumping
ChChes.description: [ChChes](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0144) steals credentials stored inside Internet Explorer.

ChChes.name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
ChChes.description: [ChChes](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0144) can encrypt C2 traffic with AES.

ChChes.name: File and Directory Discovery
ChChes.description: [ChChes](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0144) collects the victim's %TEMP% directory path and version of Internet Explorer.

Catchamas.name: Clipboard Data
Catchamas.description: [Catchamas](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0261) steals data stored in the clipboard.

Catchamas.name: Data Staged
Catchamas.description: [Catchamas](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0261) stores the gathered data from the machine in .db files and .bmp files under four separate locations.

Catchamas.name: Application Window Discovery
Catchamas.description: [Catchamas](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0261) obtains application windows titles and then determines which windows to perform [Screen Capture](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1113) on.

Catchamas.name: Modify Registry
Catchamas.description: [Catchamas](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0261) creates three Registry keys to establish persistence by adding a [New Service](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1050).

Catchamas.name: Masquerading
Catchamas.description: [Catchamas](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0261) adds a new service named NetAdapter in an apparent attempt to masquerade as a legitimate service.

Catchamas.name: New Service
Catchamas.description: [Catchamas](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0261) adds a new service named NetAdapter to establish persistence.

Catchamas.name: Input Capture
Catchamas.description: [Catchamas](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0261) collects keystrokes from the victim’s machine.

Catchamas.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Catchamas.description: [Catchamas](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0261) gathers the Mac address, IP address, and the network adapter information from the victim’s machine.

Catchamas.name: Screen Capture
Catchamas.description: [Catchamas](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0261) captures screenshots based on specific keywords in the window’s title.

FinFisher.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
FinFisher.description: [FinFisher](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0182) is heavily obfuscated in many ways, including through the use of spaghetti code in its functions in an effort to confuse disassembly programs. It also uses a custom XOR algorithm to obfuscate code.

FinFisher.name: Hooking
FinFisher.description: [FinFisher](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0182) hooks processes by modifying IAT pointers to CreateWindowEx.

FinFisher.name: Access Token Manipulation
FinFisher.description: [FinFisher](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0182) uses token manipulation with NtFilterToken as part of UAC bypass.

FinFisher.name: DLL Search Order Hijacking
FinFisher.description: A [FinFisher](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0182) variant uses DLL search order hijacking.

FinFisher.name: DLL Side-Loading
FinFisher.description: [FinFisher](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0182) uses DLL side-loading to load malicious programs.

FinFisher.name: Screen Capture
FinFisher.description: [FinFisher](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0182) takes a screenshot of the screen and displays it on top of all other windows for few seconds in an apparent attempt to hide some messages showed by the system during the setup process.

FinFisher.name: Indicator Removal on Host
FinFisher.description: [FinFisher](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0182) clears the system event logs.

FinFisher.name: Process Injection
FinFisher.description: [FinFisher](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0182) injects itself into various processes depending on whether it is low integrity or high integrity.

FinFisher.name: File and Directory Discovery
FinFisher.description: [FinFisher](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0182) enumerates directories and scans for certain files.

FinFisher.name: Bypass User Account Control
FinFisher.description: [FinFisher](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0182) performs UAC bypass.

FinFisher.name: New Service
FinFisher.description: [FinFisher](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0182) creates a new Windows service with the malicious executable for persistence.

FinFisher.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
FinFisher.description: [FinFisher](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0182) extracts and decrypts stage 3 malware, which is stored in encrypted resources.

FinFisher.name: Binary Padding
FinFisher.description: [FinFisher](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0182) contains junk code in its functions in an effort to confuse disassembly programs.

FinFisher.name: System Information Discovery
FinFisher.description: [FinFisher](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0182) checks if the victim OS is 32 or 64-bit.

FinFisher.name: Query Registry
FinFisher.description: [FinFisher](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0182) queries Registry values as part of its anti-sandbox checks.

FinFisher.name: Security Software Discovery
FinFisher.description: [FinFisher](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0182) probes the system to check for antimalware processes.

FinFisher.name: Process Discovery
FinFisher.description: [FinFisher](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0182) checks its parent process for indications that it is running in a sandbox setup.

FinFisher.name: Software Packing
FinFisher.description: A [FinFisher](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0182) variant uses a custom packer.

FinFisher.name: Masquerading
FinFisher.description: [FinFisher](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0182) renames one of its .dll files to uxtheme.dll in an apparent attempt to masquerade as a legitimate file.

FinFisher.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
FinFisher.description: [FinFisher](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0182) establishes persistence by creating the Registry key HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\Run.

FinFisher.name: Bootkit
FinFisher.description: Some [FinFisher](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0182) variants incorporate an MBR rootkit.

FinFisher.name: Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion
FinFisher.description: [FinFisher](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0182) probes the system to check for sandbox/virtualized environments.

InvisiMole.name: Network Share Discovery
InvisiMole.description: [InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) can gather network share information.

InvisiMole.name: Data Encrypted
InvisiMole.description: [InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) uses a variation of the XOR cipher to encrypt files before exfiltration.

InvisiMole.name: Automated Collection
InvisiMole.description: Each time a new drive is inserted, [InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) generates a list of all files on the drive and stores it in an encrypted file.

InvisiMole.name: Process Discovery
InvisiMole.description: [InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) obtains a list of running processes.

InvisiMole.name: Query Registry
InvisiMole.description: [InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) can enumerate Registry values, keys, and data.

InvisiMole.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
InvisiMole.description: [InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) avoids analysis by encrypting all strings, internal files, configuration data.

InvisiMole.name: Video Capture
InvisiMole.description: [InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) can remotely activate the victim’s webcam to capture content.

InvisiMole.name: File Deletion
InvisiMole.description: [InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) has a command to delete a file and deletes files after they have been successfully uploaded to C2 servers.

InvisiMole.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
InvisiMole.description: [InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) gathers informatin on the IP forwarding table, MAC address, and network SSID.

InvisiMole.name: Bypass User Account Control
InvisiMole.description: [InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) can bypass UAC and create an elevated COM object to escalate privileges.

InvisiMole.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
InvisiMole.description: [InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) can decrypt, unpack and load a DLL from its resources.

InvisiMole.name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
InvisiMole.description: [InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) communicates with its C2 servers through a TCP socket.

InvisiMole.name: File and Directory Discovery
InvisiMole.description: [InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) can lists information about files in a directory.

InvisiMole.name: Masquerading
InvisiMole.description: [InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) saves one of its files as mpr.dll in the Windows folder, masquerading as a legitimate library file.

InvisiMole.name: Modify Registry
InvisiMole.description: [InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) has a command to create, set, copy, or delete a specified Registry key or value.

InvisiMole.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
InvisiMole.description: [InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) uses HTTP for C2 communications.

InvisiMole.name: System Information Discovery
InvisiMole.description: [InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) can gather information on the mapped drives, OS version, computer name, and memory size.

InvisiMole.name: Account Discovery
InvisiMole.description: [InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) has a command to list account information on the victim’s machine.

InvisiMole.name: Commonly Used Port
InvisiMole.description: [InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) uses port 80 for C2.

InvisiMole.name: Screen Capture
InvisiMole.description: [InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) can capture screenshots of not only the entire screen, but of each separate window open, in case they are overlapping.

InvisiMole.name: Disabling Security Tools
InvisiMole.description: [InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) has a command to disable routing and the Firewall on the victim’s machine.

InvisiMole.name: Timestomp
InvisiMole.description: [InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) samples were timestomped by the authors by setting the PE timestamps to all zero values. [InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) also has a built-in command to modify file times.

InvisiMole.name: System Owner/User Discovery
InvisiMole.description: [InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) lists local users and session information.

InvisiMole.name: Remote File Copy
InvisiMole.description: [InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) can upload files to the victim's machine for operations.

InvisiMole.name: DLL Search Order Hijacking
InvisiMole.description: [InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) can be launched by using DLL search order hijacking in which the wrapper DLL is placed in the same folder as explorer.exe and loaded during startup into the Windows Explorer process instead of the legitimate library.

InvisiMole.name: Audio Capture
InvisiMole.description: [InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) can record sound using input audio devices.

InvisiMole.name: Connection Proxy
InvisiMole.description: [InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) can function as a proxy to create a serve that relays communication between the client and C&C server.

InvisiMole.name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
InvisiMole.description: [InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) uses variations of a simple XOR encryption routine for C&C communications.

InvisiMole.name: System Time Discovery
InvisiMole.description: [InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) gathers the local system time from the victim’s machine.

InvisiMole.name: Command-Line Interface
InvisiMole.description: [InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) can launch a remote shell to execute commands.

InvisiMole.name: Data Staged
InvisiMole.description: [InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) determines a working directory where it stores all the gathered data about the compromised machine.

InvisiMole.name: Data Compressed
InvisiMole.description: [InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) uses WinRAR to compress data that is intended to be exfiltrated.

InvisiMole.name: System Service Discovery
InvisiMole.description: [InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) can obtain running services on the victim.

Naid.name: System Information Discovery
Naid.description: [Naid](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0205) collects a unique identifier (UID) from a compromised host.

Naid.name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
Naid.description: [Naid](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0205) connects to C2 infrastructure and establishes backdoors over a custom communications protocol.

Naid.name: Commonly Used Port
Naid.description: [Naid](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0205) connects to external C2 infrastructure over port 443.

Naid.name: Modify Registry
Naid.description: [Naid](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0205) creates Registry entries that store information about a created service and point to a malicious DLL dropped to disk.

Naid.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Naid.description: [Naid](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0205) collects the domain name from a compromised host.

Naid.name: New Service
Naid.description: [Naid](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0205) creates a new service to establish.

MacSpy.name: Audio Capture
MacSpy.description: [MacSpy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0282) can record the sounds from microphones on a computer.

MacSpy.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
MacSpy.description: [MacSpy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0282) uses HTTP for command and control.

MacSpy.name: File Deletion
MacSpy.description: [MacSpy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0282) deletes any temporary files it creates

MacSpy.name: Screen Capture
MacSpy.description: [MacSpy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0282) can capture screenshots of the desktop over multiple monitors.

MacSpy.name: Multi-hop Proxy
MacSpy.description: [MacSpy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0282) uses Tor for command and control.

CrossRAT.name: File and Directory Discovery
CrossRAT.description: [CrossRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0235) can list all files on a system.

CrossRAT.name: Launch Agent
CrossRAT.description: [CrossRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0235) creates a Launch Agent on macOS.

CrossRAT.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
CrossRAT.description: [CrossRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0235) uses run keys for persistence on Windows

CrossRAT.name: Screen Capture
CrossRAT.description: [CrossRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0235) is capable of taking screen captures.

RawPOS.name: Data from Local System
RawPOS.description: [RawPOS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0169) dumps memory from specific processes on a victim system, parses the dumped files, and scrapes them for credit card data.

RawPOS.name: New Service
RawPOS.description: [RawPOS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0169) installs itself as a service to maintain persistence.

RawPOS.name: Masquerading
RawPOS.description: New services created by [RawPOS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0169) are made to appear like legitimate Windows services, with names such as "Windows Management Help Service", "Microsoft Support", and "Windows Advanced Task Manager".

RawPOS.name: Data Staged
RawPOS.description: Data captured by [RawPOS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0169) is placed in a temporary file under a directory named "memdump".

RawPOS.name: Data Encrypted
RawPOS.description: [RawPOS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0169) encodes credit card data it collected from the victim with XOR.

HAMMERTOSS.name: Web Service
HAMMERTOSS.description: The "tDiscoverer" variant of [HAMMERTOSS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0037) establishes a C2 channel by downloading resources from Web services like Twitter and GitHub. [HAMMERTOSS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0037) binaries contain an algorithm that generates a different Twitter handle for the malware to check for instructions every day.

HAMMERTOSS.name: Data Obfuscation
HAMMERTOSS.description: [HAMMERTOSS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0037) is controlled via commands that are appended to image files.

HAMMERTOSS.name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
HAMMERTOSS.description: Before being appended to image files, [HAMMERTOSS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0037) commands are encrypted with a key composed of both a hard-coded value and a string contained on that day's tweet. To decrypt the commands, an investigator would need access to the intended malware sample, the day's tweet, and the image file containing the command.

HAMMERTOSS.name: Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol
HAMMERTOSS.description: [HAMMERTOSS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0037) exfiltrates data by uploading it to accounts created by the actors on Web cloud storage providers for the adversaries to retrieve later.

HAMMERTOSS.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
HAMMERTOSS.description: The "Uploader" variant of [HAMMERTOSS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0037) visits a hard-coded server over HTTP/S to download the images [HAMMERTOSS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0037) uses to receive commands.

Briba.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Briba.description: [Briba](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0204) creates run key Registry entries pointing to malicious DLLs dropped to disk.

Briba.name: Rundll32
Briba.description: [Briba](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0204) uses rundll32 within [Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1060) entries to execute malicious DLLs.

Briba.name: New Service
Briba.description: [Briba](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0204) installs a service pointing to a malicious DLL dropped to disk.

Briba.name: Commonly Used Port
Briba.description: [Briba](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0204) connects to external C2 infrastructure over port 443.

Derusbi.name: Screen Capture
Derusbi.description: [Derusbi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0021) is capable of performing screen captures.

Derusbi.name: Audio Capture
Derusbi.description: [Derusbi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0021) is capable of performing audio captures.

Derusbi.name: System Owner/User Discovery
Derusbi.description: A Linux version of [Derusbi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0021) checks if the victim user ID is anything other than zero (normally used for root), and the malware will not execute if it does not have root privileges. [Derusbi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0021) also gathers the username of the victim.

Derusbi.name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
Derusbi.description: [Derusbi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0021) obfuscates C2 traffic with variable 4-byte XOR keys.

Derusbi.name: Process Injection
Derusbi.description: [Derusbi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0021) injects itself into the secure shell (SSH) process.

Derusbi.name: Process Discovery
Derusbi.description: [Derusbi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0021) collects current and parent process IDs.

Derusbi.name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
Derusbi.description: [Derusbi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0021) binds to a raw socket on a random source port between 31800 and 31900 for C2.

Derusbi.name: File and Directory Discovery
Derusbi.description: [Derusbi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0021) is capable of obtaining directory, file, and drive listings.

Derusbi.name: Standard Non-Application Layer Protocol
Derusbi.description: [Derusbi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0021) binds to a raw socket on a random source port between 31800 and 31900 for C2.

Derusbi.name: Query Registry
Derusbi.description: [Derusbi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0021) is capable of enumerating Registry keys and values.

Derusbi.name: Command-Line Interface
Derusbi.description: [Derusbi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0021) is capable of creating a remote Bash shell and executing commands.

Derusbi.name: File Deletion
Derusbi.description: [Derusbi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0021) is capable of deleting files. It has been observed loading a Linux Kernel Module (LKM) and then deleting it from the hard disk as well as overwriting the data with null bytes.

Derusbi.name: System Information Discovery
Derusbi.description: [Derusbi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0021) gathers the name of the local host, version of GNU Compiler Collection (GCC), and the system information about the CPU, machine, and operating system.

Derusbi.name: Fallback Channels
Derusbi.description: [Derusbi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0021) uses a backup communication method with an HTTP beacon.

Derusbi.name: Regsvr32
Derusbi.description: [Derusbi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0021) variants have been seen that use Registry persistence to proxy execution through regsvr32.exe.

Crimson.name: System Information Discovery
Crimson.description: [Crimson](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0115) contains a command to collect the victim PC name and operating system.

Crimson.name: Security Software Discovery
Crimson.description: [Crimson](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0115) contains a command to collect information about anti-virus software on the victim.

Crimson.name: Credential Dumping
Crimson.description: [Crimson](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0115) contains a module to steal credentials from Web browsers on the victim machine.

Crimson.name: Process Discovery
Crimson.description: [Crimson](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0115) contains a command to list processes.

Crimson.name: Screen Capture
Crimson.description: [Crimson](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0115) contains a command to perform screen captures.

Crimson.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Crimson.description: [Crimson](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0115) contains a command to collect the victim MAC address and LAN IP.

Crimson.name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
Crimson.description: [Crimson](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0115) uses a custom TCP protocol for C2.

Crimson.name: Standard Non-Application Layer Protocol
Crimson.description: [Crimson](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0115) uses a custom TCP protocol for C2.

Crimson.name: Remote File Copy
Crimson.description: [Crimson](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0115) contains a command to retrieve files from its C2 server.

Crimson.name: Email Collection
Crimson.description: [Crimson](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0115) contains a command to collect and exfiltrate emails from Outlook.

Crimson.name: File and Directory Discovery
Crimson.description: [Crimson](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0115) contains commands to list files and directories, as well as search for files matching certain extensions from a defined list.

Crimson.name: Data from Removable Media
Crimson.description: [Crimson](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0115) contains a module to collect data from removable drives.

MiniDuke.name: Remote File Copy
MiniDuke.description: [MiniDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0051) can download additional encrypted backdoors onto the victim via GIF files.

MiniDuke.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
MiniDuke.description: [MiniDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0051) uses HTTP and HTTPS for command and control.

MiniDuke.name: Web Service
MiniDuke.description: Some [MiniDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0051) components use Twitter to initially obtain the address of a C2 server or as a backup if no hard-coded C2 server responds.

MiniDuke.name: Fallback Channels
MiniDuke.description: [MiniDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0051) uses Google Search to identify C2 servers if its primary C2 method via Twitter is not working.

Matroyshka.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Matroyshka.description: [Matroyshka](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0167) can establish persistence by adding Registry Run keys.

Matroyshka.name: Rundll32
Matroyshka.description: [Matroyshka](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0167) uses rundll32.exe in a Registry Run key value for execution as part of its persistence mechanism.

Matroyshka.name: Screen Capture
Matroyshka.description: [Matroyshka](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0167) is capable of performing screen captures.

Matroyshka.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Matroyshka.description: [Matroyshka](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0167) obfuscates API function names using a substitute cipher combined with Base64 encoding.

Matroyshka.name: Command-Line Interface
Matroyshka.description: [Matroyshka](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0167) is capable of providing Meterpreter shell access.

Matroyshka.name: Credential Dumping
Matroyshka.description: [Matroyshka](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0167) is capable of stealing Outlook passwords.

Matroyshka.name: Process Injection
Matroyshka.description: [Matroyshka](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0167) uses reflective DLL injection to inject the malicious library and execute the RAT.

Matroyshka.name: Scheduled Task
Matroyshka.description: [Matroyshka](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0167) can establish persistence by adding a Scheduled Task named "Microsoft Boost Kernel Optimization".

MoonWind.name: Scripting
MoonWind.description: [MoonWind](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0149) uses batch scripts for various purposes, including to restart and uninstall itself.

MoonWind.name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
MoonWind.description: [MoonWind](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0149) completes network communication via raw sockets.

MoonWind.name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
MoonWind.description: [MoonWind](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0149) encrypts C2 traffic using RC4 with a static key.

MoonWind.name: Commonly Used Port
MoonWind.description: [MoonWind](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0149) communicates over ports 80, 443, 53, and 8080 via raw sockets instead of the protocols usually associated with the ports.

MoonWind.name: File and Directory Discovery
MoonWind.description: [MoonWind](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0149) has a command to return a directory listing for a specified directory.

MoonWind.name: New Service
MoonWind.description: [MoonWind](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0149) installs itself as a new service with automatic startup to establish persistence. The service checks every 60 seconds to determine if the malware is running; if not, it will spawn a new instance.

MoonWind.name: Data Staged
MoonWind.description: [MoonWind](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0149) saves information from its keylogging routine as a .zip file in the present working directory.

MoonWind.name: Command-Line Interface
MoonWind.description: [MoonWind](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0149) can execute commands via an interactive command shell.

MoonWind.name: Process Discovery
MoonWind.description: [MoonWind](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0149) has a command to return a list of running processes.

MoonWind.name: System Information Discovery
MoonWind.description: [MoonWind](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0149) can obtain the victim hostname, Windows version, RAM amount, number of drives, and screen resolution.

MoonWind.name: Peripheral Device Discovery
MoonWind.description: [MoonWind](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0149) obtains the number of removable drives from the victim.

MoonWind.name: File Deletion
MoonWind.description: [MoonWind](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0149) can delete itself or specified files.

MoonWind.name: Standard Non-Application Layer Protocol
MoonWind.description: [MoonWind](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0149) completes network communication via raw sockets.

Pteranodon.name: Command-Line Interface
Pteranodon.description: [Pteranodon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0147) can execute commands on the victim.

Pteranodon.name: Screen Capture
Pteranodon.description: [Pteranodon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0147) can capture screenshots at a configurable interval.

Pteranodon.name: Remote File Copy
Pteranodon.description: [Pteranodon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0147) can download and execute additional files.

Pteranodon.name: File Deletion
Pteranodon.description: [Pteranodon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0147) can delete files that may interfere with it executing. It also can delete temporary files and itself after the initial script executes.

Pteranodon.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Pteranodon.description: [Pteranodon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0147) copies itself to the Startup folder to establish persistence.

Pteranodon.name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
Pteranodon.description: [Pteranodon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0147) exfiltrates screenshot files to its C2 server.

Pteranodon.name: Data Staged
Pteranodon.description: [Pteranodon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0147) creates various subdirectories under %Temp%\reports\% and copies files to those subdirectories. It also creates a folder at C:\Users\\AppData\Roaming\Microsoft\store to store screenshot JPEG files.

Pteranodon.name: Scheduled Task
Pteranodon.description: [Pteranodon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0147) schedules tasks to invoke its components in order to establish persistence.

Pteranodon.name: File and Directory Discovery
Pteranodon.description: [Pteranodon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0147) identifies files matching certain file extension and copies them to subdirectories it created.

Bandook.name: Screen Capture
Bandook.description: [Bandook](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0234) is capable of taking an image of and uploading the current desktop.

Bandook.name: Video Capture
Bandook.description: [Bandook](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0234) has modules that are capable of capturing from a victim's webcam.

Bandook.name: Audio Capture
Bandook.description: [Bandook](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0234) has modules that are capable of capturing audio.

Bandook.name: Command-Line Interface
Bandook.description: [Bandook](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0234) is capable of spawning a Windows command shell.

Bandook.name: Process Hollowing
Bandook.description: [Bandook](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0234) has been launched by starting iexplore.exe and replacing it with [Bandook](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0234)'s payload.

HOMEFRY.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
HOMEFRY.description: Some strings in [HOMEFRY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0232) are obfuscated with XOR x56.

Mosquito.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
Mosquito.description: [Mosquito](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0256)'s installer uses WMI to search for antivirus display names.

Mosquito.name: Remote File Copy
Mosquito.description: [Mosquito](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0256) can upload and download files to the victim.

Mosquito.name: Command-Line Interface
Mosquito.description: [Mosquito](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0256) executes cmd.exe and uses a pipe to read the results and send back the output to the C2 server.

Mosquito.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Mosquito.description: [Mosquito](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0256) establishes persistence under the Registry key HKCU\Software\Run auto_update.

Mosquito.name: Component Object Model Hijacking
Mosquito.description: [Mosquito](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0256) uses COM hijacking as a method of persistence.

Mosquito.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Mosquito.description: [Mosquito](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0256)’s installer is obfuscated with a custom crypter to obfuscate the installer.

Mosquito.name: File Deletion
Mosquito.description: [Mosquito](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0256) deletes files using DeleteFileW API call.

Mosquito.name: Security Software Discovery
Mosquito.description: [Mosquito](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0256)'s installer searches the Registry and system to see if specific antivirus tools are installed on the system.

Mosquito.name: Modify Registry
Mosquito.description: [Mosquito](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0256) stores configuration values under the Registry key HKCU\Software\Microsoft\[dllname] and modifies Registry keys under HKCR\CLSID\...\InprocServer32with a path to the launcher.

Mosquito.name: Execution through API
Mosquito.description: [Mosquito](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0256) leverages the CreateProcess() and LoadLibrary() calls to execute files with the .dll and .exe extensions.

Mosquito.name: Rundll32
Mosquito.description: [Mosquito](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0256)'s launcher uses rundll32.exe in a Registry Key value to start the main backdoor capability.

Mosquito.name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
Mosquito.description: [Mosquito](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0256) uses a custom encryption algorithm, which consists of XOR and a stream that is similar to the Blum Blum Shub algorithm.

Linfo.name: Command-Line Interface
Linfo.description: [Linfo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0211) creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can start a remote shell.

Linfo.name: Scheduled Transfer
Linfo.description: [Linfo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0211) creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can change the frequency at which compromised hosts contact remote C2 infrastructure.

Linfo.name: File Deletion
Linfo.description: [Linfo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0211) creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can delete files.

Linfo.name: System Information Discovery
Linfo.description: [Linfo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0211) creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can retrieve system information.

Linfo.name: Fallback Channels
Linfo.description: [Linfo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0211) creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can change C2 servers.

Linfo.name: Data from Local System
Linfo.description: [Linfo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0211) creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can obtain data from local systems.

Linfo.name: File and Directory Discovery
Linfo.description: [Linfo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0211) creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can list contents of drives and search for files.

Linfo.name: Process Discovery
Linfo.description: [Linfo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0211) creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can retrieve a list of running processes.

Linfo.name: Remote File Copy
Linfo.description: [Linfo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0211) creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can download files onto compromised hosts.

Brave Prince.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Brave Prince.description: [Brave Prince](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0252) gathers network configuration information as well as the ARP cache.

Brave Prince.name: System Information Discovery
Brave Prince.description: [Brave Prince](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0252) collects hard drive content and system configuration information.

Brave Prince.name: File and Directory Discovery
Brave Prince.description: [Brave Prince](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0252) gathers file and directory information from the victim’s machine.

Brave Prince.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Brave Prince.description: Some [Brave Prince](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0252) variants have used South Korea's Daum email service to exfiltrate information, and later variants have posted the data to a web server via an HTTP post command.

Mivast.name: Command-Line Interface
Mivast.description: [Mivast](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0080) has the capability to open a remote shell and run basic commands.

Mivast.name: Remote File Copy
Mivast.description: [Mivast](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0080) has the capability to download and execute .exe files.

Mivast.name: Credential Dumping
Mivast.description: [Mivast](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0080) has the capability to gather NTLM password information.

CosmicDuke.name: New Service
CosmicDuke.description: [CosmicDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0050) uses Windows services typically named "javamtsup" for persistence.

CosmicDuke.name: Automated Exfiltration
CosmicDuke.description: [CosmicDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0050) exfiltrates collected files automatically over FTP to remote servers.

CosmicDuke.name: Credential Dumping
CosmicDuke.description: [CosmicDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0050) collects user credentials, including passwords, for various programs and browsers, including popular instant messaging applications, Web browsers, and email clients. Windows account hashes, domain accounts, and LSA secrets are also collected, as are WLAN keys.

CosmicDuke.name: Screen Capture
CosmicDuke.description: [CosmicDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0050) takes periodic screenshots and exfiltrates them.

CosmicDuke.name: Data from Removable Media
CosmicDuke.description: [CosmicDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0050) steals user files from removable media with file extensions and keywords that match a predefined list.

CosmicDuke.name: Email Collection
CosmicDuke.description: [CosmicDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0050) searches for Microsoft Outlook data files with extensions .pst and .ost for collection and exfiltration.

CosmicDuke.name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
CosmicDuke.description: [CosmicDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0050) attempts to exploit privilege escalation vulnerabilities CVE-2010-0232 or CVE-2010-4398.

CosmicDuke.name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
CosmicDuke.description: [CosmicDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0050) contains a custom version of the RC4 algorithm that includes a programming error.

CosmicDuke.name: Data from Network Shared Drive
CosmicDuke.description: [CosmicDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0050) steals user files from network shared drives with file extensions and keywords that match a predefined list.

CosmicDuke.name: Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol
CosmicDuke.description: [CosmicDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0050) exfiltrates collected files over FTP or WebDAV. Exfiltration servers can be separately configured from C2 servers.

CosmicDuke.name: File and Directory Discovery
CosmicDuke.description: [CosmicDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0050) searches attached and mounted drives for file extensions and keywords that match a predefined list.

CosmicDuke.name: Data from Local System
CosmicDuke.description: [CosmicDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0050) steals user files from local hard drives with file extensions that match a predefined list.

CosmicDuke.name: Scheduled Task
CosmicDuke.description: [CosmicDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0050) uses scheduled tasks typically named "Watchmon Service" for persistence.

CosmicDuke.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
CosmicDuke.description: [CosmicDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0050) can use HTTP or HTTPS for command and control to hard-coded C2 servers.

CosmicDuke.name: Clipboard Data
CosmicDuke.description: [CosmicDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0050) copies and exfiltrates the clipboard contents every 30 seconds.

CosmicDuke.name: Input Capture
CosmicDuke.description: [CosmicDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0050) uses a keylogger and steals clipboard contents from victims.

Comnie.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Comnie.description: [Comnie](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0244) uses ipconfig /all and route PRINT to identify network adapter and interface information.

Comnie.name: Process Discovery
Comnie.description: [Comnie](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0244) uses the tasklist to view running processes on the victim’s machine.

Comnie.name: Web Service
Comnie.description: [Comnie](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0244) uses blogs and third-party sites (GitHub, tumbler, and BlogSpot) to avoid DNS-based blocking of their communication to the command and control server.

Comnie.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Comnie.description: [Comnie](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0244) achieves persistence by adding a shortcut of itself to the startup path in the Registry.

Comnie.name: Automated Collection
Comnie.description: [Comnie](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0244) executes a batch script to store discovery information in %TEMP%\info.dat and then uploads the temporarily file to the remote C2 server.

Comnie.name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Comnie.description: [Comnie](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0244) encrypts command and control communications with RC4.

Comnie.name: Rundll32
Comnie.description: [Comnie](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0244) uses Rundll32 to load a malicious DLL.

Comnie.name: Binary Padding
Comnie.description: [Comnie](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0244) appends a total of 64MB of garbage data to a file to deter any security products in place that may be scanning files on disk.

Comnie.name: System Service Discovery
Comnie.description: [Comnie](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0244) runs the command: net start >> %TEMP%\info.dat on a victim.

Comnie.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Comnie.description: [Comnie](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0244) uses RC4 and Base64 to obfuscate strings.

Comnie.name: System Information Discovery
Comnie.description: [Comnie](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0244) collects the hostname of the victim machine.

Comnie.name: Shortcut Modification
Comnie.description: [Comnie](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0244) establishes persistence via a .lnk file in the victim’s startup path.

Comnie.name: Commonly Used Port
Comnie.description: [Comnie](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0244) uses Port Numbers 80, 8080, 8000, and 443 for communication to the C2 servers.

Comnie.name: Security Software Discovery
Comnie.description: [Comnie](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0244) attempts to detect several anti-virus products.

EvilGrab.name: Input Capture
EvilGrab.description: [EvilGrab](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0152) has the capability to capture keystrokes.

EvilGrab.name: Audio Capture
EvilGrab.description: [EvilGrab](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0152) has the capability to capture audio from a victim machine.

EvilGrab.name: Video Capture
EvilGrab.description: [EvilGrab](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0152) has the capability to capture video from a victim machine.

EvilGrab.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
EvilGrab.description: [EvilGrab](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0152) adds a Registry Run key for ctfmon.exe to establish persistence.

EvilGrab.name: Screen Capture
EvilGrab.description: [EvilGrab](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0152) has the capability to capture screenshots.

Hydraq.name: New Service
Hydraq.description: [Hydraq](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0203) creates new services to establish persistence.

Hydraq.name: Query Registry
Hydraq.description: [Hydraq](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0203) creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can retrieve system information, such as CPU speed, from Registry keys.

Hydraq.name: Access Token Manipulation
Hydraq.description: [Hydraq](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0203) creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can adjust token privileges.

Hydraq.name: File and Directory Discovery
Hydraq.description: [Hydraq](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0203) creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can check for the existence of files, including its own components, as well as retrieve a list of logical drives.

Hydraq.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Hydraq.description: [Hydraq](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0203) creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can retrieve IP addresses of compromised machines.

Hydraq.name: Remote File Copy
Hydraq.description: [Hydraq](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0203) creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can download files and additional malware components.

Hydraq.name: System Service Discovery
Hydraq.description: [Hydraq](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0203) creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can monitor services.

Hydraq.name: File Deletion
Hydraq.description: [Hydraq](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0203) creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can delete files.

Hydraq.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Hydraq.description: [Hydraq](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0203) uses basic obfuscation in the form of spaghetti code.

Hydraq.name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
Hydraq.description: [Hydraq](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0203) C2 traffic is encrypted using bitwise NOT and XOR operations.

Hydraq.name: Modify Registry
Hydraq.description: [Hydraq](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0203) creates a Registry subkey to register its created service, and can also uninstall itself later by deleting this value. [Hydraq](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0203)'s backdoor also enables remote attackers to modify and delete subkeys.

Hydraq.name: Service Execution
Hydraq.description: [Hydraq](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0203) uses svchost.exe to execute a malicious DLL included in a new service group.

Hydraq.name: Process Discovery
Hydraq.description: [Hydraq](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0203) creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can monitor processes.

Hydraq.name: Data from Local System
Hydraq.description: [Hydraq](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0203) creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can read data from files.

Hydraq.name: System Information Discovery
Hydraq.description: [Hydraq](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0203) creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can retrieve information such as computer name, OS version, processor speed, memory size, and CPU speed.

Hydraq.name: Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol
Hydraq.description: [Hydraq](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0203) connects to a predefined domain on port 443 to exfil gathered information.

Hydraq.name: Execution through Module Load
Hydraq.description: [Hydraq](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0203) creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can load and call DLL functions.

Hydraq.name: Screen Capture
Hydraq.description: [Hydraq](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0203) includes a component based on the code of VNC that can stream a live feed of the desktop of an infected host.

Hydraq.name: Indicator Removal on Host
Hydraq.description: [Hydraq](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0203) creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can clear all system event logs.

More_eggs.name: File Deletion
More_eggs.description: [More_eggs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0284) can remove itself from a system.

More_eggs.name: Remote File Copy
More_eggs.description: [More_eggs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0284) can download and launch additional payloads.

More_eggs.name: System Information Discovery
More_eggs.description: [More_eggs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0284) has the capability to gather the OS version and computer name.

More_eggs.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
More_eggs.description: [More_eggs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0284) has the capability to gather the IP address from the victim's machine.

More_eggs.name: System Owner/User Discovery
More_eggs.description: [More_eggs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0284) has the capability to gather the username from the victim's machine.

More_eggs.name: Security Software Discovery
More_eggs.description: [More_eggs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0284) can obtain information on installed anti-malware programs.

AutoIt backdoor.name: PowerShell
AutoIt backdoor.description: [AutoIt backdoor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0129) downloads a PowerShell script that decodes to a typical shellcode loader.

AutoIt backdoor.name: Bypass User Account Control
AutoIt backdoor.description: [AutoIt backdoor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0129) attempts to escalate privileges by bypassing User Access Control.

AutoIt backdoor.name: Data Encoding
AutoIt backdoor.description: [AutoIt backdoor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0129) has sent a C2 response that was base64-encoded.

AutoIt backdoor.name: File and Directory Discovery
AutoIt backdoor.description: [AutoIt backdoor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0129) is capable of identifying documents on the victim with the following extensions: .doc; .pdf, .csv, .ppt, .docx, .pst, .xls, .xlsx, .pptx, and .jpeg.

POSHSPY.name: Timestomp
POSHSPY.description: [POSHSPY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0150) modifies timestamps of all downloaded executables to match a randomly selected file created prior to 2013.

POSHSPY.name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
POSHSPY.description: [POSHSPY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0150) encrypts C2 traffic with AES and RSA.

POSHSPY.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
POSHSPY.description: [POSHSPY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0150) appends a file signature header (randomly selected from six file types) to encrypted data prior to upload or download.

POSHSPY.name: Remote File Copy
POSHSPY.description: [POSHSPY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0150) downloads and executes additional PowerShell code and Windows binaries.

POSHSPY.name: Windows Management Instrumentation Event Subscription
POSHSPY.description: [POSHSPY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0150) uses a WMI event subscription to establish persistence.

POSHSPY.name: PowerShell
POSHSPY.description: [POSHSPY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0150) uses PowerShell to execute various commands, one to execute its payload.

POSHSPY.name: Domain Generation Algorithms
POSHSPY.description: [POSHSPY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0150) uses a DGA to derive command and control URLs from a word list.

RTM.name: Command-Line Interface
RTM.description: [RTM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0148) uses the command line and rundll32.exe to execute.

RTM.name: Process Discovery
RTM.description: [RTM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0148) can obtain information about process integrity levels.

RTM.name: Remote File Copy
RTM.description: [RTM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0148) can download additional files.

RTM.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
RTM.description: [RTM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0148) strings, network data, configuration, and modules are encrypted with a modified RC4 algorithm.

RTM.name: Indicator Removal on Host
RTM.description: [RTM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0148) has the ability to remove Registry entries that it created during execution.

RTM.name: Clipboard Data
RTM.description: [RTM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0148) collects data from the clipboard.

RTM.name: Peripheral Device Discovery
RTM.description: [RTM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0148) can obtain a list of smart card readers attached to the victim.

RTM.name: Scheduled Task
RTM.description: [RTM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0148) tries to add a scheduled task to establish persistence.

RTM.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
RTM.description: [RTM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0148) tries to add a Registry Run key under the name "Windows Update" to establish persistence.

RTM.name: System Information Discovery
RTM.description: [RTM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0148) can obtain the computer name, OS version, and default language identifier.

RTM.name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
RTM.description: [RTM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0148) encrypts C2 traffic with a custom RC4 variant.

RTM.name: Bypass User Account Control
RTM.description: [RTM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0148) can attempt to run the program as admin, then show a fake error message and a legitimate UAC bypass prompt to the user in an attempt to socially engineer the user into escalating privileges.

RTM.name: File and Directory Discovery
RTM.description: [RTM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0148) can scan victim drives to look for specific banking software on the machine to determine next actions. It also looks at browsing history and open tabs for specific strings.

RTM.name: Input Capture
RTM.description: [RTM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0148) can record keystrokes from both the keyboard and virtual keyboard.

RTM.name: Screen Capture
RTM.description: [RTM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0148) can capture screenshots.

RTM.name: System Time Discovery
RTM.description: [RTM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0148) can obtain the victim time zone.

RTM.name: File Deletion
RTM.description: [RTM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0148) can delete all files created during its execution.

RTM.name: Code Signing
RTM.description: [RTM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0148) samples have been signed with a code-signing certificates.

RTM.name: Modify Registry
RTM.description: [RTM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0148) can delete all Registry entries created during its execution.

RTM.name: System Owner/User Discovery
RTM.description: [RTM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0148) can obtain the victim username and permissions.

RTM.name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
RTM.description: [RTM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0148) uses HTTP POST requests with data formatted using a custom protocol.

RTM.name: Security Software Discovery
RTM.description: [RTM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0148) can obtain information about security software on the victim.

RTM.name: Rundll32
RTM.description: [RTM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0148) runs its core DLL file using rundll32.exe.

RTM.name: Automated Collection
RTM.description: [RTM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0148) monitors browsing activity and automatically captures screenshots if a victim browses to a URL matching one of a list of strings.

RTM.name: Install Root Certificate
RTM.description: [RTM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0148) can add a certificate to the Windows store.

Flame.name: Authentication Package
Flame.description: [Flame](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0143) can use Windows Authentication Packages for persistence.

Flame.name: Exploitation of Remote Services
Flame.description: [Flame](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0143) can use MS10-061 to exploit a print spooler vulnerability in a remote system with a shared printer in order to move laterally.

Flame.name: Exfiltration Over Other Network Medium
Flame.description: [Flame](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0143) has a module named BeetleJuice that contains Bluetooth functionality that may be used in different ways, including transmitting encoded information from the infected system over the Bluetooth protocol, acting as a Bluetooth beacon, and identifying other Bluetooth devices in the vicinity.

Flame.name: Rundll32
Flame.description: Rundll32.exe is used as a way of executing [Flame](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0143) at the command-line.

Flame.name: Create Account
Flame.description: [Flame](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0143) can create backdoor accounts with the login "HelpAssistant" with the Limbo module.

Flame.name: Audio Capture
Flame.description: [Flame](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0143) can record audio using any existing hardware recording devices.

Flame.name: Security Software Discovery
Flame.description: [Flame](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0143) identifies security software such as antivirus through the Security module.

Flame.name: Screen Capture
Flame.description: [Flame](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0143) can take regular screenshots when certain applications are open that are sent to the command and control server.

Flame.name: Replication Through Removable Media
Flame.description: [Flame](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0143) contains modules to infect USB sticks and spread laterally to other Windows systems the stick is plugged into using Autorun functionality.

Smoke Loader.name: Process Hollowing
Smoke Loader.description: [Smoke Loader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0226) spawns a new copy of c:\windows\syswow64\explorer.exe and then replaces the executable code in memory with malware.

Smoke Loader.name: File and Directory Discovery
Smoke Loader.description: [Smoke Loader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0226) recursively searches through directories for files.

Smoke Loader.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Smoke Loader.description: [Smoke Loader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0226) adds a Registry Run key for persistence and adds a script in the Startup folder to deploy the payload.

Smoke Loader.name: Remote File Copy
Smoke Loader.description: [Smoke Loader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0226) downloads a new version of itself once it has installed. It also downloads additional plugins.

Smoke Loader.name: Supply Chain Compromise
Smoke Loader.description: [Smoke Loader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0226) was distributed through a compromised update to a Tor client with a coin miner payload.

Smoke Loader.name: Email Collection
Smoke Loader.description: [Smoke Loader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0226) searches through Outlook files and directories (e.g., inbox, sent, templates, drafts, archives, etc.).

Smoke Loader.name: Credentials in Files
Smoke Loader.description: [Smoke Loader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0226) searches for files named logins.json to parse for credentials.

Smoke Loader.name: Process Injection
Smoke Loader.description: [Smoke Loader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0226) injects into the Internet Explorer process.

Smoke Loader.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Smoke Loader.description: [Smoke Loader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0226) uses a simple one-byte XOR method to obfuscate values in the malware.

Smoke Loader.name: Scripting
Smoke Loader.description: [Smoke Loader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0226) adds a Visual Basic script in the Startup folder to deploy the payload.

Smoke Loader.name: Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion
Smoke Loader.description: [Smoke Loader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0226) scans processes to perform anti-VM checks.

Backdoor.Oldrea.name: Data Obfuscation
Backdoor.Oldrea.description: Some [Backdoor.Oldrea](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0093) samples use standard Base64 + bzip2, and some use standard Base64 + reverse XOR + RSA-2048 to decrypt data received from C2 servers.

Backdoor.Oldrea.name: Credential Dumping
Backdoor.Oldrea.description: Some [Backdoor.Oldrea](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0093) samples contain a publicly available Web browser password recovery tool.

Backdoor.Oldrea.name: System Owner/User Discovery
Backdoor.Oldrea.description: [Backdoor.Oldrea](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0093) collects the current username from the victim.

Backdoor.Oldrea.name: Data Encrypted
Backdoor.Oldrea.description: [Backdoor.Oldrea](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0093) writes collected data to a temporary file in an encrypted form before exfiltration to a C2 server.

Backdoor.Oldrea.name: File Deletion
Backdoor.Oldrea.description: [Backdoor.Oldrea](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0093) contains a cleanup module that removes traces of itself from the victim.

Backdoor.Oldrea.name: Email Collection
Backdoor.Oldrea.description: [Backdoor.Oldrea](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0093) collects address book information from Outlook.

Backdoor.Oldrea.name: File and Directory Discovery
Backdoor.Oldrea.description: [Backdoor.Oldrea](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0093) collects information about available drives, default browser, desktop file list, My Documents, Internet history, program files, and root of available drives. It also searches for ICS-related software files.

Backdoor.Oldrea.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Backdoor.Oldrea.description: [Backdoor.Oldrea](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0093) collects information about the Internet adapter configuration.

Backdoor.Oldrea.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Backdoor.Oldrea.description: [Backdoor.Oldrea](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0093) adds Registry Run keys to achieve persistence.

Backdoor.Oldrea.name: System Information Discovery
Backdoor.Oldrea.description: [Backdoor.Oldrea](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0093) collects information about the OS and computer name.

Kazuar.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Kazuar.description: [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) uses HTTP, HTTPS, FTP, and FTPS to communicate with the C2 server. [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) can also act as a webserver and listen for inbound HTTP requests through an exposed API.

Kazuar.name: Application Window Discovery
Kazuar.description: [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) gathers information about opened windows.

Kazuar.name: Web Service
Kazuar.description: [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) has used compromised WordPress blogs as C2 servers.

Kazuar.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Kazuar.description: [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) is obfuscated using the open source ConfuserEx protector. [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) also obfuscates the name of created files/folders/mutexes and encrypts debug messages written to log files using the Rijndael cipher.

Kazuar.name: System Owner/User Discovery
Kazuar.description: [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) gathers information on users.

Kazuar.name: Process Injection
Kazuar.description: If running in a Windows environment, [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) saves a DLL to disk that is injected into the explorer.exe process to execute the payload. [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) can also be configured to inject and execute within specific processes.

Kazuar.name: File Deletion
Kazuar.description: [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) can delete files.

Kazuar.name: Shortcut Modification
Kazuar.description: [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) adds a .lnk file to the Windows startup folder.

Kazuar.name: Scheduled Transfer
Kazuar.description: [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) can sleep for a specific time and be set to communicate at specific intervals.

Kazuar.name: Account Discovery
Kazuar.description: [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) gathers information on local groups and members on the victim’s machine.

Kazuar.name: Fallback Channels
Kazuar.description: [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) can accept multiple URLs for C2 servers.

Kazuar.name: Video Capture
Kazuar.description: [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) captures images from the webcam.

Kazuar.name: Screen Capture
Kazuar.description: [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) captures screenshots of the victim’s screen.

Kazuar.name: Process Discovery
Kazuar.description: [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) obtains a list of running processes through WMI querying and the ps command.

Kazuar.name: System Information Discovery
Kazuar.description: [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) gathers information on the system and local drives.

Kazuar.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Kazuar.description: [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) gathers information about network adapters.

Kazuar.name: New Service
Kazuar.description: [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) can install itself as a new service.

Kazuar.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Kazuar.description: [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) adds a sub-key under several Registry run keys.

Kazuar.name: File and Directory Discovery
Kazuar.description: [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) finds a specified directory, lists the files and metadata about those files.

Kazuar.name: Data Encoding
Kazuar.description: [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) encodes communications to the C2 server in Base64.

Kazuar.name: Remote File Copy
Kazuar.description: [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) downloads additional plug-ins to load on the victim’s machine, including the ability to upgrade and replace its own binary.

Kazuar.name: Permission Groups Discovery
Kazuar.description: [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) gathers information about local groups and members.

Kazuar.name: Data from Local System
Kazuar.description: [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) uploads files from a specified directory to the C2 server.

Kazuar.name: Command-Line Interface
Kazuar.description: [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) uses cmd.exe and /bin/bash to execute commands on the victim’s machine.

Kazuar.name: Data Staged
Kazuar.description: [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) stages command output and collected data in files before exfiltration.

Kazuar.name: Data Destruction
Kazuar.description: [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) can overwrite files with random data before deleting them.

Kazuar.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
Kazuar.description: [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) obtains a list of running processes through WMI querying.

Cherry Picker.name: File Deletion
Cherry Picker.description: Recent versions of [Cherry Picker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0107) delete files and registry keys created by the malware.

Cherry Picker.name: AppInit DLLs
Cherry Picker.description: Some variants of [Cherry Picker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0107) use AppInit_DLLs to achieve persistence by creating the following Registry key: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Windows "AppInit_DLLs"="pserver32.dll"

USBStealer.name: File Deletion
USBStealer.description: [USBStealer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0136) has several commands to delete files associated with the malware from the victim.

USBStealer.name: Data from Removable Media
USBStealer.description: Once a removable media device is inserted back into the first victim, [USBStealer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0136) collects data from it that was exfiltrated from a second victim.

USBStealer.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
USBStealer.description: Most strings in [USBStealer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0136) are encrypted using 3DES and XOR and reversed.

USBStealer.name: File and Directory Discovery
USBStealer.description: [USBStealer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0136) searches victim drives for files matching certain extensions (“.skr”,“.pkr” or “.key”) or names.

USBStealer.name: Masquerading
USBStealer.description: [USBStealer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0136) mimics a legitimate Russian program called USB Disk Security.

USBStealer.name: Replication Through Removable Media
USBStealer.description: [USBStealer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0136) drops itself onto removable media and relies on Autorun to execute the malicious file when a user opens the removable media on another system.

USBStealer.name: Exfiltration Over Physical Medium
USBStealer.description: [USBStealer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0136) exfiltrates collected files via removable media from air-gapped victims.

USBStealer.name: Data Staged
USBStealer.description: [USBStealer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0136) collects files matching certain criteria from the victim and stores them in a local directory for later exfiltration.

USBStealer.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
USBStealer.description: [USBStealer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0136) registers itself under a Registry Run key with the name "USB Disk Security."

USBStealer.name: Automated Collection
USBStealer.description: For all non-removable drives on a victim, [USBStealer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0136) executes automated collection of certain files for later exfiltration.

USBStealer.name: Peripheral Device Discovery
USBStealer.description: [USBStealer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0136) monitors victims for insertion of removable drives. When dropped onto a second victim, it also enumerates drives connected to the system.

USBStealer.name: Communication Through Removable Media
USBStealer.description: [USBStealer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0136) drops commands for a second victim onto a removable media drive inserted into the first victim, and commands are executed when the drive is inserted into the second victim.

USBStealer.name: Timestomp
USBStealer.description: [USBStealer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0136) sets the timestamps of its dropper files to the last-access and last-write timestamps of a standard Windows library chosen on the system.

USBStealer.name: Automated Exfiltration
USBStealer.description: [USBStealer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0136) automatically exfiltrates collected files via removable media when an infected device is connected to the second victim after receiving commands from the first victim.

H1N1.name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
H1N1.description: [H1N1](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0132) encrypts C2 traffic using an RC4 key.

H1N1.name: Disabling Security Tools
H1N1.description: [H1N1](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0132) kills and disables services for Windows Firewall, Windows Security Center, and Windows Defender.

H1N1.name: Command-Line Interface
H1N1.description: [H1N1](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0132) kills and disables services by using cmd.exe.

H1N1.name: Credential Dumping
H1N1.description: [H1N1](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0132) dumps usernames and passwords from Firefox, Internet Explorer, and Outlook.

H1N1.name: Remote File Copy
H1N1.description: [H1N1](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0132) contains a command to download and execute a file from a remotely hosted URL using WinINet HTTP requests.

H1N1.name: Taint Shared Content
H1N1.description: [H1N1](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0132) has functionality to copy itself to network shares.

H1N1.name: Data Obfuscation
H1N1.description: [H1N1](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0132) obfuscates C2 traffic with an altered version of base64.

H1N1.name: Replication Through Removable Media
H1N1.description: [H1N1](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0132) has functionality to copy itself to removable media.

H1N1.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
H1N1.description: [H1N1](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0132) uses multiple techniques to obfuscate strings, including XOR.

H1N1.name: Inhibit System Recovery
H1N1.description: [H1N1](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0132) disable recovery options and deletes shadow copies from the victim.

H1N1.name: Bypass User Account Control
H1N1.description: [H1N1](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0132) bypasses user access control by using a DLL hijacking vulnerability in the Windows Update Standalone Installer (wusa.exe).

Lurid.name: Data Compressed
Lurid.description: [Lurid](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0010) can compress data before sending it.

TURNEDUP.name: Process Injection
TURNEDUP.description: [TURNEDUP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0199) is capable of injecting code into the APC queue of a created [Rundll32](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1085) process as part of an "Early Bird injection."

TURNEDUP.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
TURNEDUP.description: [TURNEDUP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0199) is capable of writing to a Registry Run key to establish.

TURNEDUP.name: Remote File Copy
