TURNEDUP.description: [TURNEDUP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0199) is capable of downloading additional files.

TURNEDUP.name: System Information Discovery
TURNEDUP.description: [TURNEDUP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0199) is capable of gathering system information.

TURNEDUP.name: Command-Line Interface
TURNEDUP.description: [TURNEDUP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0199) is capable of creating a reverse shell.

Reaver.name: Query Registry
Reaver.description: [Reaver](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0172) queries the Registry to determine the correct Startup path to use for persistence.

Reaver.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Reaver.description: [Reaver](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0172) encrypts some of its files with XOR.

Reaver.name: Control Panel Items
Reaver.description: [Reaver](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0172) drops and executes a malicious CPL file as its payload.

Reaver.name: File Deletion
Reaver.description: [Reaver](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0172) deletes the original dropped file from the victim.

Reaver.name: Standard Non-Application Layer Protocol
Reaver.description: Some [Reaver](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0172) variants use raw TCP for C2.

Reaver.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Reaver.description: [Reaver](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0172) creates a shortcut file and saves it in a Startup folder to establish persistence.

Reaver.name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
Reaver.description: Some [Reaver](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0172) variants use raw TCP for C2.

Reaver.name: New Service
Reaver.description: [Reaver](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0172) installs itself as a new service.

Reaver.name: Data Encrypted
Reaver.description: [Reaver](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0172) encrypts collected data with an incremental XOR key prior to exfiltration.

Reaver.name: System Information Discovery
Reaver.description: [Reaver](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0172) collects system information from the victim, including CPU speed, computer name, volume serial number, ANSI code page, OEM code page identifier for the OS, Microsoft Windows version, and memory information.

Reaver.name: Shortcut Modification
Reaver.description: [Reaver](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0172) creates a shortcut file and saves it in a Startup folder to establish persistence.

Reaver.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Reaver.description: Some [Reaver](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0172) variants use HTTP for C2.

RemoteCMD.name: Service Execution
RemoteCMD.description: [RemoteCMD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0166) can execute commands remotely by creating a new service on the remote system.

RemoteCMD.name: Scheduled Task
RemoteCMD.description: [RemoteCMD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0166) can execute commands remotely by creating a new schedule task on the remote system

RemoteCMD.name: Remote File Copy
RemoteCMD.description: [RemoteCMD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0166) copies a file over to the remote system before execution.

OnionDuke.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
OnionDuke.description: [OnionDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0052) uses HTTP and HTTPS for C2.

OnionDuke.name: Web Service
OnionDuke.description: [OnionDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0052) uses Twitter as a backup C2 method. It also has a module designed to post messages to the Russian VKontakte social media site.

SslMM.name: Masquerading
SslMM.description: To establish persistence, [SslMM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0058) identifies the Start Menu Startup directory and drops a link to its own executable disguised as an “Office Start,” “Yahoo Talk,” “MSN Gaming Z0ne,” or “MSN Talk” shortcut.

SslMM.name: System Information Discovery
SslMM.description: [SslMM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0058) sends information to its hard-coded C2, including OS version, service pack information, processor speed, system name, and OS install date.

SslMM.name: Shortcut Modification
SslMM.description: To establish persistence, [SslMM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0058) identifies the Start Menu Startup directory and drops a link to its own executable disguised as an “Office Start,” “Yahoo Talk,” “MSN Gaming Z0ne,” or “MSN Talk” shortcut.

SslMM.name: Input Capture
SslMM.description: [SslMM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0058) creates a new thread implementing a keylogging facility using Windows Keyboard Accelerators.

SslMM.name: System Owner/User Discovery
SslMM.description: [SslMM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0058) sends the logged-on username to its hard-coded C2.

SslMM.name: Access Token Manipulation
SslMM.description: [SslMM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0058) contains a feature to manipulate process privileges and tokens.

SslMM.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
SslMM.description: To establish persistence, [SslMM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0058) identifies the Start Menu Startup directory and drops a link to its own executable disguised as an “Office Start,” “Yahoo Talk,” “MSN Gaming Z0ne,” or “MSN Talk” shortcut.

SslMM.name: Fallback Channels
SslMM.description: [SslMM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0058) has a hard-coded primary and backup C2 string.

JHUHUGIT.name: Component Object Model Hijacking
JHUHUGIT.description: [JHUHUGIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0044) has used COM hijacking to establish persistence by hijacking a class named MMDeviceEnumerator and also by registering the payload as a Shell Icon Overlay handler COM object ({3543619C-D563-43f7-95EA-4DA7E1CC396A}).

JHUHUGIT.name: Process Injection
JHUHUGIT.description: [JHUHUGIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0044) performs code injection injecting its own functions to browser processes.

JHUHUGIT.name: File Deletion
JHUHUGIT.description: The [JHUHUGIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0044) dropper can delete itself from the victim. Another [JHUHUGIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0044) variant has the capability to delete specified files.

JHUHUGIT.name: Clipboard Data
JHUHUGIT.description: A [JHUHUGIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0044) variant accesses a screenshot saved in the clipboard and converts it to a JPG image.

JHUHUGIT.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
JHUHUGIT.description: [JHUHUGIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0044) has used a Registry Run key to establish persistence by executing JavaScript code within the rundll32.exe process.

JHUHUGIT.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
JHUHUGIT.description: A [JHUHUGIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0044) variant gathers network interface card information.

JHUHUGIT.name: System Information Discovery
JHUHUGIT.description: [JHUHUGIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0044) obtains a build identifier as well as victim hard drive information from Windows registry key HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services\Disk\Enum. Another [JHUHUGIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0044) variant gathers the victim storage volume serial number and the storage device name.

JHUHUGIT.name: Remote File Copy
JHUHUGIT.description: [JHUHUGIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0044) can retrieve an additional payload from its C2 server. [JHUHUGIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0044) has a command to download files to the victim’s machine.

JHUHUGIT.name: Rundll32
JHUHUGIT.description: [JHUHUGIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0044) is executed using rundll32.exe.

JHUHUGIT.name: Screen Capture
JHUHUGIT.description: A [JHUHUGIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0044) variant takes screenshots by simulating the user pressing the "Take Screenshot" key (VK_SCREENSHOT), accessing the screenshot saved in the clipboard, and converting it to a JPG image.

JHUHUGIT.name: Scheduled Task
JHUHUGIT.description: [JHUHUGIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0044) has registered itself as a scheduled task to run each time the current user logs in.

JHUHUGIT.name: New Service
JHUHUGIT.description: [JHUHUGIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0044) has registered itself as a service to establish persistence.

JHUHUGIT.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
JHUHUGIT.description: [JHUHUGIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0044) variants have communicated with C2 servers over HTTP and HTTPS.

JHUHUGIT.name: Scripting
JHUHUGIT.description: [JHUHUGIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0044) uses a .bat file to execute a .dll.

JHUHUGIT.name: Logon Scripts
JHUHUGIT.description: [JHUHUGIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0044) has registered a Windows shell script under the Registry key HKCU\Environment\UserInitMprLogonScript to establish persistence.

JHUHUGIT.name: Data Encoding
JHUHUGIT.description: A [JHUHUGIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0044) variant encodes C2 POST data base64.

JHUHUGIT.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
JHUHUGIT.description: Many strings in [JHUHUGIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0044) are obfuscated with a XOR algorithm.

JHUHUGIT.name: Fallback Channels
JHUHUGIT.description: [JHUHUGIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0044) tests if it can reach its C2 server by first attempting a direct connection, and if it fails, obtaining proxy settings and sending the connection through a proxy, and finally injecting code into a running browser if the proxy method fails.

JHUHUGIT.name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
JHUHUGIT.description: [JHUHUGIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0044) has exploited CVE-2015-1701 and CVE-2015-2387 to escalate privileges.

JHUHUGIT.name: Process Discovery
JHUHUGIT.description: [JHUHUGIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0044) obtains a list of running processes on the victim.

Dok.name: Install Root Certificate
Dok.description: [Dok](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0281) installs a root certificate to aid in man-in-the-middle actions.

Dok.name: Multi-hop Proxy
Dok.description: [Dok](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0281) downloads and installs Tor via homebrew.

Dok.name: AppleScript
Dok.description: [Dok](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0281) uses AppleScript to create a login item for persistence.

NanHaiShu.name: Mshta
NanHaiShu.description: [NanHaiShu](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0228) uses mshta.exe to load its program and files.

NanHaiShu.name: File Deletion
NanHaiShu.description: [NanHaiShu](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0228) launches a script to delete their original decoy file to cover tracks.

NanHaiShu.name: Disabling Security Tools
NanHaiShu.description: [NanHaiShu](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0228) can change Internet Explorer settings to reduce warnings about malware activity.

NanHaiShu.name: System Information Discovery
NanHaiShu.description: [NanHaiShu](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0228) can gather the victim computer name and serial number.

NanHaiShu.name: System Owner/User Discovery
NanHaiShu.description: [NanHaiShu](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0228) collects the username from the victim.

NanHaiShu.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
NanHaiShu.description: [NanHaiShu](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0228) modifies the %regrun% Registry to point itself to an autostart mechanism.

NanHaiShu.name: Remote File Copy
NanHaiShu.description: [NanHaiShu](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0228) can download additional files from URLs.

NanHaiShu.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
NanHaiShu.description: [NanHaiShu](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0228) can gather information about the victim proxy server.

NanHaiShu.name: Scripting
NanHaiShu.description: [NanHaiShu](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0228) executes additional Jscript and VBScript code on the victim's machine.

NanHaiShu.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
NanHaiShu.description: [NanHaiShu](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0228) uses DNS for the C2 communications.

POWERSTATS.name: File Deletion
POWERSTATS.description: [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) can delete all files on the C:\, D:\, E:\ and, F:\ drives using [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1086) Remove-Item commands.

POWERSTATS.name: Uncommonly Used Port
POWERSTATS.description: [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) has used ports 8060 and 8888 for C2.

POWERSTATS.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
POWERSTATS.description: [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) can deobfuscate the main backdoor code.

POWERSTATS.name: Mshta
POWERSTATS.description: [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) can use Mshta.exe to execute additional payloads on compromised hosts.

POWERSTATS.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
POWERSTATS.description: [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) uses character replacement, [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1086) environment variables, and XOR encoding to obfuscate code. [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223)'s backdoor code is a multi-layer obfuscated, encoded, and compressed blob.

POWERSTATS.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
POWERSTATS.description: [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) can use WMI queries to retrieve data from compromised hosts.

POWERSTATS.name: Screen Capture
POWERSTATS.description: [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) can retrieve screenshots from compromised hosts.

POWERSTATS.name: Dynamic Data Exchange
POWERSTATS.description: [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) can use DDE to execute additional payloads on compromised hosts.

POWERSTATS.name: System Information Discovery
POWERSTATS.description: [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) can retrieve OS name/architecture and computer/domain name information from compromised hosts.

POWERSTATS.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
POWERSTATS.description: [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) can retrieve IP and network adapter configuration information from compromised hosts.

POWERSTATS.name: Scripting
POWERSTATS.description: [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) can use VBScript (VBE), PowerShell, and JavaScript code for execution.

POWERSTATS.name: Scheduled Transfer
POWERSTATS.description: [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) can sleep for a given number of seconds.

POWERSTATS.name: Security Software Discovery
POWERSTATS.description: [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) has detected security tools.

POWERSTATS.name: Account Discovery
POWERSTATS.description: [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) can retrieve usernames from compromised hosts.

POWERSTATS.name: PowerShell
POWERSTATS.description: [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) uses PowerShell for obfuscation and execution.

POWERSTATS.name: Scheduled Task
POWERSTATS.description: [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) has established persistence through a scheduled task using the command ”C:\Windows\system32\schtasks.exe” /Create /F /SC DAILY /ST 12:00 /TN MicrosoftEdge /TR “c:\Windows\system32\wscript.exe C:\Windows\temp\Windows.vbe”.

POWERSTATS.name: Connection Proxy
POWERSTATS.description: [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) has connected to C2 servers through proxies.

POWERSTATS.name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
POWERSTATS.description: [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) has encrypted C2 traffic with RSA.

POWERSTATS.name: Distributed Component Object Model
POWERSTATS.description: [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) can use DCOM (targeting the 127.0.0.1 loopback address) to execute additional payloads on compromised hosts.

POWERSTATS.name: Masquerading
POWERSTATS.description: [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) has created a scheduled task named "MicrosoftEdge" to establish persistence.

POWERSTATS.name: Remote File Copy
POWERSTATS.description: [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) can retrieve and execute additional [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1086) payloads from the C2 server.

POWERSTATS.name: Commonly Used Port
POWERSTATS.description: [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) has used port 80 for C2.

POWERSTATS.name: Data Encoding
POWERSTATS.description: [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) encoded C2 traffic with base64.

POWERSTATS.name: Disabling Security Tools
POWERSTATS.description: [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) can disable Microsoft Office Protected View by changing Registry keys.

POWERSTATS.name: Data from Local System
POWERSTATS.description: [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) can upload files from compromised hosts.

PoisonIvy.name: Process Injection
PoisonIvy.description: [PoisonIvy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0012) can inject a malicious DLL into a process.

PoisonIvy.name: Remote File Copy
PoisonIvy.description: [PoisonIvy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0012) creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can upload files.

PoisonIvy.name: Modify Registry
PoisonIvy.description: [PoisonIvy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0012) creates a Registry subkey that registers a new system device.

PoisonIvy.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
PoisonIvy.description: [PoisonIvy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0012) creates run key Registry entries pointing to a malicious executable dropped to disk.

PoisonIvy.name: New Service
PoisonIvy.description: [PoisonIvy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0012) creates a Registry subkey that registers a new service.

PoisonIvy.name: Rootkit
PoisonIvy.description: [PoisonIvy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0012) starts a rootkit from a malicious file dropped to disk.

PoisonIvy.name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
PoisonIvy.description: [PoisonIvy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0012) uses the Camellia cipher to encrypt communications.

PoisonIvy.name: Modify Existing Service
PoisonIvy.description: [PoisonIvy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0012) creates a Registry entry modifying the Logical Disk Manager service to point to a malicious DLL dropped to disk.

PoisonIvy.name: Data Staged
PoisonIvy.description: [PoisonIvy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0012) stages collected data in a text file.

PoisonIvy.name: Uncommonly Used Port
PoisonIvy.description: [PoisonIvy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0012) opens a backdoor on TCP ports 6868 and 7777.

PoisonIvy.name: Data from Local System
PoisonIvy.description: [PoisonIvy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0012) creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can steal system information.

PoisonIvy.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
PoisonIvy.description: [PoisonIvy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0012) hides any strings related to its own indicators of compromise.

PoisonIvy.name: Command-Line Interface
PoisonIvy.description: [PoisonIvy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0012) creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can open a command-line interface.

Daserf.name: Code Signing
Daserf.description: Some [Daserf](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0187) samples were signed with a stolen digital certificate.

Daserf.name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Daserf.description: [Daserf](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0187) uses RC4 encryption to obfuscate HTTP traffic.

Daserf.name: Indicator Removal from Tools
Daserf.description: Analysis of [Daserf](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0187) has shown that it regularly undergoes technical improvements to evade anti-virus detection.

Daserf.name: Data Obfuscation
Daserf.description: [Daserf](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0187) can use steganography to hide malicious code downloaded to the victim.

Daserf.name: Data Compressed
Daserf.description: [Daserf](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0187) hides collected data in password-protected .rar archives.

Daserf.name: Software Packing
Daserf.description: A version of [Daserf](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0187) uses the MPRESS packer.

Daserf.name: Credential Dumping
Daserf.description: [Daserf](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0187) leverages [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002) and [Windows Credential Editor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0005) to steal credentials.

Daserf.name: Data Encrypted
Daserf.description: [Daserf](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0187) hides collected data in password-protected .rar archives.

Daserf.name: Masquerading
Daserf.description: [Daserf](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0187) uses file and folder names related to legitimate programs in order to blend in, such as HP, Intel, Adobe, and perflogs.

Daserf.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Daserf.description: [Daserf](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0187) uses encrypted Windows APIs and also encrypts data using the alternative base64+RC4 or the Caesar cipher.

Daserf.name: Data Encoding
Daserf.description: [Daserf](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0187) uses custom base64 encoding to obfuscate HTTP traffic.

PowerDuke.name: System Information Discovery
PowerDuke.description: [PowerDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0139) has commands to get information about the victim's name, build, version, serial number, and memory usage.

PowerDuke.name: Process Discovery
PowerDuke.description: [PowerDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0139) has a command to list the victim's processes.

PowerDuke.name: NTFS File Attributes
PowerDuke.description: [PowerDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0139) hides many of its backdoor payloads in an alternate data stream (ADS).

PowerDuke.name: Remote File Copy
PowerDuke.description: [PowerDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0139) has a command to download a file.

PowerDuke.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
PowerDuke.description: [PowerDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0139) achieves persistence by using various Registry Run keys.

PowerDuke.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
PowerDuke.description: [PowerDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0139) has a command to get the victim's domain and NetBIOS name.

PowerDuke.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
PowerDuke.description: [PowerDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0139) uses steganography to hide backdoors in PNG files, which are also encrypted using the Tiny Encryption Algorithm (TEA).

PowerDuke.name: Application Window Discovery
PowerDuke.description: [PowerDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0139) has a command to get text of the current foreground window.

PowerDuke.name: System Owner/User Discovery
PowerDuke.description: [PowerDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0139) has commands to get the current user's name and SID.

PowerDuke.name: Command-Line Interface
PowerDuke.description: [PowerDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0139) runs cmd.exe /c and sends the output to its C2.

PowerDuke.name: File Deletion
PowerDuke.description: [PowerDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0139) has a command to write random data across a file and delete it.

PowerDuke.name: File and Directory Discovery
PowerDuke.description: [PowerDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0139) has commands to get the current directory name as well as the size of a file. It also has commands to obtain information about logical drives, drive type, and free space.

PowerDuke.name: System Time Discovery
PowerDuke.description: [PowerDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0139) has commands to get the time the machine was built, the time, and the time zone.

PowerDuke.name: Data Destruction
PowerDuke.description: [PowerDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0139) has a command to write random data across a file and delete it.

Sykipot.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Sykipot.description: [Sykipot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0018) may use ipconfig /all to gather system network configuration details.

Sykipot.name: Process Injection
Sykipot.description: [Sykipot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0018) injects itself into running instances of outlook.exe, iexplore.exe, or firefox.exe.

Sykipot.name: Input Capture
Sykipot.description: [Sykipot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0018) contains keylogging functionality to steal passwords.

Sykipot.name: Process Discovery
Sykipot.description: [Sykipot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0018) may gather a list of running processes by running tasklist /v.

Sykipot.name: System Network Connections Discovery
Sykipot.description: [Sykipot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0018) may use netstat -ano to display active network connections.

Sykipot.name: Multilayer Encryption
Sykipot.description: [Sykipot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0018) communicates using HTTPS and uses a custom encryption cipher to encrypt the HTTPS message body.

Sykipot.name: Two-Factor Authentication Interception
Sykipot.description: [Sykipot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0018) is known to contain functionality that enables targeting of smart card technologies to proxy authentication for connections to restricted network resources using detected hardware tokens.

Sykipot.name: Remote System Discovery
Sykipot.description: [Sykipot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0018) may use net view /domain to display hostnames of available systems on a network.

Sykipot.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Sykipot.description: [Sykipot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0018) has been known to establish persistence by adding programs to the Run Registry key.

Sykipot.name: Account Discovery
Sykipot.description: [Sykipot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0018) may use net group "domain admins" /domain to display accounts in the "domain admins" permissions group and net localgroup "administrators" to list local system administrator group membership.

Sykipot.name: System Service Discovery
Sykipot.description: [Sykipot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0018) may use net start to display running services.

WINERACK.name: Command-Line Interface
WINERACK.description: [WINERACK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0219) can create a reverse shell that utilizes statically-linked Wine cmd.exe code to emulate Windows command prompt commands.

WINERACK.name: System Information Discovery
WINERACK.description: [WINERACK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0219) can gather information about the host.

WINERACK.name: System Owner/User Discovery
WINERACK.description: [WINERACK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0219) can gather information on the victim username.

MobileOrder.name: System Information Discovery
MobileOrder.description: [MobileOrder](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0079) has a command to upload to its C2 server victim mobile device information, including IMEI, IMSI, SIM card serial number, phone number, Android version, and other information.

MobileOrder.name: Uncommonly Used Port
MobileOrder.description: [MobileOrder](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0079) communicates with its C2 server over TCP port 3728.

MobileOrder.name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
MobileOrder.description: [MobileOrder](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0079) uses AES to encrypt C2 communications.

MobileOrder.name: Data from Local System
MobileOrder.description: [MobileOrder](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0079) exfiltrates data collected from the victim mobile device.

MobileOrder.name: Browser Bookmark Discovery
MobileOrder.description: [MobileOrder](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0079) has a command to upload to its C2 server victim browser bookmarks.

MobileOrder.name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
MobileOrder.description: [MobileOrder](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0079) exfiltrates data to its C2 server over the same protocol as C2 communications.

MobileOrder.name: Process Discovery
MobileOrder.description: [MobileOrder](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0079) has a command to upload information about all running processes to its C2 server.

MobileOrder.name: Remote File Copy
MobileOrder.description: [MobileOrder](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0079) has a command to download a file from the C2 server to the victim mobile device's SD card.

MobileOrder.name: File and Directory Discovery
MobileOrder.description: [MobileOrder](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0079) has a command to upload to its C2 server information about files on the victim mobile device, including SD card size, installed app list, SMS content, contacts, and calling history.

Psylo.name: Remote File Copy
Psylo.description: [Psylo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0078) has a command to download a file to the system from its C2 server.

Psylo.name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
Psylo.description: [Psylo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0078) exfiltrates data to its C2 server over the same protocol as C2 communications.

Psylo.name: File and Directory Discovery
Psylo.description: [Psylo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0078) has commands to enumerate all storage devices and to find all files that start with a particular string.

Psylo.name: Timestomp
Psylo.description: [Psylo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0078) has a command to conduct timestomping by setting a specified file’s timestamps to match those of a system file in the System32 directory.

Pisloader.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Pisloader.description: [Pisloader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0124) establishes persistence via a Registry Run key.

Pisloader.name: Data Encoding
Pisloader.description: Responses from the [Pisloader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0124) C2 server are base32-encoded.

Pisloader.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Pisloader.description: [Pisloader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0124) uses DNS as its C2 protocol.

Pisloader.name: Remote File Copy
Pisloader.description: [Pisloader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0124) has a command to upload a file to the victim machine.

Pisloader.name: Command-Line Interface
Pisloader.description: [Pisloader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0124) uses cmd.exe to set the Registry Run key value. It also has a command to spawn a command shell.

Pisloader.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Pisloader.description: [Pisloader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0124) has a command to collect the victim's IP address.

Pisloader.name: File and Directory Discovery
Pisloader.description: [Pisloader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0124) has commands to list drives on the victim machine and to list file information for a given directory.

Pisloader.name: System Information Discovery
Pisloader.description: [Pisloader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0124) has a command to collect victim system information, including the system name and OS version.

Pisloader.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Pisloader.description: [Pisloader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0124) obfuscates files by splitting strings into smaller sub-strings and including "garbage" strings that are never used. The malware also uses return-oriented programming (ROP) technique and single-byte XOR to obfuscate data.

Volgmer.name: Query Registry
Volgmer.description: [Volgmer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0180) checks the system for certain Registry keys.

Volgmer.name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
Volgmer.description: [Volgmer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0180) uses a custom binary protocol to beacon back to its C2 server. It has also used XOR for encrypting communications.

Volgmer.name: Modify Registry
Volgmer.description: [Volgmer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0180) stores the encoded configuration file in the Registry key HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\CurrentContorlSet\Control\WMI\Security.

Volgmer.name: Execution through API
Volgmer.description: [Volgmer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0180) executes payloads using the Windows API call CreateProcessW().

Volgmer.name: System Service Discovery
Volgmer.description: [Volgmer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0180) queries the system to identify existing services.

Volgmer.name: Command-Line Interface
Volgmer.description: [Volgmer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0180) can execute commands on the victim's machine.

Volgmer.name: Modify Existing Service
Volgmer.description: [Volgmer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0180) installs a copy of itself in a randomly selected service, then overwrites the ServiceDLL entry in the service's Registry entry.

Volgmer.name: Commonly Used Port
Volgmer.description: Some [Volgmer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0180) variants use ports 8080 and 8000 for C2.

Volgmer.name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Volgmer.description: Some [Volgmer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0180) variants use SSL to encrypt C2 communications.

Volgmer.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Volgmer.description: [Volgmer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0180) can gather the IP address from the victim's machine.

Volgmer.name: System Information Discovery
Volgmer.description: [Volgmer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0180) can gather system information, the computer name, OS version, drive and serial information from the victim's machine.

Volgmer.name: Data Encoding
Volgmer.description: [Volgmer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0180) encodes files before exfiltration.

Volgmer.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Volgmer.description: A [Volgmer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0180) variant is encoded using a simple XOR cipher.

Volgmer.name: File and Directory Discovery
Volgmer.description: [Volgmer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0180) can list directories on a victim.

Volgmer.name: Process Discovery
Volgmer.description: [Volgmer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0180) can gather a list of processes.

Volgmer.name: Remote File Copy
Volgmer.description: [Volgmer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0180) can download remote files and additional payloads to the victim's machine.

Volgmer.name: Uncommonly Used Port
Volgmer.description: Some [Volgmer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0180) variants use port 8088 for C2.

Volgmer.name: File Deletion
Volgmer.description: [Volgmer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0180) can delete files and itself after infection to avoid analysis.

Volgmer.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Volgmer.description: [Volgmer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0180) deobfuscates its strings and APIs once its executed.

Volgmer.name: System Network Connections Discovery
Volgmer.description: [Volgmer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0180) can gather information about TCP connection state.

Volgmer.name: New Service
Volgmer.description: Some [Volgmer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0180) variants install .dll files as services with names generated by a list of hard-coded strings.

Volgmer.name: Masquerading
Volgmer.description: Some [Volgmer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0180) variants add new services with display names generated by a list of hard-coded strings such as Application, Background, Security, and Windows, presumably as a way to masquerade as a legitimate service.

FELIXROOT.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
FELIXROOT.description: [FELIXROOT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0267) uses HTTP and HTTPS to communicate with the C2 server.

FELIXROOT.name: Query Registry
FELIXROOT.description: [FELIXROOT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0267) queries the Registry for specific keys for potential privilege escalation and proxy information. [FELIXROOT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0267) has also used WMI to query the Windows Registry.

FELIXROOT.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
FELIXROOT.description: [FELIXROOT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0267) encrypts strings in the backdoor using a custom XOR algorithm.

FELIXROOT.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
FELIXROOT.description: [FELIXROOT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0267) uses WMI to query the Windows Registry.

FELIXROOT.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
FELIXROOT.description: [FELIXROOT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0267) collects information about the network including the IP address and DHCP server.

FELIXROOT.name: Commonly Used Port
FELIXROOT.description: [FELIXROOT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0267) uses Port Numbers 443, 8443, and 8080 for C2 communications.

FELIXROOT.name: Command-Line Interface
FELIXROOT.description: [FELIXROOT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0267) opens a remote shell to execute commands on the infected system.

FELIXROOT.name: System Time Discovery
FELIXROOT.description: [FELIXROOT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0267) gathers the time zone information from the victim’s machine.

FELIXROOT.name: File Deletion
FELIXROOT.description: [FELIXROOT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0267) deletes the .LNK file from the startup directory as well as the dropper components.

FELIXROOT.name: System Owner/User Discovery
FELIXROOT.description: [FELIXROOT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0267) collects the username from the victim’s machine.

FELIXROOT.name: System Information Discovery
FELIXROOT.description: [FELIXROOT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0267) collects the victim’s computer name, processor architecture, OS version, volume serial number, and system type.

FELIXROOT.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
FELIXROOT.description: [FELIXROOT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0267) adds a shortcut file to the startup folder for persistence.

FELIXROOT.name: Rundll32
FELIXROOT.description: [FELIXROOT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0267) uses Rundll32 for executing the dropper program.

FELIXROOT.name: Shortcut Modification
FELIXROOT.description: [FELIXROOT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0267) creates a .LNK file for persistence.

FELIXROOT.name: Process Discovery
FELIXROOT.description: [FELIXROOT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0267) collects a list of running processes.

FELIXROOT.name: Modify Registry
FELIXROOT.description: [FELIXROOT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0267) deletes the Registry key HKCU\Software\Classes\Applications\rundll32.exe\shell\open.

FELIXROOT.name: Scripting
FELIXROOT.description: [FELIXROOT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0267) executes batch scripts on the victim’s machine.

FELIXROOT.name: Data Encrypted
FELIXROOT.description: [FELIXROOT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0267) encrypts collected data with AES and Base64 and then sends it to the C2 server.

FELIXROOT.name: Remote File Copy
FELIXROOT.description: [FELIXROOT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0267) downloads and uploads files to and from the victim’s machine.

FELIXROOT.name: Security Software Discovery
FELIXROOT.description: [FELIXROOT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0267) checks for installed security software like antivirus and firewall.

adbupd.name: Windows Management Instrumentation Event Subscription
adbupd.description: [adbupd](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0202) can use a WMI script to achieve persistence.

adbupd.name: Command-Line Interface
adbupd.description: [adbupd](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0202) can run a copy of cmd.exe.

adbupd.name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
adbupd.description: [adbupd](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0202) contains a copy of the OpenSSL library to encrypt C2 traffic.

RIPTIDE.name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
RIPTIDE.description: [APT12](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0005) has used the [RIPTIDE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0003) RAT, which communicates over HTTP with a payload encrypted with RC4.

RIPTIDE.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
RIPTIDE.description: [APT12](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0005) has used [RIPTIDE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0003), a RAT that uses HTTP to communicate.

RIPTIDE.name: Commonly Used Port
RIPTIDE.description: [RIPTIDE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0003) is a RAT that communicates with HTTP.

CallMe.name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
CallMe.description: [CallMe](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0077) uses AES to encrypt C2 traffic.

CallMe.name: Command-Line Interface
CallMe.description: [CallMe](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0077) has the capability to create a reverse shell on victims.

CallMe.name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
CallMe.description: [CallMe](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0077) exfiltrates data to its C2 server over the same protocol as C2 communications.

CallMe.name: Remote File Copy
CallMe.description: [CallMe](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0077) has the capability to download a file to the victim from the C2 server.

TYPEFRAME.name: File Deletion
TYPEFRAME.description: [TYPEFRAME](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0263) can delete files off the system.

TYPEFRAME.name: System Information Discovery
TYPEFRAME.description: [TYPEFRAME](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0263) can gather the disk volume information.

TYPEFRAME.name: Connection Proxy
TYPEFRAME.description: A [TYPEFRAME](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0263) variant can force the compromised system to function as a proxy server.

TYPEFRAME.name: Commonly Used Port
TYPEFRAME.description: [TYPEFRAME](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0263) variants can use ports 443, 8443, and 8080 for communications.

TYPEFRAME.name: User Execution
TYPEFRAME.description: A Word document delivering [TYPEFRAME](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0263) prompts the user to enable macro execution.

TYPEFRAME.name: Scripting
TYPEFRAME.description: [TYPEFRAME](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0263) can uninstall malware components using a batch script. Additionally, a malicious Word document used for delivery uses VBA macros for execution.

TYPEFRAME.name: Disabling Security Tools
TYPEFRAME.description: [TYPEFRAME](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0263) can open the Windows Firewall on the victim’s machine to allow incoming connections.

TYPEFRAME.name: Command-Line Interface
TYPEFRAME.description: [TYPEFRAME](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0263) can execute commands using a shell.

TYPEFRAME.name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
TYPEFRAME.description: A [TYPEFRAME](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0263) variant uses fake TLS to communicate with the C2 server.

TYPEFRAME.name: Remote File Copy
TYPEFRAME.description: [TYPEFRAME](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0263) can upload and download files to the victim’s machine.

TYPEFRAME.name: File and Directory Discovery
TYPEFRAME.description: [TYPEFRAME](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0263) can search directories for files on the victim’s machine.

TYPEFRAME.name: Modify Registry
TYPEFRAME.description: [TYPEFRAME](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0263) can install encrypted configuration data under the Registry key HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\ShellCompatibility\Applications\laxhost.dll and HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\PrintConfigs.

TYPEFRAME.name: Uncommonly Used Port
TYPEFRAME.description: A [TYPEFRAME](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0263) variant can use port 127 for communications.

TYPEFRAME.name: New Service
TYPEFRAME.description: [TYPEFRAME](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0263) variants can add malicious DLL modules as new services.

TYPEFRAME.name: Modify Existing Service
TYPEFRAME.description: [TYPEFRAME](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0263) can delete services from the victim’s machine.

TYPEFRAME.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
TYPEFRAME.description: APIs and strings in some [TYPEFRAME](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0263) variants are RC4 encrypted. Another variant is encoded with XOR.

TYPEFRAME.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
TYPEFRAME.description: One [TYPEFRAME](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0263) variant decrypts an archive using an RC4 key, then decompresses and installs the decrypted malicious DLL module. Another variant decodes the embedded file by XORing it with the value "0x35".

MirageFox.name: System Information Discovery
MirageFox.description: [MirageFox](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0280) can collect CPU and architecture information from the victim’s machine.

MirageFox.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
MirageFox.description: [MirageFox](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0280) has a function for decrypting data containing C2 configuration information.

MirageFox.name: DLL Search Order Hijacking
MirageFox.description: [MirageFox](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0280) is likely loaded via DLL hijacking into a legitimate McAfee binary.

MirageFox.name: System Owner/User Discovery
MirageFox.description: [MirageFox](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0280) can gather the username from the victim’s machine.

MirageFox.name: Command-Line Interface
MirageFox.description: [MirageFox](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0280) has the capability to execute commands using cmd.exe.

Net Crawler.name: Credential Dumping
Net Crawler.description: [Net Crawler](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0056) uses credential dumpers such as [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002) and [Windows Credential Editor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0005) to extract cached credentials from Windows systems.

Net Crawler.name: Brute Force
Net Crawler.description: [Net Crawler](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0056) uses a list of known credentials gathered through credential dumping to guess passwords to accounts as it spreads throughout a network.

Net Crawler.name: Service Execution
Net Crawler.description: [Net Crawler](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0056) uses [PsExec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0029) to perform remote service manipulation to execute a copy of itself as part of lateral movement.

Net Crawler.name: Windows Admin Shares
Net Crawler.description: [Net Crawler](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0056) uses Windows admin shares to establish authenticated sessions to remote systems over SMB as part of lateral movement.

4H RAT.name: System Information Discovery
4H RAT.description: [4H RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0065) sends an OS version identifier in its beacons.

4H RAT.name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
4H RAT.description: [4H RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0065) obfuscates C2 communication using a 1-byte XOR with the key 0xBE.

4H RAT.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
4H RAT.description: [4H RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0065) uses HTTP for command and control.

4H RAT.name: Process Discovery
4H RAT.description: [4H RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0065) has the capability to obtain a listing of running processes (including loaded modules).

4H RAT.name: Command-Line Interface
4H RAT.description: [4H RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0065) has the capability to create a remote shell.

4H RAT.name: File and Directory Discovery
4H RAT.description: [4H RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0065) has the capability to obtain file and directory listings.

RedLeaves.name: System Owner/User Discovery
RedLeaves.description: [RedLeaves](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0153) can obtain information about the logged on user both locally and for Remote Desktop sessions.

RedLeaves.name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
RedLeaves.description: [RedLeaves](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0153) can communicate to its C2 over TCP using a custom binary protocol.

RedLeaves.name: DLL Search Order Hijacking
RedLeaves.description: [RedLeaves](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0153) is launched through use of DLL search order hijacking to load a malicious dll.

RedLeaves.name: System Information Discovery
RedLeaves.description: [RedLeaves](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0153) can gather extended system information including the hostname, OS version number, platform, memory information, time elapsed since system startup, and CPU information.

RedLeaves.name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
RedLeaves.description: [RedLeaves](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0153) has encrypted C2 traffic with RC4, previously using keys of 88888888 and babybear.

RedLeaves.name: File and Directory Discovery
RedLeaves.description: [RedLeaves](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0153) can enumerate and search for files and directories.

RedLeaves.name: Command-Line Interface
RedLeaves.description: [RedLeaves](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0153) can receive and execute commands with cmd.exe. It can also provide a reverse shell.

RedLeaves.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
RedLeaves.description: [RedLeaves](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0153) can communicate to its C2 over HTTP and HTTPS if directed.

RedLeaves.name: Credential Dumping
RedLeaves.description: [RedLeaves](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0153) can gather browser usernames and passwords.

RedLeaves.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
RedLeaves.description: [RedLeaves](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0153) attempts to add a shortcut file in the Startup folder to achieve persistence. If this fails, it attempts to add Registry Run keys.

RedLeaves.name: Remote File Copy
RedLeaves.description: [RedLeaves](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0153) is capable of downloading a file from a specified URL.

RedLeaves.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
RedLeaves.description: A [RedLeaves](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0153) configuration file is encrypted with a simple XOR key, 0x53.

RedLeaves.name: Shortcut Modification
RedLeaves.description: [RedLeaves](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0153) attempts to add a shortcut file in the Startup folder to achieve persistence.

RedLeaves.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
RedLeaves.description: [RedLeaves](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0153) can obtain information about network parameters.

RedLeaves.name: Commonly Used Port
RedLeaves.description: [RedLeaves](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0153) uses a specific port of 443 and can also use ports 53 and 80 for C2. One [RedLeaves](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0153) variant uses HTTP over port 443 to connect to its C2 server.

RedLeaves.name: System Network Connections Discovery
RedLeaves.description: [RedLeaves](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0153) can enumerate drives and Remote Desktop sessions.

PLAINTEE.name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
PLAINTEE.description: [PLAINTEE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0254) uses a custom UDP protocol to communicate.

PLAINTEE.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
PLAINTEE.description: [PLAINTEE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0254) uses the ipconfig /all command to gather the victim’s IP address.

PLAINTEE.name: Modify Registry
PLAINTEE.description: [PLAINTEE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0254) uses reg add to add a Registry Run key for persistence.

PLAINTEE.name: Process Discovery
PLAINTEE.description: [PLAINTEE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0254) performs the tasklist command to list running processes.

PLAINTEE.name: Bypass User Account Control
PLAINTEE.description: An older variant of [PLAINTEE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0254) performs UAC bypass.

PLAINTEE.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
PLAINTEE.description: [PLAINTEE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0254) gains persistence by adding the Registry key HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\RunOnce.

PLAINTEE.name: System Information Discovery
PLAINTEE.description: [PLAINTEE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0254) collects general system enumeration data about the infected machine and checks the OS version.

PLAINTEE.name: Command-Line Interface
PLAINTEE.description: [PLAINTEE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0254) uses cmd.exe to execute commands on the victim’s machine.

PLAINTEE.name: Remote File Copy
PLAINTEE.description: [PLAINTEE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0254) has downloaded and executed additional plugins.

POWRUNER.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
POWRUNER.description: [POWRUNER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0184) may collect network configuration data by running ipconfig /all on a victim.

POWRUNER.name: File and Directory Discovery
POWRUNER.description: [POWRUNER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0184) may enumerate user directories on a victim.

POWRUNER.name: Query Registry
POWRUNER.description: [POWRUNER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0184) may query the Registry by running reg query on a victim.

POWRUNER.name: Process Discovery
POWRUNER.description: [POWRUNER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0184) may collect process information by running tasklist on a victim.

POWRUNER.name: Account Discovery
POWRUNER.description: [POWRUNER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0184) may collect user account information by running net user /domain or a series of other commands on a victim.

POWRUNER.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
POWRUNER.description: [POWRUNER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0184) can use HTTP and DNS for C2 communications.

POWRUNER.name: System Network Connections Discovery
POWRUNER.description: [POWRUNER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0184) may collect active network connections by running netstat -an on a victim.

POWRUNER.name: Scheduled Task
POWRUNER.description: [POWRUNER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0184) persists through a scheduled task that executes it every minute.

POWRUNER.name: Screen Capture
POWRUNER.description: [POWRUNER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0184) can capture a screenshot from a victim.

POWRUNER.name: System Owner/User Discovery
POWRUNER.description: [POWRUNER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0184) may collect information about the currently logged in user by running whoami on a victim.

POWRUNER.name: Permission Groups Discovery
POWRUNER.description: [POWRUNER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0184) may collect permission group information by running net group /domain or a series of other commands on a victim.

POWRUNER.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
POWRUNER.description: [POWRUNER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0184) may use WMI when collecting information about a victim.

POWRUNER.name: Command-Line Interface
POWRUNER.description: [POWRUNER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0184) can execute commands from its C2 server.

POWRUNER.name: Remote File Copy
POWRUNER.description: [POWRUNER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0184) can download or upload files from its C2 server.

POWRUNER.name: Security Software Discovery
POWRUNER.description: [POWRUNER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0184) may collect information the victim's anti-virus software.

POWRUNER.name: Data Encoding
POWRUNER.description: [POWRUNER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0184) can use base64 encoded C2 communications.

POWRUNER.name: System Information Discovery
POWRUNER.description: [POWRUNER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0184) may collect information about the system by running hostname and systeminfo on a victim.

KOMPROGO.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
KOMPROGO.description: [KOMPROGO](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0156) is capable of running WMI queries.

KOMPROGO.name: Command-Line Interface
KOMPROGO.description: [KOMPROGO](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0156) is capable of creating a reverse shell.

KOMPROGO.name: System Information Discovery
KOMPROGO.description: [KOMPROGO](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0156) is capable of retrieving information about the infected system.

Misdat.name: Standard Non-Application Layer Protocol
Misdat.description: [Misdat](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0083) network traffic communicates over a raw socket.

Misdat.name: File and Directory Discovery
Misdat.description: [Misdat](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0083) is capable of running commands to obtain a list of files and directories, as well as enumerating logical drives.

Misdat.name: Indicator Removal on Host
Misdat.description: [Misdat](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0083) is capable of deleting Registry keys used for persistence.

Misdat.name: Remote File Copy
Misdat.description: [Misdat](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0083) is capable of downloading files from the C2.

Misdat.name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
Misdat.description: [Misdat](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0083) network traffic communicates over a raw socket.

Misdat.name: Timestomp
Misdat.description: Many [Misdat](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0083) samples were programmed using Borland Delphi, which will mangle the default PE compile timestamp of a file.

Misdat.name: Command-Line Interface
Misdat.description: [Misdat](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0083) is capable of providing shell functionality to the attacker to execute commands.

Misdat.name: System Information Discovery
Misdat.description: The initial beacon packet for [Misdat](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0083) contains the operating system version of the victim.

Misdat.name: Commonly Used Port
Misdat.description: [Misdat](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0083) network traffic communicates over common ports like 80, 443, or 1433.

Misdat.name: Masquerading
Misdat.description: [Misdat](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0083) saves itself as a file named msdtc.exe, which is also the name of the legitimate Microsoft Distributed Transaction Coordinator service.

Misdat.name: File Deletion
Misdat.description: [Misdat](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0083) is capable of deleting the backdoor file.

GravityRAT.name: Command-Line Interface
GravityRAT.description: [GravityRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0237) executes commands remotely on the infected host.

GravityRAT.name: Dynamic Data Exchange
GravityRAT.description: [GravityRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0237) has been delivered via Word documents using DDE for execution.

GravityRAT.name: Indicator Removal from Tools
GravityRAT.description: The author of [GravityRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0237) submitted samples to VirusTotal for testing, showing that the author modified the code to try to hide the DDE object in a different part of the document.

GravityRAT.name: Data from Removable Media
GravityRAT.description: [GravityRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0237) steals files based on an extension list if a USB drive is connected to the system.

GravityRAT.name: Scheduled Task
GravityRAT.description: [GravityRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0237) creates a scheduled task to ensure it is re-executed everyday.

GravityRAT.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
GravityRAT.description: [GravityRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0237) collects various information via WMI requests, including CPU information in the Win32_Processor entry (Processor ID, Name, Manufacturer and the clock speed).

GravityRAT.name: System Service Discovery
GravityRAT.description: [GravityRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0237) has a feature to list the available services on the system.

GravityRAT.name: System Owner/User Discovery
GravityRAT.description: [GravityRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0237) collects the victim username along with other account information (account type, description, full name, SID and status).

GravityRAT.name: Data from Local System
GravityRAT.description: [GravityRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0237) steals files with the following extensions: .docx, .doc, .pptx, .ppt, .xlsx, .xls, .rtf, and .pdf.

GravityRAT.name: Process Discovery
GravityRAT.description: [GravityRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0237) lists the running processes on the system.

GravityRAT.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
GravityRAT.description: [GravityRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0237) collects the victim IP address, MAC address, as well as the victim account domain name.

GravityRAT.name: File and Directory Discovery
GravityRAT.description: [GravityRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0237) collects the volumes mapped on the system, and also steals files with the following extensions: .docx, .doc, .pptx, .ppt, .xlsx, .xls, .rtf, and .pdf.

GravityRAT.name: System Information Discovery
GravityRAT.description: [GravityRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0237) collects the MAC address, computer name, and CPU information.

GravityRAT.name: System Time Discovery
GravityRAT.description: [GravityRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0237) can obtain the date and time of a system.

GravityRAT.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
GravityRAT.description: [GravityRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0237) supports file encryption (AES with the key "lolomycin2017").

GravityRAT.name: System Network Connections Discovery
GravityRAT.description: [GravityRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0237) uses the netstat command to find open ports on the victim’s machine.

GravityRAT.name: Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion
GravityRAT.description: [GravityRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0237) uses WMI to check the BIOS and manufacturer information for strings like "VMWare", "Virtual", and "XEN" and another WMI request to get the current temperature of the hardware to determine if it's a virtual machine environment.

BS2005.name: Data Encoding
BS2005.description: [BS2005](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0014) uses Base64 encoding for communication in the message body of an HTTP request.

HAPPYWORK.name: System Owner/User Discovery
HAPPYWORK.description: can collect the victim user name.

HAPPYWORK.name: Remote File Copy
HAPPYWORK.description: can download and execute a second-stage payload.

HAPPYWORK.name: System Information Discovery
HAPPYWORK.description: can collect system information, including computer name, system manufacturer, IsDebuggerPresent state, and execution path.

HDoor.name: Disabling Security Tools
HDoor.description: [HDoor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0061) kills anti-virus found on the victim.

HDoor.name: Network Service Scanning
HDoor.description: [HDoor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0061) scans to identify open ports on the victim.

Prikormka.name: Input Capture
Prikormka.description: [Prikormka](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0113) contains a keylogger module that collects keystrokes and the titles of foreground windows.

Prikormka.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Prikormka.description: Some resources in [Prikormka](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0113) are encrypted with a simple XOR operation or encoded with Base64.

Prikormka.name: Data Compressed
Prikormka.description: After collecting documents from removable media, [Prikormka](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0113) compresses the collected files.

Prikormka.name: Data Encoding
Prikormka.description: [Prikormka](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0113) encodes C2 traffic with Base64.

Prikormka.name: Data from Removable Media
Prikormka.description: [Prikormka](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0113) contains a module that collects documents with certain extensions from removable media or fixed drives connected via USB.

Prikormka.name: Indicator Removal on Host
Prikormka.description: After encrypting log files, the log encryption module in [Prikormka](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0113) deletes the original, unencrypted files from the host.

Prikormka.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Prikormka.description: [Prikormka](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0113) adds itself to a Registry Run key with the name guidVGA or guidVSA.

Prikormka.name: Data Staged
Prikormka.description: [Prikormka](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0113) creates a directory, %USERPROFILE%\AppData\Local\SKC\, which is used to store collected log files.

Prikormka.name: DLL Search Order Hijacking
Prikormka.description: [Prikormka](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0113) uses DLL search order hijacking for persistence by saving itself as ntshrui.dll to the Windows directory so it will load before the legitimate ntshrui.dll saved in the System32 subdirectory.

Prikormka.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Prikormka.description: A module in [Prikormka](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0113) collects information from the victim about its IP addresses and MAC addresses.

Prikormka.name: File and Directory Discovery
Prikormka.description: A module in [Prikormka](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0113) collects information about the paths, size, and creation time of files with specific file extensions, but not the actual content of the file.

Prikormka.name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Prikormka.description: [Prikormka](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0113) encrypts some C2 traffic with the Blowfish cipher.

Prikormka.name: Security Software Discovery
Prikormka.description: A module in [Prikormka](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0113) collects information from the victim about installed anti-virus software.

Prikormka.name: Rundll32
Prikormka.description: [Prikormka](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0113) uses rundll32.exe to load its DLL.

Prikormka.name: Screen Capture
Prikormka.description: [Prikormka](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0113) contains a module that captures screenshots of the victim's desktop.

Prikormka.name: System Information Discovery
Prikormka.description: A module in [Prikormka](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0113) collects information from the victim about Windows OS version, computer name, battery info, and physical memory.

Prikormka.name: Peripheral Device Discovery
Prikormka.description: A module in [Prikormka](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0113) collects information on available printers and disk drives.

Prikormka.name: System Owner/User Discovery
Prikormka.description: A module in [Prikormka](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0113) collects information from the victim about the current user name.

Prikormka.name: Credential Dumping
Prikormka.description: A module in [Prikormka](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0113) collects passwords stored in applications installed on the victim.

Prikormka.name: Data Encrypted
Prikormka.description: After collecting files and logs from the victim, [Prikormka](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0113) encrypts some collected data with Blowfish.

SHOTPUT.name: Process Discovery
SHOTPUT.description: [SHOTPUT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0063) has a command to obtain a process listing.

SHOTPUT.name: Remote System Discovery
SHOTPUT.description: [SHOTPUT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0063) has a command to list all servers in the domain, as well as one to locate domain controllers on a domain.

SHOTPUT.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
SHOTPUT.description: [SHOTPUT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0063) is obscured using XOR encoding and appended to a valid GIF file.

SHOTPUT.name: File and Directory Discovery
SHOTPUT.description: [SHOTPUT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0063) has a command to obtain a directory listing.

SHOTPUT.name: Account Discovery
SHOTPUT.description: [SHOTPUT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0063) has a command to retrieve information about connected users.

SHOTPUT.name: System Network Connections Discovery
SHOTPUT.description: [SHOTPUT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0063) uses [netstat](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0104) to list TCP connection status.

Nidiran.name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Nidiran.description: [Nidiran](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0118) uses RC4 to encrypt C2 traffic.

Nidiran.name: Masquerading
Nidiran.description: [Nidiran](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0118) can create a new service named msamger (Microsoft Security Accounts Manager), which mimics the legitimate Microsoft database by the same name.

Nidiran.name: New Service
Nidiran.description: [Nidiran](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0118) can create a new service named msamger (Microsoft Security Accounts Manager).

Nidiran.name: Commonly Used Port
Nidiran.description: [Nidiran](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0118) communicates with its C2 domain over ports 443 and 8443.

SPACESHIP.name: Exfiltration Over Physical Medium
SPACESHIP.description: [SPACESHIP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0035) copies staged data to removable drives when they are inserted into the system.

SPACESHIP.name: Data Staged
SPACESHIP.description: [SPACESHIP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0035) identifies files with certain extensions and copies them to a directory in the user's profile.

SPACESHIP.name: File and Directory Discovery
SPACESHIP.description: [SPACESHIP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0035) identifies files and directories for collection by searching for specific file extensions or file modification time.

SPACESHIP.name: Data Encrypted
SPACESHIP.description: Data [SPACESHIP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0035) copies to the staging area is compressed with zlib. Bytes are rotated by four positions and XOR'ed with 0x23.

SPACESHIP.name: Shortcut Modification
SPACESHIP.description: [SPACESHIP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0035) achieves persistence by creating a shortcut in the current user's Startup folder.

SPACESHIP.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
SPACESHIP.description: [SPACESHIP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0035) achieves persistence by creating a shortcut in the current user's Startup folder.

FakeM.name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
FakeM.description: The original variant of [FakeM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0076) encrypts C2 traffic using a custom encryption cipher that uses an XOR key of “YHCRA” and bit rotation between each XOR operation. [FakeM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0076) has also included HTML code in C2 traffic in an apparent attempt to evade detection. Additionally, some variants of [FakeM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0076) use modified SSL code for communications back to C2 servers, making SSL decryption ineffective.

FakeM.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
FakeM.description: Some variants of [FakeM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0076) use SSL to communicate with C2 servers.

FakeM.name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
FakeM.description: Some variants of [FakeM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0076) use RC4 to encrypt C2 traffic.

FakeM.name: Data Obfuscation
FakeM.description: [FakeM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0076) C2 traffic attempts to evade detection by resembling data generated by legitimate messenger applications, such as MSN and Yahoo! messengers.

InnaputRAT.name: New Service
InnaputRAT.description: Some [InnaputRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0259) variants create a new Windows service to establish persistence.

InnaputRAT.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
InnaputRAT.description: [InnaputRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0259) uses an 8-byte XOR key to obfuscate API names and other strings contained in the payload.

InnaputRAT.name: File and Directory Discovery
InnaputRAT.description: [InnaputRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0259) enumerates directories and obtains file attributes on a system.

InnaputRAT.name: System Information Discovery
InnaputRAT.description: [InnaputRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0259) gathers volume drive information and system information.

InnaputRAT.name: Command-Line Interface
InnaputRAT.description: [InnaputRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0259) launches a shell to execute commands on the victim’s machine.

InnaputRAT.name: File Deletion
InnaputRAT.description: [InnaputRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0259) has a command to delete files.

InnaputRAT.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
InnaputRAT.description: Some [InnaputRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0259) variants establish persistence by modifying the Registry key HKU\\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run:%appdata%\NeutralApp\NeutralApp.exe.

InnaputRAT.name: Uncommonly Used Port
InnaputRAT.description: [InnaputRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0259) uses port 52100 and 5876 for C2 communications.

InnaputRAT.name: Masquerading
InnaputRAT.description: [InnaputRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0259) variants have attempted to appear legitimate by using the file names SafeApp.exe and NeutralApp.exe, as well as by adding a new service named OfficeUpdateService.

InnaputRAT.name: Execution through API
InnaputRAT.description: [InnaputRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0259) uses the API call ShellExecuteW for execution.

FruitFly.name: File and Directory Discovery
FruitFly.description: [FruitFly](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0277) looks for specific files and file types.

FruitFly.name: Hidden Files and Directories
FruitFly.description: [FruitFly](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0277) saves itself with a leading "." to make it a hidden file.

FruitFly.name: File Deletion
FruitFly.description: [FruitFly](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0277) will delete files on the system.

FruitFly.name: Screen Capture
FruitFly.description: [FruitFly](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0277) takes screenshots of the user's desktop.

FruitFly.name: Process Discovery
FruitFly.description: [FruitFly](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0277) has the ability to list processes on the system.

FruitFly.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
FruitFly.description: [FruitFly](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0277) executes and stores obfuscated Perl scripts.

HARDRAIN.name: Connection Proxy
HARDRAIN.description: [HARDRAIN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0246) uses the command cmd.exe /c netsh firewall add portopening TCP 443 "adp" and makes the victim machine function as a proxy server.

HARDRAIN.name: Disabling Security Tools
HARDRAIN.description: [HARDRAIN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0246) opens the Windows Firewall to modify incoming connections.

HARDRAIN.name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
HARDRAIN.description: [HARDRAIN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0246) uses FakeTLS to communicate with its C2 server.

SEASHARPEE.name: Remote File Copy
SEASHARPEE.description: [SEASHARPEE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0185) can download remote files onto victims.

SEASHARPEE.name: Timestomp
SEASHARPEE.description: [SEASHARPEE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0185) can timestomp files on victims using a Web shell.

Trojan.Karagany.name: Process Discovery
Trojan.Karagany.description: [Trojan.Karagany](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0094) can use tasklist to collect a list of running tasks.

Trojan.Karagany.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Trojan.Karagany.description: [Trojan.Karagany](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0094) can create a link to itself in the Startup folder to automatically start itself upon system restart.

Trojan.Karagany.name: Remote File Copy
Trojan.Karagany.description: [Trojan.Karagany](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0094) can upload, download, and execute files on the victim.

Trojan.Karagany.name: Software Packing
Trojan.Karagany.description: [Trojan.Karagany](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0094) samples sometimes use common binary packers such as UPX and Aspack on top of a custom Delphi binary packer.

Trojan.Karagany.name: Credential Dumping
Trojan.Karagany.description: [Trojan.Karagany](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0094) can dump passwords and save them into \ProgramData\Mail\MailAg\pwds.txt.

Trojan.Karagany.name: Data Staged
Trojan.Karagany.description: [Trojan.Karagany](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0094) can create a directory (C:\ProgramData\Mail\MailAg\gl) to use as a temporary directory for uploading files.

Trojan.Karagany.name: Screen Capture
Trojan.Karagany.description: [Trojan.Karagany](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0094) can take a desktop screenshot and save the file into \ProgramData\Mail\MailAg\shot.png.

NETEAGLE.name: Process Discovery
NETEAGLE.description: [NETEAGLE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0034) can send process listings over the C2 channel.

NETEAGLE.name: Command-Line Interface
NETEAGLE.description: [NETEAGLE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0034) allows adversaries to execute shell commands on the infected host.

NETEAGLE.name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
NETEAGLE.description: [NETEAGLE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0034) will decrypt resources it downloads with HTTP requests by using RC4 with the key "ScoutEagle."

NETEAGLE.name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
NETEAGLE.description: [NETEAGLE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0034) is capable of reading files over the C2 channel.

NETEAGLE.name: Standard Non-Application Layer Protocol
NETEAGLE.description: If [NETEAGLE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0034) does not detect a proxy configured on the infected machine, it will send beacons via UDP/6000. Also, after retrieving a C2 IP address and Port Number, [NETEAGLE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0034) will initiate a TCP connection to this socket. The ensuing connection is a plaintext C2 channel in which commands are specified by DWORDs.

NETEAGLE.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
NETEAGLE.description: [NETEAGLE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0034) will attempt to detect if the infected host is configured to a proxy. If so, [NETEAGLE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0034) will send beacons via an HTTP POST request; otherwise it will send beacons via UDP/6000. [NETEAGLE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0034) will also use HTTP to download resources that contain an IP address and Port Number pair to connect to for further C2. Adversaries can also use [NETEAGLE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0034) to establish an RDP connection with a controller over TCP/7519.

NETEAGLE.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
NETEAGLE.description: The "SCOUT" variant of [NETEAGLE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0034) achieves persistence by adding itself to the HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run Registry key.

NETEAGLE.name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
NETEAGLE.description: If [NETEAGLE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0034) does not detect a proxy configured on the infected machine, it will send beacons via UDP/6000. Also, after retrieving a C2 IP address and Port Number, [NETEAGLE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0034) will initiate a TCP connection to this socket. The ensuing connection is a plaintext C2 channel in which commands are specified by DWORDs.

NETEAGLE.name: Fallback Channels
NETEAGLE.description: [NETEAGLE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0034) will attempt to detect if the infected host is configured to a proxy. If so, [NETEAGLE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0034) will send beacons via an HTTP POST request; otherwise it will send beacons via UDP/6000.

NETEAGLE.name: File and Directory Discovery
NETEAGLE.description: [NETEAGLE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0034) allows adversaries to enumerate and modify the infected host's file system. It supports searching for directories, creating directories, listing directory contents, reading and writing to files, retrieving file attributes, and retrieving volume information.

ZLib.name: Command-Line Interface
ZLib.description: [ZLib](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0086) has the ability to execute shell commands.

ZLib.name: System Information Discovery
ZLib.description: [ZLib](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0086) has the ability to enumerate system information.

ZLib.name: Screen Capture
ZLib.description: [ZLib](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0086) has the ability to obtain screenshots of the compromised system.

ZLib.name: Data Compressed
ZLib.description: The [ZLib](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0086) backdoor compresses communications using the standard Zlib compression library.

ZLib.name: File and Directory Discovery
