Epic.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Epic.description: [Epic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0091) uses the nbtstat -n and nbtstat -s commands on the victim’s machine.

Epic.name: Extra Window Memory Injection
Epic.description: [Epic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0091) has overwritten the function pointer in the extra window memory of Explorer's Shell_TrayWnd in order to execute malicious code in the context of the explorer.exe process.

TinyZBot.name: New Service
TinyZBot.description: [TinyZBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0004) can install as a Windows service for persistence.

TinyZBot.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
TinyZBot.description: [TinyZBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0004) can create a shortcut in the Windows startup folder for persistence.

TinyZBot.name: Shortcut Modification
TinyZBot.description: [TinyZBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0004) can create a shortcut in the Windows startup folder for persistence.

TinyZBot.name: Clipboard Data
TinyZBot.description: [TinyZBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0004) contains functionality to collect information from the clipboard.

Sakula.name: Command-Line Interface
Sakula.description: [Sakula](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0074) calls cmd.exe to run various DLL files via rundll32 and also to perform file cleanup. [Sakula](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0074) also has the capability to invoke a reverse shell.

Sakula.name: File Deletion
Sakula.description: Some [Sakula](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0074) samples use cmd.exe to delete temporary files.

Sakula.name: New Service
Sakula.description: Some [Sakula](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0074) samples install themselves as services for persistence by calling WinExec with the net start argument.

Sakula.name: Remote File Copy
Sakula.description: [Sakula](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0074) has the capability to download files.

Sakula.name: DLL Side-Loading
Sakula.description: [Sakula](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0074) uses DLL side-loading, typically using a digitally signed sample of Kaspersky Anti-Virus (AV) 6.0 for Windows Workstations or McAfee's Outlook Scan About Box to load malicious DLL files.

Sakula.name: Rundll32
Sakula.description: [Sakula](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0074) calls cmd.exe to run various DLL files via rundll32.

Sakula.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Sakula.description: Most [Sakula](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0074) samples maintain persistence by setting the Registry Run key SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\ in the HKLM or HKCU hive, with the Registry value and file name varying by sample.

Sakula.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Sakula.description: [Sakula](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0074) uses single-byte XOR obfuscation to obfuscate many of its files.

Sakula.name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
Sakula.description: [Sakula](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0074) encodes C2 traffic with single-byte XOR keys.

Sakula.name: Bypass User Account Control
Sakula.description: [Sakula](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0074) contains UAC bypass code for both 32- and 64-bit systems.

Micropsia.name: File and Directory Discovery
Micropsia.description: [Micropsia](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0339) can perform a recursive directory listing for all volume drives available on the victim's machine and can also fetch specific files by their paths.

Micropsia.name: Automated Collection
Micropsia.description: [Micropsia](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0339) executes an RAR tool to recursively archive files based on a predefined list of file extensions (*.xls, *.xlsx, *.csv, *.odt, *.doc, *.docx, *.ppt, *.pptx, *.pdf, *.mdb, *.accdb, *.accde, *.txt).

Micropsia.name: Security Software Discovery
Micropsia.description: [Micropsia](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0339) searches for anti-virus software and firewall products installed on the victim’s machine using WMI.

Micropsia.name: System Owner/User Discovery
Micropsia.description: [Micropsia](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0339) collects the username from the victim’s machine.

Micropsia.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Micropsia.description: [Micropsia](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0339) obfuscates the configuration with a custom Base64 and XOR.

Micropsia.name: Data Compressed
Micropsia.description: [Micropsia](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0339) creates a RAR archive based on collected files on the victim's machine.

Micropsia.name: Screen Capture
Micropsia.description: [Micropsia](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0339) takes screenshots every 90 seconds by calling the Gdi32.BitBlt API.

Micropsia.name: System Information Discovery
Micropsia.description: [Micropsia](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0339) gathers the hostname and OS version from the victim’s machine.

Micropsia.name: Hidden Files and Directories
Micropsia.description: [Micropsia](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0339) creates a new hidden directory to store all components' outputs in a dedicated sub-folder for each.

Micropsia.name: Remote File Copy
Micropsia.description: [Micropsia](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0339) can download and execute an executable from the C2 server.

Micropsia.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Micropsia.description: [Micropsia](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0339) uses HTTP and HTTPS for C2 network communications.

Micropsia.name: Shortcut Modification
Micropsia.description: [Micropsia](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0339) creates a shortcut to maintain persistence.

Micropsia.name: Command-Line Interface
Micropsia.description: [Micropsia](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0339) creates a command-line shell using cmd.exe.

Micropsia.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
Micropsia.description: [Micropsia](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0339) searches for anti-virus software and firewall products installed on the victim’s machine using WMI.

Octopus.name: System Information Discovery
Octopus.description: [Octopus](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0340) collects system drive information, the computer name, and the size of the disk.

Octopus.name: Screen Capture
Octopus.description: [Octopus](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0340) can capture screenshots of the victims’ machine.

Octopus.name: File and Directory Discovery
Octopus.description: [Octopus](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0340) collects information on the Windows directory and searches for compressed RAR files on the host.

Octopus.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Octopus.description: [Octopus](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0340) collects the host IP address from the victim’s machine.

Octopus.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
Octopus.description: [Octopus](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0340) uses wmic.exe for local discovery information.

Octopus.name: Remote File Copy
Octopus.description: [Octopus](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0340) can upload and download files to and from the victim’s machine.[

Octopus.name: System Owner/User Discovery
Octopus.description: [Octopus](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0340) collects the username from the victim’s machine.

Zeroaccess.name: NTFS File Attributes
Zeroaccess.description: Some variants of the [Zeroaccess](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0027) Trojan have been known to store data in Extended Attributes.

Azorult.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Azorult.description: [Azorult](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0344) can collect host IP information from the victim’s machine.

Azorult.name: Credentials in Files
Azorult.description: [Azorult](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0344) can steal credentials in files belonging to common software such as Skype, Telegram, and Steam.

Azorult.name: Process Discovery
Azorult.description: [Azorult](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0344) can collect a list of running processes by calling CreateToolhelp32Snapshot.

Azorult.name: Query Registry
Azorult.description: [Azorult](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0344) can check for installed software on the system under the Registry key Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Uninstall.

Azorult.name: System Owner/User Discovery
Azorult.description: [Azorult](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0344) can collect the username from the victim’s machine.

Azorult.name: System Information Discovery
Azorult.description: [Azorult](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0344) can collect the machine information, system architecture, the OS version, computer name, Windows product name, the number of CPU cores, video card information, and the system language.

Azorult.name: Access Token Manipulation
Azorult.description: [Azorult](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0344) can call WTSQueryUserToken and CreateProcessAsUser to start a new process with local system privileges.

Azorult.name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Azorult.description: [Azorult](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0344) can encrypt C2 traffic using XOR.

Azorult.name: Process Hollowing
Azorult.description: [Azorult](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0344) can decrypt the payload into memory, create a new suspended process of itself, then inject a decrypted payload to the new process and resume new process execution.

Azorult.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Azorult.description: [Azorult](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0344) uses an XOR key to decrypt content and uses Base64 to decode the C2 address.

Azorult.name: Remote File Copy
Azorult.description: [Azorult](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0344) can download and execute additional files. [Azorult](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0344) has also downloaded a ransomware payload called Hermes.

Azorult.name: File and Directory Discovery
Azorult.description: [Azorult](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0344) can recursively search for files in folders and collects files from the desktop with certain extensions.

Azorult.name: Screen Capture
Azorult.description: [Azorult](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0344) can capture screenshots of the victim’s machines.

Azorult.name: System Time Discovery
Azorult.description: [Azorult](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0344) can collect the time zone information from the system.

Azorult.name: File Deletion
Azorult.description: [Azorult](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0344) can delete files from victim machines.

OceanSalt.name: Data Encoding
OceanSalt.description: [OceanSalt](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0346) can encode data with a NOT operation before sending the data to the control server.

OceanSalt.name: Command-Line Interface
OceanSalt.description: [OceanSalt](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0346) can create a reverse shell on the infected endpoint using cmd.exe.

OceanSalt.name: Process Discovery
OceanSalt.description: [OceanSalt](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0346) can collect the name and ID for every process running on the system.

OceanSalt.name: File and Directory Discovery
OceanSalt.description: [OceanSalt](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0346) can extract drive information from the endpoint and search files on the system.

OceanSalt.name: File Deletion
OceanSalt.description: [OceanSalt](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0346) can delete files from the system.

OceanSalt.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
OceanSalt.description: [OceanSalt](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0346) can collect the victim’s IP address.

OceanSalt.name: System Information Discovery
OceanSalt.description: [OceanSalt](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0346) can collect the computer name from the system.

OceanSalt.name: Scripting
OceanSalt.description: [OceanSalt](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0346) has been executed via malicious macros.

OceanSalt.name: Spearphishing Attachment
OceanSalt.description: [OceanSalt](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0346) has been delivered via spearphishing emails with Microsoft Office attachments.

Cardinal RAT.name: Command-Line Interface
Cardinal RAT.description: [Cardinal RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0348) can execute commands.

Cardinal RAT.name: Process Injection
Cardinal RAT.description: [Cardinal RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0348) injects into a newly spawned process created from a native Windows executable.

Cardinal RAT.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Cardinal RAT.description: [Cardinal RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0348) establishes Persistence by setting the HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Windows\Load Registry key to point to its executable.

Cardinal RAT.name: Commonly Used Port
Cardinal RAT.description: [Cardinal RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0348) is downloaded using HTTP over port 443.

Cardinal RAT.name: System Information Discovery
Cardinal RAT.description: [Cardinal RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0348) can collect the hostname, Microsoft Windows version, and processor architecture from a victim machine.

Cardinal RAT.name: Fallback Channels
Cardinal RAT.description: [Cardinal RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0348) can communicate over multiple C2 host and port combinations.

Cardinal RAT.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Cardinal RAT.description: [Cardinal RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0348) encodes many of its artifacts and is encrypted (AES-128) when downloaded.

Cardinal RAT.name: Remote File Copy
Cardinal RAT.description: [Cardinal RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0348) is downloaded and installed via an executed [Assess leadership areas of interest](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1224) payload. [Cardinal RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0348) can also download and execute additional payloads.

Cardinal RAT.name: User Execution
Cardinal RAT.description: [Cardinal RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0348) lures victims into executing malicious macros embedded within Microsoft Excel documents.

Cardinal RAT.name: Query Registry
Cardinal RAT.description: [Cardinal RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0348) contains watchdog functionality that periodically ensures HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Windows\Load is set to point to its executable.

Cardinal RAT.name: Connection Proxy
Cardinal RAT.description: [Cardinal RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0348) can act as a reverse proxy.

Cardinal RAT.name: File Deletion
Cardinal RAT.description: [Cardinal RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0348) can uninstall itself, including deleting its executable.

Cardinal RAT.name: System Owner/User Discovery
Cardinal RAT.description: [Cardinal RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0348) can collect the username from a victim machine.

Cardinal RAT.name: File and Directory Discovery
Cardinal RAT.description: [Cardinal RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0348) checks its current working directory upon execution and also contains watchdog functionality that ensures its executable is located in the correct path (else it will rewrite the payload).

Cardinal RAT.name: Process Discovery
Cardinal RAT.description: [Cardinal RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0348) contains watchdog functionality that ensures its process is always running, else spawns a new instance.

Cardinal RAT.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Cardinal RAT.description: [Cardinal RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0348) is downloaded using HTTP over port 443.

Cardinal RAT.name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
Cardinal RAT.description: [Cardinal RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0348) uses a secret key with a series of XOR and addition operations to encrypt C2 traffic.

Cardinal RAT.name: Modify Registry
Cardinal RAT.description: [Cardinal RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0348) sets HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Windows\Load to point to its executable.

Cardinal RAT.name: Data Compressed
Cardinal RAT.description: [Cardinal RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0348) applies compression to C2 traffic using the ZLIB library.

Cardinal RAT.name: Input Capture
Cardinal RAT.description: [Cardinal RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0348) can log keystrokes.

Cardinal RAT.name: Screen Capture
Cardinal RAT.description: [Cardinal RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0348) can capture screenshots.

Cardinal RAT.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Cardinal RAT.description: [Cardinal RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0348) decodes many of its artifacts and is decrypted (AES-128) after being downloaded.

Cardinal RAT.name: Compile After Delivery
Cardinal RAT.description: [Cardinal RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0348) and its watchdog component are compiled and executed after being delivered to victims as embedded, uncompiled source code.

Cannon.name: System Time Discovery
Cannon.description: [Cannon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0351) can collect the current time zone information from the victim’s machine.

Cannon.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Cannon.description: [Cannon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0351) uses SMTP/S and POP3/S for C2 communications by sending and receiving emails.

Cannon.name: File and Directory Discovery
Cannon.description: [Cannon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0351) can obtain victim drive information as well as a list of folders in C:\Program Files.

Cannon.name: Screen Capture
Cannon.description: [Cannon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0351) can take a screenshot of the desktop.

Cannon.name: Process Discovery
Cannon.description: [Cannon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0351) can obtain a list of processes running on the system.

Cannon.name: Winlogon Helper DLL
Cannon.description: [Cannon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0351) adds the Registry key HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon to establish persistence.

Cannon.name: System Owner/User Discovery
Cannon.description: [Cannon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0351) can gather the username from the system.

Cannon.name: System Information Discovery
Cannon.description: [Cannon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0351) can gather system information from the victim’s machine such as the OS version, machine name, and drive information.

Cannon.name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
Cannon.description: [Cannon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0351) exfiltrates collected data over email via SMTP/S and POP3/S C2 channels.

Cannon.name: Remote File Copy
Cannon.description: [Cannon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0351) can download a payload for execution.

Agent.btz.name: Remote File Copy
Agent.btz.description: [Agent.btz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0092) attempts to download an encrypted binary from a specified domain.

Agent.btz.name: Data Encrypted
Agent.btz.description: [Agent.btz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0092) saves system information into an XML file that is then XOR-encoded.

Agent.btz.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Agent.btz.description: [Agent.btz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0092) collects the network adapter’s IP and MAC address as well as IP addresses of the network adapter’s default gateway, primary/secondary WINS, DHCP, and DNS servers, and saves them into a log file.

Agent.btz.name: System Owner/User Discovery
Agent.btz.description: [Agent.btz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0092) obtains the victim username and saves it to a file.

Agent.btz.name: Replication Through Removable Media
Agent.btz.description: [Agent.btz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0092) drops itself onto removable media devices and creates an autorun.inf file with an instruction to run that file. When the device is inserted into another system, it opens autorun.inf and loads the malware.

Agent.btz.name: Exfiltration Over Physical Medium
Agent.btz.description: [Agent.btz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0092) creates a file named thumb.dd on all USB flash drives connected to the victim. This file contains information about the infected system and activity logs.

pngdowner.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
pngdowner.description: [pngdowner](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0067) uses HTTP for command and control.

pngdowner.name: File Deletion
pngdowner.description: [pngdowner](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0067) deletes content from C2 communications that was saved to the user's temporary directory.

pngdowner.name: Credentials in Files
pngdowner.description: If an initial connectivity check fails, [pngdowner](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0067) attempts to extract proxy details and credentials from Windows Protected Storage and from the IE Credentials Store. This allows the adversary to use the proxy credentials for subsequent requests if they enable outbound HTTP access.

OopsIE.name: System Information Discovery
OopsIE.description: [OopsIE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0264) checks for information on the CPU fan, temperature, mouse, hard disk, and motherboard as part of its anti-VM checks.

OopsIE.name: File Deletion
OopsIE.description: [OopsIE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0264) has the capability to delete files and scripts from the victim's machine.

OopsIE.name: Data Compressed
OopsIE.description: [OopsIE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0264) compresses collected files with both the GZipStream class and a simple character replacement scheme before sending them to its C2 server.

OopsIE.name: Data Staged
OopsIE.description: [OopsIE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0264) stages the output from command execution and collected files in specific folders before exfiltration.

OopsIE.name: Software Packing
OopsIE.description: [OopsIE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0264) uses the SmartAssembly obfuscator to pack an embedded .Net Framework assembly used for C2.

OopsIE.name: Data Encoding
OopsIE.description: [OopsIE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0264) encodes data in hexadecimal format over the C2 channel.

OopsIE.name: Command-Line Interface
OopsIE.description: [OopsIE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0264) uses the command prompt to execute commands on the victim's machine.

OopsIE.name: Scheduled Task
OopsIE.description: [OopsIE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0264) creates a scheduled task to run itself every three minutes.

OopsIE.name: Scripting
OopsIE.description: [OopsIE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0264) creates and uses a VBScript as part of its persistent execution.

OopsIE.name: Data Transfer Size Limits
OopsIE.description: [OopsIE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0264) exfiltrates command output and collected files to its C2 server in 1500-byte blocks.

OopsIE.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
OopsIE.description: [OopsIE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0264) uses WMI to perform discovery techniques.

OopsIE.name: Remote File Copy
OopsIE.description: [OopsIE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0264) can download files from its C2 server to the victim's machine.

OopsIE.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
OopsIE.description: [OopsIE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0264) concatenates then decompresses multiple resources to load an embedded .Net Framework assembly.

OopsIE.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
OopsIE.description: [OopsIE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0264) uses the Confuser protector to obfuscate an embedded .Net Framework assembly used for C2. [OopsIE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0264) also encodes collected data in hexadecimal format before writing to files on disk and obfuscates strings.

OopsIE.name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
OopsIE.description: [OopsIE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0264) can upload files from the victim's machine to its C2 server.

OopsIE.name: System Time Discovery
OopsIE.description: [OopsIE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0264) checks to see if the system is configured with "Daylight" time and checks for a specific region to be set for the timezone.

OopsIE.name: Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion
OopsIE.description: [OopsIE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0264) performs several anti-VM and sandbox checks on the victim's machine. One technique the group has used was to perform a WMI query SELECT * FROM MSAcpi_ThermalZoneTemperature to check the temperature to see if it’s running in a virtual environment.

Mis-Type.name: Commonly Used Port
Mis-Type.description: [Mis-Type](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0084) communicates over common ports such as TCP 80, 443, and 25.

Mis-Type.name: Account Discovery
Mis-Type.description: [Mis-Type](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0084) may create a file containing the results of the command cmd.exe /c net user {Username}.

Mis-Type.name: Fallback Channels
Mis-Type.description: [Mis-Type](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0084) first attempts to use a Base64-encoded network protocol over a raw TCP socket for C2, and if that method fails, falls back to a secondary HTTP-based protocol to communicate to an alternate C2 server.

Mis-Type.name: System Owner/User Discovery
Mis-Type.description: [Mis-Type](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0084) runs tests to determine the privilege level of the compromised user.

Mis-Type.name: Create Account
Mis-Type.description: [Mis-Type](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0084) may create a temporary user on the system named “Lost_{Unique Identifier}.”

Mis-Type.name: Standard Non-Application Layer Protocol
Mis-Type.description: [Mis-Type](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0084) network traffic can communicate over a raw socket.

Mis-Type.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Mis-Type.description: [Mis-Type](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0084) network traffic can communicate over HTTP.

Mis-Type.name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
Mis-Type.description: [Mis-Type](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0084) network traffic can communicate over a raw socket.

Mis-Type.name: Command-Line Interface
Mis-Type.description: [Mis-Type](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0084) uses cmd.exe to run commands for enumerating the host.

Mis-Type.name: Data Encoding
Mis-Type.description: [Mis-Type](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0084) uses Base64 encoding for C2 traffic.

Mis-Type.name: Masquerading
Mis-Type.description: [Mis-Type](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0084) saves itself as a file named msdtc.exe, which is also the name of the legitimate Microsoft Distributed Transaction Coordinator service.

Mis-Type.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Mis-Type.description: [Mis-Type](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0084) may create a file containing the results of the command cmd.exe /c ipconfig /all.

Mis-Type.name: System Information Discovery
Mis-Type.description: The initial beacon packet for [Mis-Type](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0084) contains the operating system version and file system of the victim.

CORESHELL.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
CORESHELL.description: [CORESHELL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0137) obfuscates strings using a custom stream cipher.

CORESHELL.name: Remote File Copy
CORESHELL.description: [CORESHELL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0137) downloads another dropper from its C2 server.

CORESHELL.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
CORESHELL.description: [CORESHELL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0137) can communicate over HTTP, SMTP, and POP3 for C2.

CORESHELL.name: System Information Discovery
CORESHELL.description: [CORESHELL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0137) collects hostname, volume serial number and OS version data from the victim and sends the information to its C2 server.

CORESHELL.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
CORESHELL.description: [CORESHELL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0137) has established persistence by creating autostart extensibility point (ASEP) Registry entries in the Run key and other Registry keys, as well as by creating shortcuts in the Internet Explorer Quick Start folder.

CORESHELL.name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
CORESHELL.description: [CORESHELL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0137) C2 messages are encrypted with custom stream ciphers using six-byte or eight-byte keys.

CORESHELL.name: Binary Padding
CORESHELL.description: [CORESHELL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0137) contains unused machine instructions in a likely attempt to hinder analysis.

CORESHELL.name: Rundll32
CORESHELL.description: [CORESHELL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0137) is installed via execution of rundll32 with an export named "init" or "InitW."

httpclient.name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
httpclient.description: [httpclient](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0068) encrypts C2 content with XOR using a single byte, 0x12.

httpclient.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
httpclient.description: [httpclient](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0068) uses HTTP for command and control.

Final1stspy.name: System Information Discovery
Final1stspy.description: [Final1stspy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0355) obtains victim Microsoft Windows version information and CPU architecture.

Final1stspy.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Final1stspy.description: [Final1stspy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0355) creates a Registry Run key to establish persistence.

Final1stspy.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Final1stspy.description: [Final1stspy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0355) uses Python code to deobfuscate base64-encoded strings.

Final1stspy.name: Process Discovery
Final1stspy.description: [Final1stspy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0355) obtains a list of running processes.

ELMER.name: Process Discovery
ELMER.description: [ELMER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0064) is capable of performing process listings.

ELMER.name: Commonly Used Port
ELMER.description: [ELMER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0064) uses HTTP over port 443 for command and control.

ELMER.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
ELMER.description: [ELMER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0064) uses HTTP for command and control.

ELMER.name: File and Directory Discovery
ELMER.description: [ELMER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0064) is capable of performing directory listings.

Shamoon.name: Bypass User Account Control
Shamoon.description: [Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) attempts to disable UAC remote restrictions by modifying the Registry.

Shamoon.name: Valid Accounts
Shamoon.description: If [Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) cannot access shares using current privileges, it attempts access using hard coded, domain-specific credentials gathered earlier in the intrusion.

Shamoon.name: Scheduled Task
Shamoon.description: [Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) copies an executable payload to the target system by using [Windows Admin Shares](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1077) and then scheduling an unnamed task to execute the malware.

Shamoon.name: System Information Discovery
Shamoon.description: [Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) obtains the victim's operating system version and keyboard layout and sends the information to the C2 server.

Shamoon.name: New Service
Shamoon.description: [Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) creates a new service named “ntssrv” to execute the payload.

Shamoon.name: Masquerading
Shamoon.description: [Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) creates a new service named “ntssrv” that attempts to appear legitimate; the service's display name is “Microsoft Network Realtime Inspection Service” and its description is “Helps guard against time change attempts targeting known and newly discovered vulnerabilities in network time protocols.”

Shamoon.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Shamoon.description: [Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) obtains the target's IP address and local network segment.

Shamoon.name: Remote System Discovery
Shamoon.description: [Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) scans the C-class subnet of the IPs on the victim's interfaces.

Shamoon.name: System Time Discovery
Shamoon.description: [Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) obtains the system time and will only activate if it is greater than a preset date.

Shamoon.name: Commonly Used Port
Shamoon.description: [Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) has used TCP port 8080 for C2.

Shamoon.name: Windows Admin Shares
Shamoon.description: [Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) accesses network share(s), enables share access to the target device, copies an executable payload to the target system, and uses a [Scheduled Task](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1053) to execute the malware.

Shamoon.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Shamoon.description: [Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) uses HTTP for C2.

Shamoon.name: Query Registry
Shamoon.description: [Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) queries several Registry keys to identify hard disk partitions to overwrite.

Shamoon.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Shamoon.description: [Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) contains base64-encoded strings.

Shamoon.name: Service Execution
Shamoon.description: [Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) creates a new service named “ntssrv” to execute the payload.

Shamoon.name: Modify Registry
Shamoon.description: Once [Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) has access to a network share, it enables the RemoteRegistry service on the target system. It will then connect to the system with RegConnectRegistryW and modify the Registry to disable UAC remote restrictions by setting SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Policies\System\LocalAccountTokenFilterPolicy to 1.

Shamoon.name: Remote File Copy
Shamoon.description: [Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) can download an executable to run on the victim.

Shamoon.name: Data Destruction
Shamoon.description: [Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) attempts to overwrite operating system files and disk structures with image files. In a later variant, randomly generated data was used for data overwrites.

Shamoon.name: Data Encrypted for Impact
Shamoon.description: [Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) has an operational mode for encrypting data instead of overwriting it.

Shamoon.name: Disk Structure Wipe
Shamoon.description: [Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) has been seen overwriting features of disk structure such as the MBR.

Chaos.name: Port Knocking
Chaos.description: [Chaos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0220) provides a reverse shell is triggered upon receipt of a packet with a special string, sent to any port.

Chaos.name: Brute Force
Chaos.description: [Chaos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0220) conducts brute force attacks against SSH services to gain initial access.

Chaos.name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Chaos.description: [Chaos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0220) provides a reverse shell connection on 8338/TCP, encrypted via AES.

Chaos.name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
Chaos.description: [Chaos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0220) provides a reverse shell connection on 8338/TCP, encrypted via AES.

Chaos.name: Command-Line Interface
Chaos.description: [Chaos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0220) provides a reverse shell connection on 8338/TCP, encrypted via AES.

Chaos.name: Multi-Stage Channels
Chaos.description: After initial compromise, [Chaos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0220) will download a second stage to establish a more permanent presence on the affected system.

Kwampirs.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Kwampirs.description: [Kwampirs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0236) collects network adapter and interface information by using the commands ipconfig /all, arp -a and route print. It also collects the system's MAC address with getmac and domain configuration with net config workstation.

Kwampirs.name: Permission Groups Discovery
Kwampirs.description: [Kwampirs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0236) collects lists of local accounts with administrative access, local group user accounts, and domain local groups with the commands net localgroup administrators, net localgroup users, and net localgroup /domain.

Kwampirs.name: Binary Padding
Kwampirs.description: Before writing to disk, [Kwampirs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0236) inserts a randomly generated string into the middle of the decrypted payload in an attempt to evade hash-based detections.

Kwampirs.name: Masquerading
Kwampirs.description: [Kwampirs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0236) establishes persistence by adding a new service with the display name "WMI Performance Adapter Extension" in an attempt to masquerade as a legitimate WMI service.

Kwampirs.name: New Service
Kwampirs.description: [Kwampirs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0236) creates a new service named WmiApSrvEx to establish persistence.

Kwampirs.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Kwampirs.description: [Kwampirs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0236) downloads additional files that are base64-encoded and encrypted with another cipher.

Kwampirs.name: Remote File Copy
Kwampirs.description: [Kwampirs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0236) downloads additional files from C2 servers.

Kwampirs.name: System Information Discovery
Kwampirs.description: [Kwampirs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0236) collects OS version information such as registered owner details, manufacturer details, processor type, available storage, installed patches, hostname, version info, system date, and other system information by using the commands systeminfo, net config workstation, hostname, ver, set, and date /t.

Kwampirs.name: Remote System Discovery
Kwampirs.description: [Kwampirs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0236) collects a list of available servers with the command net view.

Kwampirs.name: System Network Connections Discovery
Kwampirs.description: [Kwampirs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0236) collects a list of active and listening connections by using the command netstat -nao as well as a list of available network mappings with net use.

Kwampirs.name: Process Discovery
Kwampirs.description: [Kwampirs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0236) collects a list of running services with the command tasklist /v.

Kwampirs.name: Password Policy Discovery
Kwampirs.description: [Kwampirs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0236) collects password policy information with the command net accounts.

Kwampirs.name: Account Discovery
Kwampirs.description: [Kwampirs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0236) collects a list of accounts with the command net users.

Kwampirs.name: Network Share Discovery
Kwampirs.description: [Kwampirs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0236) collects a list of network shares with the command net share.

Kwampirs.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Kwampirs.description: [Kwampirs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0236) decrypts and extracts a copy of its main DLL payload when executing.

Kwampirs.name: System Owner/User Discovery
Kwampirs.description: [Kwampirs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0236) collects registered owner details by using the commands systeminfo and net config workstation.

Kwampirs.name: File and Directory Discovery
Kwampirs.description: [Kwampirs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0236) collects a list of files and directories in C:\ with the command dir /s /a c:\ >> "C:\windows\TEMP\[RANDOM].tmp".

Kwampirs.name: Windows Admin Shares
Kwampirs.description: [Kwampirs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0236) copies itself over network shares to move laterally on a victim network.

Kwampirs.name: Rundll32
Kwampirs.description: [Kwampirs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0236) uses rundll32.exe in a Registry value added to establish persistence.

Kwampirs.name: Fallback Channels
Kwampirs.description: [Kwampirs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0236) uses a large list of C2 servers that it cycles through until a successful connection is established.

Kwampirs.name: System Service Discovery
Kwampirs.description: [Kwampirs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0236) collects a list of running services with the command tasklist /svc.

FLASHFLOOD.name: Data Staged
FLASHFLOOD.description: [FLASHFLOOD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0036) stages data it copies from the local system or removable drives in the "%WINDIR%\$NtUninstallKB885884$\" directory.

FLASHFLOOD.name: Data from Removable Media
FLASHFLOOD.description: [FLASHFLOOD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0036) searches for interesting files (either a default or customized set of file extensions) on removable media and copies them to a staging area. The default file types copied would include data copied to the drive by [SPACESHIP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0035).

FLASHFLOOD.name: Data Encrypted
FLASHFLOOD.description: [FLASHFLOOD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0036) employs the same encoding scheme as [SPACESHIP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0035) for data it stages. Data is compressed with zlib, and bytes are rotated four times before being XOR'ed with 0x23.

FLASHFLOOD.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
FLASHFLOOD.description: [FLASHFLOOD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0036) achieves persistence by making an entry in the Registry's Run key.

FLASHFLOOD.name: Data from Local System
FLASHFLOOD.description: [FLASHFLOOD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0036) searches for interesting files (either a default or customized set of file extensions) on the local system. [FLASHFLOOD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0036) will scan the My Recent Documents, Desktop, Temporary Internet Files, and TEMP directories. [FLASHFLOOD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0036) also collects information stored in the Windows Address Book.

FLASHFLOOD.name: File and Directory Discovery
FLASHFLOOD.description: [FLASHFLOOD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0036) searches for interesting files (either a default or customized set of file extensions) on the local system and removable media.

Miner-C.name: Taint Shared Content
Miner-C.description: [Miner-C](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0133) copies itself into the public folder of Network Attached Storage (NAS) devices and infects new victims who open the file.

RATANKBA.name: System Network Connections Discovery
RATANKBA.description: [RATANKBA](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0241) uses netstat -ano to search for specific IP address ranges.

RATANKBA.name: Process Injection
RATANKBA.description: [RATANKBA](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0241) performs a reflective DLL injection using a given pid.

RATANKBA.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
RATANKBA.description: [RATANKBA](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0241) uses WMI to perform process monitoring.

RATANKBA.name: Remote System Discovery
RATANKBA.description: [RATANKBA](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0241) runs the net view /domain and net view commands.

RATANKBA.name: System Information Discovery
RATANKBA.description: [RATANKBA](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0241) gathers information about the OS architecture, OS name, and OS version/Service pack.

RATANKBA.name: PowerShell
RATANKBA.description: There is a variant of [RATANKBA](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0241) that uses a PowerShell script instead of the traditional PE form.

RATANKBA.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
RATANKBA.description: [RATANKBA](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0241) uses HTTP/HTTPS for command and control communication.

RATANKBA.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
RATANKBA.description: [RATANKBA](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0241) gathers the victim’s IP address via the ipconfig -all command.

XAgentOSX.name: File and Directory Discovery
XAgentOSX.description: [XAgentOSX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0161) contains the readFiles function to return a detailed listing (sometimes recursive) of a specified directory.

XAgentOSX.name: Screen Capture
XAgentOSX.description: [XAgentOSX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0161) contains the takeScreenShot (along with startTakeScreenShot and stopTakeScreenShot) functions to take screenshots using the CGGetActiveDisplayList, CGDisplayCreateImage, and NSImage:initWithCGImage methods.

XAgentOSX.name: System Information Discovery
XAgentOSX.description: [XAgentOSX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0161) contains the getInstalledAPP function to run ls -la /Applications to gather what applications are installed.

XAgentOSX.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
XAgentOSX.description: [XAgentOSX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0161) contains the ftpUpload function to use the FTPManager:uploadFile method to upload files from the target system.

XAgentOSX.name: Process Discovery
XAgentOSX.description: [XAgentOSX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0161) contains the getProcessList function to run ps aux to get running processes.

XAgentOSX.name: Peripheral Device Discovery
XAgentOSX.description: [XAgentOSX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0161) contains the showBackupIosFolder function to check for IOS device backups by running ls -la ~/Library/Application\ Support/MobileSync/Backup/.

XAgentOSX.name: Input Capture
XAgentOSX.description: [XAgentOSX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0161) contains keylogging functionality that will monitor for active application windows and write them to the log, it can handle special characters, and it will buffer by default 50 characters before sending them out over the C2 infrastructure.

XAgentOSX.name: File Deletion
XAgentOSX.description: [XAgentOSX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0161) contains the deletFileFromPath function to delete a specified file using the NSFileManager:removeFileAtPath method.

XAgentOSX.name: Execution through API
XAgentOSX.description: [XAgentOSX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0161) contains the execFile function to execute a specified file on the system using the NSTask:launch method.

XAgentOSX.name: System Owner/User Discovery
XAgentOSX.description: [XAgentOSX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0161) contains the getInfoOSX function to return the OS X version as well as the current user.

Winnti.name: Masquerading
Winnti.description: A [Winnti](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0141) implant file was named ASPNET_FILTER.DLL, mimicking the legitimate ASP.NET ISAPI filter DLL with the same name.

Winnti.name: Rundll32
Winnti.description: The [Winnti](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0141) installer loads a DLL using rundll32.

Winnti.name: New Service
Winnti.description: [Winnti](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0141) sets its DLL file as a new service in the Registry to establish persistence.

Wingbird.name: Security Software Discovery
Wingbird.description: [Wingbird](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0176) checks for the presence of Bitdefender security software.

Wingbird.name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
Wingbird.description: [Wingbird](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0176) exploits CVE-2016-4117 to allow an executable to gain escalated privileges.

Wingbird.name: LSASS Driver
Wingbird.description: [Wingbird](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0176) drops a malicious file (sspisrv.dll) alongside a copy of lsass.exe, which is used to register a service that loads sspisrv.dll as a driver. The payload of the malicious driver (located in its entry-point function) is executed when loaded by lsass.exe before the spoofed service becomes unstable and crashes.

Wingbird.name: New Service
Wingbird.description: [Wingbird](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0176) uses services.exe to register a new autostart service named "Audit Service" using a copy of the local lsass.exe file.

Wingbird.name: Process Injection
Wingbird.description: [Wingbird](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0176) performs multiple process injections to hijack system processes and execute malicious code.

Wingbird.name: DLL Side-Loading
Wingbird.description: [Wingbird](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0176) side loads a malicious file, sspisrv.dll, in part of a spoofed lssas.exe service.

Wingbird.name: Service Execution
Wingbird.description: [Wingbird](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0176) uses services.exe to register a new autostart service named "Audit Service" using a copy of the local lsass.exe file.

Wingbird.name: File Deletion
Wingbird.description: [Wingbird](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0176) deletes its payload along with the payload's parent process after it finishes copying files.

Wingbird.name: System Information Discovery
Wingbird.description: [Wingbird](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0176) checks the victim OS version after executing to determine where to drop files based on whether the victim is 32-bit or 64-bit.

gh0st RAT.name: DLL Side-Loading
gh0st RAT.description: A [gh0st RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0032) variant has used DLL side-loading.

gh0st RAT.name: Remote File Copy
gh0st RAT.description: [gh0st RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0032) can download files to the victim’s machine.

gh0st RAT.name: Command-Line Interface
gh0st RAT.description: [gh0st RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0032) is able to open a remote shell to execute commands.

gh0st RAT.name: Screen Capture
gh0st RAT.description: [gh0st RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0032) can capture the victim’s screen remotely.

gh0st RAT.name: Indicator Removal on Host
gh0st RAT.description: [gh0st RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0032) is able to wipe event logs.

gh0st RAT.name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
gh0st RAT.description: [gh0st RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0032) uses RC4 and XOR to encrypt C2 traffic.

gh0st RAT.name: File Deletion
gh0st RAT.description: [gh0st RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0032) has the capability to to delete files.

gh0st RAT.name: New Service
gh0st RAT.description: [gh0st RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0032) can create a new service to establish persistence.

gh0st RAT.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
gh0st RAT.description: [gh0st RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0032) adds a Registry Run key to establish persistence.

gh0st RAT.name: Process Discovery
gh0st RAT.description: [gh0st RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0032) has the capability to list processes.

gh0st RAT.name: Rundll32
gh0st RAT.description: A [gh0st RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0032) variant has used rundll32 for execution.

Komplex.name: Launch Agent
Komplex.description: The [Komplex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0162) trojan creates a persistent launch agent called with $HOME/Library/LaunchAgents/com.apple.updates.plist with launchctl load -w ~/Library/LaunchAgents/com.apple.updates.plist.

Komplex.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Komplex.description: The [Komplex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0162) C2 channel uses HTTP POST requests.

Komplex.name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
Komplex.description: The [Komplex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0162) C2 channel uses an 11-byte XOR algorithm to hide data.

Komplex.name: Process Discovery
Komplex.description: The OsInfo function in [Komplex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0162) collects a running process list.

Komplex.name: Hidden Files and Directories
Komplex.description: The [Komplex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0162) payload is stored in a hidden directory at /Users/Shared/.local/kextd.

Komplex.name: System Owner/User Discovery
Komplex.description: The OsInfo function in [Komplex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0162) collects the current running username.

TINYTYPHON.name: Automated Exfiltration
TINYTYPHON.description: When a document is found matching one of the extensions in the configuration, [TINYTYPHON](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0131) uploads it to the C2 server.

TINYTYPHON.name: File and Directory Discovery
TINYTYPHON.description: [TINYTYPHON](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0131) searches through the drive containing the OS, then all drive letters C through to Z, for documents matching certain extensions.

TINYTYPHON.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
TINYTYPHON.description: [TINYTYPHON](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0131) has used XOR with 0x90 to obfuscate its configuration file.

TINYTYPHON.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
TINYTYPHON.description: [TINYTYPHON](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0131) installs itself under Registry Run key to establish persistence.

UPPERCUT.name: System Time Discovery
UPPERCUT.description: [UPPERCUT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0275) has the capability to obtain the time zone information and current timestamp of the victim’s machine.

UPPERCUT.name: Screen Capture
UPPERCUT.description: [UPPERCUT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0275) can capture desktop screenshots in the PNG format and send them to the C2 server.

UPPERCUT.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
UPPERCUT.description: [UPPERCUT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0275) has the capability to gather the victim's proxy information.

UPPERCUT.name: System Owner/User Discovery
UPPERCUT.description: [UPPERCUT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0275) has the capability to collect the current logged on user’s username from a machine.

UPPERCUT.name: Command-Line Interface
UPPERCUT.description: [UPPERCUT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0275) uses cmd.exe to execute commands on the victim’s machine.

UPPERCUT.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
UPPERCUT.description: [UPPERCUT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0275) has used HTTP for C2, including sending error codes in Cookie headers.

UPPERCUT.name: File and Directory Discovery
UPPERCUT.description: [UPPERCUT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0275) has the capability to gather the victim's current directory.

UPPERCUT.name: System Information Discovery
UPPERCUT.description: [UPPERCUT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0275) has the capability to gather the system’s hostname and OS version.

UPPERCUT.name: Remote File Copy
UPPERCUT.description: [UPPERCUT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0275) can download and upload files to and from the victim’s machine.

UPPERCUT.name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
UPPERCUT.description: Some versions of [UPPERCUT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0275) have used the hard-coded string “this is the encrypt key” for Blowfish encryption when communicating with a C2. Later versions have hard-coded keys uniquely for each C2 address.

iKitten.name: Input Prompt
iKitten.description: [iKitten](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0278) prompts the user for their credentials.

iKitten.name: Hidden Files and Directories
iKitten.description: [iKitten](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0278) saves itself with a leading "." so that it's hidden from users by default.

iKitten.name: Data Compressed
iKitten.description: [iKitten](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0278) will zip up the /Library/Keychains directory before exfiltrating it.

iKitten.name: Rc.common
iKitten.description: [iKitten](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0278) adds an entry to the rc.common file for persistence.

iKitten.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
iKitten.description: [iKitten](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0278) will look for the current IP address.

iKitten.name: Keychain
iKitten.description: [iKitten](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0278) collects the keychains on the system.

Umbreon.name: Port Knocking
Umbreon.description: [Umbreon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0221) provides additional access using its backdoor Espeon, providing a reverse shell upon receipt of a special packet

Umbreon.name: Valid Accounts
Umbreon.description: [Umbreon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0221) creates valid users to provide access to the system.

Umbreon.name: Rootkit
Umbreon.description: [Umbreon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0221) hides from defenders by hooking libc function calls, hiding artifacts that would reveal its presence, such as the user account it creates to provide access and undermining strace, a tool often used to identify malware.

Umbreon.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Umbreon.description: [Umbreon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0221) provides access to the system via SSH or any other protocol that uses PAM to authenticate.

Umbreon.name: Command-Line Interface
Umbreon.description: [Umbreon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0221) provides access using both standard facilities like SSH and additional access using its backdoor Espeon, providing a reverse shell upon receipt of a special packet

Emissary.name: Binary Padding
Emissary.description: A variant of [Emissary](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0082) appends junk data to the end of its DLL file to create a large file that may exceed the maximum size that anti-virus programs can scan.

Emissary.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Emissary.description: Variants of [Emissary](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0082) encrypt payloads using various XOR ciphers, as well as a custom algorithm that uses the "srand" and "rand" functions.

Emissary.name: Command-Line Interface
Emissary.description: [Emissary](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0082) has the capability to create a remote shell and execute specified commands.

Emissary.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Emissary.description: Variants of [Emissary](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0082) have added Run Registry keys to establish persistence.

Emissary.name: System Information Discovery
Emissary.description: [Emissary](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0082) has the capability to execute ver, systeminfo, and gpresult commands.

Emissary.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Emissary.description: [Emissary](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0082) has the capability to execute the command ipconfig /all.

Emissary.name: Rundll32
Emissary.description: Variants of [Emissary](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0082) have used rundll32.exe in Registry values added to establish persistence.

Emissary.name: Process Injection
Emissary.description: [Emissary](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0082) injects its DLL file into a newly spawned Internet Explorer process.

Emissary.name: New Service
Emissary.description: [Emissary](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0082) is capable of configuring itself as a service.

Emissary.name: Remote File Copy
Emissary.description: [Emissary](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0082) has the capability to download files from the C2 server.

Emissary.name: Permission Groups Discovery
Emissary.description: [Emissary](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0082) has the capability to execute the command net localgroup administrators.

Emissary.name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
Emissary.description: The C2 server response to a beacon sent by a variant of [Emissary](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0082) contains a 36-character GUID value that is used as an encryption key for subsequent network communications. Some variants of [Emissary](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0082) use various XOR operations to encrypt C2 data.

Emissary.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Emissary.description: [Emissary](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0082) uses HTTP or HTTPS for C2.

Emissary.name: System Service Discovery
Emissary.description: [Emissary](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0082) has the capability to execute the command net start to interact with services.

SOUNDBITE.name: Application Window Discovery
SOUNDBITE.description: [SOUNDBITE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0157) is capable of enumerating application windows.

SOUNDBITE.name: Modify Registry
SOUNDBITE.description: [SOUNDBITE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0157) is capable of modifying the Registry.

SOUNDBITE.name: System Information Discovery
SOUNDBITE.description: [SOUNDBITE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0157) is capable of gathering system information.

SOUNDBITE.name: File and Directory Discovery
SOUNDBITE.description: [SOUNDBITE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0157) is capable of enumerating and manipulating files and directories.

POWERSOURCE.name: NTFS File Attributes
POWERSOURCE.description: If the victim is using PowerShell 3.0 or later, [POWERSOURCE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0145) writes its decoded payload to an alternate data stream (ADS) named kernel32.dll that is saved in %PROGRAMDATA%\Windows\.

POWERSOURCE.name: Remote File Copy
POWERSOURCE.description: [POWERSOURCE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0145) has been observed being used to download [TEXTMATE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0146) and the Cobalt Strike Beacon payload onto victims.

POWERSOURCE.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
POWERSOURCE.description: [POWERSOURCE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0145) uses DNS TXT records for C2.

POWERSOURCE.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
POWERSOURCE.description: [POWERSOURCE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0145) achieves persistence by setting a Registry Run key, with the path depending on whether the victim account has user or administrator access.

POWERSOURCE.name: Query Registry
POWERSOURCE.description: [POWERSOURCE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0145) queries Registry keys in preparation for setting Run keys to achieve persistence.

KARAE.name: Drive-by Compromise
KARAE.description: [KARAE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0215) was distributed through torrent file-sharing websites to South Korean victims, using a YouTube video downloader application as a lure.

KARAE.name: Remote File Copy
KARAE.description: [KARAE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0215) can upload and download files, including second-stage malware.

KARAE.name: Web Service
KARAE.description: [KARAE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0215) can use public cloud-based storage providers for command and control.

HALFBAKED.name: System Information Discovery
HALFBAKED.description: [HALFBAKED](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0151) can obtain information about the OS, processor, and BIOS.

HALFBAKED.name: Screen Capture
HALFBAKED.description: [HALFBAKED](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0151) can obtain screenshots from the victim.

HALFBAKED.name: Process Discovery
HALFBAKED.description: [HALFBAKED](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0151) can obtain information about running processes on the victim.

HALFBAKED.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
HALFBAKED.description: [HALFBAKED](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0151) can use WMI queries to gather system information.

OwaAuth.name: Data Encrypted
OwaAuth.description: [OwaAuth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0072) DES-encrypts captured credentials using the key 12345678 before writing the credentials to a log file.

OwaAuth.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
OwaAuth.description: [OwaAuth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0072) uses incoming HTTP requests with a username keyword and commands and handles them as instructions to perform actions.

OwaAuth.name: Masquerading
OwaAuth.description: [OwaAuth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0072) uses the filename owaauth.dll, which is a legitimate file that normally resides in %ProgramFiles%\Microsoft\Exchange Server\ClientAccess\Owa\Auth\; the malicious file by the same name is saved in %ProgramFiles%\Microsoft\Exchange Server\ClientAccess\Owa\bin\.

OwaAuth.name: File and Directory Discovery
OwaAuth.description: [OwaAuth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0072) has a command to list its directory and logical drives.

OwaAuth.name: Timestomp
OwaAuth.description: [OwaAuth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0072) has a command to timestop a file or directory.

OwaAuth.name: Input Capture
OwaAuth.description: [OwaAuth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0072) captures and DES-encrypts credentials before writing the username and password to a log file, C:\log.txt.

OwaAuth.name: DLL Side-Loading
OwaAuth.description: [OwaAuth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0072) has been loaded onto Exchange servers and disguised as an ISAPI filter (DLL file). The IIS w3wp.exe process then loads the malicious DLL.

OwaAuth.name: Web Shell
OwaAuth.description: [OwaAuth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0072) is a Web shell that appears to be exclusively used by [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027). It is installed as an ISAPI filter on Exchange servers and shares characteristics with the [China Chopper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0020) Web shell.

Agent Tesla.name: Remote File Copy
Agent Tesla.description: [Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331) can download additional files for execution on the victim’s machine.

Agent Tesla.name: System Time Discovery
Agent Tesla.description: [Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331) can collect the timestamp from the victim’s machine.

Agent Tesla.name: Clipboard Data
Agent Tesla.description: [Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331) can steal data from the victim’s clipboard.

Agent Tesla.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Agent Tesla.description: [Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331) has used HTTP and SMTP for C2 communications.

Agent Tesla.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Agent Tesla.description: [Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331) obfuscates its code in an apparent attempt to make analysis difficult.

Agent Tesla.name: Process Discovery
Agent Tesla.description: [Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331) lists the current running processes on the system.

Agent Tesla.name: System Owner/User Discovery
Agent Tesla.description: [Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331) collects the username from the victim’s machine.

Agent Tesla.name: Input Capture
Agent Tesla.description: [Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331) can log keystrokes on the victim’s machine.

Agent Tesla.name: Uncommonly Used Port
Agent Tesla.description: [Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331) has enabled TCP on port 587 for C2 communications.

Agent Tesla.name: Disabling Security Tools
Agent Tesla.description: [Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331) has the capability to kill any running analysis processes and AV software.

Agent Tesla.name: Account Discovery
Agent Tesla.description: [Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331) collects account information from the victim’s machine.

Agent Tesla.name: Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol
Agent Tesla.description: [Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331) has routines for exfiltration over SMTP, FTP, and HTTP.

Agent Tesla.name: Data Encrypted
Agent Tesla.description: [Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331) encrypts the data with 3DES before sending it over the C2 server.

Agent Tesla.name: Screen Capture
Agent Tesla.description: [Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331) can capture screenshots of the victim’s desktop.

Agent Tesla.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Agent Tesla.description: [Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331) adds itself to the Registry as a startup program to establish persistence.

Agent Tesla.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Agent Tesla.description: [Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331) can collect the IP address of the victim machine.

Agent Tesla.name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Agent Tesla.description: [Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331) exploits CVE-2017-11882 in Microsoft’s Equation Editor to execute a process.

Agent Tesla.name: System Information Discovery
Agent Tesla.description: [Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331) collects the system's computer name and also has the capability to collect information on the processor, memory, and video card from the system.

Agent Tesla.name: Video Capture
Agent Tesla.description: [Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331) can access the victim’s webcam and record video.

UBoatRAT.name: Process Discovery
UBoatRAT.description: [UBoatRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0333) can list running processes on the system.

UBoatRAT.name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
UBoatRAT.description: [UBoatRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0333) has used a custom command and control protocol to communicate with C2. The string ‘488’ is placed at the top of the payload and encrypts the entre buffer with a static key using a simple XOR cipher.

UBoatRAT.name: BITS Jobs
UBoatRAT.description: [UBoatRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0333) takes advantage of the /SetNotifyCmdLine option in Bitsadmin.exe to ensure it stays running on a system to maintain persistence.

UBoatRAT.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
UBoatRAT.description: [UBoatRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0333) encrypts instructions in the payload using a simple XOR cipher.

UBoatRAT.name: Web Service
UBoatRAT.description: [UBoatRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0333) has used GitHub and a public blog service in Hong Kong for C2 communications.

UBoatRAT.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
UBoatRAT.description: [UBoatRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0333) has used HTTP for C2 communications.

UBoatRAT.name: Commonly Used Port
UBoatRAT.description: [UBoatRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0333) uses ports 80 and 443 for C2 communications.

UBoatRAT.name: Remote File Copy
UBoatRAT.description: [UBoatRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0333) can upload and download files to the victim’s machine.

UBoatRAT.name: Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion
UBoatRAT.description: [UBoatRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0333) checks for virtualization software such as VMWare, VirtualBox, or QEmu on the compromised machine.

Power Loader.name: Extra Window Memory Injection
Power Loader.description: [Power Loader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0177) overwrites Explorer’s Shell_TrayWnd extra window memory to redirect execution to a NTDLL function that is abused to assemble and execute a return-oriented programming (ROP) chain and create a malicious thread within Explorer.exe.

TrickBot.name: File and Directory Discovery
TrickBot.description: [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) searches the system for all of the following file extensions: .avi, .mov, .mkv, .mpeg, .mpeg4, .mp4, .mp3, .wav, .ogg, .jpeg, .jpg, .png, .bmp, .gif, .tiff, .ico, .xlsx, and .zip. It can also obtain browsing history, cookies, and plug-in information.

TrickBot.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
TrickBot.description: [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) uses HTTPS to communicate with its C2 servers, to get malware updates, modules that perform most of the malware logic and various configuration files.

TrickBot.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
TrickBot.description: [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) establishes persistence in the Startup folder.

TrickBot.name: Commonly Used Port
TrickBot.description: [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) uses port 443 for C2 communications.

TrickBot.name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
TrickBot.description: [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) uses a custom crypter leveraging Microsoft’s CryptoAPI to encrypt C2 traffic.

TrickBot.name: Man in the Browser
TrickBot.description: [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) uses web injects and browser redirection to trick the user into providing their login credentials on a fake or modified web page.

TrickBot.name: Remote File Copy
TrickBot.description: [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) downloads several additional files and saves them to the victim's machine.

TrickBot.name: System Service Discovery
TrickBot.description: [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) collects a list of install programs and services on the system’s machine.

TrickBot.name: System Information Discovery
TrickBot.description: [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) gathers the OS version, CPU type, amount of RAM available from the victim’s machine.

TrickBot.name: Modify Registry

TrickBot.name: Scheduled Task
