S-Type.description: [S-Type](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0085) may create a .lnk file to itself that is saved in the Start menu folder. It may also create the Registry key HKCU\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\ IMJPMIJ8.1{3 characters of Unique Identifier}.

S-Type.name: Create Account
S-Type.description: [S-Type](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0085) may create a temporary user on the system named “Lost_{Unique Identifier}” with the password “pond~!@6”{Unique Identifier}.”

S-Type.name: System Information Discovery
S-Type.description: The initial beacon packet for [S-Type](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0085) contains the operating system version and file system of the victim.

S-Type.name: Account Discovery
S-Type.description: [S-Type](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0085) runs the command net user on a victim. [S-Type](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0085) also runs tests to determine the privilege level of the compromised user.

S-Type.name: System Service Discovery
S-Type.description: [S-Type](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0085) runs the command net start on a victim.

S-Type.name: Fallback Channels
S-Type.description: [S-Type](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0085) primarily uses port 80 for C2, but falls back to ports 443 or 8080 if initial communication fails.

Sys10.name: Permission Groups Discovery
Sys10.description: [Sys10](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0060) collects the group name of the logged-in user and sends it to the C2.

Sys10.name: System Information Discovery
Sys10.description: [Sys10](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0060) collects the computer name, OS versioning information, and OS install date and sends the information to the C2.

Sys10.name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
Sys10.description: [Sys10](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0060) uses an XOR 0x1 loop to encrypt its C2 domain.

Sys10.name: System Owner/User Discovery
Sys10.description: [Sys10](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0060) collects the account name of the logged-in user and sends it to the C2.

Sys10.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Sys10.description: [Sys10](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0060) collects the local IP address of the victim and sends it to the C2.

OSInfo.name: System Network Connections Discovery
OSInfo.description: [OSInfo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0165) enumerates the current network connections similar to net use .

OSInfo.name: Permission Groups Discovery
OSInfo.description: [OSInfo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0165) specifically looks for Domain Admins, Power Users, and the Administrators groups within the domain and locally

OSInfo.name: Query Registry
OSInfo.description: [OSInfo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0165) queries the registry to look for information about Terminal Services.

OSInfo.name: Remote System Discovery
OSInfo.description: [OSInfo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0165) performs a connection test to discover remote systems in the network

OSInfo.name: System Information Discovery
OSInfo.description: [OSInfo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0165) discovers information about the infected machine.

PUNCHTRACK.name: Data from Local System
PUNCHTRACK.description: [PUNCHTRACK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0197) scrapes memory for properly formatted payment card data.

PUNCHTRACK.name: Data Staged
PUNCHTRACK.description: [PUNCHTRACK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0197) aggregates collected data in a tmp file.

PUNCHTRACK.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
PUNCHTRACK.description: [PUNCHTRACK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0197) is loaded and executed by a highly obfuscated launcher.

POORAIM.name: Drive-by Compromise
POORAIM.description: [POORAIM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0216) has been delivered through compromised sites acting as watering holes.

POORAIM.name: Web Service
POORAIM.description: [POORAIM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0216) has used AOL Instant Messenger for C2.

POORAIM.name: System Information Discovery
POORAIM.description: [POORAIM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0216) can identify system information, including battery status.

Regin.name: Modify Registry
Regin.description: [Regin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0019) appears to have functionality to modify remote Registry information.

Regin.name: NTFS File Attributes
Regin.description: The [Regin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0019) malware platform uses Extended Attributes to store encrypted executables.

Regin.name: Network Sniffing
Regin.description: [Regin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0019) appears to have functionality to sniff for credentials passed over HTTP, SMTP, and SMB.

Regin.name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
Regin.description: The [Regin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0019) malware platform can use ICMP to communicate between infected computers.

Regin.name: Connection Proxy
Regin.description: [Regin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0019) leveraged several compromised universities as proxies to obscure its origin.

Regin.name: Standard Non-Application Layer Protocol
Regin.description: The [Regin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0019) malware platform can use ICMP to communicate between infected computers.

Regin.name: Windows Admin Shares
Regin.description: The [Regin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0019) malware platform can use Windows admin shares to move laterally.

Regin.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Regin.description: The [Regin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0019) malware platform supports many standard protocols, including HTTP, HTTPS, and SMB.

Regin.name: Code Signing
Regin.description: [Regin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0019) stage 1 modules for 64-bit systems have been found to be signed with fake certificates masquerading as originating from Microsoft Corporation and Broadcom Corporation.

SNUGRIDE.name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
SNUGRIDE.description: [SNUGRIDE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0159) encrypts C2 traffic using AES with a static key.

SNUGRIDE.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
SNUGRIDE.description: [SNUGRIDE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0159) communicates with its C2 server over HTTP.

SNUGRIDE.name: Command-Line Interface
SNUGRIDE.description: [SNUGRIDE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0159) is capable of executing commands and spawning a reverse shell.

SNUGRIDE.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
SNUGRIDE.description: [SNUGRIDE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0159) establishes persistence through a Registry Run key.

Downdelph.name: Bypass User Account Control
Downdelph.description: [Downdelph](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0134) bypasses UAC to escalate privileges by using a custom “RedirectEXE” shim database.

Downdelph.name: DLL Search Order Hijacking
Downdelph.description: [Downdelph](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0134) uses search order hijacking of the Windows executable sysprep.exe to escalate privileges.

Downdelph.name: Data Obfuscation
Downdelph.description: [Downdelph](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0134) inserts pseudo-random characters between each original character during encoding of C2 network requests, making it difficult to write signatures on them.

Downdelph.name: Remote File Copy
Downdelph.description: After downloading its main config file, [Downdelph](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0134) downloads multiple payloads from C2 servers.

Downdelph.name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Downdelph.description: [Downdelph](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0134) uses RC4 to encrypt C2 responses.

RGDoor.name: Remote File Copy
RGDoor.description: [RGDoor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0258) uploads and downloads files to and from the victim’s machine.

RGDoor.name: Data Encrypted
RGDoor.description: [RGDoor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0258) encrypts files with XOR before sending them back to the C2 server.

RGDoor.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
RGDoor.description: [RGDoor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0258) decodes Base64 strings and decrypts strings using a custom XOR algorithm.

RGDoor.name: Command-Line Interface
RGDoor.description: [RGDoor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0258) uses cmd.exe to execute commands on the victim’s machine.

RGDoor.name: System Owner/User Discovery
RGDoor.description: [RGDoor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0258) executes the whoami on the victim’s machine.

Nerex.name: Code Signing
Nerex.description: [Nerex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0210) drops a signed Microsoft DLL to disk.

Nerex.name: New Service
Nerex.description: [Nerex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0210) creates a Registry subkey that registers a new service.

Nerex.name: Modify Registry
Nerex.description: [Nerex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0210) creates a Registry subkey that registers a new service.

Nerex.name: Remote File Copy
Nerex.description: [Nerex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0210) creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can download files onto a compromised host.

MURKYTOP.name: Account Discovery
MURKYTOP.description: [MURKYTOP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0233) has the capability to retrieve information about users on remote hosts.

MURKYTOP.name: File Deletion
MURKYTOP.description: [MURKYTOP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0233) has the capability to delete local files.

MURKYTOP.name: Remote System Discovery
MURKYTOP.description: [MURKYTOP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0233) has the capability to identify remote hosts on connected networks.

MURKYTOP.name: Network Share Discovery
MURKYTOP.description: [MURKYTOP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0233) has the capability to retrieve information about shares on remote hosts.

MURKYTOP.name: System Information Discovery
MURKYTOP.description: [MURKYTOP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0233) has the capability to retrieve information about the OS.

MURKYTOP.name: Scheduled Task
MURKYTOP.description: [MURKYTOP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0233) has the capability to schedule remote AT jobs.

MURKYTOP.name: Network Service Scanning
MURKYTOP.description: [MURKYTOP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0233) has the capability to scan for open ports on hosts in a connected network.

MURKYTOP.name: Permission Groups Discovery
MURKYTOP.description: [MURKYTOP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0233) has the capability to retrieve information about groups.

WINDSHIELD.name: System Information Discovery
WINDSHIELD.description: [WINDSHIELD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0155) can gather the victim computer name.

WINDSHIELD.name: File Deletion
WINDSHIELD.description: [WINDSHIELD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0155) is capable of file deletion along with other file system interaction.

WINDSHIELD.name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
WINDSHIELD.description: [WINDSHIELD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0155) C2 traffic can communicate via TCP raw sockets.

WINDSHIELD.name: Standard Non-Application Layer Protocol
WINDSHIELD.description: [WINDSHIELD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0155) C2 traffic can communicate via TCP raw sockets.

WINDSHIELD.name: System Owner/User Discovery
WINDSHIELD.description: [WINDSHIELD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0155) can gather the victim user name.

BUBBLEWRAP.name: System Information Discovery
BUBBLEWRAP.description: [BUBBLEWRAP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0043) collects system information, including the operating system version and hostname.

BUBBLEWRAP.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
BUBBLEWRAP.description: [BUBBLEWRAP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0043) can communicate using HTTP or HTTPS.

FLIPSIDE.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
FLIPSIDE.description: [FLIPSIDE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0173) uses RDP to tunnel traffic from a victim environment.

FLIPSIDE.name: Connection Proxy
FLIPSIDE.description: [FLIPSIDE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0173) is a simple proxy that creates an outbound RDP connection.

BLACKCOFFEE.name: Command-Line Interface
BLACKCOFFEE.description: [BLACKCOFFEE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0069) has the capability to create a reverse shell.

BLACKCOFFEE.name: File Deletion
BLACKCOFFEE.description: [BLACKCOFFEE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0069) has the capability to delete files.

BLACKCOFFEE.name: Web Service
BLACKCOFFEE.description: [BLACKCOFFEE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0069) uses Microsoft’s TechNet Web portal to obtain a dead drop resolver containing an encoded tag with the IP address of a command and control server. It has also obfuscated its C2 traffic as normal traffic to sites such as Github.

BLACKCOFFEE.name: Process Discovery
BLACKCOFFEE.description: [BLACKCOFFEE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0069) has the capability to discover processes.

BLACKCOFFEE.name: File and Directory Discovery
BLACKCOFFEE.description: [BLACKCOFFEE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0069) has the capability to enumerate files.

BLACKCOFFEE.name: Multi-Stage Channels
BLACKCOFFEE.description: [BLACKCOFFEE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0069) uses Microsoft’s TechNet Web portal to obtain an encoded tag containing the IP address of a command and control server and then communicates separately with that IP address for C2. If the C2 server is discovered or shut down, the threat actors can update the encoded IP address on TechNet to maintain control of the victims’ machines.

FALLCHILL.name: System Information Discovery
FALLCHILL.description: [FALLCHILL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0181) can collect operating system (OS) version information, processor information, system name, and information about installed disks from the victim.

FALLCHILL.name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
FALLCHILL.description: [FALLCHILL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0181) uses fake Transport Layer Security (TLS) to communicate with its C2 server, encoding data with RC4 encryption.

FALLCHILL.name: File and Directory Discovery
FALLCHILL.description: [FALLCHILL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0181) can search files on a victim.

FALLCHILL.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
FALLCHILL.description: [FALLCHILL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0181) collects MAC address and local IP address information from the victim.

FALLCHILL.name: File Deletion
FALLCHILL.description: [FALLCHILL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0181) can delete malware and associated artifacts from the victim.

FALLCHILL.name: Timestomp
FALLCHILL.description: [FALLCHILL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0181) can modify file or directory timestamps.

NavRAT.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
NavRAT.description: [NavRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0247) creates a Registry key to ensure a file gets executed upon reboot in order to establish persistence.

NavRAT.name: Command-Line Interface
NavRAT.description: [NavRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0247) leverages cmd.exe to perform discovery techniques.

NavRAT.name: Data Staged
NavRAT.description: [NavRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0247) writes multiple outputs to a TMP file using the >> method.

NavRAT.name: Input Capture
NavRAT.description: [NavRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0247) logs the keystrokes on the targeted system.

NavRAT.name: Scripting
NavRAT.description: [NavRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0247) loads malicious shellcode and executes it in memory.

NavRAT.name: Process Injection
NavRAT.description: [NavRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0247) copies itself into a running Internet Explorer process to evade detection.

NavRAT.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
NavRAT.description: [NavRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0247) uses the email platform, Naver, for C2 communications, leveraging SMTP.

DealersChoice.name: Exploitation for Client Execution
DealersChoice.description: [DealersChoice](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0243) leverages vulnerable versions of Flash to perform execution.

DealersChoice.name: Scripting
DealersChoice.description: [DealersChoice](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0243) makes modifications to open-source scripts from GitHub and executes them on the victim’s machine.

DealersChoice.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
DealersChoice.description: [DealersChoice](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0243) uses HTTP for communication with the C2 server.

Zebrocy.name: System Information Discovery
Zebrocy.description: [Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251) collects the OS version, computer name and serial number for the storage volume C:\. [Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251) also runs the systeminfo command to gather system information.

Zebrocy.name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
Zebrocy.description: [Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251) uses raw sockets to communicate with its C2 server.

Zebrocy.name: Data Encrypted
Zebrocy.description: [Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251) uses an encryption method similar to RC4 as well as AES to encrypt data before exfiltration.

Zebrocy.name: Remote File Copy
Zebrocy.description: [Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251) obtains additional code to execute on the victim's machine, including the downloading of a secondary payload.

Zebrocy.name: Hooking
Zebrocy.description: [Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251) installs an application-defined Windows hook to get notified when a network drive has been attached, so it can then use the hook to call its RecordToFile file stealing method.

Zebrocy.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Zebrocy.description: [Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251) uses HTTP, SMTP, and POP3 for C2.

Zebrocy.name: Peripheral Device Discovery
Zebrocy.description: [Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251) enumerates information about connected storage devices.

Zebrocy.name: Network Share Discovery
Zebrocy.description: [Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251) identifies network drives when they are added to victim systems.

Zebrocy.name: File and Directory Discovery
Zebrocy.description: [Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251) searches for files that are 60mb and less and contain the following extensions: .doc, .docx, .xls, .xlsx, .ppt, .pptx, .exe, .zip, and .rar. [Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251) also runs the echo %APPDATA% command to list the contents of the directory. [Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251) can obtain the current execution path as well as perform drive enumeration.

Zebrocy.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Zebrocy.description: [Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251) decodes its secondary payload and writes it to the victim’s machine. [Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251) also uses AES and XOR to decrypt strings and payloads.

Zebrocy.name: Screen Capture
Zebrocy.description: A variant of [Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251) captures screenshots of the victim’s machine in JPEG and BMP format.

Zebrocy.name: Process Discovery
Zebrocy.description: [Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251) uses the tasklist and wmic process get Capture, ExecutablePath commands to gather the processes running on the system.

Zebrocy.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Zebrocy.description: [Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251) creates an entry in a Registry Run key for the malware to execute on startup.

Zebrocy.name: File Deletion
Zebrocy.description: [Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251) has a command to delete files and directories.

Zebrocy.name: System Owner/User Discovery
Zebrocy.description: [Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251) gets the username from the system.

Zebrocy.name: Uncommonly Used Port
Zebrocy.description: [Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251) uses port 465 for C2.

Zebrocy.name: System Time Discovery
Zebrocy.description: [Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251) gathers the current time zone and date information from the system.

Zebrocy.name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Zebrocy.description: [Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251) uses SSL and AES ECB for encrypting C2 communications.

Zebrocy.name: Data Staged
Zebrocy.description: [Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251) stores all collected information in a single file before exfiltration.

Zebrocy.name: Automated Collection
Zebrocy.description: [Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251) scans the system and automatically collects files with the following extensions: .doc, .docx, ,.xls, .xlsx, .pdf, .pptx, .rar, .zip, .jpg, .jpeg, .bmp, .tiff, .kum, .tlg, .sbx, .cr, .hse, .hsf, and .lhz.

Zebrocy.name: Logon Scripts
Zebrocy.description: [Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251) performs persistence via adding a Registry key with a logon script.

Zebrocy.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
Zebrocy.description: One variant of [Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251) uses WMI queries to gather information.

Zebrocy.name: Software Packing
Zebrocy.description: [Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251)'s Delphi variant was packed with UPX.

Zebrocy.name: Command-Line Interface
Zebrocy.description: [Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251) uses cmd.exe to execute commands on the system.

Zebrocy.name: Query Registry
Zebrocy.description: [Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251) executes the reg query command to obtain information in the Registry.

Zebrocy.name: System Network Connections Discovery
Zebrocy.description: [Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251) uses netstat -aon to gather network connection information.

Zebrocy.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Zebrocy.description: [Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251) runs the ipconfig /all command.

Zebrocy.name: Data Encoding
Zebrocy.description: [Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251) has used URL/Percent Encoding on data exfiltrated via HTTP POST requests.

Zebrocy.name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
Zebrocy.description: [Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251) has exfiltrated data to the designated C2 server using HTTP POST requests.

ComRAT.name: Component Object Model Hijacking
ComRAT.description: [ComRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0126) samples have been seen which hijack COM objects for persistence by replacing the path to shell32.dll in registry location HKCU\Software\Classes\CLSID\{42aedc87-2188-41fd-b9a3-0c966feabec1}\InprocServer32.

ComRAT.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
ComRAT.description: [ComRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0126) has used HTTP requests for command and control.

XTunnel.name: Binary Padding
XTunnel.description: A version of [XTunnel](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0117) introduced in July 2015 inserted junk code into the binary in a likely attempt to obfuscate it and bypass security products.

XTunnel.name: Credentials in Files
XTunnel.description: [XTunnel](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0117) is capable of accessing locally stored passwords on victims.

XTunnel.name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
XTunnel.description: [XTunnel](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0117) uses SSL/TLS and RC4 to encrypt traffic.

XTunnel.name: Remote File Copy
XTunnel.description: [XTunnel](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0117) is capable of downloading additional files.

XTunnel.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
XTunnel.description: A version of [XTunnel](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0117) introduced in July 2015 obfuscated the binary using opaque predicates and other techniques in a likely attempt to obfuscate it and bypass security products.

XTunnel.name: Command-Line Interface
XTunnel.description: [XTunnel](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0117) has been used to execute remote commands.

XTunnel.name: Fallback Channels
XTunnel.description: The C2 server used by [XTunnel](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0117) provides a port number to the victim to use as a fallback in case the connection closes on the currently used port.

XTunnel.name: Network Service Scanning
XTunnel.description: [XTunnel](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0117) is capable of probing the network for open ports.

XTunnel.name: Connection Proxy
XTunnel.description: [XTunnel](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0117) relays traffic between a C2 server and a victim.

GLOOXMAIL.name: Web Service
GLOOXMAIL.description: [GLOOXMAIL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0026) communicates to servers operated by Google using the Jabber/XMPP protocol.

SHIPSHAPE.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
SHIPSHAPE.description: [SHIPSHAPE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0028) achieves persistence by creating a shortcut in the Startup folder.

SHIPSHAPE.name: Shortcut Modification
SHIPSHAPE.description: [SHIPSHAPE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0028) achieves persistence by creating a shortcut in the Startup folder.

SHIPSHAPE.name: Replication Through Removable Media
SHIPSHAPE.description: [APT30](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0013) may have used the [SHIPSHAPE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0028) malware to move onto air-gapped networks. [SHIPSHAPE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0028) targets removable drives to spread to other systems by modifying the drive to use Autorun to execute or by hiding legitimate document files and copying an executable to the folder with the same name as the legitimate document.

PinchDuke.name: File and Directory Discovery
PinchDuke.description: [PinchDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0048) searches for files created within a certain timeframe and whose file extension matches a predefined list.

PinchDuke.name: Data from Local System
PinchDuke.description: [PinchDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0048) collects user files from the compromised host based on predefined file extensions.

PinchDuke.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
PinchDuke.description: [PinchDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0048) transfers files from the compromised host via HTTP or HTTPS to a C2 server.

PinchDuke.name: Credential Dumping
PinchDuke.description: [PinchDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0048) steals credentials from compromised hosts. [PinchDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0048)'s credential stealing functionality is believed to be based on the source code of the Pinch credential stealing malware (also known as LdPinch). Credentials targeted by [PinchDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0048) include ones associated with The Bat!, Yahoo!, Mail.ru, Passport.Net, Google Talk, Netscape Navigator, Mozilla Firefox, Mozilla Thunderbird, Internet Explorer, Microsoft Outlook, WinInet Credential Cache, and Lightweight Directory Access Protocol (LDAP).

NetTraveler.name: Application Window Discovery
NetTraveler.description: [NetTraveler](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0033) reports window names along with keylogger information to provide application context.

Pasam.name: Remote File Copy
Pasam.description: [Pasam](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0208) creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can upload files.

Pasam.name: File and Directory Discovery
Pasam.description: [Pasam](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0208) creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can retrieve lists of files.

Pasam.name: Commonly Used Port

Pasam.description: [Pasam](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0208) creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can delete files.

Pasam.name: Process Discovery

Pasam.name: Data from Local System
Pasam.description: [Pasam](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0208) creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can retrieve files.

NETWIRE.name: Code Signing

NETWIRE.name: System Information Discovery

WinMM.name: File and Directory Discovery

WinMM.name: Fallback Channels

WinMM.name: System Owner/User Discovery

WinMM.name: System Information Discovery
WinMM.description: [WinMM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0059) collects the system name, OS version including service pack, and system install date and sends the information to the C2 server.

Hi-Zor.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Hi-Zor.description: [Hi-Zor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0087) uses various XOR techniques to obfuscate its components.

Hi-Zor.name: Commonly Used Port
Hi-Zor.description: [Hi-Zor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0087) communicates with its C2 server over port 443.

Hi-Zor.name: File Deletion
Hi-Zor.description: [Hi-Zor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0087) deletes its RAT installer file as it executes its DLL payload file.

Hi-Zor.name: Remote File Copy
Hi-Zor.description: [Hi-Zor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0087) has the ability to upload and download files from its C2 server.

Hi-Zor.name: Multilayer Encryption
Hi-Zor.description: [Hi-Zor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0087) encrypts C2 traffic with HTTPS and also encodes it with a single-byte XOR key.

Hi-Zor.name: Regsvr32
Hi-Zor.description: [Hi-Zor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0087) executes using regsvr32.exe called from the [Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1060) persistence mechanism.

Hi-Zor.name: Command-Line Interface
Hi-Zor.description: [Hi-Zor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0087) has the ability to create a reverse shell.

Hi-Zor.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Hi-Zor.description: [Hi-Zor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0087) creates a Registry Run key to establish persistence.

Hi-Zor.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Hi-Zor.description: [Hi-Zor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0087) communicates with its C2 server over HTTPS.

Proton.name: Input Capture
Proton.description: [Proton](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0279) uses a keylogger to capture keystrokes.

Proton.name: Sudo Caching
Proton.description: [Proton](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0279) modifies the tty_tickets line in the sudoers file.

Proton.name: Data Compressed
Proton.description: [Proton](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0279) zips up files before exfiltrating them.

Proton.name: Disabling Security Tools
Proton.description: [Proton](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0279) kills security tools like Wireshark that are running.

Proton.name: File Deletion
Proton.description: [Proton](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0279) removes all files in the /tmp directory.

Proton.name: Credentials in Files
Proton.description: [Proton](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0279) gathers credentials in files for 1password, and keychains.

Proton.name: Scripting
Proton.description: [Proton](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0279) uses macOS' .command file type to script actions.

Proton.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Proton.description: [Proton](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0279) uses an encrypted file to store commands and configuration values.

Proton.name: Remote Services
Proton.description: [Proton](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0279) uses VNC to connect into systems.

Proton.name: Screen Capture
Proton.description: [Proton](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0279) captures the content of the desktop with the screencapture binary.

SLOWDRIFT.name: System Information Discovery
SLOWDRIFT.description: [SLOWDRIFT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0218) collects and sends system information to its C2.

SLOWDRIFT.name: Web Service
SLOWDRIFT.description: [SLOWDRIFT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0218) uses cloud based services for C2.

ASPXSpy.name: Web Shell
ASPXSpy.description: [ASPXSpy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0073) is a Web shell. The ASPXTool version used by [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) has been deployed to accessible servers running Internet Information Services (IIS).

CORALDECK.name: Data Encrypted
CORALDECK.description: [CORALDECK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0212) has created password-protected RAR, WinImage, and zip archives to be exfiltrated.

CORALDECK.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol

CORALDECK.name: Data Compressed
CORALDECK.description: [CORALDECK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0212) has created password-protected RAR, WinImage, and zip archives to be exfiltrated.

SHUTTERSPEED.name: Remote File Copy

BOOTRASH.name: Bootkit

SynAck.name: Query Registry

SynAck.name: System Information Discovery

SynAck.name: System Owner/User Discovery
SynAck.description: [SynAck](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0242) gathers user names from infected hosts.

SynAck.name: File and Directory Discovery
SynAck.description: [SynAck](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0242) checks its directory location in an attempt to avoid launching in a sandbox.

SynAck.name: Process Doppelgänging
SynAck.description: [SynAck](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0242) abuses NTFS transactions to launch and conceal malicious processes.

SynAck.name: Execution through API
SynAck.description: [SynAck](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0242) parses the export tables of system DLLs to locate and call various Windows API functions.

SynAck.name: Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion
SynAck.description: [SynAck](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0242) checks its directory location in an attempt to avoid launching in a sandbox.

SynAck.name: Data Encrypted for Impact
SynAck.description: [SynAck](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0242) encrypts the victims machine followed by asking the victim to pay a ransom.

CCBkdr.name: Supply Chain Compromise
CCBkdr.description: [CCBkdr](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0222) was added to a legitimate, signed version 5.33 of the CCleaner software and distributed on CCleaner's distribution site.

Cobian RAT.name: Screen Capture

Cobian RAT.name: Input Capture

Cobian RAT.description: [Cobian RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0338) creates an autostart Registry key to ensure persistence.

AuditCred.name: Command-Line Interface

AuditCred.name: Commonly Used Port

AuditCred.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information

AuditCred.name: Remote File Copy

AuditCred.name: File Deletion

AuditCred.name: Process Injection
AuditCred.description: [AuditCred](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0347) can inject code from files to other running processes.

Denis.name: File and Directory Discovery

Denis.name: File Deletion
Denis.description: [Denis](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0354) has a command to delete files from the victim’s machine.

Denis.name: System Owner/User Discovery
Denis.description: [Denis](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0354) collects the username from the victim’s machine.

Denis.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Denis.description: [Denis](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0354) has used DNS tunneling for C2 communications.

Denis.name: System Network Configuration Discovery

Denis.name: System Information Discovery

Denis.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Denis.description: [Denis](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0354) obfuscates its code and encrypts the API names. [Denis](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0354) also encodes its payload in Base64.

Denis.name: DLL Side-Loading
Denis.description: [Denis](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0354) exploits a security vulnerability to load a fake DLL and execute its code.

Denis.name: Command-Line Interface

Denis.name: Remote File Copy

Denis.name: Process Injection

Denis.name: Data Encoding
Denis.description: [Denis](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0354) encodes the data sent to the server in Base64.

Denis.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Denis.description: [Denis](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0354) will decrypt important strings used for C&C communication.

Denis.name: Scripting
Denis.description: [Denis](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0354) executes shellcode on the victim's machine.

Denis.name: Query Registry
Denis.description: [Denis](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0354) queries the Registry for keys and values.

3PARA RAT.name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
3PARA RAT.description: [3PARA RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0066) will use an 8-byte XOR key derived from the string HYF54&%9&jkMCXuiS instead if the DES decoding fails.

3PARA RAT.name: Timestomp
3PARA RAT.description: [3PARA RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0066) has a command to set certain attributes such as creation/modification timestamps on files.

3PARA RAT.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
3PARA RAT.description: [3PARA RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0066) uses HTTP for command and control.

3PARA RAT.name: File and Directory Discovery
3PARA RAT.description: [3PARA RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0066) has a command to retrieve metadata for files on disk as well as a command to list the current working directory.

3PARA RAT.name: Redundant Access
3PARA RAT.description: [3PARA RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0066) will sleep until after a date/time value loaded from a .dat file has passed. This allows the RAT to remain dormant until a set date, which could allow a means to regain access if other parts of the actors' toolset are removed from a victim.

3PARA RAT.name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
3PARA RAT.description: [3PARA RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0066) command and control commands are encrypted within the HTTP C2 channel using the DES algorithm in CBC mode with a key derived from the MD5 hash of the string HYF54&%9&jkMCXuiS.

WEBC2.name: Command-Line Interface

WEBC2.description: [WEBC2](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0109) can download and execute a file.

NDiskMonitor.name: File and Directory Discovery

NDiskMonitor.name: System Owner/User Discovery

NDiskMonitor.name: Remote File Copy
NDiskMonitor.description: [NDiskMonitor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0272) can download and execute a file from given URL.

NDiskMonitor.name: System Information Discovery
NDiskMonitor.description: [NDiskMonitor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0272) obtains the victim computer name and encrypts the information to send over its C2 channel.

NDiskMonitor.name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
NDiskMonitor.description: [NDiskMonitor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0272) uses AES to encrypt certain information sent over its C2 channel.

Janicab.name: Code Signing
Janicab.description: [Janicab](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0163) used a valid AppleDeveloperID to sign the code to get past security restrictions.

Janicab.name: Local Job Scheduling
Janicab.description: [Janicab](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0163) used a cron job for persistence on Mac devices.

Janicab.name: Screen Capture
Janicab.description: [Janicab](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0163) captured screenshots and sent them out to a C2 server.

Janicab.name: Audio Capture
Janicab.description: [Janicab](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0163) captured audio and sent it out to a C2 server.

ROCKBOOT.name: Bootkit
ROCKBOOT.description: [ROCKBOOT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0112) is a Master Boot Record (MBR) bootkit that uses the MBR to establish persistence.

Starloader.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Starloader.description: [Starloader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0188) decrypts and executes shellcode from a file called Stars.jps.

Starloader.name: Masquerading
Starloader.description: [Starloader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0188) has masqueraded as legitimate software update packages such as Adobe Acrobat Reader and Intel.

Ixeshe.name: Data Obfuscation
Ixeshe.description: [Ixeshe](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0015) uses custom Base64 encoding schemes to obfuscate command and control traffic in the message body of HTTP requests.

Ixeshe.name: System Owner/User Discovery
Ixeshe.description: [Ixeshe](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0015) collects the username from the victim’s machine.

Ixeshe.name: Data from Local System
Ixeshe.description: [Ixeshe](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0015) can collect data from a local system.

Ixeshe.name: Remote File Copy
Ixeshe.description: [Ixeshe](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0015) can download and execute additional files.

Ixeshe.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Ixeshe.description: [Ixeshe](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0015) enumerates the IP address, network proxy settings, and domain name from a victim's system.

Ixeshe.name: File and Directory Discovery
Ixeshe.description: [Ixeshe](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0015) can list file and directory information.

Ixeshe.name: Command-Line Interface
Ixeshe.description: [Ixeshe](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0015) is capable of executing commands via [cmd](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0106).

Ixeshe.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Ixeshe.description: [Ixeshe](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0015) can achieve persistence by adding itself to the HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run Registry key.

Ixeshe.name: Masquerading
Ixeshe.description: [Ixeshe](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0015) has used registry values and file names associated with Adobe software, such as AcroRd32.exe.

Ixeshe.name: Hidden Files and Directories
Ixeshe.description: [Ixeshe](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0015) sets its own executable file's attributes to hidden.

Ixeshe.name: File Deletion
Ixeshe.description: [Ixeshe](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0015) has a command to delete a file from the machine.

Ixeshe.name: System Information Discovery
Ixeshe.description: [Ixeshe](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0015) collects the computer name of the victim's system during the initial infection.

Ixeshe.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Ixeshe.description: [Ixeshe](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0015) uses HTTP for command and control.

Ixeshe.name: Commonly Used Port
Ixeshe.description: [Ixeshe](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0015) has used TCP port 443 for C2.

It allows adversaries to bypass the standard authentication system to use a defined password for all accounts authenticating to that domain controller.

Wiper.name: Third-party Software

Socksbot.name: Process Injection

Socksbot.name: PowerShell
Socksbot.description: [Socksbot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0273) can write and execute PowerShell scripts.

HIDEDRV.name: Process Injection

HIDEDRV.name: Rootkit
HIDEDRV.description: [HIDEDRV](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0135) is a rootkit that hides certain operating system artifacts.

Twitoor.name: Web Service
Twitoor.description: [Twitoor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0302) uses Twitter for command and control.

CloudDuke.name: Remote File Copy

CloudDuke.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol

CloudDuke.name: Web Service
CloudDuke.description: One variant of [CloudDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0054) uses a Microsoft OneDrive account to exchange commands and stolen data with its operators.

Vasport.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol

Vasport.description: [Vasport](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0207) is capable of tunneling though a proxy.
