Vasport.description: [Vasport](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0207) copies itself to disk and creates an associated run key Registry entry to establish.

OLDBAIT.name: Credential Dumping
OLDBAIT.description: [OLDBAIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0138) collects credentials from Internet Explorer, Mozilla Firefox, Eudora, and several email clients.

OLDBAIT.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
OLDBAIT.description: [OLDBAIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0138) can use HTTP or SMTP for C2.

OLDBAIT.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
OLDBAIT.description: [OLDBAIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0138) obfuscates internal strings and unpacks them at startup.

OLDBAIT.name: Masquerading
OLDBAIT.description: [OLDBAIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0138) installs itself in %ALLUSERPROFILE%\\Application Data\Microsoft\MediaPlayer\updatewindws.exe; the directory name is missing a space and the file name is missing the letter "o."

CALENDAR.name: Command-Line Interface
CALENDAR.description: [CALENDAR](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0025) has a command to run cmd.exe to execute commands.

CALENDAR.name: Web Service
CALENDAR.description: The [CALENDAR](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0025) malware communicates through the use of events in Google Calendar.

Hacking Team UEFI Rootkit.name: System Firmware
Hacking Team UEFI Rootkit.description: [Hacking Team UEFI Rootkit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0047) is a UEFI BIOS rootkit developed by the company Hacking Team to persist remote access software on some targeted systems.

Hacking Team UEFI Rootkit.name: Rootkit
Hacking Team UEFI Rootkit.description: [Hacking Team UEFI Rootkit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0047) is a UEFI BIOS rootkit developed by the company Hacking Team to persist remote access software on some targeted systems.

Truvasys.name: Masquerading
Truvasys.description: To establish persistence, [Truvasys](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0178) adds a Registry Run key with a value "TaskMgr" in an attempt to masquerade as the legitimate Windows Task Manager.

Truvasys.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Truvasys.description: [Truvasys](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0178) adds a Registry Run key to establish persistence.

Taidoor.name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
Taidoor.description: [Taidoor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0011) is known to utilize encryption within network protocols.

Trojan.Mebromi.name: System Firmware
Trojan.Mebromi.description: [Trojan.Mebromi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0001) performs BIOS modification and can download and execute a file as well as protect itself from removal.

BONDUPDATER.name: Domain Generation Algorithms
BONDUPDATER.description: [BONDUPDATER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0360) uses a DGA to communicate with command and control servers.

BONDUPDATER.name: Command-Line Interface
BONDUPDATER.description: [BONDUPDATER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0360) can read batch commands in a file sent from its C2 server and execute them with cmd.exe.

BONDUPDATER.name: Scheduled Task
BONDUPDATER.description: [BONDUPDATER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0360) persists using a scheduled task that executes every minute.

BONDUPDATER.name: Remote File Copy
BONDUPDATER.description: [BONDUPDATER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0360) can download or upload files from its C2 server.

BONDUPDATER.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
BONDUPDATER.description: [BONDUPDATER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0360) can use DNS and TXT records within its DNS tunneling protocol for command and control.

Linux Rabbit.name: Data Encoding
Linux Rabbit.description: [Linux Rabbit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0362) sends the payload from the C2 server as an encoded URL parameter.

Linux Rabbit.name: .bash_profile and .bashrc
Linux Rabbit.description: [Linux Rabbit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0362) maintains persistence on an infected machine through rc.local and .bashrc files.

Linux Rabbit.name: Commonly Used Port
Linux Rabbit.description: [Linux Rabbit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0362) checks to see if an SSH server is listening on port 22.

Linux Rabbit.name: System Owner/User Discovery
Linux Rabbit.description: [Linux Rabbit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0362) opens a socket on port 22 and if it receives a response it attempts to obtain the machine's hostname and Top-Level Domain.

Linux Rabbit.name: External Remote Services
Linux Rabbit.description: [Linux Rabbit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0362) attempts to gain access to the server via SSH.

Linux Rabbit.name: Brute Force
Linux Rabbit.description: [Linux Rabbit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0362) brute forces SSH passwords in order to attempt to gain access and install its malware onto the server.

Linux Rabbit.name: Valid Accounts
Linux Rabbit.description: [Linux Rabbit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0362) acquires valid SSH accounts through brute force.

Olympic Destroyer.name: Remote File Copy
Olympic Destroyer.description: [Olympic Destroyer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0365) attempts to copy itself to remote machines on the network.

Olympic Destroyer.name: Remote System Discovery
Olympic Destroyer.description: [Olympic Destroyer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0365) uses [Windows Management Instrumentation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1047) to enumerate all systems in the network.

Olympic Destroyer.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Olympic Destroyer.description: [Olympic Destroyer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0365) uses API calls to enumerate the infected system's ARP table.

Olympic Destroyer.name: Network Share Discovery
Olympic Destroyer.description: [Olympic Destroyer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0365) will attempt to enumerate mapped network shares to later attempt to wipe all files on those shares.

Olympic Destroyer.name: Windows Admin Shares
Olympic Destroyer.description: [Olympic Destroyer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0365) uses [PsExec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0029) to interact with the ADMIN$ network share to execute commands on remote systems.

Olympic Destroyer.name: Credentials in Files
Olympic Destroyer.description: [Olympic Destroyer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0365) contains a module that tries to obtain stored credentials from web browsers.

Olympic Destroyer.name: Service Execution
Olympic Destroyer.description: [Olympic Destroyer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0365) utilizes [PsExec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0029) to help propagate itself across a network.

Olympic Destroyer.name: Credential Dumping
Olympic Destroyer.description: [Olympic Destroyer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0365) contains a module that tries to obtain credentials from LSASS, similar to [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002). These credentials are used with [PsExec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0029) and [Windows Management Instrumentation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1047) to help the malware propagate itself across a network.

Olympic Destroyer.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
Olympic Destroyer.description: [Olympic Destroyer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0365) uses WMI to help propagate itself across a network.

Olympic Destroyer.name: Data Destruction
Olympic Destroyer.description: [Olympic Destroyer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0365) overwrites files locally and on remote shares.

Olympic Destroyer.name: Indicator Removal on Host
Olympic Destroyer.description: [Olympic Destroyer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0365) will attempt to clear the System and Security event logs using wevtutil.

Olympic Destroyer.name: Service Stop
Olympic Destroyer.description: [Olympic Destroyer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0365) uses the API call ChangeServiceConfigW to disable all services on the affected system.

Olympic Destroyer.name: Inhibit System Recovery
Olympic Destroyer.description: [Olympic Destroyer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0365) uses the native Windows utilities vssadmin, wbadmin, and bcdedit to delete and disable operating system recovery features such as the Windows backup catalog and Windows Automatic Repair.

Emotet.name: Brute Force
Emotet.description: [Emotet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0367) has been observed using a hard coded list of passwords to brute force user accounts.

Emotet.name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
Emotet.description: [Emotet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0367) has been seen exfiltrating system information stored within cookies sent within an HTTP GET request back to its C2 servers.

Emotet.name: Email Collection
Emotet.description: [Emotet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0367) has been observed leveraging a module that scrapes email data from Outlook.

Emotet.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Emotet.description: [Emotet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0367) has obfuscated macros within malicious documents to hide the URLs hosting the malware,  CMD.exe arguments, and PowerShell scripts.

Emotet.name: Credentials in Files
Emotet.description: [Emotet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0367) has been observed leveraging a module that retrieves passwords stored on a system for the current logged-on user.

Emotet.name: Credential Dumping
Emotet.description: [Emotet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0367) has been observed dropping browser and password grabber modules including [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002).

Emotet.name: Commonly Used Port
Emotet.description: [Emotet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0367) has used ports 20, 22, 80, 443, 8080, and 8443.

Emotet.name: Command-Line Interface
Emotet.description: [Emotet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0367) has used cmd.exe to run a PowerShell script.

Emotet.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Emotet.description: [Emotet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0367) has been observed adding the downloaded payload to the HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run key to maintain persistence.

Emotet.name: Process Injection
Emotet.description: [Emotet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0367) has been observed injecting in to Explorer.exe and other processes.

Emotet.name: PowerShell
Emotet.description: [Emotet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0367) has used Powershell to retrieve the malicious payload and download additional resources like [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002).

Emotet.name: Scheduled Task
Emotet.description: [Emotet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0367) has maintained persistence through a scheduled task.

Emotet.name: New Service
Emotet.description: [Emotet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0367) has been observed creating new services to maintain persistence.

Emotet.name: Network Sniffing
Emotet.description: [Emotet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0367) has been observed to hook network APIs to monitor network traffic.

Emotet.name: Exploitation of Remote Services
Emotet.description: [Emotet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0367) has been seen exploiting SMB via a vulnerability exploit like ETERNALBLUE (MS17-010) to achieve lateral movement and propagation.

Emotet.name: Windows Admin Shares
Emotet.description: [Emotet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0367) leverages the Admin$ share for lateral movement once the local admin password has been brute forced.

Emotet.name: Uncommonly Used Port
Emotet.description: [Emotet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0367) has been observed communicating over non standard ports, including 7080 and 50000.

Emotet.name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Emotet.description: [Emotet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0367) is known to use RSA keys for encrypting C2 traffic.

Emotet.name: Spearphishing Link
Emotet.description: [Emotet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0367) has been delivered by phishing emails containing links.

Emotet.name: Spearphishing Attachment
Emotet.description: [Emotet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0367) has been delivered by phishing emails containing attachments.

Emotet.name: Software Packing
Emotet.description: [Emotet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0367) has used custom packers to protect its payloads.

Emotet.name: Scripting
Emotet.description: [Emotet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0367) has sent Microsoft Word documents with embedded macros that will invoke scripts to download additional payloads.

Emotet.name: User Execution
Emotet.description: [Emotet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0367) has relied upon users clicking on a malicious link or attachment delivered through spearphishing.

Emotet.name: Data Encrypted
Emotet.description: [Emotet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0367) has been observed encrypting the data it collects before sending it to the C2 server.

Emotet.name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
Emotet.description: [Emotet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0367) has been observed using an encrypted, modified protobuf-based protocol for command and control messaging.

Emotet.name: Process Discovery
Emotet.description: [Emotet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0367) has been observed enumerating local processes.

Emotet.name: Valid Accounts
Emotet.description: [Emotet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0367) can brute force a local admin password, then use it to facilitate lateral movement.

Emotet.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
Emotet.description: [Emotet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0367) has used WMI to execute powershell.exe.

WannaCry.name: Exploitation of Remote Services
WannaCry.description: [WannaCry](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0366) uses an exploit in SMBv1 to spread itself to other remote systems on a network.

WannaCry.name: File Permissions Modification
WannaCry.description: [WannaCry](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0366) uses attrib +h and icacls . /grant Everyone:F /T /C /Q to make some of its files hidden and grant all users full access controls.

WannaCry.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
WannaCry.description: [WannaCry](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0366) will attempt to determine the local network segment it is a part of.

WannaCry.name: Peripheral Device Discovery
WannaCry.description: [WannaCry](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0366) contains a thread that will attempt to scan for new attached drives every few seconds. If one is identified, it will encrypt the files on the attached device.

WannaCry.name: Remote System Discovery
WannaCry.description: [WannaCry](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0366) scans its local network segment for remote systems to try to exploit and copy itself to.

WannaCry.name: Remote Desktop Protocol
WannaCry.description: [WannaCry](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0366) enumerates current remote desktop sessions and tries to execute the malware on each session.

WannaCry.name: Data Encrypted for Impact
WannaCry.description: [WannaCry](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0366) encrypts user files and demands that a ransom be paid in Bitcoin to decrypt those files.

WannaCry.name: New Service
WannaCry.description: [WannaCry](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0366) creates the service "mssecsvc2.0" with the display name "Microsoft Security Center (2.0) Service."

WannaCry.name: Remote File Copy
WannaCry.description: [WannaCry](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0366) attempts to copy itself to remote computers after gaining access via an SMB exploit.

WannaCry.name: Multilayer Encryption
WannaCry.description: [WannaCry](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0366) uses [Tor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0183) for command and control traffic and routes a custom cryptographic protocol over the [Tor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0183) circuit.

WannaCry.name: Multi-hop Proxy
WannaCry.description: [WannaCry](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0366) uses [Tor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0183) for command and control traffic.

WannaCry.name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
WannaCry.description: [WannaCry](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0366) uses a custom cryptographic protocol over the [Tor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0183) circuit.

WannaCry.name: Inhibit System Recovery
WannaCry.description: [WannaCry](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0366) uses vssadmin, wbadmin, bcdedit, and wmic to delete and disable operating system recovery features.

WannaCry.name: Service Stop
WannaCry.description: [WannaCry](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0366) attempts to kill processes associated with Exchange, Microsoft SQL Server, and MySQL to make it possible to encrypt their data stores.

WannaCry.name: Hidden Files and Directories
WannaCry.description: [WannaCry](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0366) uses attrib +h to make some of its files hidden.

WannaCry.name: File and Directory Discovery
WannaCry.description: [WannaCry](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0366) searches for variety of user files by file extension before encrypting them using RSA and AES, including Office, PDF, image, audio, video, source code, archive/compression format, and key and certificate files.

NotPetya.name: Scheduled Task
NotPetya.description: [NotPetya](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0368) creates a task to reboot the system one hour after infection.

NotPetya.name: Indicator Removal on Host
NotPetya.description: [NotPetya](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0368) uses wevtutil to clear the Windows event logs.

NotPetya.name: Rundll32
NotPetya.description: [NotPetya](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0368) uses rundll32.exe to install itself on remote systems when accessed via [PsExec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0029) or wmic.

NotPetya.name: Data Encrypted for Impact
NotPetya.description: [NotPetya](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0368) encrypts user files and disk structures like the MBR with 2048-bit RSA.

NotPetya.name: Credential Dumping
NotPetya.description: [NotPetya](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0368) contains a modified version of [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002) to help gather credentials that are later used for lateral movement.

NotPetya.name: Valid Accounts
NotPetya.description: [NotPetya](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0368) can use valid credentials with [PsExec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0029) or wmic to spread itself to remote systems.

NotPetya.name: Windows Admin Shares
NotPetya.description: [NotPetya](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0368) can use [PsExec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0029), which interacts with the ADMIN$ network share to execute commands on remote systems.

NotPetya.name: Supply Chain Compromise
NotPetya.description: [NotPetya](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0368)'s initial infection vector for the June 27, 2017 compromise was a backdoor in the Ukrainian tax accounting software M.E.Doc.

NotPetya.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
NotPetya.description: [NotPetya](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0368) can use wmic to help propagate itself across a network.

NotPetya.name: Service Execution
NotPetya.description: [NotPetya](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0368) can use [PsExec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0029) to help propagate itself across a network.

NotPetya.name: Exploitation of Remote Services
NotPetya.description: [NotPetya](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0368) can use two exploits in SMBv1, EternalBlue and EternalRomance, to spread itself to other remote systems on the network.

SamSam.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
SamSam.description: [SamSam](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0370) has been seen using AES or DES to encrypt payloads and payload components.

SamSam.name: Binary Padding
SamSam.description: [SamSam](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0370) has used garbage code to pad some of its malware components.

SamSam.name: Data Encrypted for Impact
SamSam.description: [SamSam](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0370) encrypts victim files using RSA-2048 encryption and demands a ransom be paid in Bitcoin to decrypt those files.

SamSam.name: File Deletion
SamSam.description: [SamSam](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0370) has been seen deleting its own files and payloads to make analysis of the attack more difficult.

SamSam.name: Scripting
SamSam.description: [SamSam](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0370) uses custom batch scripts to execute some of its components.

POWERTON.name: Credential Dumping
POWERTON.description: [POWERTON](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0371) has the ability to dump password hashes.

POWERTON.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
POWERTON.description: [POWERTON](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0371) can install a Registry Run key for persistence.

POWERTON.name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
POWERTON.description: [POWERTON](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0371) has used AES for encrypting C2 traffic.

POWERTON.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
POWERTON.description: [POWERTON](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0371) has used HTTP/HTTPS for C2 traffic.

POWERTON.name: Commonly Used Port
POWERTON.description: [POWERTON](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0371) has used port 443 for C2 traffic.

LockerGoga.name: Remote File Copy
LockerGoga.description: [LockerGoga ](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0372) has been observed moving around the victim network via SMB, indicating the actors behind this ransomware are manually copying files form computer to computer instead of self-propagating.

LockerGoga.name: File Deletion
LockerGoga.description: [LockerGoga ](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0372) has been observed deleting its original launcher after execution.

LockerGoga.name: Data Encrypted for Impact
LockerGoga.description: [LockerGoga ](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0372) has encrypted files, including core Windows OS files, using RSA-OAEP MGF1 and then demanded Bitcoin be paid for the decryption key.

LockerGoga.name: Disabling Security Tools
LockerGoga.description: [LockerGoga ](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0372) installation has been immediately preceded by a "task kill" command in order to disable anti-virus.

LockerGoga.name: Code Signing
LockerGoga.description: [LockerGoga ](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0372) has been signed with stolen certificates in order to make it look more legitimate.

Astaroth.name: Process Discovery
Astaroth.description: [Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373) searches for different processes on the system.

Astaroth.name: Software Packing
Astaroth.description: [Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373) uses a software packer called Pe123\RPolyCryptor.

Astaroth.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Astaroth.description: [Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373) obfuscates its JScript code.

Astaroth.name: XSL Script Processing
Astaroth.description: [Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373) executes embedded JScript or VBScript in an XSL stylesheet located on a remote domain.

Astaroth.name: Command-Line Interface
Astaroth.description: [Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373) spawns a CMD process to execute commands.

Astaroth.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Astaroth.description: [Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373) uses a fromCharCode() deobfuscation method to avoid explicitly writing execution commands and to hide its code.

Astaroth.name: Clipboard Data
Astaroth.description: [Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373) collects information from the clipboard by using the OpenClipboard() and GetClipboardData() libraries.

Astaroth.name: Compiled HTML File
Astaroth.description: [Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373) uses ActiveX objects for file execution and manipulation.

Astaroth.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
Astaroth.description: [Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373) uses WMIC to execute payloads.

Astaroth.name: Scripting
Astaroth.description: [Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373) uses JavaScript to perform its core functionalities.

Astaroth.name: System Information Discovery
Astaroth.description: [Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373) collects the machine name and keyboard language from the system.

Astaroth.name: Remote File Copy
Astaroth.description: [Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373) uses [certutil](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0160) and [BITSAdmin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0190) to download additional malware.

Astaroth.name: Input Capture
Astaroth.description: [Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373) logs keystrokes from the victim's machine.

Astaroth.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Astaroth.description: [Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373) collects the external IP address from the system.

Astaroth.name: Shortcut Modification
Astaroth.description: [Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373)'s initial payload is a malicious .LNK file.(Citation :Cybereason Astaroth Feb 2019)

Astaroth.name: Security Software Discovery
Astaroth.description: [Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373) checks for the presence of Avast antivirus in the C:\Program\Files\ folder.

Astaroth.name: System Time Discovery
Astaroth.description: [Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373) collects the timestamp from the infected machine.

Astaroth.name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
Astaroth.description: [Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373) exfiltrates collected information from its r1.log file to the external C2 server.

Astaroth.name: Data Staged
Astaroth.description: [Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373) collects data in a plaintext file named r1.log before exfiltration.

Astaroth.name: Credential Dumping
Astaroth.description: [Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373) uses an external software known as NetPass to recover passwords.

Astaroth.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Astaroth.description: [Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373) creates a startup item for persistence.

Astaroth.name: Data Encoding
Astaroth.description: [Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373) encodes data using Base64 before sending it to the C2 server.

Astaroth.name: Execution through Module Load
Astaroth.description: [Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373) uses the LoadLibraryExW() function to load additional modules.

Astaroth.name: Regsvr32
Astaroth.description: [Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373) can be loaded through regsvr32.exe.

Astaroth.name: Process Hollowing
Astaroth.description: [Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373) searches for unins000.exe (GAS Tecnologia software), Syswow64\userinit.exe or System32\userinit.exe to evasively create a new process in suspended state.

SpeakUp.name: Network Service Scanning
SpeakUp.description: [SpeakUp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0374) checks for availability of specific ports on servers.

SpeakUp.name: Brute Force
SpeakUp.description: [SpeakUp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0374) can perform brute forcing using a pre-defined list of usernames and passwords in an attempt to log in to administrative panels.

SpeakUp.name: Exploitation for Client Execution
SpeakUp.description: [SpeakUp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0374) attempts to exploit the following vulnerabilities in order to execute its malicious script: CVE-2012-0874, CVE-2010-1871, CVE-2017-10271, CVE-2018-2894, CVE-2016-3088, JBoss AS 3/4/5/6, and the Hadoop YARN ResourceManager.

SpeakUp.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
SpeakUp.description: [SpeakUp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0374) encodes its second-stage payload with Base64.

SpeakUp.name: Local Job Scheduling
SpeakUp.description: [SpeakUp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0374) uses cron tasks to ensure persistence.

SpeakUp.name: System Information Discovery
SpeakUp.description: [SpeakUp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0374) uses the cat /proc/cpuinfo | grep -c “cpu family” 2>&1 command to gather system information.

SpeakUp.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
SpeakUp.description: [SpeakUp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0374) uses POST and GET requests over HTTP to communicate with its main C&C server.

SpeakUp.name: File Deletion
SpeakUp.description: [SpeakUp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0374) deletes files to remove evidence on the machine.

SpeakUp.name: Remote File Copy
SpeakUp.description: [SpeakUp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0374) downloads and executes additional files from a remote server.

Remexi.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Remexi.description: [Remexi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0375) decrypts the configuration data using XOR with 25-character keys.

Remexi.name: Data Encrypted
Remexi.description: [Remexi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0375) encrypts and adds all gathered browser data into files for upload to C2.

Remexi.name: Command-Line Interface
Remexi.description: [Remexi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0375) silently executes received commands with cmd.exe.

Remexi.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
Remexi.description: [Remexi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0375) executes received commands with wmic.exe (for WMI commands).

Remexi.name: File and Directory Discovery
Remexi.description: [Remexi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0375) searches for files on the system.

Remexi.name: Scripting
Remexi.description: [Remexi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0375) uses AutoIt and VBS scripts throughout its execution process.

Remexi.name: Winlogon Helper DLL
Remexi.description: [Remexi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0375) achieves persistence using Userinit by adding the Registry key HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon\Userinit.

Remexi.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Remexi.description: [Remexi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0375) uses [BITSAdmin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0190) to communicate with the C2 server over HTTP.

Remexi.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Remexi.description: [Remexi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0375) obfuscates its configuration data with XOR.

Remexi.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Remexi.description: [Remexi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0375) utilizes Run Registry keys in the HKLM hive as a persistence mechanism.

Remexi.name: Scheduled Task
Remexi.description: [Remexi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0375) utilizes scheduled tasks as a persistence mechanism.

Remexi.name: Screen Capture
Remexi.description: [Remexi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0375) takes screenshots of windows of interest.

Remexi.name: Input Capture
Remexi.description: [Remexi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0375) gathers and exfiltrates keystrokes from the machine.

Remexi.name: Application Window Discovery
Remexi.description: [Remexi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0375) has a command to capture active windows on the machine and retrieve window titles.

Remexi.name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
Remexi.description: [Remexi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0375) performs exfiltration over [BITSAdmin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0190), which is also used for the C2 channel.

HOPLIGHT.name: Command-Line Interface
HOPLIGHT.description: [HOPLIGHT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0376) can launch cmd.exe to execute commands on the system.

HOPLIGHT.name: Service Execution
HOPLIGHT.description: [HOPLIGHT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0376) has used svchost.exe to execute a malicious DLL .

HOPLIGHT.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
HOPLIGHT.description: [HOPLIGHT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0376) has used WMI to recompile the Managed Object Format (MOF) files in the WMI repository.

HOPLIGHT.name: Credential Dumping
HOPLIGHT.description: [HOPLIGHT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0376) has the capability to harvest credentials and passwords.

HOPLIGHT.name: Pass the Hash
HOPLIGHT.description: [HOPLIGHT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0376) has been observed loading several APIs associated with Pass the Hash.

HOPLIGHT.name: Uncommonly Used Port
HOPLIGHT.description: [HOPLIGHT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0376) has used uncommon TCP "high port" to "high port" communication.

HOPLIGHT.name: Commonly Used Port
HOPLIGHT.description: [HOPLIGHT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0376) has connected outbound over TCP port 443.

HOPLIGHT.name: Data Obfuscation
HOPLIGHT.description: [HOPLIGHT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0376) has utilized Zlib compression to obfuscate the communications payload.

HOPLIGHT.name: Remote File Copy
HOPLIGHT.description: [HOPLIGHT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0376) has the ability to connect to a remote host in order to upload and download files.

HOPLIGHT.name: Modify Registry
HOPLIGHT.description: [HOPLIGHT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0376) has modified Managed Object Format (MOF) files within the Registry to run specific commands and create persistence on the system.

HOPLIGHT.name: System Information Discovery
HOPLIGHT.description: [HOPLIGHT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0376) has been observed collecting victim machine information like OS version, drivers, volume information and more.

HOPLIGHT.name: System Time Discovery
HOPLIGHT.description: [HOPLIGHT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0376) has been observed collecting system time from victim machines.

HOPLIGHT.name: File and Directory Discovery
HOPLIGHT.description: [HOPLIGHT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0376) has been observed enumerating system drives and partitions.

HOPLIGHT.name: Connection Proxy
HOPLIGHT.description: [HOPLIGHT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0376) has multiple proxy options that mask traffic between the malware and the remote operators.

HOPLIGHT.name: Fallback Channels
HOPLIGHT.description: [HOPLIGHT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0376) has multiple C2 channels in place in case one fails.

HOPLIGHT.name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
HOPLIGHT.description: [HOPLIGHT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0376) has used its C2 channel to exfiltrate data.

HOPLIGHT.name: Query Registry
HOPLIGHT.description: A variant of [HOPLIGHT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0376) hooks lsass.exe, and lsass.exe then checks the Registry for the data value 'rdpproto' under the key SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Lsa Name.

Ebury.name: Private Keys
Ebury.description: [Ebury](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0377) has intercepted unencrypted private keys as well as private key pass-phrases.

Ebury.name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
Ebury.description: [Ebury](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0377) has encrypted C2 traffic using the client IP address, then encoded it as a hexadecimal string.

Ebury.name: Code Signing
Ebury.description: [Ebury](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0377) has installed a self-signed RPM package mimicking the original system package on RPM based systems.

Ebury.name: SSH Hijacking
Ebury.description: [Ebury](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0377) has hijacked the OpenSSH process by injecting into the existing session as opposed to creating a new session.

Ebury.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Ebury.description: [Ebury](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0377) has used DNS requests over UDP port 53.

Ebury.name: Commonly Used Port
Ebury.description: [Ebury](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0377) has used UDP port 53 for C2.

Ebury.name: Disabling Security Tools
Ebury.description: [Ebury](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0377) has disabled logging when the backdoor is used.

Ebury.name: Domain Generation Algorithms
Ebury.description: [Ebury](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0377) has used a DGA to generate a domain name for C2.

Ebury.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Ebury.description: [Ebury](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0377) has obfuscated its strings with a simple XOR encryption with a static key.

CoinTicker.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
CoinTicker.description: [CoinTicker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0369) initially downloads a hidden encoded file.

CoinTicker.name: Uncommonly Used Port
CoinTicker.description: [CoinTicker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0369) establishes outbound connections for command and control on ports 2280 and 1339.

CoinTicker.name: Hidden Files and Directories
CoinTicker.description: [CoinTicker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0369) downloads the following hidden files to evade detection and maintain persistence: /private/tmp/.info.enc, /private/tmp/.info.py, /private/tmp/.server.sh, ~/Library/LaunchAgents/.espl.plist, ~/Library/Containers/.[random string]/[random string].

CoinTicker.name: Gatekeeper Bypass
CoinTicker.description: [CoinTicker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0369) downloads the EggShell mach-o binary using curl, which does not set the quarantine flag.

CoinTicker.name: Scripting
CoinTicker.description: [CoinTicker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0369) executes a bash script to establish a reverse shell and a Python script to download its second stage.

CoinTicker.name: Launch Agent
CoinTicker.description: [CoinTicker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0369) creates user launch agents named .espl.plist and com.apple.[random string].plist to establish persistence.

CoinTicker.name: Command-Line Interface
CoinTicker.description: [CoinTicker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0369) executes a bash script to establish a reverse shell.

CoinTicker.name: Remote File Copy
CoinTicker.description: [CoinTicker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0369) executes a Python script to download its second stage.

CoinTicker.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
CoinTicker.description: [CoinTicker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0369) decodes the initially-downloaded hidden encoded file using OpenSSL.

Revenge RAT.name: Video Capture
Revenge RAT.description: [Revenge RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0379) has the ability to access the webcam.

Revenge RAT.name: Remote File Copy
Revenge RAT.description: [Revenge RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0379) has the ability to upload and download files.

Revenge RAT.name: Scripting
Revenge RAT.description: [Revenge RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0379) executes scripts on the victim's machine.

Revenge RAT.name: Remote Desktop Protocol
Revenge RAT.description: [Revenge RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0379) has a plugin to perform RDP access.

Revenge RAT.name: Screen Capture
Revenge RAT.description: [Revenge RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0379) has a plugin for screen capture.

Revenge RAT.name: Audio Capture
Revenge RAT.description: [Revenge RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0379) has a plugin for microphone interception.

Revenge RAT.name: Input Capture
Revenge RAT.description: [Revenge RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0379) has a plugin for keylogging.

Revenge RAT.name: Uncommonly Used Port
Revenge RAT.description: [Revenge RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0379) has communicated over TCP port 3333.

Revenge RAT.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Revenge RAT.description: [Revenge RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0379) creates a Registry key at HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon\Shell to survive a system reboot.

Revenge RAT.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Revenge RAT.description: [Revenge RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0379) collects the IP address and MAC address from the system.

Revenge RAT.name: System Owner/User Discovery
Revenge RAT.description: [Revenge RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0379) gathers the username from the system.

Revenge RAT.name: Credential Dumping
Revenge RAT.description: [Revenge RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0379) has a plugin for credential harvesting.

Revenge RAT.name: System Information Discovery
Revenge RAT.description: [Revenge RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0379) collects the CPU information, OS information, and system language.

Revenge RAT.name: Data Encoding
Revenge RAT.description: [Revenge RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0379) uses Base64 to encode information sent to the C2 server.

Revenge RAT.name: Indirect Command Execution
Revenge RAT.description: [Revenge RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0379) uses the [Forfiles](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0193) utility to execute commands on the system.

Revenge RAT.name: PowerShell
Revenge RAT.description: [Revenge RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0379) uses the PowerShell command Reflection.Assembly to load itself into memory to aid in execution.

Revenge RAT.name: Command-Line Interface
Revenge RAT.description: [Revenge RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0379) uses cmd.exe to execute commands and run scripts on the victim's machine.

Revenge RAT.name: Mshta
Revenge RAT.description: [Revenge RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0379) uses mshta.exe to run maliicous scripts on the system.

Revenge RAT.name: Scheduled Task
Revenge RAT.description: [Revenge RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0379) schedules tasks to run malicious scripts at different intervals.

Revenge RAT.name: Web Service
Revenge RAT.description: [Revenge RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0379) used blogpost.com as its primary command and control server during a campaign.

StoneDrill.name: File Deletion
StoneDrill.description: [StoneDrill](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0380) has been observed deleting the temporary files once they fulfill their task.

StoneDrill.name: Scripting
StoneDrill.description: [StoneDrill](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0380) has several VBS scripts used throughout the malware's lifecycle.

StoneDrill.name: Query Registry
StoneDrill.description: [StoneDrill](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0380) has looked in the registry to find the default browser path.

StoneDrill.name: Remote File Copy
StoneDrill.description: [StoneDrill](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0380) has downloaded and dropped temporary files containing scripts; it additionally has a function to upload files from the victims machine.

StoneDrill.name: Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion
StoneDrill.description: [StoneDrill](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0380) has used several anti-emulation techniques to prevent automated analysis by emulators or sandboxes.

StoneDrill.name: Process Injection
StoneDrill.description: [StoneDrill](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0380) has relied on injecting its payload directly into the process memory of the victim's preferred browser.

StoneDrill.name: Security Software Discovery
StoneDrill.description: [StoneDrill](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0380) can check for antivirus and antimalware programs.

StoneDrill.name: System Time Discovery
StoneDrill.description: [StoneDrill](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0380) can obtain the current date and time of the victim machine.

StoneDrill.name: System Information Discovery
StoneDrill.description: [StoneDrill](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0380) has the capability to discover the system OS, Windows version, architecture and environment.

StoneDrill.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
StoneDrill.description: [StoneDrill](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0380) has used the WMI command-line (WMIC) utility to run tasks.

StoneDrill.name: Data Destruction
StoneDrill.description: [StoneDrill](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0380) has a disk wiper module that targets files other than those in the Windows directory.

StoneDrill.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
StoneDrill.description: [StoneDrill](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0380) has obfuscated its module with an alphabet-based table or XOR encryption.

StoneDrill.name: Disk Content Wipe
StoneDrill.description: [StoneDrill](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0380) can wipe the accessible physical or logical drives of the infected machine.

StoneDrill.name: Disk Structure Wipe
StoneDrill.description: [StoneDrill](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0380) can wipe the master boot record of an infected computer.

FlawedAmmyy.name: Peripheral Device Discovery
FlawedAmmyy.description: [FlawedAmmyy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0381) will attempt to detect if a usable smart card is current inserted into a card reader.

FlawedAmmyy.name: System Owner/User Discovery
FlawedAmmyy.description: [FlawedAmmyy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0381) enumerates the current user during the initial infection.

FlawedAmmyy.name: System Information Discovery
FlawedAmmyy.description: [FlawedAmmyy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0381) beacons out the victim operating system and computer name during the initial infection.

FlawedAmmyy.name: Security Software Discovery
FlawedAmmyy.description: [FlawedAmmyy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0381) will attempt to detect anti-virus products during the initial infection.

FlawedAmmyy.name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
FlawedAmmyy.description: [FlawedAmmyy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0381) has used SEAL encryption during the initial C2 handshake.

FlawedAmmyy.name: Data Obfuscation
FlawedAmmyy.description: [FlawedAmmyy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0381) may obfuscate portions of the initial C2 handshake.

FlawedAmmyy.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
FlawedAmmyy.description: [FlawedAmmyy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0381) leverages WMI to enumerate anti-virus on the victim.

FlawedAmmyy.name: Permission Groups Discovery
FlawedAmmyy.description: [FlawedAmmyy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0381) enumerates the privilege level of the victim during the initial infection.

ServHelper.name: System Owner/User Discovery
ServHelper.description: [ServHelper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0382) will attempt to enumerate the username of the victim.

ServHelper.name: System Information Discovery
ServHelper.description: [ServHelper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0382) will attempt to enumerate Windows version and system architecture.

ServHelper.name: Commonly Used Port
ServHelper.description: [ServHelper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0382) has used port 80 and 443 for C2.

ServHelper.name: File Deletion
ServHelper.description: [ServHelper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0382) has a module to delete itself from the infected machine.

ServHelper.name: Rundll32
ServHelper.description: [ServHelper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0382) contains a module for downloading and executing DLLs that leverages rundll32.exe.

ServHelper.name: Remote File Copy
ServHelper.description: [ServHelper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0382) may download additional files to execute.

ServHelper.name: Remote Desktop Protocol
ServHelper.description: [ServHelper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0382) has commands for adding a remote desktop user and sending RDP traffic to the attacker through a reverse SSH tunnel.

ServHelper.name: Create Account
ServHelper.description: [ServHelper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0382) may create a new account and add the new user to the "Remote Desktop Users" and "Administrators" groups.

ServHelper.name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
ServHelper.description: [ServHelper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0382) may set up a reverse SSH tunnel to give the attacker access to services running on the victim, such as RDP.

ServHelper.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
ServHelper.description: [ServHelper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0382) may attempt to establish persistence via the HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\ run key.

ServHelper.name: Scheduled Task
ServHelper.description: [ServHelper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0382) contains modules that will use [schtasks](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0111) to carry out malicious operations.

FlawedGrace.name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
FlawedGrace.description: [FlawedGrace](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0383) uses a custom binary protocol for its C2 communications.

FlawedGrace.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
FlawedGrace.description: [FlawedGrace](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0383) encrypts its C2 configuration files with AES in CBC mode.

FlawedGrace.name: Commonly Used Port
FlawedGrace.description: [FlawedGrace](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0383) has used port 443 for C2 communications.

Dridex.name: Connection Proxy
Dridex.description: [Dridex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0384) contains a backconnect module for tunneling network traffic through a victim's computer. Infected computers become part of a P2P botnet that can relay C2 traffic to other infected peers.

Dridex.name: Man in the Browser
Dridex.description: [Dridex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0384) can perform browser attacks via web injects to steal information such as credentials, certificates, and cookies.

Dridex.name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Dridex.description: [Dridex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0384) has encrypted traffic with RSA and RC4.

Dridex.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Dridex.description: [Dridex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0384) has used HTTPS for C2 communications.

njRAT.name: Video Capture

njRAT.name: Input Capture
njRAT.description: [njRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0385) is capable of logging keystrokes.

njRAT.name: Remote File Copy

njRAT.name: File Deletion

njRAT.name: Modify Registry

njRAT.name: Screen Capture

njRAT.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
njRAT.description: [njRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0385) has added persistence via the Registry key HKCU\Software\Microsoft\CurrentVersion\Run\.

njRAT.name: Uncommonly Used Port

njRAT.name: Remote Desktop Protocol
njRAT.description: [njRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0385) has a module for performing remote desktop access.

njRAT.name: Disabling Security Tools
njRAT.description: [njRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0385) has modified the Windows firewall to allow itself to communicate through the firewall.

njRAT.name: Data Encoding
njRAT.description: [njRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0385) uses Base64 encoding for C2 traffic.

njRAT.name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
njRAT.description: [njRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0385) communicates to the C2 server using a custom protocol over TCP.

njRAT.name: System Owner/User Discovery
njRAT.description: [njRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0385) enumerates the current user during the initial infection.

njRAT.name: System Information Discovery
njRAT.description: [njRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0385) enumerates the victim operating system and computer name during the initial infection.

njRAT.name: Application Window Discovery
njRAT.description: [njRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0385) gathers information about opened windows during the initial infection.

njRAT.name: Peripheral Device Discovery

njRAT.name: Remote System Discovery
njRAT.description: [njRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0385) can identify remote hosts on connected networks.

njRAT.name: Data from Local System

Ursnif.description: [Ursnif ](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) has dropped payload and configuration files to disk. [Ursnif ](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) has also been used to download and execute additional payloads.

Ursnif.name: System Information Discovery
Ursnif.description: [Ursnif ](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) has used [Systeminfo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0096) to gather system information.

Ursnif.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Ursnif.description: [Ursnif ](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) has used Registry Run keys to establish automatic execution at system startup.

Ursnif.name: New Service
Ursnif.description: [Ursnif ](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) has registered itself as a system service in the Registry for automatic execution at system startup.

Ursnif.name: Replication Through Removable Media
Ursnif.description: [Ursnif ](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) has copied itself to and infected removable drives for propagation.

Ursnif.name: Masquerading
Ursnif.description: [Ursnif ](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) has used strings from legitimate system files and existing folders for its file, folder, and Registry entry names.

Ursnif.name: Process Discovery
Ursnif.description: [Ursnif ](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) has gathered information about running processes.

Ursnif.name: Process Injection
Ursnif.description: [Ursnif ](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) has injected code into target processes via thread local storage callbacks.

Ursnif.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Ursnif.description: [Ursnif ](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) has used HTTPS for C2 as well as HTTP POSTs to exfil gathered information.

Ursnif.name: System Service Discovery
Ursnif.description: [Ursnif ](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) has gathered information about running services.

Ursnif.name: Hooking
Ursnif.description: [Ursnif ](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) has hooked APIs to perform a wide variety of information theft, such as monitoring traffic from browsers.

Ursnif.name: Screen Capture
Ursnif.description: [Ursnif ](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) has used hooked APIs to take screenshots.

Ursnif.name: Man in the Browser
Ursnif.description: [Ursnif ](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) has injected HTML codes into banking sites to steal sensitive online banking information (ex: usernames and passwords).

Ursnif.name: Data from Local System
Ursnif.description: [Ursnif ](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) has collected files from victim machines, including certificates and cookies.

Ursnif.name: Modify Registry
Ursnif.description: [Ursnif ](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) has used Registry modifications as part of its installation routine.

Ursnif.name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
Ursnif.description: [Ursnif ](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) has used a custom packet format over TCP and UDP for a peer-to-peer (P2P) network for C2.

Ursnif.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Ursnif.description: [Ursnif ](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) has used crypto key information stored in the Registry to decrypt Tor clients dropped to disk.

Ursnif.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Ursnif.description: [Ursnif ](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) has used an XOR-based algorithm to encrypt Tor clients dropped to disk.	[Ursnif ](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) droppers have also been delivered as password-protected zip files that execute base64 encoded [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1086) commands.

Ursnif.name: Data Encoding
Ursnif.description: [Ursnif ](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) has used encoded data in HTTP URLs for C2.

Ursnif.name: Domain Generation Algorithms
Ursnif.description: [Ursnif ](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) has used a DGA to generate domain names for C2.

Ursnif.name: Process Hollowing
Ursnif.description: [Ursnif ](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) has used process hollowing to inject into child processes.

Ursnif.name: Execution through API
Ursnif.description: [Ursnif ](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) has used CreateProcessW to create child processes.

Ursnif.name: Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion
Ursnif.description: [Ursnif ](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) has used a 30 minute delay after execution to evade sandbox monitoring tools.

Ursnif.name: Distributed Component Object Model
Ursnif.description: [Ursnif ](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) droppers have used COM objects to execute the malware's full executable payload.

Ursnif.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
Ursnif.description: [Ursnif ](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) droppers have used WMI classes to execute [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1086) commands.

Ursnif.name: PowerShell
Ursnif.description: [Ursnif ](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) droppers have used PowerShell in download cradles to download and execute the malware's full executable payload.

Ursnif.name: Scripting
Ursnif.description: [Ursnif ](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) droppers have used VBA macros and [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1086) to download and execute the malware's full executable payload.

KeyBoy.name: Command-Line Interface

KeyBoy.name: Remote File Copy
